paragraph1: I've often found myself contemplating the complex tapestry of identity and how intertwined it is with the perceptions others hold of us. Philosophers might argue that our true essence should remain unshaken by public opinion, but I can't help but question this idea. As social beings, we naturally navigate a world rich with interpretations, where our very existence feels linked to how others see us. It makes me ponder whether we can ever truly know each other without the filters of appearance and preconceived notions. This interplay becomes especially poignant in matters of love. Isn't it crucial to consider how our loved ones perceive us? To me, love demands an investment in the image we project. Indifference towards how we're viewed by someone dear might even suggest an absence of affection. Hence, I wrestle with balancing self-perception against the myriad external lenses through which I am viewed.
paragraph2: A person is nothing but his image. Philosophers can tell us that it doesn't matter what the world thinks of us, that nothing matters but what we really are. But philosophers don't understand anything. As long as we live with other people, we are only what other people consider us to be. Thinking about how others see us and trying to make our image as attractive as possible is considered a kind of dissembling or cheating. But does there exist another kind of direct contact between my self and their selves except through the mediation of the eyes? Can we possibly imagine love without anxiously following our image in the mind of the beloved? When we are no longer interested in how we are seen by the person we love, it means we no longer love.

paragraph1: Just behind the kingdom that failed ran a nice little river. It was a clear, lovely stream, and many fish lived in it. Weeds grew there, too, and the fish ate the weeds. The fish didn’t care whether or not the kingdom had failed, of course. Whether it was a kingdom or a republic made no difference to them. They didn’t vote or pay taxes. Makes no difference to us, they figured.I washed my feet in the stream. A short soak in the icy-cold water turned them red. From the stream, you could see the walls and the tower of the castle in the kingdom that failed. The two-colored flag still flew from the tower, fluttering in the breeze. Everyone passing along the riverbanks would see the flag and say, “Hey, look at that. It’s the flag of the kingdom that failed.”
paragraph2: As I sit by the clear, lovely stream that runs just behind the remnants of a once-glorious kingdom, I dip my feet into the icy-cold water. The shock of the cold is invigorating, and I watch as fish glide gracefully through the stream, utterly indifferent to the political upheaval that has unfolded around them. These simple creatures seem entirely detached from the woes of failed governance, focusing only on their existence, nibbling on the weeds untroubled by any notion of human folly. As I gaze upstream, the fallen kingdom's remnants cast shadows on the water—a looming, crumbling wall and a solitary tower, where a two-colored flag still flutters against the sky, a stubborn remnant of a bygone power. Occasionally, passersby pause to comment on it, echoing tales of the kingdom's failure as they gaze up at that forlorn emblem, still defiantly marking the landscape.

Everyone passing along the riverbanks would see the flag and say, “Hey, look at that. It’s the flag of the kingdom that failed.”

paragraph1: In 1967, the air around the village of Naxalbari, nestled in the Darjeeling District of West Bengal, India, buzzed with rising tensions as the marginalized reality of its tribal peasant populace took center stage. Predominantly employed on tea plantations and estates, these peasants, shackled by an enduring feudal system, found themselves ensnared in cycles of manipulation and exploitation by wealthy landowners. This longstanding inequity reached a boiling point when a sharecropper, attempting to reclaim his rightful land, was brutally attacked by thugs dispatched by his landlord, an incident that served as a catalyst for collective outrage and resistance. In a fervent stand against their oppressors, the sharecroppers began to orchestrate militant uprisings, discarding passivity for bold defiance. They set fire to the oppressive deeds tethering them to servitude and occupied lands that were once mere dreams of ownership. Their struggles and aspirations resonated with Maoist ideologies, a connection that was emblazoned in their carrying of red flags and the fervent chants that filled the air, signifying a newfound unity and determination to reclaim not only their land but their dignity and rights.
paragraph2: In 1967, in the papers and on All India Radio, they started hearing about a place called Naxalbari. It was one of a string of villages in the Darjeeling District, a narrow corridor at the northern tip of West Bengal. Tucked into the foothills of the Himalayas, nearly four hundred miles from Calcutta, closer to Tibet than to Tollygunge.Most of the villagers were tribal peasants who worked on tea plantations and large estates. For generations, they’d lived under a feudal system that hadn’t substantially changed. They were manipulated by wealthy landowners. They were pushed off fields they’d cultivated, denied revenue from crops they’d grown.That March, when a sharecropper in Naxalbari tried to plow land from which he’d been illegally evicted, his landlord sent thugs to beat him. The police had refused to intervene. After this, groups of sharecroppers began retaliating. They started burning deeds and records that had cheated them. Forcibly occupying land.It wasn’t the first instance of peasants in the Darjeeling District revolting. But this time their tactics were militant. Armed with primitive weapons, carrying red flags, shouting “Long Live Mao Tse-tung.”

paragraph1: Traffic was slow, and he heard"I want to be sure that there's no confusion between you and me, that we understand each other completely—" He had to brake. A pedestrian had slipped between cars to cross the street and turned toward Alain with a threatening gesture."I'll be frank. I've always felt that it's horrible to send a person into the world who didn’t ask to be there." "I know," Alain said. "Look around you. Of all the people you see, no one is here by his own wish. Of course, what I just said is the most banal truth there is. So banal, and so basic, that we’ve stopped seeing it and hearing it." For several minutes he kept to a lane between a truck and a car that were pressing him from either side. "Everyone jabbers about human rights. What a joke! Your existence isn’t founded on any right. They don’t even allow you to end your life by your own choice, these defenders of human rights."The light at the intersection went red. He stopped. Pedestrians from both sides of the street set out toward the opposite sidewalk.
paragraph2: Alain sat tensely in his vehicle, enveloped by the cacophony of engines and the steady crawl of traffic inching forward with exasperating slowness. His grip on the steering wheel tightened reflexively as a pedestrian suddenly darted across his path, eyes locked with his, projecting a silent yet menacing challenge that unsettled the rhythm of his thoughts. Despite the chaos outside, Alain found himself entrenched in a philosophical dialogue within, grappling with notions of human existence that felt as unavoidable as the oppressive gridlock surrounding him. These reflections, shared with an unseen interlocutor, dissected the involuntary nature of life, where individuals are thrust into existence without consent, and touched upon the sometimes hollow proclamations of human rights, a veneer of nobility often undermined by hypocrisy. Alain navigated the narrow space available, deftly maneuvering between cumbersome lorries that dwarfed his car, each movement deliberate and cautious. As he finally reached the red light, the car came to a gentle halt, and he watched pedestrians traverse the crosswalk leisurely, a moving tapestry of lives intersecting with his own, momentarily connected by the enforced pause of the traffic signal, underscoring his contemplation of life's unyielding intersections and contradictions.

paragraph1: O Bilquis. Naked and eyebrowless beneath the golden knight, wrapped in the delirium of the firewind, she saw her youth flying past her, borne away on the wings of the explosion which were still beating in her ears. All migrants leave their pasts behind, although some try to pack it into bundles and boxes but on the journey something seeps out of the treasured mementoes and old photographs, until even their owners fail to recognize them, because it is the fate of migrants to be stripped of history, to stand naked amidst the scorn of strangers upon whom they see the rich clothing, the brocades of continuity and the eyebrows of belonging at any rate, my point is that Bilquis's past left her even before she left that city; she stood in a gully, denuded by the suicide of her father, and watched it go
paragraph2: Bilquis stood naked beneath the "golden knight," a metaphorical spotlight that rendered her bare and vulnerable, stripped not only of clothing but also of identity and history, represented strikingly by her absent eyebrows. This moment of introspection was charged with a profound sense of loss, as if the very essence of her youth had been spirited away by the inexorable "firewind" of change. The narrative conveys the immigrant's struggle—how the past vanishes, leaving them disconnected, unmoored, unrecognizable to themselves as they are severed from continuity and identity. For Bilquis, this disconnection was a haunting presence, amplified by her father's suicide—a cataclysmic event that had already begun erasing the threads to her history even before she physically departed her homeland. Stripped of all that defined her, she felt exposed and isolated, confronting the disconcerting void left by her history's dissolution, yet yearning for reconnection.

paragraph1: He thought of the house as his own, though for years it had been irretrievably mortgaged. And during these months of illness and despair he was struck again and again by the wonder of being in his own house, the audacity of itto walk in through his own front gate, to bar entry to whoever he wished, to close his doors and windows every night, to hear no noises except those of his family, to wander freely from room to room and about his yard, instead of being condemned, as before, to retire the moment he got home to the crowded room in one or the other of Mrs Tulsi’s houses, crowded with Shama’s sisters, their husbands, their children. As a boy he had moved from one house of strangers to another; and since his marriage he felt he had lived nowhere but in the house of the Tulsis, at Hanuman House in Arwacas, in the decaying wooden house at Shorthills, in the clumsy concrete house in Port of Spain. And now at the end he found himself in his own house, on his own half-lot of land, his own portion of the earth. That he should have been responsible for this seemed to him, in these last months, stupendous.
paragraph2: In the quiet solitude of his living room, he found himself reflecting deeply on the profound connection he felt with the house he considered his own, notwithstanding the fact that it was mortgaged and still partially owned by the bank. The sense of ownership offered him a comforting sanctuary during his periods of illness and despair, a stark and welcome contrast to the bustling, overcrowded homes where he once resided as he shared space with his extended family. His past experiences with the sprawling family of Mrs. Tulsi, his wife Shama’s relatives, were marked by a sense of transience and lack of privacy. As a child, the frequent moves between homes left him feeling rootless, and this continued after his marriage when he always felt like an outsider in the vast estates of Mrs. Tulsi. Memories of Hanuman House in Arwacas, and others in Shorthills and Port of Spain, lingered as reminders of a time when personal space seemed a distant luxury. Now, standing on his own front lawn and gazing at his home, he experienced an overwhelming sense of accomplishment and wonder; despite the mortgage papers in his drawer, he finally felt he had a personal stake in his own land and space, a true testament to a long-sought feeling of autonomy and personal success.

paragraph1: Chantal said“But still, tell me—you yourself, when you were a ski instructor, when you were writing for magazines on interior design or later on medicine, or maybe when you were working as a designer in a furniture studio …”
paragraph2: Chantal leaned forward, curiosity sparking in her eyes, and asked about the array of professional experiences the character opposite her had navigated. "Tell me," she said, "how did being a ski instructor segue into writing about interior design and medicine, and then designing furniture?"

paragraph1: Inside the confines of a small apartment filled with mundane activities like movie nights and negotiating household chores, Eileen and Aidan seek comfort in their shared routines while life swirls with change around them. Eileen learns of her sister Lola's engagement to Matthew, a joyous event that contrasts with the bittersweet news that follows: their friend Alice, a celebrated author, wins a literary award that takes her to New York, only for her journey to spiral into challenges with her mental health, resulting in her hospitalization back in Dublin. This shifting landscape unfolds as Eileen engages in a significant yet tense conversation with Simon, a mutual friend who becomes the bearer of updates about Alice's somber trajectory. As Simon shares Alice's struggles, Eileen and Aidan remain in the same space, their presence underscored by a palpable tension marking the unspoken strain on their own relationship. The silence between Eileen and Simon echoes a deeper undercurrent of unease, as if foreshadowing the inevitable unraveling of her bond with Aidan. Eventually, Eileen and Aidan's relationship reaches its threshold, prompting their separation. Aidan returns to his parents' home, leaving Eileen to forge a new chapter living with another couple, a backdrop of change resonating through her life. Social gatherings become a tapestry where Eileen navigates the looming shadows of departures as friends leave Dublin, and conversations orbit around her sister's upcoming wedding, a topic Eileen broaches with an air of detachment amidst a shifting social circle. The narrative, viewed through Eileen's eyes, captures her interactions and the evolving dynamics with Aidan, Simon, and allied characters, painting a vivid portrait of personal epochs and transformations resonating through the fabric of her everyday existence.
paragraph2: For the next three years, Eileen and Aidan lived in a one-bedroom apartment in the south city center, illegally downloading foreign films, arguing about how to split the rent, taking turns cooking and washing up. Lola and Matthew got engaged. Alice won a lucrative literary award, moved to New York, and started sending Eileen e-mails at strange hours of the day and night. In December, Simon called Eileen and told her that Alice was back in Dublin and had been admitted to a psychiatric hospital. Eileen was sitting on the sofa, her phone held to her ear, while Aidan was at the sink, rinsing a plate under the tap. After she and Simon had finished speaking, she sat there on the phone, saying nothing, and he said nothing. They were both silent. Right, he said eventually. I’ll let you go. A few weeks later, Eileen and Aidan broke up. He told her there was a lot going on and they both needed space. He went to live with his parents, and she moved into a two-bedroom apartment with a married couple. Lola and Matthew decided to have a small wedding in the summer. Simon went on answering his correspondence promptly, taking Eileen out for lunch now and then, and keeping his personal life to himself. It was April, and several of Eileen’s friends had recently left or were in the process of leaving Dublin. She attended the leaving parties, wearing her dark-green dress with the buttons, or her yellow dress with the matching belt. In living rooms with low ceilings and paper lampshades, people talked to her about the property market. My sister’s getting married in June, she would tell them. That’s exciting, they would reply. You must be so happy for her. Yeah, it’s funny, Eileen would say. I’m not.

paragraph1: Her column, which is read by some men as well as by many women, is about issues. Social issues, problems that may come upcaring for the aged at home, breast-feeding in public, bulimia in the workplace. She interviews people, she writes from the particular to the general; she believes, in what she considers to be an old-fashioned, romantic way, that life is something that happens to individuals, despite the current emphasis on statistics and trends. Lately things have taken a grimmer turn in Marcia’s columnthere’s been more about such things as malnutrition in kindergartens, wife beating, overcrowding in prisons, child abuse. How to behave if you have a friend with AIDS. Homeless people who ask for handouts at the entrances to subway stations.Ian does not like this new slant of Marcia’s; he doesn’t like her bad news. Businessmen don’t want to read about this stuff, about people who can’t work the system; or so Ian says. She’s heard this through the grapevine. He has called her style “hysterical.” He thinks she’s too soppy. Probably she is too soppy. Her days at The World are probably numbered.
paragraph2: Marcia's column, which delves deeply into pressing social issues, has often been a beacon for narratives that highlight the personal over the statistical. Her focus on real stories, such as individuals managing the complexities of elder care or navigating bulimia in the workplace, has provided readers with a nuanced understanding that transcends mere data points or trends. However, as of late, Marcia's written work has transitioned into a more somber examination of societal issues, shedding light on harrowing topics, including malnutrition, domestic violence, and homelessness. This shift towards darker subjects has not been well-received by everyone, particularly by Ian, who vocally opposes the direction Marcia has chosen to pursue. Ian criticizes her stylistic approach as "hysterical" and excessively emotional, arguing that such topics might dissuade businessmen from engaging with her columns. This critique has left Marcia uneasy, planting seeds of doubt about her professional security at The World. She worries that her commitment to addressing these critical issues, despite their unsettling nature, could ultimately jeopardize her position, even as she remains steadfast in her belief that these stories need to be told.

paragraph1: Connell listened intently as Marianne recounted the discomforting incident involving Eric, one of Connell's friends, who had thoughtlessly insulted her by calling her flat-chested in front of their peers. Although Connell hadn't been present to witness the incident, he felt a flicker of frustration at Eric's insensitivity, mingled with concern for Marianne's feelings. In an effort to console her, Connell tenderly assured Marianne that Eric's flippant remarks held no truth about her worth or beauty, emphasizing qualities far beyond mere physical appearance. Embracing her gently, Connell whispered assurances and praises, refuting the careless words that had momentarily wounded her. As they held each other, the comfortable silence between them began to speak volumes about their relationship—a depth and understanding that few could claim. Their conversation soon turned inward, exploring their own emotions and the uncertain paths that lay before them. Through whispered words and lingering touches, they reaffirmed a bond that transcended superficial judgments and societal measures, revealing an intimacy that, Marianne mused quietly to herself, was rare and precious. In that shared moment, with questions about their futures and a mutual acknowledgment of their feelings, Marianne realized the profound rarity of their connection, acknowledging that such closeness was not only exceptional but a cherished anomaly in their lives.
paragraph2: Your friend Eric called me flat-chested today in front of everyone.Connell paused. She felt his breathing. I didn’t hear that, he said. You were in the bathroom or somewhere. He said I looked like an ironing board.Fuck's sake, he's such a prick. Is that why you're in a bad mood? She shrugged. Connell put his arms around her belly. He's only trying to get on your nerves, he said. If he thought he had the slightest chance with you, he would be talking very differently. He just thinks you look down on him. She shrugged again, chewing on her lower lip.You have nothing to worry about with your appearance, Connell said.Hm.I don’t just like you for your brains, trust me.She laughed, feeling silly.He rubbed her ear with his nose and addedI would miss you if you didn’t want to see me anymore. Would you miss sleeping with me? she said. He touched his hand against her hipbone, rocking her back against his body, and said quietlyYeah, a lot. Can we go back to your house now? He nodded. For a few seconds they just stood there in stillness, his arms around her, his breath on her ear. Most people go through their whole lives, Marianne thought, without ever really feeling that close with anyone.

paragraph1: When my mother got cancer I’d folded my life down. I was a senior in college in Minneapolis, and I’d convinced my professors to allow me to be in class only two days each week. As soon as those days were over, I drove north to the house in rural Minnesota where I’d grown up, racing home, to my mother. I could not bear to be away from her. Plus, I was needed. My stepfather was with my mother when he could be, when he wasn’t working as a carpenter in an attempt to pay the bills. I cooked food that my mother tried to eat. She’d saypork chops and stuffed green peppers, cherry cheesecake and chicken with rice, and then holler the recipes out to me from her bed. When I’d finished she’d sit like a prisoner staring down at her steaming plate. “It smells good,” she’d say. “I think I’ll be able to eat it later.” I scrubbed the floors. I took everything from the cupboards and put new paper down. My mother slept and moaned and counted and swallowed her pills, or on good days she sat in a chair and talked to me, she paged through books.
paragraph2: As I navigated my senior year in college, nestled in the vibrant cityscape of Minneapolis, life took an unforeseen turn when my mother was diagnosed with cancer. Determined to be there for her, I recalibrated my academic schedule, attending classes only on Tuesdays and Thursdays, leaving the remaining days free to journey back to our tranquil rural home in Minnesota. Every week, I embarked on the familiar drive through rolling landscapes, my heart a mix of anticipation and apprehension. With my stepfather tirelessly working as a carpenter, I stepped into the role of caregiver, a shift that taught me as much about resilience as any college course. Under my mother's gentle guidance, I found myself in the kitchen, crafting meals from her cherished recipes, each dish a tangible connection to better times. Beyond cooking, I assumed the responsibilities of various household chores, transforming labor into acts of love. My presence offered companionship, a buffer against the solitude that illness can impose. On more fortunate days, we indulged in conversation or shared the quiet comfort of reading, her voice a soft reminder of the unyielding bond we shared. This unexpected chapter, though challenging, underscored the profound, albeit bittersweet, beauty of family and sacrifice.
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of creative writing for a given writing instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
When my mother got cancer I’d folded my life down. I was a senior in college in Minneapolis, and I’d convinced my professors to allow me to be in class only two days each week. As soon as those days were over, I drove north to the house in rural Minnesota where I’d grown up, racing home, to my mother. I could not bear to be away from her. Plus, I was needed. My stepfather was with my mother when he could be, when he wasn’t working as a carpenter in an attempt to pay the bills. I cooked food that my mother tried to eat. She’d saypork chops and stuffed green peppers, cherry cheesecake and chicken with rice, and then holler the recipes out to me from her bed. When I’d finished she’d sit like a prisoner staring down at her steaming plate. “It smells good,” she’d say. “I think I’ll be able to eat it later.” I scrubbed the floors. I took everything from the cupboards and put new paper down. My mother slept and moaned and counted and swallowed her pills, or on good days she sat in a chair and talked to me, she paged through books.

Paragraph 2:
As I navigated my senior year in college, nestled in the vibrant cityscape of Minneapolis, life took an unforeseen turn when my mother was diagnosed with cancer. Determined to be there for her, I recalibrated my academic schedule, attending classes only on Tuesdays and Thursdays, leaving the remaining days free to journey back to our tranquil rural home in Minnesota. Every week, I embarked on the familiar drive through rolling landscapes, my heart a mix of anticipation and apprehension. With my stepfather tirelessly working as a carpenter, I stepped into the role of caregiver, a shift that taught me as much about resilience as any college course. Under my mother's gentle guidance, I found myself in the kitchen, crafting meals from her cherished recipes, each dish a tangible connection to better times. Beyond cooking, I assumed the responsibilities of various household chores, transforming labor into acts of love. My presence offered companionship, a buffer against the solitude that illness can impose. On more fortunate days, we indulged in conversation or shared the quiet comfort of reading, her voice a soft reminder of the unyielding bond we shared. This unexpected chapter, though challenging, underscored the profound, albeit bittersweet, beauty of family and sacrifice.

paragraph1: It goes without saying that one of the men is tall, rather handsome—in a vulgar way—a little dim and vicious, while the other man is shorter, weasel-faced, and sly. This short, sly man leaned on the Coca-Cola hoarding that marked the entrance to the village and raised a hand in friendly greeting, while his companion took the small stick that he had, up to that point, been chewing, threw it on the ground, and smiled. They could just as well have been leaning on a lamppost and chewing gum, and the smell of borscht could have been in the air, but in our village we do not make borscht—we eat couscous and tilefish and that was the smell in the air, tilefish, which even to this day we can hardly bear to smell because it reminds us of the day the two men arrived in the village.
paragraph2: As they arrived at the edge of the village, two men presented an odd and unsettling contrast against the backdrop of the serene countryside. The taller man, with a face that could be charitably described as somewhat handsome but edged with vulgarity, carried himself with an air of dim-witted viciousness, his eyes scanning the surroundings with a predatory gaze. His companion was notably shorter, with a face that bore a striking resemblance to a weasel, complete with a sly demeanor that suggested an innate cunning. Leaning nonchalantly against a faded Coca-Cola billboard that marked the village's entrance, the shorter man raised a hand in a seemingly friendly gesture, a smile playing on his lips. His taller companion tossed aside a small, chewed stick and returned the gesture with a grin. The air was thick with the distinctive scent of tilefish, an aroma that heralded their arrival. Unlike other villages that might favor borscht, this one was characterized by its staple diet of couscous and tilefish, a culinary fact as inseparable from their presence as the men themselves.

paragraph1: I remember vividly the night the storm struck, like nature was staging a theatrical mirror to the whirlwind of scandal unfolding in our lives. I was at home flicking through the news, when fierce winds lashed against the windows and thunderstorm raged overhead, ominously shaking the walls of my small abode. Just across the street, Jocelyn's house was equally battered by the tempest, the violent weather somehow magnifying the tumult occurring in our community. It all centered around a wretched villain, whose deceitful actions were finally exposed. Accused of plagiarism, they had audaciously pilfered entire passages and concepts from an esteemed work for their book, "The Tumult." As the controversy unfolded, the book was emphatically withdrawn and condemned to destruction. Yet, amidst this storm of accusations and ruined reputations, something remarkable emerged—an old friend, a quiet hero and true genius, who had been overshadowed and betrayed by the villain. Despite suffering through professional setbacks and personal hardship, this friend reemerged with a luminous grace, their work suddenly revered and hailed as a modern classic. The world was captivated, and a flurry of excitement ensued as people scrambled to acquire rights, leading to high-profile awards and immense commercial success. Reflecting on these events, themes of plagiarism and self-destructive behavior in later life played out vividly in my mind, serving as a cautionary tale inspired by this scandal.
paragraph2: Much of the rest you will know. It was the perfect story. A wild storm surged through my house and Jocelyn’s. All the correct ingredients. A wretched villain, a quiet hero. A national treasure knocked flying from his pedestal, dishonest fingers deep in the till, an old friend down on his luck, betrayed, whole passages lifted, whole conception stolen, characters, too, no plausible explanation from the guilty man, whose friends now understood his reluctance to publish, tens of thousands of copies of “The Tumult” removed from the shops and pulped. And the old friend? Nobly refused to condemn, unavailable for interviews—and, of course, a genius revealed, best book in years, a modern classic, a mild man loved by his students and colleagues, dumped by his publisher, books out of print. Then a scramble to procure the rights, all the rights, to the backlist as well as “Dance,” agents and auctions involved, film rights and movie people involved. Then the prizes—Booker, Whitbread, Medici, Critics Circle, in one long noisy banquet. Copies of the Gorgeous edition selling for five thousand pounds on AbeBooks. Then, as the dust settled, and with my book still “flying” off the shelves, thoughtful articles on the nature of literary kleptomania, the strange compulsion to be caught, and acts of artistic self-destruction in late middle age.

paragraph1: Yet I went on living. In other words, the act of writing didn’t lessen my grief. As soon as I had set down my pen, I felt pangs for the man whose voice and foreign accent I could no longer hear, whose skin I could no longer touch, living an unknown life in some cold city—the real man, far more inaccessible than the written man designated by the letter A. And so I went on doing the things that help alleviate sorrow, offering hope when, theoretically, there is no longer cause for anyplaying patience, slipping a ten-franc coin into a beggar’s paper cup at Auber Metro station, making the wish that “he’ll call, he’ll come back.” (Perhaps, after all, writing is one of these things.)Despite my aversion to meeting people, I agreed to attend a seminar in Copenhagen because it was an opportunity to send him news of me discreetlya postcard I felt he would have to answer. As soon as I arrived in Copenhagen, I thought of nothing elsebuying a card, copying out the few sentences I had carefully written before leaving, finding a letter box. On the plane, on the way back, I reflected that I had traveled to Denmark simply to send a postcard to a man.
paragraph2: Grief has a peculiarly stubborn way of nestling into the cracks of one's existence, impervious to the passage of time or the therapeutic nature of writing. I find myself caught in this emotional maelstrom, grappling with the aching absence of the man I call "the letter A," whose presence now only lingers as an elusive memory. No written word seems potent enough to ease this sorrow, yet I persist in the futile act of penning out my heart's lamentations. In the midst of this ongoing struggle, small gestures anchor me: the tender exchange of coins with a shivering beggar, the soothing monotony of a solitary game of patience. Despite my discomfort with social gatherings, my aching heart propels me to a seminar in Copenhagen. Beneath the guise of scholarly pursuits lies the clandestine intent to send a postcard to A, entwining hope with quiet desperation. The bustling city fades to a singular mission—dispatching words inked with longing into an uncertain void, clinging to the fragile possibility of rekindled connection. It is on the homeward flight that the enormity of my actions dawns on me: this entire journey, each step taken and word uttered, exists solely as a silent plea for reconnection with him, a testament to an undying affection that refuses to be quelled.

paragraph1: I didn’t know which was worse—the idea of my father’s remarrying for love or of his actively seeking out a stranger for companionship. My parents had had an arranged marriage, but there was a touch of romance about it, too, my father seeing my mother for the first time at a wedding and being so attracted that he had asked, the following week, for her hand. They had always been affectionate with each other, but it wasn’t until her illness that he seemed fully, recklessly, to fall in love with her, so that I was witness to a courtship that ought to have faded before I was born. He doted on her then, arriving home at our Bombay flat with flowers, lingering in bed with her in the mornings, going in late to work, wanting to be alone with her to the point where I, a teen-ager, felt in the way. “I thought,” he continued, “since your bedroom is a good size, of putting the girls together there. Would you mind terribly staying in the guest room when you visit, Kaushik? Most of your things are with you now anyway. It is just a matter of where to sleep. But please tell me if you mind.” He seemed more concerned about my reaction to a new room than the fact that I had just acquired a new family.
paragraph2: As I sit here pondering the latest twist in my father's life, a myriad of emotions swirls within me. The thought of him remarrying fills me with a mixture of curiosity and concern. Is he truly in love again, or is this about companionship, a shared comfort that perhaps eludes him when alone? Reflecting on his past, my parents' marriage was arranged yet laced with subtle romance that blossomed unexpectedly. In my mother's illness, I witnessed his love for her grow fiercely, even as the end loomed closer. Now, with him proposing to remarry, I’m faced with a new reality—one where my room shall be transformed to accommodate "the girls," new family members whose faces I have yet to fathom. I will become a guest in my own home when I visit, stashed away in the guest room like a temporary fixture. My father's attention, surprisingly, lingers on the logistics of my comfort in this room transition, rather than addressing the profound change this marriage brings to our family dynamics. It's disconcerting, this lack of focus on the emotional upheaval it might instigate, which leaves me feeling somewhat displaced, a secondary character in the unfolding narrative of his new life chapters. It's clear he desires happiness, yet I can't help but wonder how I truly fit into this impending family mosaic.

paragraph1: The day before Nell and Lizzie are due to leave for the city, Nell comes across a note written by Tig, long ago, when the two of them installed mosquito nets over the beds as a communal service. The mosquitoes can be thick as fur on the outsides of the screens, especially in June; they can squeeze through the tiniest cracks. Once inside, they whine. Even if you’ve got repellent on, they can ruin your night."Large mosquito nettingAt the end of the bug season the large netting should be packed in this bag. The wooden frame, once collapsed, is inserted in the inner compartment of the green bag—Thanks."What green bag? she wonders. Probably it got mildew and someone discarded it. In any case, no one had ever followed these instructions of Tig’s; the mosquito netting is merely left in place and tied into a bundle when not in use.She smooths out the piece of paper carefully and stores it away in her bag. It’s a message, left by Tig for her to find. Magical thinking, she knows that perfectly well, but she indulges in it, anyway, because it’s comforting. She’ll take this piece of paper back to the city, but what will she do with it there? What does one ever do with these cryptic messages from the dead?
paragraph2: Nell stood in the attic, a place where memories seemed to cling to the walls and whisper secrets long forgotten. Her fingers traced the edges of a yellowed note, its corners curled with time, penned by Tig, whose presence she felt more acutely in these moments of quiet solitude. The note was straightforward, detailing the careful packing of mosquito netting into a green bag once the bug season drew to a close, part of a forgotten community service project they had once embarked on together. Yet, Nell couldn't help but smile wryly at the thought of Tig’s meticulously outlined plans never coming to fruition, musing that the green bag was likely discarded, and the netting left haphazardly bundled and tucked away. To her, the note resonated beyond its mundane instructions; it was a relic, a piece of Tig that persisted beyond the constraints of life and death. Nell folded the fragile paper with a tenderness reserved for precious artifacts and slipped it into her own bag, a silent pact formed with the past. As she turned to leave, her mind wandered to the city, a world bustling and indifferent to such personal relics. She mused on the nature of messages left by those who had departed from life, wondering if they crafted these notes as markers for others to stumble upon and find solace in their cryptic echoes.

paragraph1: You've spent enough of your life already on all of that. Let's go away tomorrow, let's not waste a single day more, let's go before it's too late for us."Too late for what, exactly?" "Too late for... oh, I don't know. All I know is that I've wasted all these years looking for something, a sort of trophy I'd get only if I really, really did enough to deserve it. But I don't want it any more, I want something else now, something warm and sheltering, something I can turn to, regardless of what I do, regardless of who I become. Something that will just be there, always, like tomorrow's sky. That's what I want now, and I think it's what you should want too. But it will be too late soon. We'll become too set to change. If we don't take our chance now, another may never come for either of us."
paragraph2: "I know it sounds daunting," I began, my voice tinged with urgency, "but we can't keep letting our lives slip away while striving for impermanent highs. I’ve spent years chasing dreams that, once grasped, melted like mist in the morning sun. It’s time for a change—something real, something that lasts." My friend sat across from me, deep in thought, as I continued, "Don't you feel it too? This need for stability, for something that won't vanish the moment we think we've captured it?" The lines between the pursuit of endless ambition and the fear of stagnation blurred as I spoke. "Before we lose our chance, we have to switch gears, leave behind this unfulfilling cycle. Time is a relentless thief, and soon it will be too late. Let’s seek something more grounded, something that doesn’t just promise satisfaction but truly delivers it consistently." Their silence suggested contemplation, a slight shimmer of hope.

paragraph1: People talk about the happy quiet that can exist between two loves, but this, too, was great; sitting between his sister and his brother, saying nothing, eating. Before the world existed, before it was populated, and before there were wars and jobs and colleges and movies and clothes and opinions and foreign travel -- before all of these things there had been only one person, Zora, and only one placea tent in the living room made from chairs and bed-sheets. After a few years, Levi arrived; space was made for him; it was as if he had always been. Looking at them both now, Jerome found himself in their finger joints and neat conch ears, in their long legs and wild curls. He heard himself in their partial lisps caused by puffy tongues vibrating against slightly noticeable buckteeth. He did not consider if or how or why he loved them. They were just lovethey were the first evidence he ever had of love, and they would be the last confirmation of love when everything else fell away.
paragraph2: Jerome sat quietly between his sister, Zora, and his brother, Levi, savoring the warmth of a familiar silence as they shared a meal. The room was filled with the comforting clatter of cutlery against plates and the soft murmur of contented sighs. As he glanced from Zora to Levi, Jerome felt a profound connection that transcended words—a tapestry woven from shared memories and unspoken understanding. He recalled the nights of their childhood spent camping under makeshift tents crafted from old chairs and bed-sheets, the living room transforming into a magical world just for them. Observing their familiar gestures and expressions, he found pieces of himself mirrored in Levi's mischievous grin and Zora's thoughtful gaze. These shared traits were more than mere coincidences; they were a testament to their inseparable bond. In moments like these, Jerome realized that his siblings were essential threads in the fabric of his identity. The love he shared with them was a touchstone, grounding him in a profound truth that had always shaped his understanding of love and would continue to do so throughout his life.

paragraph1: Ordinary for me, but for my brother it wasn’t going to be like that. He was going to break away; he was going to be a professional man; I was going to see to that. For the rich and the professional the world is not ordinary. I know, I see them. Where you build a hut, they build a mansion; where you have mud and a pará-grass field, they have a garden; when you kill time on a Sunday, they have parties. We all come out of the same pot, but some people move ahead and some people get left behind. Some people get left behind so far they don’t know and they stop caring .Like my father. He couldn’t read and write and he didn’t care. He even joke about his illiteracy, slapping his fat arms and laughing. He say he is happy to leave that side of life to his younger brother, who is a law clerk in the city.
paragraph2: I find myself constantly reflecting on the world around me, particularly the stark contrast between my mundane existence and the lives of the affluent and accomplished. It's almost as if we inhabit different universes, where the boundaries of opportunity are drawn sharply by our birth circumstances. My primary goal, however, is not to wallow in self-pity but to invest in the future of my younger brother, aspiring to see him rise above the limitations we've known. Unlike our father, who seems content with his illiteracy—often turning it into a joke—my brother and I are driven by a relentless ambition to change our narrative. Our father relies heavily on his younger brother, a law clerk in the city, to navigate legalities and paperwork. This dependency illustrates the divide between those who triumph and those who lag behind, a divide I am determined to bridge for my brother. I remain steadfast, ensuring he steps into a world brimming with opportunities waiting to be seized.

paragraph1: There are beings who are overwhelmed by the reality of others, their way of speaking, of crossing their legs, of lighting a cigarette. They become mired in the presence of others. One day, or rather one night, they are swept away inside the desire and the will of a single Other. Everything they believed about themselves vanishes. They dissolve and watch a reflection of themselves act, obey, swept into a course of events unknown. They trail behind the will of the Other, which is always one step ahead. They never catch up.There is no submission, no consent, only the stupefaction of the real. All one can do is repeat “This can’t be happening to me” or “It is me this is happening to,” but in the event, “me” is no longer, has already changed. All that remains is the Other, master of the situation, of every gesture and the moment to follow, which only he foresees.
paragraph2: In the throes of engagement with an overpowering presence, individuals often find themselves submerged beneath an external will so dominating that it effectively erases their own identity. This transformative experience is characterized by the overpowering influence of a singular "Other" whose desires and dictates become the governing force of their existence. As if entrapped within an invisible cocoon, they observe their lives unfold, with roles diminished to mere spectators, passive participants in a reality carefully crafted by this ever-controlling entity. The third-person narrative voice underscores the universality of this situation, illustrating how these characters grapple with a profound identity crisis. A persistent internal dialogue churns within them, echoing with phrases like, “This can’t be happening to me,” a mantra of disbelief that ironically highlights their already-altered self-concept. Such internal conflicts manifest as poignant realizations of lost autonomy, as they struggle to reclaim a sense of individual identity from the clutches of this omnipresent "Other."

paragraph1: Ivan has come to understand that it must be awkward to receive unwanted sexual comments and invitations, and there was that one occasion even in his own case, which was also a man, which probably just goes to show. He would personally go to great lengths to avoid ever encountering that guy again, not that he even did anything bad, but purely from the awkwardness. Then imagine being an attractive woman and it’s not just one man you have to avoid but almost all of them. At the same time, how to reach a mutually agreeable situation without one person making an advance on the other which may turn out to be unwanted? It’s like the problem with the chairs and tables. In a haphazard and inefficient way, without any fixed method, solutions can be reached, and, evidently, are reached all the time, considering that someone like Ollie is married. People get to know each other, things happen, that’s life. The question for Ivan is how to become one of those people, how to live that kind of life.
paragraph2: Ivan found himself reflecting on the awkwardness of unsolicited sexual comments and invitations, a situation he had personally experienced in an encounter with a man. This incident left him feeling discomfort unparalleled, prompting a silent pledge to avoid the individual, despite recognizing there had been no explicit wrongdoing. The thought lingered with Ivan, forcing him to consider how much more frequent and challenging these encounters must be for attractive women who often face such uncomfortable advances. He marveled at the delicate dance involved in forming mutual relationships without crossing unwelcome boundaries, likening it to an intricate problem-solving task. Yet, he acknowledged the evidence of success in this sphere all around him, often noticing how people forged connections seemingly effortlessly. His friend Ollie served as a prime example, being comfortably married, a fact that both puzzled and inspired Ivan. He found himself deeply contemplating the nuances of relationship-building, pondering how he might achieve such successful connections himself, navigating the complex social landscape that surrounded him with quiet determination and curiosity about the possibilities.

paragraph1: "It’s very late," I said. "Are you sure a bus will come?" "Oh, yes. Of course, you may have to wait. But eventually a bus will come." Then he touched me reassuringly on the shoulder. "I can see it might get a little lonely standing out here. But once the bus arrives your spirits will rise, believe me. Oh, yes. That bus is always a joy. It’ll be brightly lit up, and it’s always full of cheerful people, laughing and joking and pointing out the window. Once you board it, you’ll feel warm and comfortable, and the other passengers will chat with you, perhaps offer you things to eat or drink. There may even be singing—that depends on the driver. Some drivers encourage it, others don’t. Well, Fletcher, it was good to see you." We shook hands, then he turned and walked away. I watched him disappear into the darkness between two cottages.I walked up to the green and put my bag down at the foot of the lamppost. I listened for the sound of a vehicle in the distance, but the night was utterly still. Nevertheless, I had been cheered by Roger Button's description of the bus. Moreover, I thought of the reception awaiting me at my journey’s end—of the adoring faces of the young people—and felt the stirrings of optimism somewhere deep within me.
paragraph2: Standing under the dim, flickering glow of the streetlamp, the night air wrapping around us like a cool whisper, I found myself deeply engaged in conversation with a man named Roger Button. It was late—one of those nights when the silence hums and time feels malleable—and we were perched together at a lonely bus stop, shrouded in uncertainty, questioning the arrival of the last bus of the night. Roger, with a comforting smile, assured me that it would eventually make its way down the dusky road. He painted vivid pictures of the journey ahead, describing the bus as a vessel of joy, filled with passengers whose spirits were as bright and warm as a summer's day. Their laughter, he promised, would be contagious, their stories engaging enough to make time fly like the wind. After we exchanged goodbyes, Roger ambled off into the shadows of the night, leaving a trail of his buoyant optimism behind. Alone, I set my bag carefully at the foot of a lamppost and stood in quiet anticipation, ears poised for the faint, hopeful rumble of an approaching vehicle. Roger's words had left me with a sense of calm, a newfound optimism about not just reaching the destination, but the welcoming reception awaiting at journey's end, a sentiment I clung to as the city sighed around me.

paragraph1: We are split people. For myself, half of me wishes to sit quietly with my legs crossed, letting the things that are beyond my control wash over me. But the other half wants to fight the holy war. Jihad! And certainly we could argue this out in the street, but I think, in the end, your past is not my past and your truth is not my truth and your solution — it is not my solution. So I do not know what it is you would like me to say. Truth and firmness is one suggestion, though there are many other people you can ask if that answer does not satisfy. Personally, my hope lies in the last days. The prophet Muhammad — peace be upon Him! — tells us that on the Day of Resurrection everyone will be struck unconscious. Deaf and dumb. No chit-chat. Tongueless. And what a bloody relief that will be. Now, if you will excuse me.
paragraph2: Reflecting on my internal struggles, I find myself caught in a dichotomy. On one hand, there's a deep yearning for peace and quiet acceptance of those matters beyond my control, a simple surrender to the flow of life. On the other, there's an almost fervent urge to engage in a holy war, a spiritual "Jihad," not against others but within myself, to reconcile these contradictory desires. I understand that each of us walks along a path shaped by unique pasts, truths, and solutions, and it's this divergence that often seeds conflict among us. I grapple with uncertainty about what others expect of me. Should I speak in truths even if they might be uncomfortable, or stand firm in silence and contemplation? Perhaps neither will fully satisfy the diverse expectations I encounter. My solace lies in the hope of the Day of Resurrection, as foretold by the Prophet Muhammad, when all voices will be silenced, giving us all perhaps a much-needed respite. And so, with these thoughts, I politely excuse myself.

paragraph1: The mother does what I doshe sweeps the floor, cooks, washes dishes. At least once a day she hangs up the laundry. Our clothes mingle and dry on a shared line. She tells her husband, clasping the laundry basket in her arms, how happy this makes her. Since they live in the city, in a crowded apartment, she can never hang their clothes out in the open like this.After lunch, the father takes the girls to the beach and the mother stays home alone. She stretches out and smokes a cigarette, writing in her notebook with an air of concentration.One day, back from the beach, the girls run around for hours trying to catch crickets that jump through the grass. They snatch them up. They put a few in a jar with little pieces of tomato stolen from their parents’ salads. They turn them into pets, even naming them. The next day the crickets die, suffocated in the jar, and the girls cry. They bury them under one of the plum trees and put some wildflowers on top.
paragraph2: Amidst the gentle sounds of domestic life, the mother found a rhythm in sweeping, cooking, washing dishes, and hanging laundry. Her delight was evident as she remarked to her husband about the joy of drying their clothes outside—a luxury they weren’t accustomed to in their usual cramped city living. After lunch, the father took the daughters to the beach, leaving her with a rare moment for herself. Embracing the solitude, she indulged in a quiet cigarette and penned her thoughts into a notebook, relishing her brief escape. Meanwhile, the girls returned from their sandy adventures, brimming with energy and fascination for their latest endeavor: capturing crickets. They carefully placed the creatures in a jar, adding chunks of tomato from their family salads, and affectionately named them as if they were treasured pets. The next day, however, was tinged with sadness as the crickets, having suffocated, were tenderly buried under a plum tree. The girls solemnly laid wildflowers over the small grave, mourning their short-lived joyous companionship.

paragraph1: Grief has a peculiarly stubborn way of nestling into the cracks of one's existence, impervious to the passage of time or the therapeutic nature of writing. I find myself caught in this emotional maelstrom, grappling with the aching absence of the man I call "the letter A," whose presence now only lingers as an elusive memory. No written word seems potent enough to ease this sorrow, yet I persist in the futile act of penning out my heart's lamentations. In the midst of this ongoing struggle, small gestures anchor me: the tender exchange of coins with a shivering beggar, the soothing monotony of a solitary game of patience. Despite my discomfort with social gatherings, my aching heart propels me to a seminar in Copenhagen. Beneath the guise of scholarly pursuits lies the clandestine intent to send a postcard to A, entwining hope with quiet desperation. The bustling city fades to a singular mission—dispatching words inked with longing into an uncertain void, clinging to the fragile possibility of rekindled connection. It is on the homeward flight that the enormity of my actions dawns on me: this entire journey, each step taken and word uttered, exists solely as a silent plea for reconnection with him, a testament to an undying affection that refuses to be quelled.
paragraph2: Yet I went on living. In other words, the act of writing didn’t lessen my grief. As soon as I had set down my pen, I felt pangs for the man whose voice and foreign accent I could no longer hear, whose skin I could no longer touch, living an unknown life in some cold city—the real man, far more inaccessible than the written man designated by the letter A. And so I went on doing the things that help alleviate sorrow, offering hope when, theoretically, there is no longer cause for anyplaying patience, slipping a ten-franc coin into a beggar’s paper cup at Auber Metro station, making the wish that “he’ll call, he’ll come back.” (Perhaps, after all, writing is one of these things.)Despite my aversion to meeting people, I agreed to attend a seminar in Copenhagen because it was an opportunity to send him news of me discreetlya postcard I felt he would have to answer. As soon as I arrived in Copenhagen, I thought of nothing elsebuying a card, copying out the few sentences I had carefully written before leaving, finding a letter box. On the plane, on the way back, I reflected that I had traveled to Denmark simply to send a postcard to a man.

Despite my discomfort with social gatherings, my aching heart propels me to a seminar in Copenhagen. Beneath the guise of scholarly pursuits lies the clandestine intent to send a postcard to A, entwining hope with quiet desperation. The bustling city fades to a singular mission—dispatching words inked with longing into an uncertain void, clinging to the fragile possibility of rekindled connection. It is on the homeward flight that the enormity of my actions dawns on me: this entire journey, each step taken and word uttered, exists solely as a silent plea for reconnection with him, a testament to an undying affection that refuses to be quelled.

Paragraph 2:
Yet I went on living. In other words, the act of writing didn’t lessen my grief. As soon as I had set down my pen, I felt pangs for the man whose voice and foreign accent I could no longer hear, whose skin I could no longer touch, living an unknown life in some cold city—the real man, far more inaccessible than the written man designated by the letter A. And so I went on doing the things that help alleviate sorrow, offering hope when, theoretically, there is no longer cause for anyplaying patience, slipping a ten-franc coin into a beggar’s paper cup at Auber Metro station, making the wish that “he’ll call, he’ll come back.” (Perhaps, after all, writing is one of these things.)Despite my aversion to meeting people, I agreed to attend a seminar in Copenhagen because it was an opportunity to send him news of me discreetlya postcard I felt he would have to answer. As soon as I arrived in Copenhagen, I thought of nothing elsebuying a card, copying out the few sentences I had carefully written before leaving, finding a letter box. On the plane, on the way back, I reflected that I had traveled to Denmark simply to send a postcard to a man.

paragraph1: I have lived in Istanbul for sixty years, and Taksim Square has been a constant axis around which countless memories have orbited. In its vibrant history, I recall the days when the old artillery barracks, a relic of another era, were transformed into a bustling football stadium in the 1930s, a hub of excitement and sporting fervor that drew crowds from all over the city. The 1940s and 1950s ushered in a new era of nightlife with the Taksim Gazino club becoming an epicenter for music and dance, offering a glamorous escape amidst the challenges of the time. Over the decades, the square has seen trees planted where once stood strong buildings, and an esteemed art gallery that became my muse when, in the 1960s, I dreamed of being an artist and hoped my work might grace its walls. By the 1970s, Taksim became the vibrant heart of Labor Day demonstrations. Standing shoulder to shoulder with fellow dreamers—trade unionists and NGO members—I felt the pulse of a city and community striving for change.
paragraph2: Today, Taksim Square is Istanbul's chestnut tree. I've been living in Istanbul for sixty years, and I cannot imagine that there is a single inhabitant of this city who does not have at least one memory connected to Taksim Square. In the nineteen-thirties, the old artillery barracks, which the government now wants to convert into a shopping mall, contained a small football stadium that hosted official matches. The famous club Taksim Gazino, which was the center of Istanbul night life in the nineteen-forties and fifties, stood on a corner of Gezi Park. Later, buildings were demolished, trees were cut down, new trees were planted, and a row of shops and Istanbul's most famous art gallery were set up along one side of the park.In the nineteen-sixties, I used to dream of becoming a painter and displaying my work at this gallery. In the seventies, the square was home to enthusiastic celebrations of Labor Day, led by leftist trade unions and N.G.O.s; for a time, I took part in these gatherings.

Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
I have lived in Istanbul for sixty years, and Taksim Square has been a constant axis around which countless memories have orbited. In its vibrant history, I recall the days when the old artillery barracks, a relic of another era, were transformed into a bustling football stadium in the 1930s, a hub of excitement and sporting fervor that drew crowds from all over the city. The 1940s and 1950s ushered in a new era of nightlife with the Taksim Gazino club becoming an epicenter for music and dance, offering a glamorous escape amidst the challenges of the time. Over the decades, the square has seen trees planted where once stood strong buildings, and an esteemed art gallery that became my muse when, in the 1960s, I dreamed of being an artist and hoped my work might grace its walls. By the 1970s, Taksim became the vibrant heart of Labor Day demonstrations. Standing shoulder to shoulder with fellow dreamers—trade unionists and NGO members—I felt the pulse of a city and community striving for change.

Paragraph 2:
Today, Taksim Square is Istanbul's chestnut tree. I've been living in Istanbul for sixty years, and I cannot imagine that there is a single inhabitant of this city who does not have at least one memory connected to Taksim Square. In the nineteen-thirties, the old artillery barracks, which the government now wants to convert into a shopping mall, contained a small football stadium that hosted official matches. The famous club Taksim Gazino, which was the center of Istanbul night life in the nineteen-forties and fifties, stood on a corner of Gezi Park. Later, buildings were demolished, trees were cut down, new trees were planted, and a row of shops and Istanbul's most famous art gallery were set up along one side of the park.In the nineteen-sixties, I used to dream of becoming a painter and displaying my work at this gallery. In the seventies, the square was home to enthusiastic celebrations of Labor Day, led by leftist trade unions and N.G.O.s; for a time, I took part in these gatherings.

paragraph1: Finding someone to look after my father's house has been a persistent concern, one that gnaws at the edges of my daily thoughts like a silent, yet insistent, reminder of how dramatically the world has transformed. I reflect, often nostalgically, on how in the bygone days, a significant portion of the population was engaged in domestic service. This provided homeowners with a serene and deeply envied flexibility to leave their homes for weeks, or even months, assured that the caretakers would maintain everything with due diligence. Such peace of mind seems elusive now as the so-called "servant class" has all but disappeared, though echoes of their indispensable roles resonate subtly in today's culture, etched into the very fabric of our society's attitudes and expectations. These days, the landscape has shifted dramatically; you need only to look to the outer stretches of towns and villages where extensive council estates rise. They serve as housing for those at the economic margins, their utilitarian designs often lacking the charm and grace of times past. Yet, in observing these housing estates, I can't help but muse about how the multitude residing within them perhaps mirrors the sheer numbers once involved in domestic service. Ironically, while their living spaces have altered, their societal roles still revolve around service, albeit in different capacities.
paragraph2: But duty is duty, and one of my big worries was finding someone to look after the house for my father. There was a time when a substantial portion of the population was in domestic service. There was no problem then. A certain amount of coming and going, but no lasting problem. When you read books from before the war, you notice, if you have this particular worry on your mind, that people quite easily left their houses and went away visiting for days and weeks. Servants gave them that freedom.Now the servant class has vanished. No one knows what the servants have metamorphosed into. One thing we can be sure of is that we have not lost them, that they are still in varying ways with us, in culture and attitudes of dependence. In every town and large village, we now have ancillary council estates, clusters of subsidized dwellings meant originally for the poor. These clusters are recognizable even from the train. They have a deliberate socialist ugliness, a conscious suppression of those ideas of beauty and humanity that rise naturally from the heart. There can be no absolute match of one age with another, but I wouldn’t be surprised if the percentage of people at one time in domestic service isn’t matched now by the numbers on these council estates.

paragraph1: In the spring semester of his second year, for three weeks, Subhash boarded a research vessel with a group of students and professors. As the ship pulled away, the water cleaved a foaming trail that vanished even as it was being formed. The shoreline receded, resting calmly like a thin brown snake upon the water. He saw the earth’s mass shrinking, turning faint.Under the sun’s glare, as the ship picked up speed, he felt the wind’s motion on his face, the wild turbulence of the atmosphere. He watched the life that circled the ship, gannets with creamy heads and black-and-white wings, dolphins that leaped in pairs. Humpback whales spouted mists as they breathed, playfully breaching in the water, sometimes swimming beneath the ship without disturbing it, emerging on the other side.Sailing even slightly east reminded Subhash of how far away he was from his family. He thought of the time it took to cross even a tiny portion of the earth’s surface.
paragraph2: As the research vessel sliced through the ocean, churning the water into a foamy trail, Subhash stood at the deck's edge, feeling the salty breeze on his face. It was the spring semester of his second year, and he was aboard with students and professors who bustled about, engaged in lively discussions on marine biodiversity. Subhash allowed himself a moment of solitude, his eyes following the swooping gannets that skimmed the water’s surface, while dolphins leapt alongside the boat, their slick bodies glistening under the sun. Occasionally, he glimpsed the majestic arch of a humpback whale breaching in the distance, its massive form momentarily defying gravity. Each sighting stirred within him a profound reflection on the natural world’s grandeur and diversity. Yet, amidst nature’s spectacle, there lingered a wistful thought of his family, distant and unreachable. The vessel’s steady movement across the endless expanse accentuated his sense of separation, compelling him to contemplate the vastness of the earth and the passage of time required to bridge such distances.

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: Michael could hear Marlon’s TV in the background. It was tuned to the same channel Michael was watching, but only Michael could see the images on the screen replicated simultaneously through his own window, a strange doubling sensation, like when you stand on a stage and look up at yourself on the Jumbotron. Elizabeth and Marlon were staying uptown; normally Michael, too, would be staying uptown—until five days ago he’d almost never set foot below Forty-second Street. Everyone—his brothers and sisters, all his West Coast friends—had warned him not to go downtown. It’s dangerous downtown, it’s always been that way, just stick with what you know, stay at the Carlyle. But because the helipad near the Garden had, for some reason, been out of commission it had been decided he should stay downtown, for reasons of proximity and to avoid traffic. Now Michael looked south and saw a sky darkened with ash. The ash seemed to be moving toward him. Downtown was really so much worse than anyone in L.A. could even begin to imagine.
paragraph2: Michael stood at his downtown apartment window, a strange sensation of doubling washing over him as he simultaneously heard and saw the exact broadcast playing on Marlon's television across town. Through his window and on his own screen, the same images flickered, creating an uncanny echo of sight and sound. Normally, he would have joined Elizabeth and Marlon uptown, but unusual circumstances had left him stranded downtown. A helipad near the Garden, usually his swift exit path, was unexpectedly out of commission. Ignoring the concerned voices of family and friends who had cautioned him about the perils of downtown life, Michael felt an unsettling determination to navigate his current situation. As he gazed southward, the sight of the sky, streaked with ash, seemed to confirm his loved ones' fears. It loomed ominously, a foreboding omen that the evolving situation downtown was dire, maybe even catastrophic—far worse than his West Coast acquaintances, wrapped in their coastal ignorance, might have ever imagined. Yet there was a pull, as though this chaos was his to observe, to endure, to understand.

paragraph1: Time ceased to be a series of meaningless days punctuated by university talks and lectures, afternoons spent in cafés and at the library, leading up to exams and the summer vacation, to the future. It became a shapeless entity growing inside me which had to be destroyed at all costs.I attended literature and sociology classes, I ate in the university canteen, I drank coffee twice a day at La Faluche, the students’ hangout. Yet I was living in a different world. There were the other girls, with their empty bellies, and there was me. To convey my predicament, I never resorted to descriptive terms or expressions such as "I’m expecting," "pregnant" or "pregnancy." They endorsed a future event that would never materialize. There was no point naming something that I was planning to get rid of. In my diary I would write, "it" or "that thing,"" only once “pregnant."
paragraph2: Every tick of the clock seems to drag me further into the murky depths of uncertainty, each minute marking a departure from the predictable cadence of my former life as a university student. My world was once a smooth rhythm of lectures, late-night study sessions, and laughter echoing around La Faluche as I sipped my coffee. Now, it feels as if each second I spend in the company of my peers only magnifies the chasm between us. I watch "the other girls," all seemingly buoyant in their blissful states of freedom, unaware of the burden I silently carry. My belly remains outwardly unchanged, yet inside I’m besieged by turmoil. I can’t bring myself to utter the words "pregnant" or "expecting" even in the privacy of my diary. I refer to it simply as "it" or "that thing," grasping desperately at a sense of detachment, driven by an unwillingness to fully accept my current reality—my determination to end this nightmare palpable in every strained breath.

paragraph1: During the summer of 1964, when I was around 12 or 13, I found myself mesmerized by the endless wonders of the seaside near Istanbul. Each day was a new adventure as I eagerly explored the shoreline, my footsteps guided by the rhythmic lull of the waves. One particular day, I stumbled upon a secluded natural pool nestled among the rocks. This small sanctuary became my treasure trove, a vibrant world bustling with marine life. As I peered into its crystalline depths, I felt like an intrepid explorer on the brink of discovering a hidden civilization. The colorful fish would dart and dance, crabs scuttling sideways with a curious grace, and sea urchins clinging steadfastly to their rocky homes. It was a delicate microcosm, alive with color and movement, and I, a solitary observer, was privy to its silent stories. Each detail of this miniature world captured my imagination, filling me with a profound sense of wonder and connection during my solitary wanderings.
paragraph2: In 1964, when I was about 12 or 13, I spent the summer at a house by the seaside 35 miles from Istanbul. I would leap over the low garden wall and walk towards the beach through the rocks and empty fields that lined the shore, inspecting all the marvelous little surprises that nature would lay upon my path. One day I came across a small pool of water among the rocks. It wasn’t exactly a pool. The sea kept pouring in through the gaps among the rocks and stones. But like a real pool, it was about one foot deep and six or seven meters wide, and shielded from the assault of the sea’s unruly waves. I quickly discovered that below the unruffled and perfectly transparent surface of my “pool” was another world, a whole civilization, and I began to spend more and more time there, alone in the summer heat, fascinated by the bustling realm submerged in the tepid seawater.

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: Now that he has stopped missing the peace and quiet of the “yes” years, the old man has actually begun to enjoy the quarrelsomeness of his fellow-citizens. The vanity of certainty, which gives each finger-wagging debater his or her reason for her or his insistence on that or this dispute, strikes the old man as the very fons et origo of comedy. The fervor with which many people in the piazza hold opinions that are demonstrably untrue—the sun, madam, does not rise in the west, no matter how vehemently you may argue that it does, and, sir, the moon is not made of Gorgonzola cheese, and to say this is not to agree with your opponent, who describes it as an elaborate papier-mâché fake, nailed to the sky to make us believe that we live in a three-dimensional universe of stars, planets, and satellites, rather than upon a dish with a great lid over it, a lid like an inverted colander, with many holes through which, at night, shines the bright thing we have been deceived into calling starlight. The piazza is full of passionate nonsense such as this, and the old man thinks, Oh, let them go on, there’s no harm in it, after all.
paragraph2: For the old man lounging comfortably on the weathered bench in the bustling piazza, the cacophony of animated debates swirling around him served as an unexpected source of amusement and reflection. Once, in the distant past he fondly referred to as the "yes" years, he had longed for a world imbued with calm and collective agreement, where truth seemed as serene and unobtrusive as the gentle breeze sweeping through golden autumn leaves. However, age and wisdom imparted a new appreciation for the combative spirit of his fellow citizens, whose insistence on arguing every inconceivable point—ranging from asinine assertions about the sun making its grand daily entrance from the west to outrageously claiming cheese as the moon's origin story—filled his days with endless entertainment. It was the vanity of their certainty, the earnest conviction wrapped around fallacies like tender vines around fragile trellises, that amused him most. These debaters, each a modern-day Sisyphus, rolled their intellectual boulders up hills of unfounded certainty and let them tumble hilariously down paths of reason. In observing them, he found a gentle charm; these debates were not matters of life and death but exercises in the frivolity of thought, emphasizing humanity's innate desire to question, no matter how absurdly. And so, in the heart of this lively discourse, he discovered an unexpected harmony—a quiet, personal solace amidst the roaring tide of nonsensical eloquence.

paragraph1: Reflecting on the trajectory of my life, I often find myself caught in the juxtaposition of past dreams and present realities. I once dreamed of weaving stories, becoming a writer whose words could transcend time. Yet, life, in its unpredictable manner, nudged me towards engineering geology, leading me ultimately to the pragmatic world of building construction. My journey has been winding, marked by moments of clarity and confusion, largely influenced by my relationship with my father. It's a bond interwoven with unspoken expectations and silent understanding, a journey that still shapes me. In 1984, my world pivoted around Beşiktaş, near the nostalgic Ihlamur Palace. I frequently found solace and purpose in my father's pharmacy, Hayat, where the late-night whirring of machines and the comforting aroma of mixed herbs became imprinted on my soul. Now, at forty-five, those scents linger vividly, a comforting tether to a past that continues to affect me deeply, even as I navigate the complexities of adulthood and personal identity in the present.
paragraph2: I had wanted to be a writer. But after the events I am about to describe, I studied engineering geology and became a building contractor. Even so, readers shouldn’t conclude from my telling the story now that it is over, that I’ve put it all behind me. The more I remember, the deeper I fall into it. Perhaps you, too, will follow, lured by the enigma of fathers and sons.In 1984, we lived in a small apartment deep in Beşiktaş, near the nineteenth-century Ottoman Ihlamur Palace. My father had a little pharmacy called Hayat, meaning “Life.” Once a week, it stayed open all night, and my father took the late shift. On those evenings, I’d bring him his dinner. I liked to spend time there, breathing in the medicinal smells while my father, a tall, slim, handsome figure, had his meal by the cash register. Almost thirty years have passed, but even at fortyfive I still love the smell of those old pharmacies lined with wooden drawers and cupboards.
