paragraph1: As it happened, she was right about the homesickness. After her return to Bombay, she never had a day’s heart trouble again; and, as the letter from her niece Stella confirmed, at ninety-one she was still going strong. Soon after she left, my father told us he had decided to "shift location" to Pakistan. As usual, there were no discussions, no explanations, just the simple fiat. He gave up the lease on the flat in Waverley House at the end of the summer holidays, and they all went off to Karachi, while I went back to school. I became a British citizen that year. I was one of the lucky ones, I guess, because in spite of that chess game I had the Dodo on my side. And the passport did, in many ways, set me free. It allowed me to come and go, to make choices that were not the ones my father would have wished. But I, too, have ropes around my neck, I have them to this day, pulling me this way and that, East and West, the nooses tightening, commanding, choose, choose. I buck, I snort, I whinny, I rear, I kick. Ropes, I do not choose between you.Lassoes, lariats, I choose neither of you, and both. Do you hear? I refuse to
paragraph2: Reflecting on the decisions that shaped our lives, I often find myself torn by the memory of my father's sudden choice to uproot the family to Pakistan, leaving behind the familiar confines of Waverley House, a place that had been home for as long as I could remember. I stayed behind, clinging to the routine of school, and in doing so, I stumbled upon an unexpected path that led me to becoming a British citizen. This newfound status was laden with freedoms I never imagined but, ironically, also came with internal chains, binding me to an incessant tug-of-war between dual identities. The passport, a symbol of liberation, instead felt like a paradoxical tether, a testament to the complex nature of belonging. While my father anticipated a straightforward allegiance to our roots, I found myself ensnared in the clashing worlds he left behind and the one he sought ahead. Through all of this, she, at ninety-one, the family matriarch perhaps, returned to Bombay, free from heart troubles, her well-being confirmed by a note from her devoted niece Stella. Her resilience, far surpassing mine, only deepens my contemplation of the ropes that invisibly stretch across oceans and generations, tying me to a decision I must make, yet fear to commit to.

paragraph1: Amid the clamor and mundane chaos of the bustling train station platform, two characters stood locked in an intense embrace, entirely absorbed in their own world. The ordinary yet somewhat unpleasant scenes unfolded around them—a person sneezed violently, sending droplets into the air; a grimy plastic bottle skittered across the pavement, propelled by the capricious wind; and an ever-changing billboard flickered with incessant advertisements. Yet, these potential distractions seemed to fade into insignificance for the couple. It was as if they were momentarily oblivious to the superficial vulgarities of their surroundings, possibly even untouched by the disconcerting realities of the urban environment. In their embrace, they appeared to access a deeper, concealed reality, where a profound sense of beauty prevailed despite the world's harsher, cruder aspects, offering a glimpse of grace amid chaos.
paragraph2: Were they aware, in the intensity of their embrace, of something slightly ridiculous about this tableau, something almost comical, as someone nearby sneezed violently into a crumpled tissue; as a dirty discarded plastic bottle scuttled along the platform under a breath of wind; as a mechanised billboard on the station wall rotated from an advertisement for hair products to an advertisement for car insurance; as life in its ordinariness and even ugly vulgarity imposed itself everywhere all around them? Or were they in this moment unaware, or something more than unaware—were they somehow invulnerable to, untouched by, vulgarity and ugliness, glancing for a moment into something deeper, something concealed beneath the surface of life, not unreality but a hidden realitythe presence at all times, in all places, of a beautiful world?

paragraph1: At twenty-four the ambassador's daughter slept badly through the warm, unsurprising nights. She woke up frequently and even when sleep did come her body was rarely at rest, thrashing and flailing as if trying to break free of dreadful invisible manacles. At times she cried out in a language she did not speak. Men had told her this, nervously. Not many men had ever been permitted to be present while she slept. The evidence was therefore limited, lacking consensus; however, a pattern emerged. According to one report she sounded guttural, glottal-stoppy, as if she were speaking Arabic. Night-Arabian, she thought, the dreamtongue of Scheherazade. Another version described her words as science-fictional, like Klingon, like a throat being cleared in a galaxy far, far away. Like Sigourney Weaver channeling a demon in Ghostbusters. One night in a spirit of research the ambassador's daughter left a tape recorder running by her bedside but when she heard the voice on the tape its death's-head ugliness, which was somehow both familiar and alien, scared her badly and she pushed the erase button, which erased nothing important. The truth was still the truth.
paragraph2: The ambassador's daughter grappled nightly with restlessness that transformed her sleep into a mysterious battleground fraught with invisible constraints. Her nights were punctuated by frequent awakenings and an inexplicable aggression, as though unseen forces held her in a precarious grasp. Reports from those who witnessed her nocturnal unrest spoke of words issuing from her lips in harsh, guttural tones—languages foreign to her by any conscious standard. Some claimed these sounds bore the harsh cadence of Arabic, while others ventured into the realm of fiction with mentions of Klingon. Intrigued yet unnerved by these reports, she dared to record her bedtime utterances. The playback, however, revealed an unsettling reality—her voice echoed ominously, a strange and frightful chorus filling the room. Overcome by fear, she quickly erased the recording, hoping to banish the unease it spawned. Yet, despite this act of erasure, there remained an unshakable truth: the uncanny disturbances in her sleep persisted, a haunting reminder of the mysterious forces at play each night when twilight descended. There, in the silence, her subconscious danced with shadows only it could see and speak to.

paragraph1: The doors banged together, and the train started back.Then there was silence, the air like ice. Brittle-looking birch trees with black marks on their white bark, and some small, untidy evergreens, rolled up like sleepy bears. The frozen lake not level but mounded along the shore, as if the waves had turned to ice in the act of falling. And the building, with its deliberate rows of windows and its glassed-in porches at either end. Everything austere and northerly, black-and-white under the high dome of clouds. So still, so immense an enchantment.But the birch bark not white after all, as you got closer. Grayish yellow, grayish blue, gray.
paragraph2: As the train's doors banged shut and it slowly pulled away, an eerie silence settled over the winter landscape, the air bristling with an icy chill. From the train's window, the scenery unfolded with a stark, monochromatic beauty. Brittle-looking birch trees stood like sentinels, their bark marked with black streaks that contrasted sharply against what first seemed an all-encompassing whiteness. On closer inspection, the birch bark revealed subtle shades of grayish yellow and blue, whispering tales of the austere northern environment. Small evergreens gathered along the tracks resembled sleepy bears, while a frozen lake lay blanketed, its wavy mounds along the shore momentarily arrested in time, adding to the stillness and grandeur. Nearby, a building with structured rows of windows and glass porches punctuated the vista, offering a glimpse of human presence amidst nature's profound quietude.

paragraph1: During those empty, sleepless nights, I thought a lot about The Knife as an idea. A knife was a tool, and acquired meaning from the use we made of it. Language, too, was a knife. I could cut open the world and reveal its meaning, its inner workings, its secrets, its truths. It could cut through from one reality to another. It could call bullshit, open people's eyes, create beauty. Language was my knife. If I had unexpectedly been caught in an unwanted knife fight, maybe this was the knife I could use to fight back.
paragraph2: During those seemingly endless sleepless nights, I find myself ensnared in thoughts about "The Knife." At times, it represents an actual, tangible blade, but mostly, I ponder it as a metaphor for language—an instrument whose significance is shaped entirely by its use. Just as a knife carves through layers, revealing what's beneath, language possesses the astonishing ability to unveil hidden truths, traverse different realities, and peel back the surface of falsehoods to disclose what lies beneath. For me, language is my tool and my weapon; a trusty ally that, should I ever find myself thrust into an unwanted confrontation, can be wielded decisively, offering both defense and resolute counteraction.
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of creative writing for a given writing instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
During those empty, sleepless nights, I thought a lot about The Knife as an idea. A knife was a tool, and acquired meaning from the use we made of it. Language, too, was a knife. I could cut open the world and reveal its meaning, its inner workings, its secrets, its truths. It could cut through from one reality to another. It could call bullshit, open people's eyes, create beauty. Language was my knife. If I had unexpectedly been caught in an unwanted knife fight, maybe this was the knife I could use to fight back.

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: In contemplating self-awareness and individuality, I find myself drawn to the contrasting realms of intellectual ideas and physical experiences. While thoughts are abstract and effortlessly exchanged, like currency among minds, feelings, particularly pain, remain uniquely intimate. Philosophically speaking, the shared nature of thoughts might connect us, but it is the visceral reality of suffering that shapes my self-awareness, far more than any exchange of ideas ever could. Personal experiences of pain, as when I inadvertently step on a foot or witness a cat in distress, remind me of the boundaries that define selfhood. These moments are mine alone, untouched by external understanding, forming an intense, inescapable essence of who I am. Such pain encapsulates the core of individuality, grounding my existence in a way that no intellectual discourse might achieve.
paragraph2: I think, therefore I am is the statement of an intellectual who underrates toothaches. I feel, therefore I am is a truth much more universally valid, and it applies to everything that's alive. My self does not differ substantially from yours in terms of its thought. Many people, few ideaswe all think more or less the same, and we exchange, borrow, steal thoughts from one another. However, when someone steps on my foot, only I feel the pain. The basis of the self is not thought but suffering, which is the most fundamental of all feelings. While it suffers, not even a cat can doubt its unique and uninterchangeable self. In intense suffering the world disappears and each of us is alone with his self. Suffering is the university of egocentrism.

paragraph1: I can still recall the shaky nights and the dizzying highs of that pranksterish half love with him, whose laughter once twinkled like forbidden fireworks in the dim corridors of our entangled lives. It began as a reckless dance with destiny, a vivid tapestry of impulsive joys, until heroin cast its sinister shadow over our ill-fated romance. As his addiction spiraled, and I teetered on the precipice of the same abyss, our connection frayed until there was nothing left but the echo of shared laughs and hollow promises. Driven by my own burgeoning hunger for that drug rather than love, I eventually left not in pursuit of clarity but in sheer desperation for escape. Miles apart and worlds away, I filed for divorce with a determination born of self-preservation, shunning not only the drug but also any partners who carried similar ghosts in their pocketed souls. Now, he exists more as a symbol of youthful folly than as a person with dreams that once mirrored my own. Though nostalgia occasionally tugs at me, I am neither heartbroken nor regretful, simply wishing him well with a skeptical heart. In the vast narrative of my journey towards self-discovery, he is but a single chapter—not the book itself, a past I learned from, but dare not revisit.
paragraph2: In the end it wasn’t much. A pranksterish half love that took on tragic undertones as he descended into the depths of heroin addiction and I came close to tumbling in after him. There was drama at my leaving, though it was more about my yearning for heroin than about my feelings for him. By autumn I was fifteen hundred miles away, having returned to the city where I actually lived, shaken and drained. By winter I’d come into the clear and continued on with my life, working at my job and filing for divorce, staying away from heroin and boys with blue hair.Time passed, and he became not himself in my memory but an emblem of my youthful folly, my experimental daring, my authentic scrabble to find a way in the world. I was nostalgic for him on occasion, though not even remotely heartbroken. I wished him well in my mind, though I doubted in a far-off way that “well” was how he was doing. He was not an actual, potentially suffering person, not a boy I’d once known who had his own hopes and dreams, but a symbol of my own period of liberation and self-destruction. He was part of a story I got to tell, but not the story itself.

paragraph1: Why in fact should one tell the truth? What obliges us to do it? And why do we consider telling the truth to be a virtue? Imagine that you meet a madman, who claims that he is a fish and that we are all fish. Are you going to argue with him? Are you going to undress in front of him and show him that you don't have fins? Are you going to say to his face what you think?...If you told him the whole truth and nothing but the truth, only what you thought, you would enter into a serious conversation with a madman and you yourself would become mad. And it is the same way with the world that surrounds us. If I obstinately told the truth to its face, it would mean that I was taking it seriously. And to take seriously something so unserious means to lose all one's own seriousness. I have to lie, if I don't want to take madmen seriously and become a madman myself.
paragraph2: Truth-telling, often deemed a virtuous obligation, is scrutinized through a first-person narrative exploring its necessity and implications. Using a hypothetical scenario involving a madman who fervently believes everyone is a fish, the narrator delves into the conundrum of engaging with delusional beliefs. This analogy serves to question whether it is beneficial or even practical to attempt reasoning with an individual whose perspectives are untethered from reality. The narrator suggests that engaging earnestly with such absurdity not only proves futile but might also erode one's own seriousness, thereby destabilizing one's grasp on reality. They further ponder whether maintaining one's sanity might occasionally require embracing deception, or at least withholding the truth. By doing so, the narrator asserts that one avoids getting entangled in the web of irrationality that such interactions often entail. Consequently, the evaluation leads to the unsettling yet pragmatic conclusion that lying, though morally contentious, serves as a crucial mechanism for preserving one's mental stability in face of overwhelming absurdity.

paragraph1: As we sat sipping tea in Shiva’s flat, I found solace in the gentle clinking of cups, a stark contrast to the emotional weight of our conversation. Kamla, my elder sister, brought up a childhood memory that lingered heavily in the air—a time when Shiva, as a mischievous boy, nearly met his end choking on a plum. A doctor’s timely intervention turned a potential tragedy into a family anecdote, but now, more than anything, it served as a painful reminder of Shiva’s mortality. I couldn't help but feel a hollow emptiness since Shiva's death, a sentiment Kamla echoed with a shared grief. In those quiet moments, we silently acknowledged our connected loss. I realized that the two years following his death had been filled with a profound sorrow, each calendar day marked by its proximity to that heart-wrenching event, an indelible timestamp on our lives.
paragraph2: Afterward, at tea in Shiva’s flat, I talked to my elder sister Kamla. We talked about Shiva as a child; we remembered how, shortly after we had moved to our own house, he had once swallowed a plum and had begun seriously to choke. Fortunately, our house was next door to a doctor’s office, and he was in attendance that afternoon. He swiftly attended to the matter. It was a small crisis, but we could still, my sister and I, after all these years, celebrate the little boy’s escape from death, as though it were something final.I said to Kamla, expecting some solace from her, "And now we have nothing." She said, "And now we have nothing." My sorrow lasted for two years. For two years I mentally dated everything, even the purchase of a book, by its distance from Shiva's death.

paragraph1: So over the next five or six days, I told him whatever he wanted to know, and he'd lie there, all hooked up, a gentle smile breaking through. He'd ask me about the big things and the little things. About our guardians, about how we each had our own collection chests under our beds, the football, the rounders, the little path that took you all round the outside of the main house, round all its nooks and crannies, the duck pond, the food, the view from the Art Room over the fields on a foggy morning. Sometimes he'd make me say things over and over; things I'd told him only the day before, he'd ask about like I'd never told him. "Did you have a sports pavilion?" "Which guardian was your special favourite?" At first I thought this was just the drugs, but then I realised his mind was clear enough. What he wanted was not just to hear about Hailsham, but to remember Hailsham, just like it had been his own childhood. He knew he was close to completing and so that's what he was doinggetting me to describe things to him, so they'd really sink in, so that maybe during those sleepless nights, with the drugs and the pain and the exhaustion, the line would blur between what were my memories and what were his. That was when I first understood, really understood, just how lucky we'd been—Tommy, Ruth, me, all the rest of us.
paragraph2: I sat beside him in that sterile room, the rhythmic beeping of medical equipment our constant, uninvited companion, while he lay there, all hooked up, his body still but his mind alive with curiosity. Over several days, I shared fragments of our life at Hailsham, each memory serving as a beacon in the encroaching fog of finality he faced. His questions were unrelenting, probing deeper with each retelling about favorite places on the grounds, the guardians who had shaped us in those formative years, and the silly games we devised in the idle afternoons. His eyes, once lively, now dulled by the weight of his impending "completion," nevertheless sparked with an eagerness that urged me to repeat certain stories over and over, as if in recounting he could somehow make them his own, weaving them into the tapestry of his existence. It was as though by clutching to these borrowed memories, he might stave off the inevitable, keeping pieces of us alive within his fading self. Tommy and Ruth would occasionally filter into our reminiscences, brief apparitions of a shared youth now slipping further into the past. This ritual, this exchange of recollections, made me see our history in a new light—each moment at Hailsham was not merely a transient passage of time, but a precious trove of experiences that took on an almost sacred significance in his presence. To witness him imbuing each story with such profound importance compelled me to acknowledge, perhaps for the first time, the true fortune we had in having lived them.

paragraph1: As a child, I viewed my relationship with my mother as an incessant war of attrition, born from my selfish, childlike desire for her complete attention and unwavering submission to my whims, entirely oblivious to her own needs, desires, and ambitions. I wanted her world to revolve around me, not realizing that she was a person apart with dreams and struggles of her own. She was, in my youthful eyes, the general in our domestic skirmishes, somehow always holding the line against my tireless demands, and yet I failed to see the truth of her resilience. Her refusals and quiet resistance seemed threatening, but in truth, they were the boundaries she set to retain some semblance of self amidst the chaos of motherhood. Now, as an adult, I admire her not only for her strength but for her unfaltering commitment to carve out her own space. Her spirit, especially evident in her later, more challenging years, has become a source of inspiration, a testament to the delicate balance she achieved.
paragraph2: What do we want from our mothers when we are children? Complete submission. Oh, it's very nice and rational and respectable to say that a woman has every right to her life, to her ambitions, to her needs, and so on--it's what I've always demanded myself--but as a child, no, the truth is it's a war of attrition, rationality doesn't come into it, not one bit, all you want from your mother is that she once and for all admit that she is your mother and only your mother, and that her battle with the rest of life is over. She has to lay down arms and come to you. And if she doesn't do it, then it's really a war, and it was a war between my mother and me. Only as an adult did I come to truly admire her--especially in the last, painful years of her life--for all that she had done to claw some space in this world for herself.

paragraph1: In spring I suffer. The season doesn’t invigorate me, I find it depleting. The new light disorients, the fulminating nature overwhelms, and the air, dense with pollen, bothers my eyes. To calm my allergies I take a pill in the morning that makes me sleepy. It knocks me out, I can’t focus, and by lunchtime I’m tired enough to go to bed. I sweat all day and at night I’m freezing. No shoe seems right for this temperamental time of year.Every blow in my life took place in spring. Each lasting sting. That’s why I’m afflicted by the green of the trees, the first peaches in the market, the light flowing skirts that the women in my neighborhood start to wear. These remind me only of loss, of betrayal, of disappointment. I dislike waking up and feeling pushed inevitably forward. But today, Saturday, I don’t have to leave the house. I can wake up and not have to get up. There’s nothing better.
paragraph2: Spring is a challenging time for me, with its promise of renewal ironically sapping my energy. The influx of spring light and the explosion of nature’s blooms seem to conspire against my senses, overwhelming me rather than refreshing me. Pollen fills the air, and each day begins with the ritual of a morning allergy pill, which unfortunately leaves me drowsy and unfocused—a kind of fog that intensifies as afternoon approaches. Adding to my discomfort, the erratic temperatures play a cruel trick; while the day can be uncomfortably warm, the nights often plunge into a cold that leaves me shivering. This season also stirs within me a deep-seated unease, as it is tightly interwoven with personal memories of loss and heartache. Each budding tree, each vibrant fruit in the market, seems to whisper stories of betrayal and disappointment. Today, though, is a Saturday, providing rare refuge from these discomforts. With no obligations pressing upon me, the mere act of staying indoors offers a quiet solace, making it the best part of my day.

This season also stirs within me a deep-seated unease, as it is tightly interwoven with personal memories of loss and heartache. Each budding tree, each vibrant fruit in the market, seems to whisper stories of betrayal and disappointment. Today, though, is a Saturday, providing rare refuge from these discomforts. With no obligations pressing upon me, the mere act of staying indoors offers a quiet solace, making it the best part of my day.

paragraph1: On Christmas Day, Marcia will orchestrate a festive meal, meticulously preparing a succulent turkey, a selection of root vegetables simmered in fragrant herbs, and a tantalizing mince pie that fills the home with the warm, spiced aroma synonymous with the season. As the savory scents waft through the air, Noriega, confined to the solitude of a securely guarded room, will be tormented by unsettling dreams, shadows of his past mingling with fears of possible consequences from paths he's yet to take. Meanwhile, Eric will exhibit childlike excitement as he discovers a fragment of the Berlin Wall nestled in his Christmas stocking—an artifact steeped in history—only to misplace it amid the holiday whirlwind. Marcia, caught in the holiday's emotional undertow, will indulge in perhaps one too many cups of creamy eggnog, its warmth momentarily masking her mounting wave of nostalgia and introspection. Later, seeking solace, she will retreat to the bathroom, where she will embrace the family cat affectionately, retrieved reluctantly from its sanctuary beneath the bed. There, she will let her tears flow silently, her heart heavy with a profound sense of the relentless passage of time, the bittersweet dance of presence and absence of her children, and an overarching feeling of unpreparedness to face life's inevitable transformations. The season's innate focus on hope and renewal will only underscore her current struggle to find solace or focus in the ever-changing present—a poignant juxtaposition that leaves her deep in contemplation.
paragraph2: Then Christmas Day will come. It will be a Monday, yet another Monday, pastel blue, and they will eat a turkey and some more root vegetables and a mince pie that Marcia will have finally got around to making, while Noriega sleeps unmothered in a room in a house ringed with soldiers, dreaming of how he got there or of how he will get out, or dreaming of killing he has done or would like to do, or dreaming of nothing, his round face pocked and bleak as an asteroid. The piece of the Berlin Wall that Marcia has given Eric in his stocking will get lost under the chesterfield. The cat will hide.Marcia will get a little drunk on the eggnog, and later, after the dishes are done, she will cry silently to herself, shut into the bathroom and hugging in her festive arms the grumbling cat, which she will have dragged out from under a bed for this purpose. She will cry because the children are no longer children, or because she herself is not a child anymore, or because there are children who have never been children, or because she can’t have a child anymore, ever again. Her body has gone past too quickly for her; she has not made herself ready.It’s all this talk of babies, at Christmas. It’s all this hope. She gets distracted by it, and has trouble paying attention to the real news.

paragraph1: Five straight days she spent in front of the television, staring at crumbled banks and hospitals, whole blocks of stores in flames, severed rail lines and expressways. She never said a word. Sunk deep in the cushions of the sofa, her mouth clamped shut, she wouldn’t answer when Komura spoke to her. She wouldn’t shake her head or nod. Komura could not be sure that the sound of his voice was even getting through to her.Komura’s wife came from way up north in Yamagata, and, as far as he knew, she had no friends or relatives who could have been hurt in Kobe. Yet she stayed planted in front of the television from morning to night. When he got up, Komura would make his own toast and coffee, and head off to work. When he came home in the evening, he’d fix himself a snack with whatever he found in the refrigerator and eat it by himself. She’d still be glaring at the late news when he dropped off to sleep. In his presence, at least, she ate nothing and drank nothing and never went to the toilet. A stone wall of silence surrounded her. Komura gave up trying to break through.And when he came home from work on Sunday, the sixth day, his wife had disappeared.
paragraph2: In the hushed confines of their apartment, a strained tension clung to the air like an invisible fog, as Komura and his wife, a woman from Yamagata whose name goes unmentioned, navigated their widening emotional chasm. For five relentless days, she remained a ghostly figure, planted firmly in front of the television, her eyes glued to the relentless cycle of disaster news from Kobe—a place she had no personal ties to, yet seemed to consume her entirely. Each day, Komura endeavored to pierce the veil of her silence, his efforts colliding with what felt like an impenetrable stone wall, thick and cold. She seemed entrapped in a world of her own making, unresponsive to his gentle proddings, detached from hunger, and oblivious to his presence. Meals became solitary rituals for Komura, stark reminders of his isolation within their shared space, as he navigated the daily mundanities in a household that once resonated with the vibrancy of shared lives. The silent broadcasts seemed to speak a language only she understood, leaving Komura to grapple with a profound solitude, crescendoing in her sudden disappearance on the sixth day. His return to an empty home was a poignant punctuation to the chapter, leaving behind the flickering shadows of the television's glow and questions that lingered like echoes in the silence.

paragraph1: In the dim quiet of the cafe, surrounded by the gentle clinking of cups and low murmur of distant conversations, he sat across from her, feeling as though he were floating aimlessly in the vast, empty expanse of the universe. The words tumbled out of him, heavy and forlorn, as he tried to convey the depth of his sadness and the aching isolation that clung to him like a second skin. She listened, her brow slightly furrowed in puzzlement as she attempted to make sense of his abstract expressions. His feelings, complex and nebulous, seemed to elude her grasp, prompting her to offer a practical solution – "Would you like some coffee or tea?" Her well-meaning offer irked him, her pragmatic response colliding with the chaotic swirl of emotions inside him. Frustration simmered beneath his skin as he withdrew further into his thoughts, where a gnawing sense of incompleteness festered. He yearned for connection, a profound linkage that seemed perpetually out of reach. Within the confines of his mind, he envisioned the "Female Body" as a symbol of fertility and completeness, an embodiment of all he longed to capture and possess. It became an object of his fascination, its allure akin to a vessel that promised containment and control, yet always eluding his grasp, leaving him adrift, searching for solace in the void.
paragraph2: This is why men are so sad, why they feel so cut off, why they think of themselves as orphans cast adrift, footloose and stringless in the deep void.“What void?” she asks.“What are you talking about? The void of the Universe,” he says.And she says “Oh,” and looks out the window and tries to get a handle on it, but it’s no use, there’s too much going on, too many rustlings in the leaves, too many voices, so she says, "Would you like a cheese sandwich, a piece of cake, a cup of tea?"And he grinds his teeth because she doesn’t understand, and wanders off, not just alone but Alone, lost in the dark, lost in the skull, searching for the other half, the twin who could complete him.Then it comes to himhe’s lost the Female Body! Look, it shines in the gloom, far ahead, a vision of wholeness, ripeness, like a giant melon, like an apple, like a metaphor for breast in a bad sex novel; it shines like a balloon, like a foggy noon, a watery moon, shimmering in its egg of light.Catch it. Put it in a pumpkin, in a high tower, in a compound, in a chamber, in a house, in a room. Quick, stick a leash on it, a lock, a chain, some pain, settle it down, so it can never get away from you again.

paragraph1: Swimming has been a constant thread weaving through my life, tying together moments and memories across various landscapes and with different groups of people. In Portugal, I found myself submerged in the healing waters with my friends Mary and Sarah, all of us recovering from the grip of COVID, feeling the gentle reassurance of the ocean as it cradled our weary bodies. Solo swims offered solitude, a chance to retreat inward, while the times I swam with my husband Brian deepened our bond amid the rhythmic embrace of waves. Memories of plunging into cool waters with Rachel and Zayd flood back, their laughter echoing like a melody as we chased the sun's reflection. When swimming alongside my four children, I witness their pure joy at the discovery of the sea's endless wonders, each splash a reminder of innocence. In Greece, alongside fellow writing workshop participants, I found inspiration as we surrendered to the pull of the tide, metaphors swirling around us. Finally, with family friends Roda and Tor and their children in Oslo, Norway, I relished in the laughter and camaraderie that buoyed us nearly as much as the water itself. For me, diving in has always been more than just a physical act; it's a metaphor for releasing fears and embracing the endless new experiences that life offers.
paragraph2: In Portugal, I swam with Mary and Sarah while the three of us were recovering from the COVID we gave each other. In Greece, I swam alone and with my husband Brian and with our friends Rachel and Zayd and with all four of our collective kids and off the side of a boat with a good number of the sixty people who were taking our writing workshop. In Norway, I swam with my family and our friends Roda and Tor and their kids in the middle of Oslo.I floated. I paddled and kicked. I waded and wavered and eventually dove in. And I remembered how I used to love to do those things. I realized that I still do.It made me think about what mustering up the energy to dive in gives us, in a larger sense—both in the water and out of it. It rattles the bones. It makes us shiver and squeal. It wakes us up and gives us the chance to feel the kind of liberation one feels when you plunge ahead and dive in, which is another way of saying let go.

Paragraph 1:

Finally, with family friends Roda and Tor and their children in Oslo, Norway, I relished in the laughter and camaraderie that buoyed us nearly as much as the water itself. For me, diving in has always been more than just a physical act; it's a metaphor for releasing fears and embracing the endless new experiences that life offers.

paragraph1: Hello, sweet pea. It's only human to crave recognition and value, isn't it? We all know the pang of envy when others bask in good fortune. It’s natural, yet it can become consuming if left unchecked. So, rather than letting these emotions tighten their grip on your heart, redirect them towards self-improvement and personal growth. Remember, true fulfillment arises from inner work, not external validation. Stay focused on becoming the best version of yourself.
paragraph2: We are all savages inside. We all want to be the chosen, the beloved, the esteemed. There isn’t a person reading this who hasn’t at one point or another had that why not me? voice pop into the interior mix when something good has happened to someone else. But that doesn’t mean you should allow it to rule your life, sweet pea. It means you have work to do.

Paragraph 1:
Hello, sweet pea. It's only human to crave recognition and value, isn't it? We all know the pang of envy when others bask in good fortune. It’s natural, yet it can become consuming if left unchecked. So, rather than letting these emotions tighten their grip on your heart, redirect them towards self-improvement and personal growth. Remember, true fulfillment arises from inner work, not external validation. Stay focused on becoming the best version of yourself.

Paragraph 2:
We are all savages inside. We all want to be the chosen, the beloved, the esteemed. There isn’t a person reading this who hasn’t at one point or another had that why not me? voice pop into the interior mix when something good has happened to someone else. But that doesn’t mean you should allow it to rule your life, sweet pea. It means you have work to do.

paragraph1: Verna stood on the precipice of her journey, contemplating her true intentions for this Arctic retreat. What started as a genuine desire for self-reflection and renewal seemed on the verge of unraveling into something unintended. Her initial plan was pure—a stark contrast to any nefarious undertakings. She sought solace in the vast, undisturbed expanse of the Arctic, away from the cacophony of urban life and the persistent presence of men, from whom she wanted a temporary reprieve. This journey was not about flirtations or entanglements, as she was long past the need for monetary gain from such encounters. Her financial position had evolved to a point where wealth was no longer a pursuit but instead a comforting shield, keeping her sheltered from life's potential hazards. Her desires remained modest: to be surrounded by enough wealth to feel safe and distant from harm. Yet, as she embarked on this journey, Verna silently questioned if her quest for peace might have other chapters yet unwritten.
paragraph2: At the outset Verna had not intended to kill anyone. What she had in mind was a vacation, pure and simple. Take a breather, do some inner accounting, shed worn skin. The Arctic suits herthere’s something inherently calming in the vast cool sweeps of ice and rock and sea and sky, undisturbed by cities and highways and trees and the other distractions that clutter up the landscape to the south.Among the clutter she includes other people, and by other people she means men. She’s had enough of men for a while. She’s made an inner memo to renounce flirtations and any consequences that might result from them. She doesn’t need the cash, not anymore. She’s not extravagant or greedy, she tells herselfall she ever wanted was to be protected by layer upon layer of kind, soft, insulating money, so that nobody and nothing could get close enough to harm her. Surely she has at last achieved this modest goal.

paragraph1: A seagull lies dying on the shore. Alone. Its beak is resting on the pebbles. Its eyes are sad and sick. The waves beat against the nearby rocks. The wind ruffles feathers that look dead already. Then the seagull's eyes begin to follow me. It's early in the morning; the wind is cool. Above, life goes on; in the sky are other seagulls. The dying seagull is a baby.Seeing me, the seagull suddenly tries to get up. The legs under its body quiver hopelessly. Its chest pushes forward, but it can't raise its beak from the pebbles. As it struggles, a meaning forms in its eyes. Just then, it falls back onto the pebbles, spreading out now into an attitude of death. The meaning in its eyes is lost among the clouds and the waves. There's no doubt now. The seagull is dying.
paragraph2: As I walked along the shore, I stumbled upon a young seagull that lay nearly lifeless among the scattered pebbles, its beak resting as if gently placed there by some compassionate hand. Its eyes, mirrors of profound sorrow and illness, reflected a world it seemed to increasingly detach from. Upon noticing my approach, it mustered a feeble attempt to stand, limbs quivering with an earnestness that was both heartbreaking and admirable. This struggle seemed to awaken something within the seagull—a fleeting glow of purpose or understanding—but reality quickly consumed it, and it collapsed again, defeated, its beak heavy, unable to rise. The ephemeral spark in its eyes snuffed out, leaving a vacant gaze, a poignant testament to its nearing end. Above it, indifferent to this solitary struggle, the vibrant life of the skies continued, only deepening the somber hue of the moment I witnessed on the shore.

paragraph1: In a didactic tone, Ka elucidates his perspective on the dual nature of men when it comes to love. He categorizes the first type as those who fall for a woman based on a deep understanding of her habits and personal history. These men are drawn to the nuances of her life, which then fuels their affection. In contrast, Ka allies himself with the second type, who are enamored by the mere essence of a woman, despite knowing little about her intricacies. The narrative primarily operates in the third person, centering on Ka's insightful categorization.
paragraph2: There are two kind of men,' said Ka, in a didatic voice. 'The first kind does not fall in love until he's seen how the girls eats a sandwich, how she combs her hair, what sort of nonsense she cares about, why she's angry at her father, and what sort of stories people tell about her. The second type of man -- and I am in this category -- can fall in love with a woman only if he knows next to nothing about her.

'The first kind does not fall in love until he's seen how the girls eats a sandwich, how she combs her hair, what sort of nonsense she cares about, why she's angry at her father, and what sort of stories people tell about her. paragraph1: But today for the first time she was certain that even in Paul’s presence she would find the courage to say what she wanted, what she really wanted, in the depth of her soul; she was certain that she would find this courage even at the price of ruining everything between them. Next to her, she heard the sound of loud breathing. Paul had really fallen asleep. As if she were putting the same reel of film back in the projector, she ran through the whole scene once againshe is speaking to the visitor, Paul is watching them with astonishment, and the guest is saying, “In your next life, do you want to stay together or never meet again?" (It is strangeeven though he has all the necessary information about them, terrestrial psychology is incomprehensible to him, the concept of love unfamiliar, so he cannot guess what a difficult situation he would create by his sincere, practical, and well-intended question.)Agnes gathers all her inner strength and answers in a firm voice, “We prefer never to meet again.”These words are like the click of a door shutting on the illusion of love.
paragraph2: As the first light of dawn crept through the curtains, Agnes lay awake, her heart a tumultuous sea of anticipation and self-doubt. Paul slumbered soundly beside her, blissfully unaware of the internal dialogue she was conducting beneath the soft rustle of the sheets. Her mind conjured an ethereal visitor, a being devoid of earthly sentiments, who asked a question that resonated deeply within her soul: if given the choice, would she and Paul choose to remain together or never cross paths in another life? This question, though simple on the surface, churned up emotions she had long kept buried under layers of perfunctory smiles and unspoken yearnings. Agnes weighed her response carefully, recognizing the profound impact it would have not merely in her imagination but in reality. In a moment of clarity and courage, she imagined herself telling the visitor that she would prefer never to meet Paul again. This decision felt like releasing the grip of a book she had been clutching closed, allowing its pages to drift away as she relinquished the illusion of their love. With a steady heart, she embraced the inevitability of change, ready to confront the authenticity of her desires.

paragraph1: Michael Beard’s childhood was marked by a solitary existence, with no siblings to teach him the nuances of brotherly camaraderie. Growing up in a household where his mother's affection manifested through food, he was doted upon by Angela, a woman whose striking appearance and eagerness to care were evident in the ample meals she prepared. From infancy, Michael was celebrated, first as the plump infant who won a local contest, a charm indicative of his future accomplishments, like that prestigious Nobel Prize. Angela nurtured his intellect, foreseeing his academic triumphs such as earning a scholarship to Oxford. Despite her declining health, she embarked on an intricate culinary journey, acquiring advanced cooking techniques to delight him during his homecomings. Her culinary prowess became a symbolic gesture, reflecting her desire for a bond built on admiration and pride. In stark contrast, his father, Henry, preferred comfort in simplicity, satisfied with traditional culinary staples, and shied away from the incompatibly exotic flavors embraced by Angela. The emotional chasm between Angela and Henry defined their marriage early on, leaving Angela to channel her enthusiasm into Michael, crafting him into a man forever in pursuit of affection reminiscent of hers. This dynamic etched itself into Michael, carving a path seeking relationships with women who mirrored Angela's allure and culinary talents, whether deliberately so or subconsciously as an echo of maternal affection from his formative years. Angela's dedication, laced with an undying hope for her son’s brilliance, underscored her life’s work, shaping the very essence of who Michael became—not merely in his monumental achievements but in the intimate choices of companionship that bore testament to her indelible influence. Through love expressed in flavors and familial expectation, Michael's upbringing was a mosaic of aspiration, unconditional affection, and the enduring quest for achievement that echoed the nurturing confines of his childhood home.
paragraph2: It surprised no one to learn that Michael Beard had been an only child, and he would have been the first to concede that he’d never quite got the hang of brotherly feeling. His mother, Angela, was an angular beauty who doted on him, and the medium of her love was food. She bottle-fed him with passion, surplus to demand. Some four decades before he won the Nobel Prize in Physics, he came top in the Cold Norton and District Baby Competition, birth-to-six-months class. In those harsh postwar years, ideals of infant beauty resided chiefly in fat, in Churchillian multiple chins, in dreams of an end to rationing and of the reign of plenty to come. Babies were exhibited and judged like prize marrows, and, in 1947, the five-month-old Michael, bloated and jolly, swept all before him. However, it was unusual at a village fête for a middle-class woman, a stockbroker’s wife, to abandon the cake-and-chutney stall and enter her child for such a gaudy event. She must have known that he was bound to win, just as she later claimed always to have known that he would get a scholarship to Oxford. Once he was on solids, and for the rest of her life, she cooked for him with the same commitment with which she had held the bottle, sending herself in the mid-sixties, despite her illness, on a Cordon Bleu cookery course so that she could try new meals during his occasional visits home. Her husband, Henry, was a meat-and-two-veg man, who despised garlic and the smell of olive oil. Early in the marriage, for reasons that remained private, Angela withdrew her love from him. She lived for her son, and her legacy was cleara fat man who restlessly craved the attentions of beautiful women who could cook.

paragraph1: Early in the morning, as the first hints of dawn gently painted the sky, the phone rang, its persistent voice piercing the stillness of the room. I answered it to hear the nurse’s calm yet solemn words informing me that my mother had passed away shortly after breakfast, in the care facility where she had spent her last days. The trip to the hospital in Pontoise felt surreal, like moving through a dense fog, each moment tinged with a profound sense of loss. Upon arrival, I was guided to the quiet room where her body rested. The room was heavy with the echo of silence, and there she lay, with gauze softly wrapped around her head, a sheet drawn up to her shoulders as if she were merely asleep. It was a poignant image, both haunting and peaceful. I found myself wanting to give her the dignity she deserved by dressing her in the nightdress she had carefully chosen for this inevitable farewell. Her bedside drawer had a small crucifix that needed to be placed on her chest, a testament of her faith. The nurse, a gentle presence, suggested I visit the administration office. I realized this was a step towards bringing closure and understanding of her last belongings, those few personal items she had kept with her till the end. The inventory echoed a simplicity that marked her life, a reminder of what truly remained after a lifetime, underscoring the notion that, in the end, our attachments are ephemeral.
paragraph2: Mother died on Monday 7 April in the old people’s home attached to the hospital at Pontoise, where I had installed her two years previously. The nurse said over the phone“Your mother passed away this morning, after breakfast.” It was around ten o’clock.For the first time the door of her room was closed. The body had already been washed and a strip of gauze had been wrapped around her head and under her chin, pushing all the skin up around her eyes and mouth. A sheet covered her body up to her shoulders, hiding her hands. She looked like a small mummy. The cot sides had been taken down and left on either side of the bed. I wanted to slip her into the white nightdress with a crochet border that she had once bought for her own funeral. The nurse told me one of the staff would see to this and would also take the crucifix my mother kept in her bedside drawer and place it on her chest. The two screws that pinned the copper arms on to the cross were missing. The nurse wasn’t sure they could be replaced. It didn’t matter, I wanted her to have her crucix all the same. On the trolley stood the bunch of forsythia I had brought the day before. The nurse suggested I go straight to the administration office while they drew up an inventory of my mother’s personal belongings. She had very few things of her own left – a suit, a pair of blue summer shoes, an electric shaver.

paragraph1: Florence found herself in a complex emotional maze, struggling with a profound discomfort surrounding sexual intimacy, particularly when it involved Edward, the man she deeply loved. Despite her affection for him, the thought of physical intimacy invoked a visceral reaction of squeamishness and revulsion within her. However, this aversion was paradoxically accompanied by a genuine fondness for children. Florence often daydreamed about the possibility of one day embracing motherhood, envisioning herself nurturing a child with warmth and affection. Yet, she harbored a secret wish that this dream could be realized magically, circumventing the act she so detested. Her reflections led her to ponder whether her unease stemmed from more than just physical disgust—perhaps it was rooted in a deeper, more pervasive issue that fundamentally disrupted her inner peace and happiness. She felt as though every fiber of her being recoiled at the thought of sexual engagement, as if it were an impending threat to her serenity and composure. To her, intimacy with Edward was not an anticipated joy but a burdensome necessity she felt compelled to endure, merely to preserve other facets of happiness in their relationship. This inner conflict left Florence trapped in a paradox where love and revulsion coexisted uncomfortably, threatening her chance at true contentment.
paragraph2: In optimistic moments, she tried to convince herself that she suffered from no more than a heightened form of squeamishness that was bound to pass. Certainly, the thought of Edward’s testicles, pendulous below his “engorged penis”—another horrifying term—had the potency to make her upper lip curl, and the idea of herself being touched “down there” by someone else, even someone she loved, was as repulsive as, say, a surgical procedure on her eye. But her squeamishness did not extend to babies. She liked them; she had looked after her cousin’s little boys on occasion and enjoyed herself. She thought that she would love being pregnant by Edward, and in the abstract, at least, she had no fears about childbirth. If only she could, like the mother of Jesus, arrive at that swollen state by magic.Florence suspected that there was something profoundly wrong with her, that she had always been different, and that at last she was about to be exposed. Her problem, she thought, was greater, deeper, than straightforward physical disgusther whole being was in revolt against the prospect of entanglement and flesh; her composure and essential happiness were about to be violated. She simply did not want to be “entered” or “penetrated.” Sex with Edward could not be the summation of her joy but the price she must pay for it.

paragraph1: The idea of living in my imagination in that classical Roman world was attractive to me. A beautiful, clear, dangerous world, far removed from the setting in which I had found myself; the story, more a mood than a story, so different from the book on which I was working. A taxing bookit had been occupying me for eight or nine months, and I still hadn’t completed a draft. At the center of the book I was writing was a story set in an African country, once a colony, with white and Asian settlers, and now independent. It was the story of a daylong journey made in a car by two white people at a time of tribal war—war suddenly coming, suddenly overwhelming colonial order and simplicity. Africa had given both those white people a chance, made them bigger, brought out their potential; now, when they were no longer so young, it was consuming them. It was a violent book—violent not in its incidents but in its emotions.It was a book about fear. All the jokes were silenced by this fear. And the mist that hung over the valley where I was writing, the darkness that came early, the absence of knowledge of where I was—all this uncertainty emanating from the valley I transferred to my Africa.
paragraph2: As I sit hunched over my desk, grappling with the weight of words yet unwritten, I often find myself escaping into daydreams of living in a classical Roman world. The elegance and structure of such an ancient civilization feel freeing compared to the sprawling, tangled narrative I'm wrestling into shape. For the past eight or nine months, I've been consumed by the complexities of my current book, yet a complete draft still eludes me. The story is set in an independent African country, newly liberated from colonial rule, where two white characters embark on a tense car journey amidst the backdrop of an erupting tribal war. It’s a narrative thick with themes of fear and the disintegration of a once-imposed order. Although there is no overt violence, the intense emotions speak louder than any battlefield could. My immediate environment—shrouded in mist and swallowed by darkness—seeps into the fabric of my writing, clouding each scene with an atmosphere of uncertainty that mirrors my own existential musings. This uncertainty stretches its roots into my story's African landscape, creating a fictional reality where every moment is fraught with tension. Despite the grueling process, there’s a peculiar comfort in juxtaposing my chaotic experience with a distant world of imagined Roman tranquility.

paragraph1: As I sat on the floor with Bobbi, our legs crossed and a bottle of wine nestled between us, the conversation took a complicated turn. We were sharing a cracked plastic cup—an emblem of our enduring, if slightly chaotic, friendship—and talking about someone who seemed to be deeply entangled in Melissa's life. I was convinced that this individual was still in love with Melissa, and their current relationship appeared to be a ploy to provoke jealousy. Bobbi, in her typical fashion, challenged my perspective. "You know," she said, tilting the cup to her lips and offering me a wry smile, "it's possible to love more than one person. It's not so different from having multiple friends." Her words floated through the dimly lit room, filled with an aura of consideration, yet I remained unconvinced. To me, love was an emotion that demanded exclusivity, a unique connection that could not be scattered among many like seeds in the wind. As we leaned closer, our shoulders nearly touching in the closeness of the space, I pondered Bobbi's viewpoint. While I could see the logic—after all, the heart has its own enigmatic journey—I still couldn't fully embrace it. I preferred to think of love as something fiercely singular, like the connection between two stars burning brightly in an expansive sky.
paragraph2: I'm pretty sure he’s still in love with Melissa, I said.People can be in love and have affairs. It would depress me to sleep with someone who loved someone else. Bobbi sat up then, I could hear her. She swung her legs down off the bed, and I knew she was looking down at me, onto my scalp. I get the sense you’ve given this some consideration, she said. Did he make a pass at you or something? Not as such. I just don’t think I would enjoy being someone's second choice. Not as such? I mean, he’s probably just trying to make her jealous, I said. She slipped down off the bed, holding the wine bottle, which she passed to me. We were sitting on the floor together then, our upper arms pressed together. I splashed a little wine into the cracked plastic cup. You can love more than one person, she said. That’s arguable. Why is it any different from having more than one friend? You’re friends with me and you also have other friends, does that mean you don't really value me? I don't have other friends, I said. She shrugged and took back the bottle of wine. I turned the cup around so nothing would spill from the crack and swallowed two warm mouthfuls.

As I sat on the floor with Bobbi, our legs crossed and a bottle of wine nestled between us, the conversation took a complicated turn. We were sharing a cracked plastic cup—an emblem of our enduring, if slightly chaotic, friendship—and talking about someone who seemed to be deeply entangled in Melissa's life. I was convinced that this individual was still in love with Melissa, and their current relationship appeared to be a ploy to provoke jealousy. Bobbi, in her typical fashion, challenged my perspective. "You know," she said, tilting the cup to her lips and offering me a wry smile, "it's possible to love more than one person. It's not so different from having multiple friends." Her words floated through the dimly lit room, filled with an aura of consideration, yet I remained unconvinced. To me, love was an emotion that demanded exclusivity, a unique connection that could not be scattered among many like seeds in the wind. As we leaned closer, our shoulders nearly touching in the closeness of the space, I pondered Bobbi's viewpoint. While I could see the logic—after all, the heart has its own enigmatic journey—I still couldn't fully embrace it. I preferred to think of love as something fiercely singular, like the connection between two stars burning brightly in an expansive sky.

Paragraph 2:
I'm pretty sure he’s still in love with Melissa, I said.People can be in love and have affairs. It would depress me to sleep with someone who loved someone else. Bobbi sat up then, I could hear her. She swung her legs down off the bed, and I knew she was looking down at me, onto my scalp. I get the sense you’ve given this some consideration, she said. Did he make a pass at you or something? Not as such. I just don’t think I would enjoy being someone's second choice. Not as such? I mean, he’s probably just trying to make her jealous, I said. She slipped down off the bed, holding the wine bottle, which she passed to me. We were sitting on the floor together then, our upper arms pressed together. I splashed a little wine into the cracked plastic cup. You can love more than one person, she said. That’s arguable. Why is it any different from having more than one friend? You’re friends with me and you also have other friends, does that mean you don't really value me? I don't have other friends, I said. She shrugged and took back the bottle of wine. I turned the cup around so nothing would spill from the crack and swallowed two warm mouthfuls.

paragraph1: As I sit in the car, the engine humming beneath me, the road blurring past in a dizzying array of colors, my mind is a tumultuous mix of emotions and memories. On one end, there's Joe; captivating and unpredictable, a whirlwind of rebellion and spontaneity that threatens to consume me whole. The electricity of his presence is unmistakable, a stark contrast to the safety and predictability I once cherished in my now broken marriage to Paul. Paul was my rock, my anchor after my mother's death, carrying me through some of the darkest times of my life. His unwavering support was a balm then, comforting but ultimately unable to quench the restlessness growing within me. In Joe's company, I'm not just fascinated by the magnetic pull of his free-spirited life but also enticed by the unrestrained version of myself he coaxes into being—a woman unafraid of roads less traveled, one eager for adventure's intoxicating embrace even as it teeters on self-destruction. Driving to meet Joe, I wonder if it is really him I am drawn to or the reflection of myself I see in his eyes—a self that craves the wildness, a tempest raging against the confines of a life once neatly assembled and now irrevocably changed.
paragraph2: It wasn’t because I was in love with him. We’d only spoken a few times in the six months since he’d visited me in Minneapolis and gotten me pregnant. It had been Paul I’d grieved in the previous months, despite the fact that it was me who’d shattered our marriage to bits. Paul who occupied the center of my broken heart. Paul who’d been my lover and companion, my best friend and anchor in the years after my mother died, when my life had become unmoored. But I was compelled by Joe, powerfully drawn to his bad boy ways, sparked if not to life, then to flame. What I felt for him was weightless and by virtue of its weightlessness it seemed when I was with him that everything else in my life weighed less too. As if the sincere, earnest, sentimental life I’d made with Paul was nothing but a funny dream. I knew, as I drove to see Joe that day, that it wasn’t so much him that I longed to visit, but rather the version of myself that he brought out in me—the one who was outlandish and bold, the wild, self-destructive woman who would do anything.

paragraph1: The land come nearer, and one morning through the rain you see it, more white than green, no colours there. The ship stop suddenly and it is very quiet, and there in the water below is a boat and some men in oilskins. You see them move but you can’t hear them. And after all the days at sea everything in and around that little boat is very bright, as though a black-and-white picture suddenly turn Technicolor. The rocking water is deep and green, the oilskins very yellow, the faces of the people very pink.The mystery land is theirs, the stranger is you. None of those houses in the rain there belong to you. You can’t see yourself walking down those streets set down so flat on that cliff. But that is where you have to go, and as soon as everybody get down in the launch with their luggage the ship hoot. It is white and big and safe, it is saying goodbye, it is in a hurry to get away and to leave you behind. The Technicolor is over, the picture change. Now is only noise and rush and luggage, train and traffic. This is it, and already you are like a man in blinkers.
paragraph2: As you step off the ship onto the creaking, weather-beaten dock, a sense of both wonder and trepidation envelops you. Before you lies a landscape shrouded in mystique, with rolling hills and jagged cliffs painted in shades of deep gray and faded black, as though an artist had drained the world of its colors. Yet, in stark contrast, the people around you bustle with vibrancy—men in bright yellow oilskins maneuvering their small boat through choppy waters, their rain-slickers gleaming like beacons amidst the drab surroundings. Objects of striking reds, blues, and greens flash before your eyes, blurring with the kaleidoscope of colors carried by fellow travelers as they disembark. The once harmonious scene rapidly transforms into a cacophony of sounds and sights, each more overwhelming than the last, with shouted instructions, the clatter of luggage, and the clamor of footsteps against the wooden planks resonating through the air. You pause, breathing in the unfamiliar scents carried by the brisk sea breeze, feeling not unlike a leaf caught in the tide. The ship, now a shrinking silhouette behind you, represents the familiarity you have left behind, its comforts fading into memory as you confront the daunting prospect of navigating this new world alone.

paragraph1: He puts his glass down. You asked me to come in, he says. You asked if we could watch the fireworks together, remember? And then you asked me to walk home with you, and then you asked me inside. And I’m the one who’s inserting myself into your life, am I? I never wanted anything from you.She seems to consider this, looking grave. Finally she says, I thought you liked me.What does that mean? If I liked you that means something bad about me? As if she has not heard him, she replies, I liked you.He now feels utterly confused as to why they seem to be arguing, confused to the point of abrupt despair. Right, he says. Look, I’m going to go.By all means.He experiences this parting with her—this parting he himself announced spontaneously and called into existence—as an excruciating ordeal, almost a physical pain. He can’t quite believe he’s going through with it, actually standing upright from the sofa and turning away toward the door they entered through. Why is everything so strange now? At what point did his relations with Pauline begin to violate the ordinary rules of social contact? It started normally enough. Or did it? He still doesn’t even know if she’s his brother’s girlfriend.
paragraph2: As he stood before Pauline, confusion wrapped around him like a dense fog, clouding his thoughts and emotions. The evening had started with an air of lightness, with Pauline inviting him to watch fireworks, a gesture that seemed innocuous yet contradicted her past grievances of him imposing on her life. He replayed the sequence of events in his mind like scenes from a jumbled film, trying to understand how they had arrived at this bewildering crossroads. Her admission—that she thought he liked her—hung in the air, heavy with the weight of misinterpreted intentions and unrealized truths. His questioning gaze met hers, both searching for clarity yet finding only more uncertainty as each sought the true essence of the other's feelings. The gap between them widened, filled with unspoken words and mixed signals that neither knew how to unravel. Deciding to leave felt like tearing apart a piece of his own soul; each step away from her was agony, underscored by the still-fresh memory of what once seemed possible. When, he wondered, had their interactions grown so intricate and fraught with tension? Questions about her mysterious involvement with his brother flickered briefly in his mind, adding another layer of complexity to their already convoluted relationship, yet the answers eluded him just as she seemed to.

paragraph1: Jerome sat quietly between his sister, Zora, and his brother, Levi, savoring the warmth of a familiar silence as they shared a meal. The room was filled with the comforting clatter of cutlery against plates and the soft murmur of contented sighs. As he glanced from Zora to Levi, Jerome felt a profound connection that transcended words—a tapestry woven from shared memories and unspoken understanding. He recalled the nights of their childhood spent camping under makeshift tents crafted from old chairs and bed-sheets, the living room transforming into a magical world just for them. Observing their familiar gestures and expressions, he found pieces of himself mirrored in Levi's mischievous grin and Zora's thoughtful gaze. These shared traits were more than mere coincidences; they were a testament to their inseparable bond. In moments like these, Jerome realized that his siblings were essential threads in the fabric of his identity. The love he shared with them was a touchstone, grounding him in a profound truth that had always shaped his understanding of love and would continue to do so throughout his life.
paragraph2: People talk about the happy quiet that can exist between two loves, but this, too, was great; sitting between his sister and his brother, saying nothing, eating. Before the world existed, before it was populated, and before there were wars and jobs and colleges and movies and clothes and opinions and foreign travel -- before all of these things there had been only one person, Zora, and only one placea tent in the living room made from chairs and bed-sheets. After a few years, Levi arrived; space was made for him; it was as if he had always been. Looking at them both now, Jerome found himself in their finger joints and neat conch ears, in their long legs and wild curls. He heard himself in their partial lisps caused by puffy tongues vibrating against slightly noticeable buckteeth. He did not consider if or how or why he loved them. They were just lovethey were the first evidence he ever had of love, and they would be the last confirmation of love when everything else fell away.

paragraph1: I can’t complain. Unlike me, P, to whom I owe these pages, didn’t make it out of the story. She’ll never visit her children in other countries, or cry about distances or the passing of days, that merciless, automatic plot device which propels us forward and brings us to our knees. Her parties, however, have stayed with me, and the thought of them still quickens the heartthe secluded house packed with people, the sunlit lawn, those hours of sublime detachment. A setting I cherished, a promising start I tried to finish, to put into words, in which I’d been, briefly, a wayward husband, an inspired author, a happy man.
paragraph2: As I reflect on the memories of P, I find myself grappling with the stark contrast between my own survival and P's untimely departure from our shared narrative. P will never again have the chance to reconnect with distant family members or experience the changing seasons, a realization that anchors me in the present. Despite this permanence, P's lively parties remain incredibly vivid in my mind—those were days marked by a secluded house, a sunlit lawn, and an atmosphere brimming with joy. I cherished these gatherings, not just as moments of socialization but as intervals of profound creativity and happiness. I was a wayward husband then, yet also an author truly inspired by the vibrant energy P's gatherings always fostered.

paragraph1: On November 16, 1989, the fabric of my life unraveled with a simple phone call that forever altered my perception of stability and trust. Standing in the dim light of my Paris apartment, clinging to the receiver, I remember my fingers growing numb as a dispassionate female voice informed me that Mr. S, the Russian diplomat with whom I had shared intensely passionate, albeit clandestine, moments had abruptly returned to Moscow the day before. It was as if she'd struck a resonant chord in my soul, one that vibrated with a dissonance similar to when I was informed of my dear mother's death three and a half years earlier. This shared echo of grief and horror pulled me into a vortex of despair, magnified by the monumental shifts taking place globally. Only days had passed since the Berlin Wall, an insurmountable symbol of division, crumbled, heralding an era of change that saw Soviet regimes collapsing across Europe. My memories drifted inexorably back to my venture with a group of writers to Moscow, Tbilisi, and Leningrad the previous year—a journey where our eyes first met, where our fates entwined amidst the chaos of changing times. In France, our liaisons were brief yet suffused with breathtaking intimacy, each encounter layered with unspoken promises and woven with a thread of dependability that became central to my life's rhythm. Anticipation of Mr. S's next call had been the metronome of my existence. Now silenced, that beat was gone, leaving behind a haunting emptiness interlaced with memories of a world that once was.
paragraph2: On 16 Nov, 1989, I phoned the Soviet embassy in Paris and asked to speak to Mr S. The switchboard operator did not reply. After a long silence, a woman’s voice said‘You know, Mr S returned to Moscow yesterday.’ I immediately hung up. I felt as if I’d heard this sentence before, over the phone. The words were not the same but they had the same meaning, the same weight of horror, and were just as impossible to believe. Later, I remembered the announcement of my mother’s death, three and a half years earlier, how the nurse at the hospital had said‘Your mother passed away this morning after breakfast.’The Berlin Wall had fallen several days before. The Soviet regimes established in Europe were toppling one after the other. The man who had just returned to Moscow was a faithful servant of the USSR, a Russian diplomat posted in Paris.I had met him the previous year on a writers’ junket to Moscow, Tbilisi, and Leningrad, a voyage he had been assigned to accompany. We had spent the last night together, in Leningrad. After returning to France, we continued to see each other. The ritual was invariable. He would ring to ask if he could come around to see me in the afternoon or evening, or, more rarely, a day or two later. He would arrive and stay just a few hours, which we spent making love. Then he left, and I would live in wait for his next call.

paragraph1: Pampa Kampana's life was irreversibly altered on the harrowing day she witnessed her mother's cremation. The memory of that event stayed with her, ingrained in her mind and senses—a haunting presence she could never shake. The air was intended to be sweetened by sandalwood and a mix of exotic spices, artfully chosen to mask the odor of death. However, the aromatic veneer only magnified the grotesque smell of burning flesh, embedding itself deeply within her being. This olfactory memory became an unyielding specter, reminding her of the painful finality of loss. Consequently, Pampa was repelled by any semblance of that scent; it drove her to refrain entirely from consuming meat. The simple act of entering a kitchen where meat was prepared became an insurmountable obstacle, as the aroma inevitably transported her back to that funeral pyre. Thus, Pampa's entire existence became intertwined with this traumatic memory, shaping her future choices and inhibiting her from escaping its profound psychological grip.
paragraph2: For the rest of her life, Pampa Kampana, who shared a name with the river on whose banks all this happened, would carry the scent of her mother’s burning flesh in her nostrils. The pyre was made of perfumed sandalwood, and an abundance of cloves, garlic, cumin seeds, sticks of cinnamon, and other spices had been added to it as if the burning women were being prepared as a gourmet dish to set before the sultan’s victorious generals, but those fragrances—the turmeric, the big cardamoms, and the little cardamoms, too—failed to mask the unique, cannibal pungency of women being cooked alive, and made the odor, if anything, even harder to bear. Pampa Kampana never ate meat again, and could not bring herself to remain in any kitchen in which it was being prepared. All meat dishes exuded the memory of her mother, and when other people ate dead animals she had to avert her gaze.

Paragraph 1:
Pampa Kampana's life was irreversibly altered on the harrowing day she witnessed her mother's cremation. The memory of that event stayed with her, ingrained in her mind and senses—a haunting presence she could never shake. The air was intended to be sweetened by sandalwood and a mix of exotic spices, artfully chosen to mask the odor of death. However, the aromatic veneer only magnified the grotesque smell of burning flesh, embedding itself deeply within her being. This olfactory memory became an unyielding specter, reminding her of the painful finality of loss. Consequently, Pampa was repelled by any semblance of that scent; it drove her to refrain entirely from consuming meat. The simple act of entering a kitchen where meat was prepared became an insurmountable obstacle, as the aroma inevitably transported her back to that funeral pyre. Thus, Pampa's entire existence became intertwined with this traumatic memory, shaping her future choices and inhibiting her from escaping its profound psychological grip.

Paragraph 2:
For the rest of her life, Pampa Kampana, who shared a name with the river on whose banks all this happened, would carry the scent of her mother’s burning flesh in her nostrils. The pyre was made of perfumed sandalwood, and an abundance of cloves, garlic, cumin seeds, sticks of cinnamon, and other spices had been added to it as if the burning women were being prepared as a gourmet dish to set before the sultan’s victorious generals, but those fragrances—the turmeric, the big cardamoms, and the little cardamoms, too—failed to mask the unique, cannibal pungency of women being cooked alive, and made the odor, if anything, even harder to bear. Pampa Kampana never ate meat again, and could not bring herself to remain in any kitchen in which it was being prepared. All meat dishes exuded the memory of her mother, and when other people ate dead animals she had to avert her gaze.
