paragraph1: I am amazed sometimes to think how old I am. I can remember when the streets of the town I lived in were sprinkled with water to lay the dust in summer, and when girls wore waist cinchers and crinolines that could stand up by themselves, and when there was nothing much to be done about things like polio and leukemia. Some people who got polio got better, crippled or not, but people with leukemia went to bed, and, after some weeks’ or months’ decline in a tragic atmosphere, they died.It was because of such a case that I got my first job, in the summer holidays, when I was thirteen.Old Mrs. Crozier lived on the other side of town. Her stepson, Bruce, who was usually called Young Mr. Crozier, had come safely home from the war, where he had been a fighter pilot, had gone to college and studied history, and got married, and now he had leukemia. He and his wife were staying with Old Mrs. Crozier.
paragraph2: As I look back on the years I've traversed, it's intriguing to reflect on how much the world has transformed around me. In those bygone days, I remember streets being thoughtfully watered every summer to keep the dust at bay, while women gracefully adorned themselves with waist cinchers and crinolines, embodying a distinct sartorial elegance. Those times, however, were not without their shadows—ailments like polio and leukemia loomed large, casting a pall over many lives. My thoughts often drift to my first job at the tender age of thirteen, a milestone as much as a necessity born out of tragedy. This opportunity came about because of Young Mr. Crozier's misfortune—a former fighter pilot who survived the throes of war only to face leukemia after working towards becoming a historian. He moved with his wife to live with his stepmother, Old Mrs. Crozier, as his health waned. Even now, his courage amidst adversity remains etched in my memory, shaping not just my first job, but also my understanding of resilience.

paragraph1: Across the tracks was the electric train, empty, waiting. No other passengers showed up, and after a while the stationmaster stuck his head out the station window and called, "San."" At first I thought he was calling a man’s name, Sam. And another man wearing some kind of official outfit did come around the end of the building. He crossed the tracks and boarded the electric car. The woman with the parcels stood up and followed him, so I did the same. There was a burst of shouting from across the street, and the doors of a dark-shingled flat-roofed building opened, letting loose several men, who were jamming caps on their heads and banging lunch buckets against their thighs. By the noise they were making, you’d have thought the car was going to run away from them at any minute. But when they settled on board nothing happened. The car sat while they counted one another and worked out who was missing and told the driver that he couldn’t go yet. Then somebody remembered that the missing man hadn’t been around all day. The car started, though I couldn’t tell if the driver had been listening to any of this, or cared.
paragraph2: As I stood on the platform, my gaze fixed on the empty electric train across the tracks, a voice resonated through the station, cutting through the quiet ambiance with a sharp call: "San!" Strangely, it echoed in my ears as "Sam," sparking a moment of confusion as I scanned the area for an unfamiliar, summoned figure. Just then, a man clad in an official-looking uniform emerged from the shadows and boarded the waiting train. This seemingly normal event was soon followed by an unexpected parade, led by a resolute woman burdened with parcels. Intrigued and pulled by an undefined urge, I joined the impromptu procession. Suddenly, the tranquility was shattered; a chaotic scene unraveling as a bustling group of men burst forth from a nearby building, their frantic rush to board the train accompanied by a cacophony of shouting and counting. Realization dawned half-aloud among them that a missing member had eluded the day's chaos entirely, a curious absence registering in their minds too late to amend. As the train jerked into motion, the mystery lingered—whether the driver had been made impatient by the gregarious troupe’s delay, or was simply indifferent to their frenzied state, remained a tantalizing enigma as the platform retreated from view.

paragraph1: From the training session (it took place at one of the castles of central Bohemia) she sent me a letter that was one hundred percent Marketa, chock-full of earnest enthusiasm for everything around her. It was all so wonderfulthe early-morning calisthenics, the talks, the discussions, even the songs they sang; she praised the "healthy atmosphere" that reigned there and diligently added a few words to the effect that the revolution in the West would not be long in coming. Actually I quite agreed with what she said; I even believed in the imminence of a revolution in Western Europe; there was only one thing I could not accepther happy, buoyant mood in the face of my desire. So I bought a postcard and (to hurt, shock, and confuse her) wroteOptimism is the opium of the people! A healthy atmosphere stinks of stupidity! Long live Trotsky! Ludvik
paragraph2: I received a letter from Marketa today, brimming with her characteristic enthusiasm. She's currently at a training session set in a picturesque castle in central Bohemia, and her excitement practically leapt from the page. She described the diverse activities, deep discussions, and the spirited songs that filled her days, all contributing to what she referred to as a "healthy atmosphere." Her optimism was infectious, particularly as she spoke about the potential for a revolutionary shift in the West. While I agreed with her about the winds of change possibly blowing in our favor, her cheerful tone clashed sharply with my own conflicted feelings. In a somewhat vexed response, I penned a postcard to unsettle her buoyant spirit: "Optimism is the opium of the people! A healthy atmosphere stinks of stupidity! Long live Trotsky!" I signed it simply, but meaningfully, with my name—Ludvik—hoping to provoke her into reflection.

paragraph1: It was like another Sunday in the capital, which, in spite of the white exodus to South Africa and in spite of deportations, remained an English-Indian creation in the African wilderness. It owed nothing to African skill; it required none. Not far from the capital were bush villages, half-day excursions for tourists. But in the capital Africa showed only in the semi-tropical suburban gardens, in the tourist-shop displays of carvings and leather goods and souvenir drums and spears, and in the awkward liveried boys in the new tourist hotels, where the white or Israeli supervisors were never far away. Africa here was décor. Glamour for the white visitor and expatriate; glamour too for the African, the man flushed out from the bush, to whom, in the city, with independence, civilization appeared to have been granted complete. It was still a colonial city, with a colonial glamour. Everyone in it was far from home.
paragraph2: In the heart of an African nation, the capital city stirs to life on a typical Sunday, its character defined by English and Indian influences that linger from its colonial past. Despite a notable decline in the white population, driven by departures to South Africa or the ramifications of past deportations, the city still clings to its colonial legacy. The African essence here is subtle, woven into the fabric of suburban gardens and manifesting through the lens of commercial tourism, where vibrant local crafts and enticing souvenir items offer fleeting glimpses of the continent's rich artistry. In stark contrast to surrounding bush villages, the city presents a tantalizing allure of modernity. Both white visitors and Africans who have migrated from rural areas find themselves enticed by its urban charm. Yet, it is unmistakably apparent that the city's ostentatious colonial glamour leaves an indelible impression on its inhabitants, creating a sense of disconnect from their origins.

paragraph1: Driving through the familiar rural landscape where I spent my childhood, the summer afternoon felt like a serene pause before the many changes ahead. Sitting in the passenger seat, I glanced out at the scattered, isolated houses that had become as much a part of me as the memories shaped within them. Mom was driving leisurely down the winding roads, the fields stretching out endlessly on either side. The sun cast long shadows, immersing the day in a warm glow. It was August, marking my last summer at home after completing my first year of college. I hadn’t realized just yet that this would be the final chapter of my life in this area. As we drove, we spotted a yard sale sign outside the home of an elderly woman who lived there alone, a friendly figure in my memory. Mom's eyes lit up with curiosity and nostalgia, and at her gentle suggestion, we decided to stop and explore. We spent time sifting through trinkets and treasures, each item a relic of a life well-lived, while Mom exchanged stories with the woman. I relished this moment, unaware that it symbolized the closing of a significant chapter of my life, a quiet farewell to the landscape and the comfort of shared moments with Mom.
paragraph2: The summer I was 18 I was driving down a country road with my mother. This was in the rural county where I grew up and all of the roads were country, the houses spread out over miles, hardly any of them in sight of a neighbor. Driving meant going past an endless stream of trees and fields and wildflowers. On this particular afternoon, my mother and I came upon a yard sale at a big house where a very old woman lived alone, her husband dead, her kids grown and gone.“Let’s look and see what she has,” my mother said as we passed, so I turned the car around and pulled into the old woman’s driveway and the two of us got out.We were the only people there. Even the old woman whose sale it was didn’t come out of the house, only waving to us from a window. It was August, the last stretch of time that I would I live with my mother. I’d completed my first year of college by then and I’d returned home for the summer because I’d gotten a job in a nearby town. In a few weeks I’d go back to college and I’d never again live in the place I called home, though I didn’t know that then.

paragraph1: As I lie in bed, cocooned in a soft bubble of blankets, I read under the dim glow of a single lamp, trying to find that perfect balance between consciousness and slumber. The steady hum of cars rolling by on the road below my apartment is like a lullaby that wraps around me, becoming an essential element for my journey into sleep. The symphony of engines and faint tires against asphalt creates a comforting cadence that eases my mind into a tranquil state, making each passing vehicle seem like a gentle nudge towards dreams. Yet, there are times I wake to an unexpected silence, the unusual stillness in the air palpably unsettling. Without the familiar noise to guide me back to rest, my mind becomes a haven for restless and gloomy contemplations, each louder in the absence of traffic. It's only when the early morning returns with the renewed flow of cars that I feel a welcomed relief, allowing their quiet reassurance to lead me into the next day.
paragraph2: This evening as I read in bed I hear the roar of cars that speed down the road below my apartment. And the fact of their passing makes me aware of my own stillness. I can only fall asleep when I hear them. And when I wake up in the middle of the night, always at the same time, it’s the absolute silence that interrupts my sleep. That’s the hour when there’s not a single car on the road, when no one needs to get anywhere. My sleep grows lighter and lighter and then it abandons me entirely. I wait until someone, anyone, drives by. The thoughts that come to roost in my head in those moments are always the gloomiest, also the most precise. That silence, combined with the black sky, takes hold of me until the first light returns and dispels those thoughts, until I hear the presence of lives passing along the road below me.

paragraph1: There’s a pair of pants I wore almost every day for the first five years I knew my husband. They were what I like to call sport pants, which differ from all-out sweatpants (or yoga pants, as fancy people now like to call them) in that they were made of a sturdy cotton twill rather than jersey material. Cut comfortably loose, the elastic waistband was the only place where the pants made any contact with my body. Anything could happen inside those pants without detection. I could be fat or less fat or kind of slender. They were extraordinarily utilitarian and patently unsexy. Nuns might opt to wear them. Or park rangers. Or seventy-year-old piano teachers. Or butch lesbians who captained coed Ultimate Frisbee teams. Or me. I wore them so often my husband took to referring to them as my uniform.
paragraph2: In the first five years of knowing my husband, I practically lived in a pair of sport pants that, to me, epitomized comfort and utility. Made from sturdy cotton twill, they had a loose fit and an elastic waistband that accommodated every shift and change in my body shape with remarkable ease. Despite their reliability, they were utterly unremarkable in style, almost the antithesis of fashion. I often joked that such pants could be the chosen attire for nuns or park rangers, given their practicality that inevitably crossed over into the realm of unattractiveness. My husband, always quick with a witty remark, took to calling them my "uniform," a moniker that stuck, reflecting the frequency with which I wore them. Those pants were a constant presence in my life, embodying a seamless blend of comfort and function that I cherished in those early days with him.

I often joked that such pants could be the chosen attire for nuns or park rangers, given their practicality that inevitably crossed over into the realm of unattractiveness. My husband, always quick with a witty remark, took to calling them my "uniform," a moniker that stuck, reflecting the frequency with which I wore them. Those pants were a constant presence in my life, embodying a seamless blend of comfort and function that I cherished in those early days with him.

paragraph1: This evening as I read in bed I hear the roar of cars that speed down the road below my apartment. And the fact of their passing makes me aware of my own stillness. I can only fall asleep when I hear them. And when I wake up in the middle of the night, always at the same time, it’s the absolute silence that interrupts my sleep. That’s the hour when there’s not a single car on the road, when no one needs to get anywhere. My sleep grows lighter and lighter and then it abandons me entirely. I wait until someone, anyone, drives by. The thoughts that come to roost in my head in those moments are always the gloomiest, also the most precise. That silence, combined with the black sky, takes hold of me until the first light returns and dispels those thoughts, until I hear the presence of lives passing along the road below me.
paragraph2: As I lie in bed, cocooned in a soft bubble of blankets, I read under the dim glow of a single lamp, trying to find that perfect balance between consciousness and slumber. The steady hum of cars rolling by on the road below my apartment is like a lullaby that wraps around me, becoming an essential element for my journey into sleep. The symphony of engines and faint tires against asphalt creates a comforting cadence that eases my mind into a tranquil state, making each passing vehicle seem like a gentle nudge towards dreams. Yet, there are times I wake to an unexpected silence, the unusual stillness in the air palpably unsettling. Without the familiar noise to guide me back to rest, my mind becomes a haven for restless and gloomy contemplations, each louder in the absence of traffic. It's only when the early morning returns with the renewed flow of cars that I feel a welcomed relief, allowing their quiet reassurance to lead me into the next day.

paragraph1: They will all vanish at the same time, like the millions of images that lay behind the foreheads of the grandparents, dead for half a century, and of the parents, also dead. Images in which we appeared as a little girl in the midst of beings who died before we were born, just as in our own memories our small children are there next to our parents and schoolmates. And one day we’ll appear in our children’s memories, among their grandchildren and people not yet born. Like sexual desire, memory never stops. It pairs the dead with the living, real with imaginary beings, dreams with history.
paragraph2: In our reflections on memory, we recognize its inevitable fading, much like the images that once lived in the minds of our deceased grandparents and parents. Memories form a continuous tapestry, weaving together not only the past generations we've lost but also future descendants yet to be born. This intergenerational connection is expressed through the inclusive "we," emphasizing the intertwining of different times and individuals, whether living, deceased, or entirely imagined. Within this narrative, characters such as our parents, grandparents, children, and future grandchildren appear as figures connected through memory's persistent and unyielding force. Memory, similar to sexual desire, remains an unending, powerful presence in our lives.

paragraph1: In the wake of my mother’s death, I find myself engulfed in a storm of emotions that twist and turn within me, leaving a palpable void that no amount of distraction can fill. What unsettles me most is the inappropriate semblance of my longing; it feels like the yearning born from a place akin to sexual love, an inexplicable tie that knots my heart and refuses to loosen its grip. My mother was always my heroine, a woman of unyielding courage who dared to walk away from a toxic marriage with my father, shielding me with her resilience. With time, she found companionship with another—my stepfather—who, for a decade, seemed a worthy partner. Yet, it was all too fleeting; just as I’m left grappling with loss, he seems to embrace forgetfulness, allowing his new partner and her children to sweep into their home and erase all remnants of my mother. The ease with which he moves on feels like a betrayal, compounding my grief with layers of helplessness. Amidst the turmoil, one resolve emerges clear and unwavering: I will honor her memory, clutching her legacy close, unwilling to let time or new occupants erode the space she etched in my heart.
paragraph2: We aren’t supposed to want our mothers that way, with the pining intensity of sexual love, but I did, and if I couldn’t have her, I couldn’t have anything. Most of all I couldn’t have pleasure, not even for a moment. I was bereft, in agony, destroyed over her death. To experience sexual joy, it seemed, would have been to negate that reality. And more, it would have been to betray my mother, to be disloyal to the person she had been to memy hero, a single mother after she bravely left an unhealthy relationship with my father when I was five. She remarried when I was eleven. My stepfather had loved her and been a good husband to her for ten years, but shortly after she died, he’d fallen in love with someone else. His new girlfriend and her two daughters moved into my mother’s house, took her photos off the walls, erased her. I needed my stepfather to be the kind of man who would suffer for my mother, unable to go on, who would carry a torch. And if he wouldn’t do it, I would.

paragraph1: She gets up and quickly dresses and walks through every room in the house, introducing the walls and the furniture to this new idea. A cavity everywhere, most notably in her chest. She makes coffee and doesn’t drink it. She ends up in her bedroom once more, and finds that the introduction to the current reality has to be done all over again.But then there is a surprise. She is capable, still, of shaping up another possibility.If he doesn’t know that Sadie is dead he will just expect things to go on as usual. And how would he know, unless he is told? And who would he be told by, unless by Corrie herself?She could say something that would destroy them, but she does not have to.What a time it has taken her, to figure this out.And after all, if what they had—what they have—demands payment, she is the one who can afford to pay.When she goes down to the kitchen again she goes gingerly, making everything fit into its proper place.
paragraph2: Corrie moved through her morning with an unsettling sense of emptiness, a hollow ache settling in her chest as she mechanically dressed and wandered through the quiet rooms of her house. The familiar ritual of making coffee offered no comfort; she left the mug untouched, her hands unable to bridge the gap between her usual routine and the profound change she faced. Continuously, she attempted to reorient herself to the stark new reality that had descended upon her life, yet found herself adrift, grappling with the upheaval wrought by Sadie's sudden absence. Sadie's death loomed unspoken, an invisible barrier she wasn't ready to breach with him. In her solitude, Corrie realized the weight of the decision she held—the knowledge of Sadie's death was her secret to unveil. In those silent moments, she understood the magnitude of her choice, accepting the responsibility to shape their shared narrative and to shoulder the consequences of years entwined. Navigating back into the kitchen, Corrie moved with deliberate care, as if by careful action, she might impose a semblance of order onto her fractured world.

paragraph1: Under the cloak of secrecy, she orchestrated a delightful storm, whispering to the universe her mischievous intentions. Pen in hand, she elegantly crafted a note to Gerald, a tapestry of words spun with careful detachment and subtle hints. Her absence warranted an apology, yet the promise of something fashionable as a gift carried an air of expectation, a tantalizing lure into the depths of her plot. She meticulously arranged for Cheryl to open the mysterious gift, a Pandora’s box guaranteed to unfurl a whirlwind of emotions—distress mingling with curiosity, the air thick with the whispers of long-buried secrets. As the gears of her plan set in motion, she acknowledged the knot tightening in her stomach, a physical unrest juxtaposed with a newfound mental liberation. As the snow crunched underfoot, she was pulled into a reverie of her childhood, the crisp air freeing her from the shackles of guilt. Wrapped in anonymity, she found peace within the chaos she had so artfully designed.
paragraph2: She prints on the card, “Gerald, Sorry I couldn’t be with you. This is all the rage. Love, K.”When evening has fallen and the party must be in full swing, she calls a delivery taxi. Cheryl will not distrust anything that arrives in such an expensive bag. She will open it in public, in front of everyone. There will be distress, there will be questions. Secrets will be unearthed. There will be pain. After that, everything will go way too far.She is not well; her heart is pounding, space is wavering once more. But outside the window it’s snowing—the soft, damp, windless flakes of her childhood. She puts on her coat and goes out, foolishly. She intends to walk just to the corner, but when she reaches the corner she goes on. The snow melts against her face like small fingers touching. She has done an outrageous thing, but she doesn’t feel guilty. She feels light and peaceful and filled with charity, and temporarily without a name.

paragraph1: As I reflect on that moment when we were all desperately clinging to the tether of the balloon, I've come to understand the inner turmoil that defined our actions. The howling wind gusts seemed to whisper forgotten fears into our ears, urging each of us to fight for survival as individuals instead of as a unified group. It was as though we were little more than marionettes, our strings cut by the force of nature, leaving us flailing in the overwhelming breeze. In those split seconds, instinct overshadowed reason, and our collective grip faltered under the pressure of selfish desires. We broke ranks, and what could have been a testament to unity unraveled into a tapestry of misery and regret. That day, I witnessed the dual nature of humanity: the innate drive to protect oneself colliding with the profound understanding that our strength often lies in togetherness. Now, in hindsight, I'm grappling with the contradiction within us all, keenly aware of how easily self-preservation can shatter the fragile lattice of cooperation.
paragraph2: I didn't know, nor have I ever discovered, who let go first. I'm not prepared to accept that it was me. But everyone claims not to have been first. What is certain is that if we had not broken ranks, our collective weight would have brought the balloon to earth a quarter of the way down the slope a few seconds later as the gust subsided. But as I've said, there was no team, there was no plan, no agreement to be broken. No failure. So can we accept that it was right, every man for himself? Were we all happy afterwards that this was a reasonable course? We never had that comfort, for there was a deeper covenant, ancient and automatic, written in our nature. Co-operation - the basis of our earliest hunting successes, the force behind our evolving capacity for language, the glue of our social cohesion. Our misery in the aftermath was proof that we knew we had failed ourselves. But letting go was in our nature too. Selfishness is also written in our hearts.

paragraph1: Life in the bustling city of Toronto has a way of swirling around you, bustling and busy, yet one afternoon the tide swept an unexpected presence into my path. As I threaded my way through the throngs of people teeming along the street, an all-too-familiar face appeared before me—a man I hadn’t seen in over a decade. Our eyes locked, a brief flicker of recognition passing between us, as if no time had separated us. We exchanged rushed pleasantries, voices mingling with the cacophony of the city, each word tinged with a sense of nostalgia and unspoken understanding. I assured him of my happiness, though inwardly, I dwelt on the quiet tumult roiling beneath the surface—a recent disagreement with my husband over a pressing debt that seemed to loom large over our lives. It was one of those mundane, yet profound, domestic conflicts that can shake the foundations of one's contentment; frustrating in its persistence, like a dark cloud hovering just out of sight. Despite the lingering emotions stirred by our encounter, both he and I were swept away in the currents of the crowd, moving opposite ways, yet somehow anchored momentarily by shared history. As I walked on, I couldn’t shake off the feeling of déjà vu, as if our parting was a mirror to a time long gone—a poignant departure from a place called Amundsen that left echoes of disbelief in my heart. Just as love once whispered its stories to me there, this encounter seemed to weave itself into the narrative of disbelief yet continuity, reminding me of the tangled, tentative nature of human connections, which flutter by like leaves on the wind, leaving behind traces that persistently shape the contours of my emotions.
paragraph2: For years, I thought I might run into him. I lived, and still live, in Toronto. It seemed to me that everybody ended up in Toronto, at least for a little while.Then, more than a decade later, it finally happened. Crossing a crowded street where we could not even slow down. Going in opposite directions. Staring, at the same time, a bald shock on our time-damaged faces.He called out, “How are you?,” and I answered, “Fine.” Then added, for good measure, “Happy.”At the time, this was only generally true. I was having some kind of dragged-out row with my husband, about our paying a debt run up by one of his children. I had gone that afternoon to a show at the Art Gallery, to get myself into a more comfortable frame of mind.He called back to me once more. “Good for you,” he said.It still seemed as if we would make our way out of that crowd, as if in just a moment we would be together. But it was just as certain, also, that we would carry on in the directions we were going, and so we did.No breathless cry, no hand on my shoulder when I reached the sidewalk. Just the flash that I had caught when one of his eyes opened wider than the other. It was the left eye—always the left, as I remembered. And it always looked so strange, alert and wondering, as if some crazy impossibility had occurred to him that almost made him laugh.That was all. I went on home.Feeling the same as when I’d left Amundsen. The train dragging me, disbelieving. Nothing changes, apparently, about love.

I had gone that afternoon to a show at the Art Gallery, to get myself into a more comfortable frame of mind.He called back to me once more. “Good for you,” he said.It still seemed as if we would make our way out of that crowd, as if in just a moment we would be together. But it was just as certain, also, that we would carry on in the directions we were going, and so we did.No breathless cry, no hand on my shoulder when I reached the sidewalk. Just the flash that I had caught when one of his eyes opened wider than the other. It was the left eye—always the left, as I remembered. And it always looked so strange, alert and wondering, as if some crazy impossibility had occurred to him that almost made him laugh.That was all. I went on home.Feeling the same as when I’d left Amundsen. The train dragging me, disbelieving. Nothing changes, apparently, about love.

paragraph1: Writing two copies of a letter is pretty tiring. To write home and then to write to you about the same thing is a heavy task.That, however, is no excuse for my not writing you. It was sheer laziness. I thought the people at home had packed me up. For 3 weeks I got no word from them; in the meantime I had letters from people in France and Germany and several from friends here. The first communication I had was an official one—from the Colonial office.I think you will be glad to know that I am absolutely happy. The only thing I need to make me feel the happiest man on earth is a girl, but what can I do? Nobody could ever like me; and I am despairing of myself.
paragraph2: Lately, I've felt tangled in a web of correspondence, where writing even the simplest of letters has become an exhausting feat. I fool myself into thinking that drafting two similar letters—one for my family and one for a friend—is too daunting. Yet, in honesty, my failure to write is pure laziness. In the past three weeks, there's been an unsettling silence from my family, leaving me to rely solely on letters from friends in France, Germany, and nearby. The only echo of familial communication came through the cold, bureaucratic voice of the Colonial office. Strangely, amidst this silence, I'm generally quite happy, yet there's an aching incompleteness stemming from the absence of a romantic partner. This emptiness breeds doubt, casting shadows of despair as I wonder if anyone could truly like me.

paragraph1: In the quiet hum of the office, she sits in front of the glowing screen, diligently working on the text-editing interface that dominates her afternoon. Her tasks, though seemingly mundane, require a precision that keeps her focused; she meticulously adjusts punctuation, ensuring apostrophes and commas are perfectly placed to uphold the integrity of the text. Between these bouts of concentration, she indulges in quick, habitual checks of her social media feeds, finding an odd solace in the digital tapestry presented to her: a juxtaposition of a shocking news report about a distant natural disaster and a light-hearted joke from an acquaintance. Yet, her expression remains an enigma, unaffected and unwavering, her demeanor a steady constant amidst the varying emotions portrayed on her screen. Suddenly, with no clear catalyst, she minimizes the feed, returning her attention to the text awaiting her careful scrutiny. Her environment, though largely composed of solitary effort, is occasionally punctuated by interactions with her colleagues. She answers work-related queries with quiet authority or joins in the rare burst of office humor, her laughter adding a momentary ripple in her day of tranquility. Despite these brief deviations, her afternoon remains a testament to the quiet resolve of uninterrupted work.
paragraph2: For the rest of the afternoon in the office, the woman worked on the same text-editing interface, moving apostrophes and deleting commas. After closing one file and before opening another, she routinely checked her social-media feeds. Her expression, her posture, did not vary depending on the information she encountered therea news report about a horrific natural disaster, a photograph of someone’s beloved pet, a female journalist speaking out about death threats, a recondite joke requiring familiarity with several other previous Internet jokes in order to be even vaguely comprehensible, a passionate condemnation of white supremacy, or a promoted tweet advertising a health supplement for expectant mothers. Nothing changed in her outward relationship to the world that would allow an observer to determine what she felt about what she saw. Then, after some length of time, with no apparent trigger, she closed the browser window and reopened the text editor. Occasionally one of her colleagues would interject with a work-related question and she would answer, or someone would share a funny anecdote with the office and they would all laugh, but mostly the work continued quietly.

paragraph1: Prue struck a pose reminiscent of the iconic "Rosie the Riveter," exuding the empowerment and resolve symbolic of the 1940s, as she attempted to draw George into a nostalgic conversation about the war years. Her enthusiasm was palpable, but George, whose true name was not George, slipped into a silent reverie, the memories of his own harsh childhood during the forties bubbling to the surface. Unlike the industrious and spirited image Prue referenced, George's childhood was a tapestry of scavenging and begging, a grim contrast to the optimism surrounding the wartime workforce. He remembered, with a flicker of resentment, the youthful vandalism against a film star's image, a rebellious act fueled by frustration and the harshness of his upbringing. Yet, he chose to keep these memories tucked away, not sharing them with Prue. Instead, he leaned back into the comfort of a weathered deck chair, letting the Scotch warm his throat as he exhaled a plume of smoke into the cool air. With a smile, one that revealed his long canines, he met her gaze, masking the complexity of his emotions. Prue's nostalgic gesture stood in stark contrast to George's grim memories, a reminder of their different perspectives on a past shaped by vastly different experiences.
paragraph2: "It’s the forties look," she says to George, hand on her hip, doing a pirouette. "Rosie the Riveter. From the war. Remember her?" George, whose name is not really George, does not remember. He spent the forties rooting through garbage heaps and begging, and doing other things unsuitable for a child. He has a dim memory of some film star posed on a calendar tattering on a latrine wall. Maybe this is the one Prue means. He remembers for an instant his intense resentment of the bright, ignorant smile, the well-fed body. A couple of buddies had helped him take her apart with the rusty blade from a kitchen knife they’d found somewhere in the rubble. He does not consider telling any of this to Prue.George is sitting in a green-and-white striped canvas deck chair, reading the Financial Post and drinking Scotch. The ashtray beside him overflows with butts; many women have tried to cure him of smoking; many have failed. He looks up at Prue from behind his paper and smiles his foxy smile. This is a smile he does with the cigarette held right in the center of his mouthon either side of it his lips curl back, revealing teeth. He has long canines, miraculously still his.

paragraph1: “Sometimes I have this dream,” the young man in the wheelchair said. His voice had a strange echo to it, as if it were rising up from the bottom of a cavernous hole. “There’s a sharp knife stabbed into the soft part of my head, where the memories are. It’s stuck deep down inside. It doesn’t hurt or weigh me down—it’s just stuck there. And I’m standing off to one side, looking at this like it’s happening to someone else. I want someone to pull the knife out, but no one knows that it’s stuck inside my head. I think about yanking it out myself, but I can’t reach my hands inside my head. It’s the strangest thing. I can stab myself, but I can’t reach the knife to pull it out. And then everything starts to disappear. I start to fade away, too. And only the knife is left. Only the knife is always there—to the very end. Like the bone of some prehistoric animal on the beach. That’s the kind of dream I have,” he said.
paragraph2: The young man, confined to his wheelchair, often found himself sharing his recurring dream with those who would listen, a dream that haunted him like an unsolvable riddle. In this dream, a sharp knife was conspicuously embedded in the very part of his head where his memories were stored. Strangely, the knife brought no pain or discomfort; instead, he observed it dispassionately, as if the scenario was unfolding in front of him rather than within him. There was an unfulfilled longing for someone to notice and gently remove the knife, yet no one ever seemed aware of its silent presence. On occasion, he wondered if he might extract it himself, but the task always proved impossible, as though his arms were made of thin air. This dreamscape, relentless in its surreal nature, invariably led to the dissolution of everything else around him, leaving the knife as the sole survivor, a stark reminder resembling an ancient bone washed ashore, devoid of history or explanation. It was a mysterious, solitary fixture on the landscape of his subconscious, hauntingly resilient.

paragraph1: In the heart of Istanbul, where spring wraps the city in a tender embrace, my partner and I found ourselves entwined on a musty mattress, tucked away in the cool shadows of our room. The air outside was thick with warmth, a stark contrast to the delightful chill that swept in through the open window. As we moved together, the soft breeze caressed our skin, a rare treat in the midst of the rising temperatures. We paused momentarily when the lively sounds of boys playing football echoed up from the garden below, their voices laced with a boyish bravado as they swore and laughed. A shared smile crossed our lips, the humor of our mirrored indulgences not lost on us, as we embraced the whimsical parallel of our own intimacy. That fleeting moment of distraction, filled with youthful exuberance, passed quickly. Our playful elation resumed, carrying us far from any lingering thoughts of the boys' antics—or of the earring that slipped from my partner's ear, forgotten amid the fervor of our afternoon.
paragraph2: Outside the sky was shimmering as it does only in Istanbul in the spring. In the streets people still in their winter clothes were perspiring, but inside shops and buildings, and under the linden and chestnut trees, it was still cool. We felt the same coolness rising from the musty mattress on which we were making love, the way children play, happily forgetting everything else. A breeze wafted in through the balcony window, tinged with the sea and linden leaves; it lifted the tulle curtains, and they billowed down again in slow motion, chilling our naked bodies. From the bed of the back bedroom of the second- floor apartment, we could see a group of boys playing football in the garden below, swearing furiously in the May heat, and as it dawned on us that we were enacting, word for word, exactly those indecencies, we stopped making love to look into each other’s eyes and smile. But so great was our elation that the joke life had sent us from the back garden was forgotten as quickly as the earring.

paragraph1: As my feeling of isolation in the classroom increased, I sought out my brother in the yard during recess. Sometimes we held hands. His birthday was a week too late for him to be in fourth grade, the year he would have enrolled in had we stayed in Istanbul, so he was in third grade instead. He already knew all the numbers, and had made a name for himself in class by counting backward by threes.Two days later, as my mother was getting us ready for school, I suddenly declared, “I’m not going!” I lowered my eyes and did not respond to her cajoling or her questions.“I’m going!” my brother said.They hurried out. Alone at home, I understood that if we had been in Istanbul my mother would not have indulged me. Although I was justified in not wanting to go to school, I felt a burning remorse. (In the years that followed, I skipped school many times, and each time I was gripped by similar feelings of loneliness and guilt.)Three days later, my father announced that it would be better for my brother and me to live with his mother and attend school in Turkey, so we left the French school. We never did manage to learn French.
paragraph2: Every day in my new classroom feels like an endless cycle of words I don't understand, leaving me adrift in a sea of unfamiliar syllables and faces. My heart feels heavy with the weight of isolation, and the classroom becomes a silent echo of loneliness, where the laughter and chatter of my classmates bounce off walls that seem to close in on me with each passing day. During recess, I seek solace in the company of my younger brother, clinging to the familiar comfort he brings, despite him being one grade below where he would have been back in Istanbul. The decision to skip school in a fleeting act of defiance fills me with an immediate wave of remorse and guilt, especially when I see him head off to school each morning without me, brave in ways I seem not to be. Those solitary moments at home, absent of his innocent banter, amplify my feelings of abandonment. It's then that my father makes the monumental decision that we would be better off returning to Turkey, to live with our grandmother and attend school there. The idea is a bittersweet revelation, and as we leave the French school, I realize I've escaped without even understanding a word of the language, parting with a tinge of relief and the hope of belonging.

paragraph1: Ivan found himself reflecting on the awkwardness of unsolicited sexual comments and invitations, a situation he had personally experienced in an encounter with a man. This incident left him feeling discomfort unparalleled, prompting a silent pledge to avoid the individual, despite recognizing there had been no explicit wrongdoing. The thought lingered with Ivan, forcing him to consider how much more frequent and challenging these encounters must be for attractive women who often face such uncomfortable advances. He marveled at the delicate dance involved in forming mutual relationships without crossing unwelcome boundaries, likening it to an intricate problem-solving task. Yet, he acknowledged the evidence of success in this sphere all around him, often noticing how people forged connections seemingly effortlessly. His friend Ollie served as a prime example, being comfortably married, a fact that both puzzled and inspired Ivan. He found himself deeply contemplating the nuances of relationship-building, pondering how he might achieve such successful connections himself, navigating the complex social landscape that surrounded him with quiet determination and curiosity about the possibilities.
paragraph2: Ivan has come to understand that it must be awkward to receive unwanted sexual comments and invitations, and there was that one occasion even in his own case, which was also a man, which probably just goes to show. He would personally go to great lengths to avoid ever encountering that guy again, not that he even did anything bad, but purely from the awkwardness. Then imagine being an attractive woman and it’s not just one man you have to avoid but almost all of them. At the same time, how to reach a mutually agreeable situation without one person making an advance on the other which may turn out to be unwanted? It’s like the problem with the chairs and tables. In a haphazard and inefficient way, without any fixed method, solutions can be reached, and, evidently, are reached all the time, considering that someone like Ollie is married. People get to know each other, things happen, that’s life. The question for Ivan is how to become one of those people, how to live that kind of life.

paragraph1: There once lived, at a series of temporary addresses across the United States of America, a travelling man of Indian origin, advancing years, and retreating mental powers, who had developed an unwholesome, because entirely one-sided, passion for a certain television personality, the beautiful, witty, and adored talk-show host Miss Salma R., whom he had never metan infatuation that he characterized, quite inaccurately, as love. In the name of this so-called love, he christened himself Quichotte, for the opera “Don Quichotte,” and resolved to be his “beloved” ’s knight-errant, to pursue her zealously right through the television screen into whatever exalted high-definition reality she and her kind inhabited, and, by deeds as well as by grace, to win her heart.
paragraph2: An aging Indian man, experiencing the unsettling decline of his mental faculties, embarks on a journey across the United States fueled by an obsessive infatuation with a television personality named Miss Salma R., a captivating and renowned talk-show host. Paragraph 1:
There once lived, at a series of temporary addresses across the United States of America, a travelling man of Indian origin, advancing years, and retreating mental powers, who had developed an unwholesome, because entirely one-sided, passion for a certain television personality, the beautiful, witty, and adored talk-show host Miss Salma R., whom he had never metan infatuation that he characterized, quite inaccurately, as love. In the name of this so-called love, he christened himself Quichotte, for the opera “Don Quichotte,” and resolved to be his “beloved” ’s knight-errant, to pursue her zealously right through the television screen into whatever exalted high-definition reality she and her kind inhabited, and, by deeds as well as by grace, to win her heart.

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: In the heart of an African nation, the capital city stirs to life on a typical Sunday, its character defined by English and Indian influences that linger from its colonial past. Despite a notable decline in the white population, driven by departures to South Africa or the ramifications of past deportations, the city still clings to its colonial legacy. The African essence here is subtle, woven into the fabric of suburban gardens and manifesting through the lens of commercial tourism, where vibrant local crafts and enticing souvenir items offer fleeting glimpses of the continent's rich artistry. In stark contrast to surrounding bush villages, the city presents a tantalizing allure of modernity. Both white visitors and Africans who have migrated from rural areas find themselves enticed by its urban charm. Yet, it is unmistakably apparent that the city's ostentatious colonial glamour leaves an indelible impression on its inhabitants, creating a sense of disconnect from their origins.
paragraph2: It was like another Sunday in the capital, which, in spite of the white exodus to South Africa and in spite of deportations, remained an English-Indian creation in the African wilderness. It owed nothing to African skill; it required none. Not far from the capital were bush villages, half-day excursions for tourists. But in the capital Africa showed only in the semi-tropical suburban gardens, in the tourist-shop displays of carvings and leather goods and souvenir drums and spears, and in the awkward liveried boys in the new tourist hotels, where the white or Israeli supervisors were never far away. Africa here was décor. Glamour for the white visitor and expatriate; glamour too for the African, the man flushed out from the bush, to whom, in the city, with independence, civilization appeared to have been granted complete. It was still a colonial city, with a colonial glamour. Everyone in it was far from home.

paragraph1: When that first pregnancy was well advanced, around Christmas time, Avie had received a brief letter from Grace."I hear you are married and expecting. You may not have heard I have dropped out of college, due to some troubles I have had with my health and my nerves. I often think of our talks and particularly the dream you told me about. It still scares the daylights out of me. Love, Grace."Avie remembered then the conversation with Marsha. The colitis. The tone of Grace’s letter seemed off kilter, with some pleading note in it that made her put off answering. She herself was feeling quite happy at the time, full of practical concerns, light-years away from whatever stuff they had talked about in college. She didn’t know if she could ever find her way back there or find a way to talk to Grace as she was now. And later, of course, she got too busy.She asks Royce if he heard anything from Grace, ever."No. No. Why should I?" "I just thought." "No.""I thought you might have looked her up later on."Not a good idea."She has disappointed him. Prying. Trying to get at some spot of live regret right under the ribs. A woman.
paragraph2: Avie sat in the quiet of her small study, the soft glow of the desk lamp lending a gentle warmth to the room as she pondered the contents of a letter she had received many years ago from Grace during her first pregnancy. Grace’s words, penned in a shaky hand, revealed the turmoil of her post-college life, marked by health issues and anxiety that seemed to grip her when she had dropped out of college. A vivid image of her once vibrant friend haunted by nervy uncertainty filled Avie’s mind, as she remembered a disturbing dream she had shared with Grace, now eerily etched in the letter. Avie, in that moment years back, had been swept up in the vibrant whirlwind of her life’s new chapter, her thoughts wrapped tightly around the small yet all-consuming universe that pregnancy wove around her, leaving little room for contemplation of past collegiate exchanges. The remembrance of a deep conversation with Marsha about colitis flitted through her mind, a ghostly echo of past talks. Yet Grace’s pleading tone made her pause, and she had postponed replying. Wondering about Grace’s current state, Avie had tentatively brought it up with Royce, whose curt dismissal reminded her of cherished memories and lingering regrets.

paragraph1: As the final bell rang at Torrance House School for Girls in June 1965, Juliet packed her things, reflecting on her tenure as a temporary teacher. Despite her dedication and the connection she'd formed with her students, the position she'd hoped would become permanent slipped away as the teacher she'd been filling in for had recovered. Instead of heading directly home, Juliet chose a different path, deciding to visit a friend up the coast, seeking solace and company after the term’s end. She thought back to a memorable evening with Juanita, her only friend among the staff. The two had shared quiet laughter and whispered hopes while attending a revival screening of "Hiroshima, Mon Amour." For Juliet, the film's themes of love and despair mirrored their subsequent conversation at a nearby cafe. Juanita had earnestly confessed her love for a married man, the father of one of her students, a precarious affair shadowed by the potential wrath of his formidable wife. Juliet quietly admitted to similar forbidden feelings, though she had chosen not to pursue them out of empathy for the incapacitated condition of the man's wife. Together, they navigated the murky waters of desire and discretion, sharing a bond forged in secrecy.
paragraph2: Halfway through June of 1965, the term at Torrance House School for Girls is over. Juliet has not been offered a permanent job—the teacher she was replacing has recovered from a bout of depression—and she could now be on her way home. Instead, she is taking what she has described as a little detour. A little detour to see a friend who lives up the coast.About a month ago, she went with another teacher—Juanita, the only person on the staff who is near her age, and her only friend—to see a revival of a movie called “Hiroshima, Mon Amour.” Juanita confessed afterward that she herself, like the woman in the picture, was in love with a married man—the father of one of her students. Then Juliet said that she had found herself in somewhat the same situation but had not allowed things to go on because of the tragic plight of the man’s wife, who was a total invalid, more or less brain-dead. Juanita said she wished that her lover’s wife were brain-dead, but she was not—she was vigorous and powerful and could get Juanita fired.

paragraph1: But the airplane is a wonderful thing. You are still in one place when you arrive at the other. The airplane is faster than the heart. You arrive quickly and you leave quickly. You don't grieve too much. And there is something else about the airplane. You can go back many times to the same place. And something strange happens if you go back often enough. You stop grieving for the past. You see that the past is something in your mind alone, that it doesn't exist in real life. You trample on the past, you crush it. In the beginning it is like trampling on a garden. In the end you are just walking on ground. That is the way we have to learn to live now. The past is here." He touched his heart. "It isn't there." And he pointed at the dusty road.
paragraph2: The metaphorical power of airplanes serves as a transformative tool for those grappling with past grievances and emotional transitions. Airplanes, with their remarkable speed, symbolize the capacity to swiftly navigate through emotional landscapes, allowing one to revisit and reshape past experiences. Through the lens of a third person narrative, this perspective philosophically explores how revisiting old places diminishes the hold of bygone grievances, transforming these once persistent memories into mere constructs that fade from reality. The narrative implies the presence of two characters: the narrator, who articulates the philosophical underpinnings of this phenomenon, and an unspecified male character who embodies this notion. He physically demonstrates the concept by touching his heart, then gesturing toward a dusty road, vividly illustrating the stark contrast between the internalized memory of past events and the tangible reality before him. Such journeys highlight the profound shift from lingering emotional burdens to liberated mental spaces.

paragraph1: We aren’t supposed to want our mothers that way, with the pining intensity of sexual love, but I did, and if I couldn’t have her, I couldn’t have anything. Most of all I couldn’t have pleasure, not even for a moment. I was bereft, in agony, destroyed over her death. To experience sexual joy, it seemed, would have been to negate that reality. And more, it would have been to betray my mother, to be disloyal to the person she had been to memy hero, a single mother after she bravely left an unhealthy relationship with my father when I was five. She remarried when I was eleven. My stepfather had loved her and been a good husband to her for ten years, but shortly after she died, he’d fallen in love with someone else. His new girlfriend and her two daughters moved into my mother’s house, took her photos off the walls, erased her. I needed my stepfather to be the kind of man who would suffer for my mother, unable to go on, who would carry a torch. And if he wouldn’t do it, I would.
paragraph2: In the wake of my mother’s death, I find myself engulfed in a storm of emotions that twist and turn within me, leaving a palpable void that no amount of distraction can fill. What unsettles me most is the inappropriate semblance of my longing; it feels like the yearning born from a place akin to sexual love, an inexplicable tie that knots my heart and refuses to loosen its grip. My mother was always my heroine, a woman of unyielding courage who dared to walk away from a toxic marriage with my father, shielding me with her resilience. With time, she found companionship with another—my stepfather—who, for a decade, seemed a worthy partner. Yet, it was all too fleeting; just as I’m left grappling with loss, he seems to embrace forgetfulness, allowing his new partner and her children to sweep into their home and erase all remnants of my mother. The ease with which he moves on feels like a betrayal, compounding my grief with layers of helplessness. Amidst the turmoil, one resolve emerges clear and unwavering: I will honor her memory, clutching her legacy close, unwilling to let time or new occupants erode the space she etched in my heart.

paragraph1: She stares into the bathroom mirror, assesses her face in the misted glass. A face of the eighties, a mask face, a bottom-line face; push the weak to the wall and grab what you can. But now it’s the nineties. Is she out of style, so soon? She’s only thirty-five, and she’s already losing track of what people ten years younger are thinking. That could be fatal. As time goes by, she’ll have to race faster and faster to keep up, and for what? Part of the life she should have had is just a gap, it isn’t there, it’s nothing. What can be salvaged from it, what can be redone, what can be done at all?When she climbs out of the tub after her sponge bath, she almost falls. She has a fever, no doubt about it. Inside her, something is leaking, or else festering; she can hear it, like a dripping tap. A running sore, a sore from running so hard. She should go to the emergency ward at some hospital, get herself shot up with antibiotics. Instead, she lurches into the living room, takes Hairball down from the mantelpiece in its bottle, places it on the coffee table.She’s cross-legged, listens. Filaments wave. She can hear a kind of buzz, like bees at work.
paragraph2: Standing before the bathroom mirror, she examined her reflection, the years etched lightly across her thirty-five-year-old face, a stark reminder of the passage of time and the shifting sands of trends and mores. It was the precipice of a new decade, one that promised to sweep society into uncharted waters, leaving her grappling with the feeling of being adrift, a relic of the eighties thrust into the uncertain embrace of the nineties. Though relatively young, the pervasive sensation of being out of step with the world gnawed at her spirit, igniting an introspective journey through her life’s landscape, littered with the ghosts of missed opportunities and roads not taken. Each decision, each path turned away from now reemerged in her mind like spectral signposts pointing toward what might have been. In the throes of a peculiar illness, a fever clinging to her skin like a stubborn mist, she eschewed the rational step of seeking medical guidance. Instead, drawn inexplicably to the living room, she perched herself cross-legged before the mantelpiece where Hairball resided in its glass prison. The object drew her in, its presence both comforting and peculiarly unsettling. The room hummed with an enigmatic buzzing, a sound resonant of bees, enveloping her in a cocoon of eerie introspection as she delved deeper into the labyrinth of her thoughts, questioning what might be reclaimed or renewed from the chapters of her life she still held dominion over.

paragraph1: Aidan closes the door and puts his bag down at his feet. O.K., he says. The car smells of alcohol. Aidan still feels that he doesn’t really know who this woman is, this woman lying on the back seat. She’s coming up fairly often in his life at this point, but who is she? At first he thought she was Declan’s girlfriend, or at least a candidate for that role, but then in the hotel the other night she seemed different—glamorous in a way, with all those men looking at her—and of course Declan wasn’t there, and she even invited Aidan for a drink afterward. He could ask his brother, How do you know this girl? I mean, are you riding her, or what? But Declan’s sensibilities would be offended by that kind of thing.How would you get home if you didn’t have a lift? Pauline says.Walk, Aidan says.How long would it take?
paragraph2: Aidan carefully closed the car door behind him and placed his bag on the ground, his mind preoccupied with thoughts of a woman whose presence seemed to weave in and out of his life like an enigmatic breeze. He couldn't quite pinpoint her connection to Declan, his brother, whom he initially believed she was dating. Yet their recent encounter at the hotel introduced a new, perplexing dynamic; she had appeared strikingly glamorous and self-assured, offering him a discreet invitation for a drink. He pondered whether he should confront Declan and unravel the mystery, recognizing the risk of provoking his brother's ire with such a direct inquiry. Meanwhile, Pauline, who had been observing him with curiosity, interrupted his contemplation with a pragmatic question. She asked how he planned to get home without a lift, to which he casually replied that he would walk, prompting her to curiously ask how long the journey might take.

He could ask his brother, How do you know this girl? I mean, are you riding her, or what? But Declan’s sensibilities would be offended by that kind of thing.How would you get home if you didn’t have a lift? Pauline says.Walk, Aidan says.How long would it take?

Paragraph 2:
Aidan carefully closed the car door behind him and placed his bag on the ground, his mind preoccupied with thoughts of a woman whose presence seemed to weave in and out of his life like an enigmatic breeze. He couldn't quite pinpoint her connection to Declan, his brother, whom he initially believed she was dating. Yet their recent encounter at the hotel introduced a new, perplexing dynamic; she had appeared strikingly glamorous and self-assured, offering him a discreet invitation for a drink. He pondered whether he should confront Declan and unravel the mystery, recognizing the risk of provoking his brother's ire with such a direct inquiry. Meanwhile, Pauline, who had been observing him with curiosity, interrupted his contemplation with a pragmatic question. She asked how he planned to get home without a lift, to which he casually replied that he would walk, prompting her to curiously ask how long the journey might take.

paragraph1: As I sit at my desk, staring at the fading ink on the pages of my latest writing project, I'm struck by how time has dimmed the clarity of my memories. Our house, which once echoed with our son's laughter, has become a gallery of recollections. I find solace in the small, intimate moments shared with my wife, the gentle embrace of routine after years together. Our dinners with friends, where laughter and witticisms flowed as freely as the wine, are now stored in the recesses of my mind. While my wife is often busy with her gallery visits or on business trips, I immerse myself in writing—a novel in progress and a myriad of articles. Our evenings are a cherished ritual: a shared glass of wine as she recounts her day. On weekends, we lose ourselves in the symphony of classical music, explore new culinary delights, or surrender to the allure of art exhibits. Our love for books draws us to the library, and every year, we escape to the mountains and seaside, marking our birthdays with the serenity of nature.
paragraph2: Over time, the memory began to dim. I went on living with my wife, in the house where we’d raised our son. I made love to her still slender body, I invited the same friends over for dinner, cooked the same reliable recipes. While my wife went to the gallery or away on the occasional business trip, I worked at home, in the corner of our bedroom, making slow progress on my fifth novel, my articles, my tepid reviews. When she returned in the evenings, I’d pour us some wine and pretend to listen while she gave me the full rundown of her complicated days. On Saturdays, once a month, we’d go to hear classical music, then out to a restaurant, or else to the opening of a new art exhibit. I would go to the library, and we’d go on vacationto the mountains every year, for her birthday, and to the sea, in the off-season, for mine.

paragraph1: The arrangement of the bowls, small glass bowls in which we normally had ice cream, felt too formal to me. This was the old-fashioned, ceremonious way I remembered my grandfathers eating in Calcutta, being treated each day like kings after their morning baths. I wondered what was the best way to go about it, whether to take a spoonful of each dish as I went or to dump everything onto the plate at once. In the meantime, I ate the luchis, still warm and impressively puffed. I was reminded of Sunday mornings in Bombay, eating luchis prepared by our Parsi cook, Zareen. I could hear my mother complaining cheerfully in the kitchen, telling Zareen to try another batch, that she was frying them before the oil was hot enough.
paragraph2: Sitting at the dining table, the formal arrangement of glass bowls, poised elegantly for ice cream, transports me back to my grandfathers' home in Calcutta, where they were treated with a certain regal air each day. The setting here almost mirrors that past, making me ponder how best to savor each dish before me. As I bite into the warm, fluffy luchis, nostalgia sweeps over me, evoking memories of Sunday mornings in Bombay. I can almost hear Zareen, our family's Parsi cook, bustling around the kitchen, her distinctive frying technique prompting my mother's good-natured grumbles from across the room. It's these vivid memories that flood back while dining, drawing parallels between the tender treatment of my grandfathers and my own cherished experiences in those kitchens of my youth.

paragraph1: As she stood before the group of eager, young faces, her voice carried the weight of a thousand unsaid words, each one heavier with the reality she was about to impart. My impression was one of reluctant determination, as though she, too, had wrestled with the gravity of what she was about to say. She began, her tone firm but not unkind, addressing them as one might address innocent souls about to embark on a journey they never chose. "It is important for you to understand," she said, her eyes scanning the room, "that your lives will not unfold like those out there," referring to a world of boundless possibilities, unlike the rigid paths theirs must follow. Her words painted a stark contrast between these students and the freedom of choice enjoyed by countless others, the actors and singers they adored, or even herself, who had a semblance of choice in her life. They would not visit America, shine on the silver screen, or even find solace in the mundane aisles of a supermarket. Instead, their existence had been predetermined, orchestrated towards a singular, somber purpose—to be the givers of life, one vital organ at a time. Yet, as if to offer a glimmer amidst the rain-soaked heaviness, she raised her eyes to the drizzly field outside, hinting at the possibility of sunshine. "Let’s hope for brighter skies; let's go outside," she suggested, infusing a sense of optimism into the bleakness, a whisper of hope that resonated more profoundly than the storm just passed.
paragraph2: None of you will go to America, none of you will be film stars. And none of you will be working in supermarkets as I heard some of you planning the other day. Your lives are set out for you. You’ll become adults, then before you ‘re old, before you ‘re even middle-aged, you’ll start to donate your vital organs. That’s what each of you was created to do. You’re not like the actors you watch on your videos, you’re not even like me. You were brought into this world for a purpose, and your futures, all of them, have been decided. So you’re not to talk that way any more. You’ll be leaving Hailsham before long, and it’s not so far off, the day you’ll be preparing for your first donations. You need to remember that. If you ‘re to have decent lives, you have to know who you are and what lies ahead of you, every one of you.”Then she went silent, but my impression was that she was continuing to say things inside her head, because for sometime her gaze kept roving over us, going from face to face just as if she were still speaking to us. We were all pretty relieved when she turned to look out over the playing field again.“It’s not so bad now,” she said, even though the rain was as steady as ever. “Let’s just go out there. Then maybe the sun will come out too.”

paragraph1: In fact, this is a town of cats. When the sun starts to go down, many cats come trooping across the bridge—cats of all different kinds and colors. They are much larger than ordinary cats, but they are still cats. The young man is shocked by this sight. He rushes into the bell tower in the center of town and climbs to the top to hide. The cats go about their business, raising the shop shutters or seating themselves at their desks to start their day’s work. Soon, more cats come, crossing the bridge into town like the others. They enter the shops to buy things or go to the town hall to handle administrative matters or eat a meal at the hotel restaurant or drink beer at the tavern and sing lively cat songs. Because cats can see in the dark, they need almost no lights, but that particular night the glow of the full moon floods the town, enabling the young man to see every detail from his perch in the bell tower. When dawn approaches, the cats finish their work, close up the shops, and swarm back across the bridge.
paragraph2: As evening draped its gentle shadow over the peculiar town, an unusual procession unfolded: a diverse array of exceptionally large cats strode purposefully across the bridge that led into the settlement. Each feline, with a gait both majestic and deliberate, slipped into their respective roles within the town. Some busied themselves with raising the shutters of quaint little shops, while others seated themselves behind desks, tending to the day’s paperwork. At the town hall, a few cats deftly managed a variety of administrative duties. Meanwhile, their counterparts indulged in daily routines; some browsed charming boutiques, while others dined elegantly in the soft glow of the hotel restaurant's chandeliers. A lively group gathered at the tavern, where laughter mingled with the clink of glasses and resonated with hearty, jovial singing. Perched atop the bell tower at the town's heart, a young man, his heart racing with incredulity, watched this remarkable spectacle unfold. Was he dreaming? Yet the brilliant moonlight assured him of his reality, illuminating each feline face with an ethereal glow. As the first whispers of dawn began to color the sky, the cats finished their nightly labors and elegantly retraced their steps across the bridge, retreating silently back to whence they came.

paragraph1: Bilquis stood naked beneath the "golden knight," a metaphorical spotlight that rendered her bare and vulnerable, stripped not only of clothing but also of identity and history, represented strikingly by her absent eyebrows. This moment of introspection was charged with a profound sense of loss, as if the very essence of her youth had been spirited away by the inexorable "firewind" of change. The narrative conveys the immigrant's struggle—how the past vanishes, leaving them disconnected, unmoored, unrecognizable to themselves as they are severed from continuity and identity. For Bilquis, this disconnection was a haunting presence, amplified by her father's suicide—a cataclysmic event that had already begun erasing the threads to her history even before she physically departed her homeland. Stripped of all that defined her, she felt exposed and isolated, confronting the disconcerting void left by her history's dissolution, yet yearning for reconnection.
paragraph2: O Bilquis. Naked and eyebrowless beneath the golden knight, wrapped in the delirium of the firewind, she saw her youth flying past her, borne away on the wings of the explosion which were still beating in her ears. All migrants leave their pasts behind, although some try to pack it into bundles and boxes but on the journey something seeps out of the treasured mementoes and old photographs, until even their owners fail to recognize them, because it is the fate of migrants to be stripped of history, to stand naked amidst the scorn of strangers upon whom they see the rich clothing, the brocades of continuity and the eyebrows of belonging at any rate, my point is that Bilquis's past left her even before she left that city; she stood in a gully, denuded by the suicide of her father, and watched it go

paragraph1: Lately, I've felt tangled in a web of correspondence, where writing even the simplest of letters has become an exhausting feat. I fool myself into thinking that drafting two similar letters—one for my family and one for a friend—is too daunting. Yet, in honesty, my failure to write is pure laziness. In the past three weeks, there's been an unsettling silence from my family, leaving me to rely solely on letters from friends in France, Germany, and nearby. The only echo of familial communication came through the cold, bureaucratic voice of the Colonial office. Strangely, amidst this silence, I'm generally quite happy, yet there's an aching incompleteness stemming from the absence of a romantic partner. This emptiness breeds doubt, casting shadows of despair as I wonder if anyone could truly like me.
paragraph2: Writing two copies of a letter is pretty tiring. To write home and then to write to you about the same thing is a heavy task.That, however, is no excuse for my not writing you. It was sheer laziness. I thought the people at home had packed me up. For 3 weeks I got no word from them; in the meantime I had letters from people in France and Germany and several from friends here. The first communication I had was an official one—from the Colonial office.I think you will be glad to know that I am absolutely happy. The only thing I need to make me feel the happiest man on earth is a girl, but what can I do? Nobody could ever like me; and I am despairing of myself.

paragraph1: "I know it sounds daunting," I began, my voice tinged with urgency, "but we can't keep letting our lives slip away while striving for impermanent highs. I’ve spent years chasing dreams that, once grasped, melted like mist in the morning sun. It’s time for a change—something real, something that lasts." My friend sat across from me, deep in thought, as I continued, "Don't you feel it too? This need for stability, for something that won't vanish the moment we think we've captured it?" The lines between the pursuit of endless ambition and the fear of stagnation blurred as I spoke. "Before we lose our chance, we have to switch gears, leave behind this unfulfilling cycle. Time is a relentless thief, and soon it will be too late. Let’s seek something more grounded, something that doesn’t just promise satisfaction but truly delivers it consistently." Their silence suggested contemplation, a slight shimmer of hope.
paragraph2: You've spent enough of your life already on all of that. Let's go away tomorrow, let's not waste a single day more, let's go before it's too late for us."Too late for what, exactly?" "Too late for... oh, I don't know. All I know is that I've wasted all these years looking for something, a sort of trophy I'd get only if I really, really did enough to deserve it. But I don't want it any more, I want something else now, something warm and sheltering, something I can turn to, regardless of what I do, regardless of who I become. Something that will just be there, always, like tomorrow's sky. That's what I want now, and I think it's what you should want too. But it will be too late soon. We'll become too set to change. If we don't take our chance now, another may never come for either of us."

"Too late for... oh, I don't know. All I know is that I've wasted all these years looking for something, a sort of trophy I'd get only if I really, really did enough to deserve it.
