paragraph1: As I stood on the platform, my gaze fixed on the empty electric train across the tracks, a voice resonated through the station, cutting through the quiet ambiance with a sharp call: "San!" Strangely, it echoed in my ears as "Sam," sparking a moment of confusion as I scanned the area for an unfamiliar, summoned figure. Just then, a man clad in an official-looking uniform emerged from the shadows and boarded the waiting train. This seemingly normal event was soon followed by an unexpected parade, led by a resolute woman burdened with parcels. Intrigued and pulled by an undefined urge, I joined the impromptu procession. Suddenly, the tranquility was shattered; a chaotic scene unraveling as a bustling group of men burst forth from a nearby building, their frantic rush to board the train accompanied by a cacophony of shouting and counting. Realization dawned half-aloud among them that a missing member had eluded the day's chaos entirely, a curious absence registering in their minds too late to amend. As the train jerked into motion, the mystery lingered—whether the driver had been made impatient by the gregarious troupe’s delay, or was simply indifferent to their frenzied state, remained a tantalizing enigma as the platform retreated from view.
paragraph2: Across the tracks was the electric train, empty, waiting. No other passengers showed up, and after a while the stationmaster stuck his head out the station window and called, "San."" At first I thought he was calling a man’s name, Sam. And another man wearing some kind of official outfit did come around the end of the building. He crossed the tracks and boarded the electric car. The woman with the parcels stood up and followed him, so I did the same. There was a burst of shouting from across the street, and the doors of a dark-shingled flat-roofed building opened, letting loose several men, who were jamming caps on their heads and banging lunch buckets against their thighs. By the noise they were making, you’d have thought the car was going to run away from them at any minute. But when they settled on board nothing happened. The car sat while they counted one another and worked out who was missing and told the driver that he couldn’t go yet. Then somebody remembered that the missing man hadn’t been around all day. The car started, though I couldn’t tell if the driver had been listening to any of this, or cared.
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of creative writing for a given writing instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
As I stood on the platform, my gaze fixed on the empty electric train across the tracks, a voice resonated through the station, cutting through the quiet ambiance with a sharp call: "San!" Strangely, it echoed in my ears as "Sam," sparking a moment of confusion as I scanned the area for an unfamiliar, summoned figure. Just then, a man clad in an official-looking uniform emerged from the shadows and boarded the waiting train. This seemingly normal event was soon followed by an unexpected parade, led by a resolute woman burdened with parcels. Intrigued and pulled by an undefined urge, I joined the impromptu procession. Suddenly, the tranquility was shattered; a chaotic scene unraveling as a bustling group of men burst forth from a nearby building, their frantic rush to board the train accompanied by a cacophony of shouting and counting. Realization dawned half-aloud among them that a missing member had eluded the day's chaos entirely, a curious absence registering in their minds too late to amend. As the train jerked into motion, the mystery lingered—whether the driver had been made impatient by the gregarious troupe’s delay, or was simply indifferent to their frenzied state, remained a tantalizing enigma as the platform retreated from view.

Paragraph 2:
Across the tracks was the electric train, empty, waiting. No other passengers showed up, and after a while the stationmaster stuck his head out the station window and called, "San."" At first I thought he was calling a man’s name, Sam. And another man wearing some kind of official outfit did come around the end of the building. He crossed the tracks and boarded the electric car. The woman with the parcels stood up and followed him, so I did the same. There was a burst of shouting from across the street, and the doors of a dark-shingled flat-roofed building opened, letting loose several men, who were jamming caps on their heads and banging lunch buckets against their thighs. By the noise they were making, you’d have thought the car was going to run away from them at any minute. But when they settled on board nothing happened. The car sat while they counted one another and worked out who was missing and told the driver that he couldn’t go yet. Then somebody remembered that the missing man hadn’t been around all day. The car started, though I couldn’t tell if the driver had been listening to any of this, or cared.

where `preference` should be "1" if you think Paragraph 1 is better, "2" if you think Paragraph 2 is better.

paragraph1: As dusk descended over the landscape, the howls of jackals reverberated through the evening air, signaling to Subhash and his brother that it was time to depart from the humble club they frequented. The jackals, restless and hungry, prowled the vicinity in search of sustenance, marking the end of day with their plaintive cries. In the fading light, Subhash and his brother relied on makeshift markers fashioned from kerosene tins to guide their way back from the club. Yet Subhash returned to that serene spot often, drawn by the natural wonders it held, collecting feathers and wild almonds scattered like treasures. On one visit, he was captivated by the sight of vultures circling above, and delighted to stumble upon an unhatched warbler's egg. Nurturing hope, he placed the egg in a terra-cotta container at home, but when his incubation efforts didn't succeed, he solemnly buried it beneath a mango tree, granting it peace nurtured by nature's generous care.
paragraph2: Groups of jackals sat erect in packs, their tawny hides mottled with gray. As the light dwindled, a few began to search for food. Their distraught howling, echoing within the club, signalled that it was late, time for the brothers to go home.They left the two kerosene tins, the one on the outside to mark the place. They made sure to hide the one inside the club behind some shrubbery.On subsequent visits, Subhash collected feathers and wild almonds. He saw vultures bathing in puddles, spreading their wings to dry. Once, he found an egg that had dropped, intact, from a warbler’s nest. Carefully, he carried it home with him, placing it in a terra-cotta container from a sweet shop, covering it with twigs. Digging a hole for it in the garden behind their house, at the base of the mango tree, when the egg did not hatch.

paragraph1: As we drive to the station, I feel my mother's eyes darting towards me intermittently, her gaze a cocktail of concern and hesitation. It's as if she senses something off in my demeanor but can't quite pinpoint or articulate it. Her voice breaks through the silence, reminding me to take my feet off the dashboard—a request I wordlessly comply with, almost as if I'm on autopilot. She cautiously asks about my financial situation, probing gently into the abyss I’m hesitant to disclose. Her next question about the doctor makes me pause with a sense of vulnerability that I can't quite shake off. My answers are curt, more perfunctory than revealing, as I ruminate on an evolving sense of loss stirring within me. It is a peculiar loss—the evaporation of seeing myself as a 'normal' individual, whatever that even means. Yet, in this quiet turmoil, there's a realization that my suffering is unremarkable, common even, in its lack of transformative power. Whether I decide to vocalize it or bury it deep doesn’t change the fact of its ordinariness. Upon reaching the station, I thank her mechanically and exit the car, leaving her with words unspoken.
paragraph2: On the way to the station that evening my mother kept glancing at me, as if something about my behaviour was off-putting, and she wanted to reprimand me for it but couldn’t decide what it was. Eventually she told me to take my feet off the dashboard, which I did. You must be relieved, she said. Yeah, delighted. How are you managing for money? Oh, I said. I’m okay. She glanced in the rear-view mirror. The doctor didn’t say anything else, did he? she said. No, that was it. I looked out the window at the station. I had the sense that something in my life had ended, my image of myself as a whole or normal person maybe. I realised my life would be full of mundane physical suffering, and that there was nothing special about it. Suffering wouldn’t make me special, and pretending not to suffer wouldn’t make me special. Talking about it, or even writing about it, would not transform the suffering into something useful. Nothing would. I thanked my mother for the lift to the station and got out of the car.

paragraph1: This summer, for the first time, I watched an X-rated film on Canal Plus. My television set doesn't have a decoder; the images on the screen were blurred, the words replaced by strange sound effects, hissing and babbling, a different sort of language, soft and continuous. One could make out the figure of a woman in a corset and stockings, and a man. The story was incomprehensible; it was impossible to predict any of their actions or movements. The man walked up to the woman. There was a close-up of the woman's genitals, clearly visible among the shimmerings of the screen, then of the man's penis, fully erect, sliding into the woman's vagina. For a long time this coming and going of the two sex organs was shown from several angles. The cock reappeared, in the man's hand, and the sperm spilled on to the woman's belly. No doubt one gets used to such a sight; the first time is shattering. Centuries and centuries, hundreds of generations have gone by, and it is only now that one can see this—a man's penis and a woman's vagina coming together, the sperm—something one could barely take in without dying has become as easy to watch as a handshake.It occurred to me that writing should also aim for that—the impression conveyed by sexual intercourse, a feeling of anxiety and stupefaction, a suspension of moral judgment.
paragraph2: As I sat in front of my television, tuning into Canal Plus, there was a particular aura of excitement tempered with a tinge of frustration, given my lack of a proper decoder which left the images blurred and the audio distorted, transforming my first encounter with an X-rated film into an indistinct yet intriguing experience. Through the haze, I could just about make out the contours of a woman in a corset and stockings, her presence barely distinguishable alongside a man whose actions were equally obscured by the lack of clarity. This obscured narrative played out like a shadow play on the screen, leaving me to piece together the storyline where comprehension struggled against the fog of uncertainty, leaving me unable to predict the characters' intentions or actions. Yet it was unmistakably clear when the scene shifted to a more explicit focus—switching angles multiple times to hone in on their genitals and the fervent act of intercourse, which somehow pierced through the grainy fog and hit with unexpected intensity. The culmination arrived in the form of the man’s ejaculation on the woman’s belly, a moment as shocking as it was mesmerizing given the novelty and visual bluntness of such an act. Reflecting on this visual specter, I pondered the cinematic power encompassed therein, how it forces a viewer into confronting visceral reactions—an amalgam of anxiety and awe untainted by moral judgments—and mused how meaningful writing should emulate this raw, unfiltered emotional pull.

paragraph1: For many years I celebrated the night of January 20-21 as an anniversary.Now I know that this ordeal and this sacrifice were necessary for me to want to have children. To accept the turmoil of reproduction inside my body and, in turn, to let the coming generations pass through me.I have finished putting into words what I consider to be an extreme human experience, hearing on life and death, time, law, ethics and taboo ‒ an experience that sweeps through the body.I have rid myself of the only feeling of guilt in connection with this eventthe fact that it had happened to me and I had done nothing about it. A sort of discarded present. Among all the social and psychological reasons that may account for my past, of one I am certainthese things happened to me so that I might recount them. Maybe the true purpose of my life is for my body, my sensations and my thoughts to become writing, in other words, something intelligible and universal, causing my existence to merge into the lives and heads of other people.
paragraph2: On the night of January 20-21, an event once carved into my memory as an anniversary of sorts, I embarked on a journey that would redefine the contours of my existence. That night, an ordeal unfolded, a gauntlet of emotions and decisions forcing me to confront the latent shadows of guilt I harbored for my past inaction. It was a necessary sacrifice, an initiation into the arena of life where children—concepts wrapped in awe and trepidation—emerge not just in dreams but through the visceral vows of body and soul. The profound interplay of life and death, of societal whispers and personal truths, transformed before my eyes. In striving to give words to this primal experience, I found myself slowly untethering from the weight of inaction, my soul liberated through articulation. Perhaps my purpose transcended mere survival, evolving into a bridge between solitude and the collective human narrative. As I distill my essence into prose, a shared tapestry of understanding becomes woven from strands of both fear and acceptance, tightly binding the unique to the universal, the personal to the shared.

paragraph1: Under the covers, Kino curled up like a worm, shut his eyes tight, and thought of the willow. One by one, he pictured its qualities—its color and shape and movements. And he prayed for dawn to come. All he could do was wait like this, patiently, until it grew light out and the birds awoke and began their day. All he could do was trust in the birds, in all the birds, with their wings and beaks. Until then, he couldn’t let his heart go blank. That void, the vacuum created by it, would draw them in.When the willow tree wasn’t enough, Kino thought of the slim gray cat, and its fondness for grilled seaweed. He remembered Kamita at the counter, lost in a book, young runners going through gruelling repetition drills on a track, the lovely Ben Webster solo on “My Romance.” He remembered his wife in her new blue dress, her hair trimmed short. He hoped that she was living a healthy, happy life in her new home. Without, he hoped, any wounds on her body. She apologized right to my face, and I accepted that, he thought. I need to learn not just to forget but to forgive.
paragraph2: Kino lay in bed, seeking solace in the refuge of his wandering thoughts, as he tried to extricate himself from the relentless feelings that threatened to engulf him. Through the quiet and dim-lit room, he wandered back to a place of cherished memories, focusing intently on comforting images that offered a brief respite from the turmoil within. A majestic willow tree rustled gently in the breeze of his mind, its leaves cascading like an ethereal curtain, accompanied by the graceful slink of a slim gray cat weaving through its branches. His mind flickered to Kamita at the counter, a stable presence he held dear. His thoughts seamlessly transitioned to the energy of youth, visualizing young athletes training on a sunlit track, as well as the soulful notes of a beautiful jazz solo reverberating through him. When he thought about his wife, he saw her enlivened in a new blue dress, her life unfolding in a new home. Kino harbored hopes that she was thriving, unharmed by the past shadows that lingered over them. Amidst these reflections, he recalled their exchanged apologies, a bittersweet acknowledgment that forgiving was just as crucial as forgetting. Kino knew, in the gentle surrender to these memories, he found a necessary grace.

paragraph1: Maybe I’ll try it myself sometime. On sleepless nights, that random, fanciful thought sometimes comes to me. I’ll filch the I.D. or the nametag of a woman I love, focus on it like a laser, pull her name inside me, and possess a part of her, all to myself. What would that feel like?No. That’ll never happen. I’ve never been deft with my hands, and would never be able to steal something that belonged to someone else. Even if that something had no physical form, and stealing it wasn’t against the law.Extreme love, extreme loneliness. Ever since then, whenever I listen to a Bruckner symphony I ponder that Shinagawa Monkey’s personal life. I picture the elderly monkey in that tiny hot-springs town, in an attic in a rundown inn, asleep on a thin futon. And I think of the snacks—the kakipi and the dried squid—that we enjoyed as we drank beer together, propped up against the wall.I haven’t seen the beautiful travel-magazine editor since then, so I have no idea what fate befell her name after that. I hope it didn’t cause her any real hardship. She was blameless, after all. Nothing was her fault. I do feel bad about it, but I still can’t bring myself to tell her about the Shinagawa Monkey.
paragraph2: In certain silent hours on sleepless nights, I find myself haunted by an intrusive thought, bizarre and somewhat tempting, though not without its moral implications. I imagine the curious act of symbolically stealing a woman's identity—not through any direct theft or harm, but rather by taking something mundane yet intimately hers, like an I.D. card or perhaps a simple nametag. It's not a notion I entertain seriously; instead, it's dismissed as quickly as it arrives, as I'm neither cunning nor ethically unburdened enough to pursue such a peculiar whim. This thought somehow brings me back to my strange encounter with the Shinagawa Monkey, an enigmatic creature who resided secretly in an attic within a quaint hot-springs town. The elderly monkey, with his odd penchant for 'stealing' names or identities, formed an unexpected yet comforting company as we shared beers and snacks, fostering a bizarre sense of camaraderie. My memory drifts further, leading me to worry about a travel-magazine editor whose name might have been tampered with by that unusual creature's mischief. Despite my lingering concern, I've never actually reached out to her to confirm or warn her of such a possibility, perhaps out of fear of being thought foolish or because of the unsettling allure that such mysteries hold.

paragraph1: Nita, a woman navigating the choppy waters of recent bereavement, finds herself at the center of a whirlwind of concerned calls from friends and acquaintances who are keenly aware of her past tendencies to lean on a glass of wine during trying times—a coping mechanism now stripped away from her. These callers, with voices tinged with worry, seek assurance of her well-being, probing gently while fearing her potential solitude and vulnerability. Nita, with an air of practiced composure, manages to put them at ease, deploying a balanced demeanor that is neither steeped in excessive sorrow nor artificially bright. To those who inquire about her immediate needs, she insists she has sufficient groceries and supplies, but her inner circle harbors quiet suspicions that she might be neglecting her health, perhaps even discarding the sympathy notes that have come to dot her kitchen counter. Curiously, she has opted against informing distant relatives—such as Rich's ex-wife who resides in Arizona or his brother in Nova Scotia—perceiving, perhaps, that their emotional distance might lend them a unique understanding of her actions, a comprehension that those physically closer might miss entirely.
paragraph2: At first, people kept phoning, to make sure that Nita was not too depressed, not too lonely, not eating too little or drinking too much. (She had been such a diligent wine drinker that many forgot that she was now forbidden to drink at all.) She held them off, without sounding nobly grief-stricken or unnaturally cheerful or absent-minded or confused. She said that she didn’t need groceries; she was working through what she had on hand. She had enough of her prescription pills and enough stamps for her thank-you notes.Her closer friends probably suspected the truth—that she was not bothering to eat much and that she threw out any sympathy note she happened to get. She had not even informed the people who lived at a distance, to elicit such notes. Not Rich’s ex-wife in Arizona or his semi-estranged brother in Nova Scotia, though those two might have understood, perhaps better than the people near at hand, why she had proceeded with the non-funeral as she had done.
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of creative writing for a given writing instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
Nita, a woman navigating the choppy waters of recent bereavement, finds herself at the center of a whirlwind of concerned calls from friends and acquaintances who are keenly aware of her past tendencies to lean on a glass of wine during trying times—a coping mechanism now stripped away from her. These callers, with voices tinged with worry, seek assurance of her well-being, probing gently while fearing her potential solitude and vulnerability. Nita, with an air of practiced composure, manages to put them at ease, deploying a balanced demeanor that is neither steeped in excessive sorrow nor artificially bright. To those who inquire about her immediate needs, she insists she has sufficient groceries and supplies, but her inner circle harbors quiet suspicions that she might be neglecting her health, perhaps even discarding the sympathy notes that have come to dot her kitchen counter. Curiously, she has opted against informing distant relatives—such as Rich's ex-wife who resides in Arizona or his brother in Nova Scotia—perceiving, perhaps, that their emotional distance might lend them a unique understanding of her actions, a comprehension that those physically closer might miss entirely.

Paragraph 2:
At first, people kept phoning, to make sure that Nita was not too depressed, not too lonely, not eating too little or drinking too much. (She had been such a diligent wine drinker that many forgot that she was now forbidden to drink at all.) She held them off, without sounding nobly grief-stricken or unnaturally cheerful or absent-minded or confused. She said that she didn’t need groceries; she was working through what she had on hand. She had enough of her prescription pills and enough stamps for her thank-you notes.Her closer friends probably suspected the truth—that she was not bothering to eat much and that she threw out any sympathy note she happened to get. She had not even informed the people who lived at a distance, to elicit such notes. Not Rich’s ex-wife in Arizona or his semi-estranged brother in Nova Scotia, though those two might have understood, perhaps better than the people near at hand, why she had proceeded with the non-funeral as she had done.

where `preference` should be "1" if you think Paragraph 1 is better, "2" if you think Paragraph 2 is better.

paragraph1: My father was forty-five or forty-six when he had a heart attack. This trouble with his heart was surprising, since for all the years we had known him as children his trouble was his stomach and his indigestion, requiring bottles and bottles of a particular brand of medicinal stomach powder, which he never had the foresight to buy when he was all right, preferring instead during a crisis to send his children on the long walk to the local pharmacy for the powder.A couple of years after this heart trouble, my father was put on half pay by the Trinidad Guardian, the newspaper for which he worked. I was in school in England when this happened, and I worried about the effect of this half pay on my family; things had been bad enough on my father’s full pay. But my father, now near the end of things, was possessed by a strange lightness of spirit. It was as though the heart illness, officially recognized by doctors and the newspaper, gave full expression and an extra validity to the unhappiness he had felt for years, with the Guardian, with my mother’s family, with his poverty, with prejudice and the British Empire and the unhappy state of India, and with many other things; and it was no longer necessary now for him to go over any of the points.
paragraph2: My father's health took an alarming turn when he suffered a heart attack in his mid-forties, an incident that cast a long shadow over our family. Before this, his health struggles had mostly manifested as persistent gastric issues, necessitating frequent trips to the pharmacy for stomach powder. It seemed an unlikely precursor to something as serious as a heart attack, and the shock of it reverberated through our lives. Just a couple of years after the heart attack, his employer, the Trinidad Guardian newspaper, dealt us another blow by placing him on half pay. At that time, I was attending school in England, aware of the precarious balancing act our family finances had been even with my father's full salary. The news of his reduced income weighed heavily on me as I worried about how we would manage. Yet, to my surprise, my father seemed to find an unexpected solace in his diagnosis. It was as if the heart condition had stripped away any expectations, freeing him from the burdens he'd so often lamented, like his frustrations with his job, family dynamics, social inequities, and even his discontent with the British Empire. This peculiar sense of lightness enveloped him, as though he finally had an excuse to stop grappling with these grievances, leaving me both relieved for him and apprehensive about our uncertain future.

paragraph1: Ivan stands alone in the corner of the room, keenly observing the bustling activities of the chess club members as they go about the seemingly chaotic task of rearranging chairs and tables in preparation for their next meeting. He hears snippets of conversation floating around him—phrases like "Back a bit there, Tom" and "Mind yourself now" drift through the air. To Ivan, the method of communication between the club members appears scattered, almost disjointed, as if each was following a different set of instructions entirely. He finds himself baffled; he cannot discern which chairs are intended to be moved and which are meant to remain in place, as their movements appear erratic and arbitrary at best. Despite this, a familiar setup—the predictable U-shaped table configuration surrounded by chairs—begins to emerge from the chaos, but Ivan can't help but see inefficiencies in the process. As he observes, he slips into his own world of thought, mentally programming a sequence in which a computer might handle this task with more precision and speed. His musing doesn't seem new; it echoes thoughts he's entertained on numerous occasions in various settings. The conclusion he reaches is not novel but reaffirmed by what he sees: this group’s method, while functional, lacks the accuracy and efficiency only a well-designed algorithm could provide.
paragraph2: Ivan is standing on his own in the corner while the men from the chess club move the chairs and tables around. The men are saying things to one another likeBack a bit there, Tom. Mind yourself now. Alone, Ivan is standing, wanting to sit down but uncertain which of the chairs need to be rearranged still and which are in their correct places already. This uncertainty arises because the way in which the men are moving the furniture corresponds to no specific method Ivan has been able to discern. A familiar arrangement is slowly beginning to emerge—a central U shape composed of ten tables, with ten chairs along the outer rim of the shape, and a general seating area around the outside—but the process by which the men are reaching this arrangement seems haphazard. Standing on his own in the corner, Ivan thinks with no especially intense focus about the most efficient method of arranging, say, a random distribution of a given number of tables and chairs into the aforementioned shape. It’s something he has thought about before, while standing in other corners, watching other people move similar furniture around similar indoor spacesthe different approaches you could use, if you happened to be writing a computer program to maximize process efficiency. The accuracy of these particular men would be, Ivan thinks, pretty low, like actually very low.

paragraph1: Outside the sky was shimmering as it does only in Istanbul in the spring. In the streets people still in their winter clothes were perspiring, but inside shops and buildings, and under the linden and chestnut trees, it was still cool. We felt the same coolness rising from the musty mattress on which we were making love, the way children play, happily forgetting everything else. A breeze wafted in through the balcony window, tinged with the sea and linden leaves; it lifted the tulle curtains, and they billowed down again in slow motion, chilling our naked bodies. From the bed of the back bedroom of the second- floor apartment, we could see a group of boys playing football in the garden below, swearing furiously in the May heat, and as it dawned on us that we were enacting, word for word, exactly those indecencies, we stopped making love to look into each other’s eyes and smile. But so great was our elation that the joke life had sent us from the back garden was forgotten as quickly as the earring.
paragraph2: In the heart of Istanbul, where spring wraps the city in a tender embrace, my partner and I found ourselves entwined on a musty mattress, tucked away in the cool shadows of our room. The air outside was thick with warmth, a stark contrast to the delightful chill that swept in through the open window. As we moved together, the soft breeze caressed our skin, a rare treat in the midst of the rising temperatures. We paused momentarily when the lively sounds of boys playing football echoed up from the garden below, their voices laced with a boyish bravado as they swore and laughed. A shared smile crossed our lips, the humor of our mirrored indulgences not lost on us, as we embraced the whimsical parallel of our own intimacy. That fleeting moment of distraction, filled with youthful exuberance, passed quickly. Our playful elation resumed, carrying us far from any lingering thoughts of the boys' antics—or of the earring that slipped from my partner's ear, forgotten amid the fervor of our afternoon.

paragraph1: Leo, you stand there, tangled in the web of your self-inflicted despair, fixated on that wound as if it were a badge of honor. It seems to be the axis around which your entire existence spins, the only thing you truly cherish. You wear it with a kind of twisted pride, not realizing it has become a prison of your own making. No matter how many times life offers you the tools to rebuild, to achieve something greater, you end up sabotaging those efforts. It's almost as if you're afraid of what lies beyond that familiar pain. The people you meet, the passions you briefly entertain, are mere distractions to you; temporary solace, never blossoming into true commitments. I watch, disheartened, as you retreat into this cycle of attachment to your anguish, while others, people facing challenges greater than you've ever known, stride forward courageously. They continue to mold meaningful lives despite their battles, courageously embracing each new sunrise. But you, Leo, with all your potential, remain shackled to that wound, unwilling to confront the truth and rise above it. And in that unwillingness, you remain a shadow of what you could be.
paragraph2: Your wound, your silly little wound! That's your real love, Leo, that wound, the one true love of your life! I know how it will be, even if we tried, even if we managed to build something all over again. The music too, that would be no different. Even if they'd accepted you tonight, even if you became celebrated in this town, you'd destroy it all, you'd destroy everything, pull it all down around you just as you did before. And all because of that wound. Me, the music, we're neither of us anything more to you than mistresses you seek consolation from. You'll always go back to your one real love. To that wound! And you know what makes me so angry? Leo, are you listening to me? Your wound, it's nothing special, nothing special at all. In this town alone, I know there are many people with far worse. And yet they carry on, every one of them, with far greater courage than you ever did. They go on with their lives. They become something worthwhile. But you, Leo, look at you. Always tending your wound.

paragraph1: She was a woman still controlled by the traumas of her girlhood. It made more sense to put her three-year-old self in the dock. As Dr Byford explained, she was really the victim of a vicious, peculiarly female psycological disordershe felt one thing and did another. She was a stranger to herself.And were they still like that, she wondered - these new girls, this new generation? Did they still feel one thing and do another? Did they still only want to be wanted? Were they still objects of desire instead of - as Howard might put it - desiring subjects? No, she could see no serious change. Still starving themselves, still reading women's magazines that explicitly hate women, still cutting themselves with little knives in places they think can't be seen, still faking their orgasms with men they dislike, still lying to everybody about everything.
paragraph2: The woman sat quietly in Dr. Byford's office, confronting the echoes of her girlhood traumas that seemed to cling to her every step, manifesting in a dissonance between what she felt and how she acted. Dr. Byford, with a gentle but matter-of-fact demeanor, named her condition: a psychological disorder marked by this dichotomy. As she listened, her mind wandered to the newer generation of girls, pondering if they too felt the relentless tug of societal expectations that demanded one thing but accepted another, burdened by the pressure to be seen as objects of desire rather than as beings with desires of their own. The thought was unsettling, as little seemed to have changed; behaviors like extreme dieting, self-harm, and dishonesty persisted, underscoring a grim continuity. Howard's ideals quietly hovered over her musings, suggesting yet another layer of expectation regarding women's roles, equally complex and onerous.

paragraph1: Over the course of two peculiar days, Tomas found himself drifting into a rare and unexpected sanctuary from his relentless waves of compassion, a pause he likened to the deep, restorative slumber of a miner after an arduous week's labor. During this interlude, his mind was continuously drawn to thoughts of Tereza, a presence both haunting and cherished. As he reflected on the solitude that came with her absence, Tomas faced an unsettling realization: it was not Tereza herself from whom he sought refuge, but rather the profound compassion her presence stirred within him. This compassion was a relentless force, unfurling within him like an unstoppable tide. The weekend gifted him a fleeting sense of freedom, a respite as liberating as it was disquieting, leaving him to grapple with the emotions that welled up in her absence. However, as Monday dawned, reality rushed back with an intensity Tomas found crushingly familiar. The compassion he felt, an emotion that eclipsed any personal suffering he had known, returned with a force equatable to the relentless, imposing weight of Russian tanks. It bore down on him, a relentless heaviness that pressed steadily upon his soul, reminding him of the inescapable bond tethered to his own heart’s earnest virtues.
paragraph2: During those two beautiful days of melancholy, his compassion (that curse of emotional telepathy) had taken a holiday. It had slept the sound Sunday sleep of a miner who, after a hard week's work, needs to gather strength for his Monday shift. Instead of the patients he was treating, Tomas saw Tereza. He tried to remind himself. Don't think about her! Don't think about her! He said to himself, I'm sick with compassion. It's good that she's gone and that I'll never see her again, though it's not Tereza I need to be free of—it's that sickness, compassion, which I thought I was immune to until she infected me with it. On Saturday and Sunday, he felt the sweet lightness of being rise up to him out of the depths of the future. On Monday, he was hit by a weight the likes of which he had never known. The tons of steel of the Russian tanks were nothing compared with it. For there is nothing heavier than compassion. Not even one's own pain weighs so heavy as the pain one feels with someone, for someone, a pain intensified by the imagination and prolonged by a hundred echoes.

paragraph1: During those two idyllic summers, I often found myself by the peaceful pool, a place that became engrained in my memories. One particular incident left a lasting impression: a seagull swooping down with startling precision to snatch a goby from the water's surface. The suddenness and raw power of nature left me gripped with an unfamiliar fear. Meanwhile, my mother's calls echoed from our home, yet I remained silent, choosing not to reveal my hiding spot. I was determined to be part of the serenity and mystery of the pool's world, maintaining stillness and silence as my companions.
paragraph2: Over the course of those two summers, one terrifying incident took place at the otherwise tranquil pool. A seagull plunged down from the heavens and skillfully caught a plump, hapless goby in its beak before soaring back up towards the sky. I have never forgotten the fear I felt in that moment.Every now and then my mother would call out for me from home.“Orhaaaaan! Ooooorrrhaaaaan!”I never replied, lest I should reveal my whereabouts. I wanted to belong to the world inside the pool, and so I would just wait there, quiet and motionless.

Paragraph 2:
Over the course of those two summers, one terrifying incident took place at the otherwise tranquil pool. A seagull plunged down from the heavens and skillfully caught a plump, hapless goby in its beak before soaring back up towards the sky. I have never forgotten the fear I felt in that moment.Every now and then my mother would call out for me from home.“Orhaaaaan! Ooooorrrhaaaaan!”I never replied, lest I should reveal my whereabouts. I wanted to belong to the world inside the pool, and so I would just wait there, quiet and motionless.

paragraph1: I sat beside him in that sterile room, the rhythmic beeping of medical equipment our constant, uninvited companion, while he lay there, all hooked up, his body still but his mind alive with curiosity. Over several days, I shared fragments of our life at Hailsham, each memory serving as a beacon in the encroaching fog of finality he faced. His questions were unrelenting, probing deeper with each retelling about favorite places on the grounds, the guardians who had shaped us in those formative years, and the silly games we devised in the idle afternoons. His eyes, once lively, now dulled by the weight of his impending "completion," nevertheless sparked with an eagerness that urged me to repeat certain stories over and over, as if in recounting he could somehow make them his own, weaving them into the tapestry of his existence. It was as though by clutching to these borrowed memories, he might stave off the inevitable, keeping pieces of us alive within his fading self. Tommy and Ruth would occasionally filter into our reminiscences, brief apparitions of a shared youth now slipping further into the past. This ritual, this exchange of recollections, made me see our history in a new light—each moment at Hailsham was not merely a transient passage of time, but a precious trove of experiences that took on an almost sacred significance in his presence. To witness him imbuing each story with such profound importance compelled me to acknowledge, perhaps for the first time, the true fortune we had in having lived them.
paragraph2: So over the next five or six days, I told him whatever he wanted to know, and he'd lie there, all hooked up, a gentle smile breaking through. He'd ask me about the big things and the little things. About our guardians, about how we each had our own collection chests under our beds, the football, the rounders, the little path that took you all round the outside of the main house, round all its nooks and crannies, the duck pond, the food, the view from the Art Room over the fields on a foggy morning. Sometimes he'd make me say things over and over; things I'd told him only the day before, he'd ask about like I'd never told him. "Did you have a sports pavilion?" "Which guardian was your special favourite?" At first I thought this was just the drugs, but then I realised his mind was clear enough. What he wanted was not just to hear about Hailsham, but to remember Hailsham, just like it had been his own childhood. He knew he was close to completing and so that's what he was doinggetting me to describe things to him, so they'd really sink in, so that maybe during those sleepless nights, with the drugs and the pain and the exhaustion, the line would blur between what were my memories and what were his. That was when I first understood, really understood, just how lucky we'd been—Tommy, Ruth, me, all the rest of us.

paragraph1: Quichotte, a figure ensconced in solitude, had gradually retreated from the vibrant tapestry of social interaction, leaving a slender thread of friendships still intact. His connections to the wider world were tenuous, primarily comprising a sparse network of commercial travelers he occasionally encountered and a disparate group of individuals on Facebook. This collection of online acquaintances spanned from lonely hearts seeking connection to those sharing provocative content, each adding a peculiar flavor to his digital universe. Upon unveiling his latest grandiose endeavor involving Miss Salma R., Quichotte met with a chorus of skepticism from his online circle. What he viewed as an ambitious pursuit of love and fulfillment, they dismissed as the ravings of a man untethered from reality. Their collective disapproval was palpable in the virtual realm, taking shape through frown emojis, reproachful Bitmojis, and mocking GIFs featuring Salma R. herself, all designed to underscore the perceived insanity of his quest. Yet, standing firm against this tide of digital ridicule, Quichotte remained unfazed, resolutely clinging to his belief in the transformative power of his unlikely dream.
paragraph2: The truth was that Quichotte had almost no friends anymore—no social group, no cohort, no posse, no real pals—having long ago abandoned the social whirl. On his Facebook page, he had “friended” or “been friended by” a small and dwindling group of commercial travellers like himself, as well as by an assortment of lonely hearts, braggarts, exhibitionists, and salacious ladies behaving as erotically as the social medium’s somewhat puritanical rules allowed. Every single one of these quote-unquote “friends” saw his plan, when he had enthusiastically posted it, for what it was—a harebrained scheme, verging on lunacy—and attempted to dissuade him, for his own good, from stalking or harassing Miss Salma R. In response to his post there were frown emojis and Bitmojis wagging fingers at him reprovingly, and there were GIFs of Salma R. herself, crossing her eyes, sticking out her tongue, and rotating a finger by her right temple, all of which added up to the universally recognized set of gestures meaning “cray cray.” However, Quichotte would not be deterred.

paragraph1: Standing under the dim, flickering glow of the streetlamp, the night air wrapping around us like a cool whisper, I found myself deeply engaged in conversation with a man named Roger Button. It was late—one of those nights when the silence hums and time feels malleable—and we were perched together at a lonely bus stop, shrouded in uncertainty, questioning the arrival of the last bus of the night. Roger, with a comforting smile, assured me that it would eventually make its way down the dusky road. He painted vivid pictures of the journey ahead, describing the bus as a vessel of joy, filled with passengers whose spirits were as bright and warm as a summer's day. Their laughter, he promised, would be contagious, their stories engaging enough to make time fly like the wind. After we exchanged goodbyes, Roger ambled off into the shadows of the night, leaving a trail of his buoyant optimism behind. Alone, I set my bag carefully at the foot of a lamppost and stood in quiet anticipation, ears poised for the faint, hopeful rumble of an approaching vehicle. Roger's words had left me with a sense of calm, a newfound optimism about not just reaching the destination, but the welcoming reception awaiting at journey's end, a sentiment I clung to as the city sighed around me.
paragraph2: "It’s very late," I said. "Are you sure a bus will come?" "Oh, yes. Of course, you may have to wait. But eventually a bus will come." Then he touched me reassuringly on the shoulder. "I can see it might get a little lonely standing out here. But once the bus arrives your spirits will rise, believe me. Oh, yes. That bus is always a joy. It’ll be brightly lit up, and it’s always full of cheerful people, laughing and joking and pointing out the window. Once you board it, you’ll feel warm and comfortable, and the other passengers will chat with you, perhaps offer you things to eat or drink. There may even be singing—that depends on the driver. Some drivers encourage it, others don’t. Well, Fletcher, it was good to see you." We shook hands, then he turned and walked away. I watched him disappear into the darkness between two cottages.I walked up to the green and put my bag down at the foot of the lamppost. I listened for the sound of a vehicle in the distance, but the night was utterly still. Nevertheless, I had been cheered by Roger Button's description of the bus. Moreover, I thought of the reception awaiting me at my journey’s end—of the adoring faces of the young people—and felt the stirrings of optimism somewhere deep within me.

paragraph1: On a sunlit afternoon, Roland sat at his modest kitchen table, absently trailing the fork through his omelette, a dish that was more ritualistic necessity than culinary delight. The bright rays streaming through the window seemed at odds with the tangled emotions stirring within him. On the surface, everything appeared serene; the rhythmic clatter of dishes in the background, Roland's obligatory task. Yet, beneath this veneer of normalcy lay a profound yearning for liberation, an escape from the invisible chains that bound him. This dichotomy of freedom and constraint was magnified by the presence of "her," the pivotal figure who stood across the room, methodically ironing clothes. Her influence over Roland was indelible, shaping not only his day-to-day existence but also his deepest notions of love and loyalty. Raised under her watchful eye, Roland's perception of affection had been a skewed reflection of her ideals, unwittingly distorting his understanding of life's grander narrative. Now, as he chewed a tasteless bite of the omelette, a creeping suspicion nudged at the corners of his consciousness—that something vital had been denied to him, an awareness whose clarity would only emerge after many long years. This moment was a microcosm of Roland's life journey, an intricate dance of control, compliance, and the slow, unhurried awakening to his own suppressed truths. The afternoon's warm light, seemingly benign, only highlighted the shadows of realization that cloaked Roland’s heart.
paragraph2: It was another cloudless day. The low afternoon sun, well past the equinox, blazed through the glazed upper half of the kitchen door into the little sitting room and spilled across the table. As Roland ate his omelette, he felt again the insidious desire to be off, hurtling along the route he had in mind. Out of the question. He had already been told that while she ironed his clothes he would be washing the dishes. She had earned the right to tell him what to do. But she’d had it from the beginning.“What a relief,” she kept saying. “Aren’t you happy? You don’t look it.” “I am, honestly. It’s amazing. What a relief.”Thirty years later, he would understand the damage, how derailed his life was by her, how distorted his expectation of love. When he was twelve, she had touched and unwound a little coil in his being and, without having to do more, she had possessed him. Two years later, pursued by fear and childish vanity and incoherent desire, he had run to her. It would take him half a lifetime to frame it in such simple terms. But now, here at the sunlit lunch table, many layers below his outward decorum, and barely available to the ignorant boy, was a mere suspicion that he had been cheated of something. The world would go on, he would remain unvaporized. He needn’t have done a thing.

paragraph1: The Minister felt as if he were being carried by an unseen force as he approached the waiting plane, guided by the hands and voices surrounding him. Each step felt more like a motion directed by others than an act of his own volition, casting a shadow of detachment over his thoughts. His faith in the power of words waned, replaced by the understanding that, in this precise moment, only his actions held significance. As the stairs to the plane came within reach, the night sky shifted; a lone gray cloud swept over the moon, plunging the world into a brief, somber twilight. Suddenly, large raindrops crashed down, blurring the Minister's vision and muffling the hurried instructions shouted at him. The rain, however, ceased as abruptly as it had begun, the cloud drifted away, and moonlight cut through the darkness once more. Regaining his composure, the Minister clutched his suit bag tighter, collecting himself against the unexpected chill, and pressed on, attentively following the directives of his entourage without further hesitation.
paragraph2: "This way, Minister. This way.” So many people seemed to be touching the Minister, guiding him, advising him, that he felt as if he were not so much walking as being carried. He stopped trying to speak. What point was there in words? Actions, only actions. A few feet from the stairs to the plane, he became aware of a sudden change in the lightan impudent gray cloud between the Minister of the Interior and that fat beautiful moon. Large warm raindrops big as acorns fell on his nose, on his single shoe, on his lapel, on the world. Rain fell off the curve of the plane in torrential sheets, rain rioted on the cheap tin roof of the airport, soaking the Minister to the skin, making it even harder to hear instructions, and then, just as abruptly, stopped. The cloud moved on, the moon returned. The Minister held his elbow together. He pressed his suit bag to his chest. "This way, Minister, this way.” The Minister shut his mouth and followed.

paragraph1: Suddenly, it was all before him, the prospect of freedom, of working whenever he wanted, of inviting home some of the women he had seen on the Falmer campus, lolling on the steps outside the library, of returning to his unexamined self and being guiltlessly shot of Maisie. All this caused a tear of gratitude to roll down his cheek. He also felt fierce impatience for her to be gone. It crossed his mind to offer to drive her to the station now, but there were no trains from Lewes at 3 A.M., and she had not packed. Hearing his sob, she reached for the bedside light and, leaning over to look into his face, saw the dampness around his eyes. Firmly and deliberately she whispered, “I will not be blackmailed, Michael. I will not, repeat not, be emotionally manipulated by you into staying.”Was ever a marriage dissolved so painlessly? Within a week she had left for the hill farm in Powys. In the course of a year they exchanged a couple of postcards. Then one came from an ashram in India, where she remained for three years and from where she sent one day her cheery acceptance of a divorce, all papers duly signed. He did not see her until his twenty-sixth birthday, at which she appeared with a shaved head and a jewel in her nose. Many years later, he spoke at her funeral. Perhaps it was the ease of their parting in the old rectory that made him so incautious about marrying again, and again
paragraph2: Michael stood in the dimly lit room, his mind a tumultuous whirlwind of emotions at the collapse of his marriage to Maisie. He was caught in the crosscurrents of despair and an intoxicating sense of newfound freedom, the latter whispering promises of a life unshackled by the constraints he had felt so keenly in recent years. The idea of inviting other women home fluttered through his mind, alongside images of a carefree existence devoid of marital burdens. A single tear traced a path down his cheek, a rare drop of gratitude mingling with impatience, yearning for Maisie's departure to mark the beginning of this anticipated chapter. Anticipating her exit, Maisie, attuned to Michael's emotional turmoil, responded assertively, her hand flipping the light switch as she declared her refusal to be manipulated into staying. Their once-shared life unraveled with a startling swiftness, Maisie leaving for a hill farm in Powys merely a week later, and eventually journeying to an ashram in India. The years that followed saw little contact—just a sparse exchange of postcards, each message inching them toward the finality of divorce. The stark simplicity of their parting foreshadowed Michael’s future, an ease of separation that perhaps paved the way for multiple remarriages. On his twenty-sixth birthday, Maisie reappeared, transformed from the woman he had once known, marking a moment where past and present subtly collided, reminding him of the path he had chosen. This pivotal experience in Michael's life seemed to send ripples outward, influencing his subsequent attitudes towards relationships, marriage, and the nature of personal freedom.

paragraph1: At the close of a serene voyage, the ship's corridors were abuzz with discreet concern as Bob unexpectedly failed to settle his bill or collect his passport, a situation that piqued the quiet anxiety of the crew. Behind closed doors, a hushed meeting of staff unfolded, orchestrated to ensure the calm of oblivious passengers nestled in their cabins, with whispers of Bob's mysterious disappearance spreading like an undercurrent through the crew’s ranks. It was rumored that Bob had fallen off the ship while admiring the mesmerizing northern lights, camera in hand, though some wondered about the shadow of foul play lurking in the air. Among the passengers, Verna sat alone, contemplating her next move and whether her yet undefined plan would unfold as intended. She was caught in the waves of her own thoughts—thoughts tinged with an inexplicable exhaustion and a hollow sense of emptiness that gnawed at her, despite an odd sense of peace settling in her heart. Her mind drifted to the exasperating quirks of her third husband, who had a penchant for quoting Victorian poets at the most inopportune moments, although the particular bard’s name eluded her memory in that moment of reflection.
paragraph2: There will be a moment of truth at the end of the voyage, when Bob will not appear to pay his bill and pick up his passport; nor will he pack his bags. There will be a flurry of concern, followed by a staff meeting—behind closed doors, so as not to alarm the passengers. Ultimately, there will be a news itemBob, tragically, must have fallen off the ship on the last night of the voyage while leaning over to get a better camera angle on the northern lights. No other explanation is possible.Meanwhile, the passengers will have scattered to the winds, Verna among them. If, that is, she pulls it off. Will she or won’t she? She ought to care more about that—she ought to find it an exciting challenge—but right now she just feels tired and somewhat empty.Though at peace, though safe. Calm of mind all passion spent, as her third husband used to say so annoyingly after his Viagra sessions. Those Victorians always coupled sex with death. Who was that poet anyway? Keats? Tennyson? Her memory isn’t what it was. But the details will come back to her later.

paragraph1: As I stand in the club bathroom, I hear snippets of conversations drifting through the enclosed space, voices raw with emotion as women recount stories of being forsaken by men they insist were incapable of love. It's a common scene in this modern era, sparking a cascade of reflective thoughts within me on the nature of love and how society perceives it. There's this pervasive belief that every person is inherently lovable and entitled to receive love, but I question this assumption. Why do we hold romantic love in such high esteem, often judging those who find fulfillment in religion or spirituality as somehow inferior or lacking? These encounters make me challenge the narrative that everyone unconditionally deserves love. Isn't it more essential that everyone deserves the basics necessary for survival, like clean water, rather than an elusive emotional connection that society elevates? My reflections cast a critical eye on these deeply ingrained societal values, wondering if perhaps our priorities have drifted away from tangible needs towards idealistic romantic pursuits that may never be truly satisfied.
paragraph2: It's a funny thing about the modern world. You hear girls in the toilets of clubs saying, "Yeah, he fucked off and left me. He didn't love me. He just couldn't deal with love. He was too fucked up to know how to love me." Now, how did that happen? What was it about this unlovable century that convinced us we were, despite everything, eminently lovable as a people, as a species? What made us think that anyone who fails to love us is damaged, lacking, malfunctioning in some way? And particularly if they replace us with a god, or a weeping madonna, or the face of Christ in a ciabatta roll---then we call them crazy. Deluded. Regressive. We are so convinced of the goodness of ourselves, and the goodness of our love, we cannot bear to believe that there might be something more worthy of love than us, more worthy of worship. Greeting cards routinely tell us everybody deserves love. No. Everybody deserves clean water. Not everybody deserves love all the time.

paragraph1: On the night of January 20-21, an event once carved into my memory as an anniversary of sorts, I embarked on a journey that would redefine the contours of my existence. That night, an ordeal unfolded, a gauntlet of emotions and decisions forcing me to confront the latent shadows of guilt I harbored for my past inaction. It was a necessary sacrifice, an initiation into the arena of life where children—concepts wrapped in awe and trepidation—emerge not just in dreams but through the visceral vows of body and soul. The profound interplay of life and death, of societal whispers and personal truths, transformed before my eyes. In striving to give words to this primal experience, I found myself slowly untethering from the weight of inaction, my soul liberated through articulation. Perhaps my purpose transcended mere survival, evolving into a bridge between solitude and the collective human narrative. As I distill my essence into prose, a shared tapestry of understanding becomes woven from strands of both fear and acceptance, tightly binding the unique to the universal, the personal to the shared.
paragraph2: For many years I celebrated the night of January 20-21 as an anniversary.Now I know that this ordeal and this sacrifice were necessary for me to want to have children. To accept the turmoil of reproduction inside my body and, in turn, to let the coming generations pass through me.I have finished putting into words what I consider to be an extreme human experience, hearing on life and death, time, law, ethics and taboo ‒ an experience that sweeps through the body.I have rid myself of the only feeling of guilt in connection with this eventthe fact that it had happened to me and I had done nothing about it. A sort of discarded present. Among all the social and psychological reasons that may account for my past, of one I am certainthese things happened to me so that I might recount them. Maybe the true purpose of my life is for my body, my sensations and my thoughts to become writing, in other words, something intelligible and universal, causing my existence to merge into the lives and heads of other people.

paragraph1: For the old man lounging comfortably on the weathered bench in the bustling piazza, the cacophony of animated debates swirling around him served as an unexpected source of amusement and reflection. Once, in the distant past he fondly referred to as the "yes" years, he had longed for a world imbued with calm and collective agreement, where truth seemed as serene and unobtrusive as the gentle breeze sweeping through golden autumn leaves. However, age and wisdom imparted a new appreciation for the combative spirit of his fellow citizens, whose insistence on arguing every inconceivable point—ranging from asinine assertions about the sun making its grand daily entrance from the west to outrageously claiming cheese as the moon's origin story—filled his days with endless entertainment. It was the vanity of their certainty, the earnest conviction wrapped around fallacies like tender vines around fragile trellises, that amused him most. These debaters, each a modern-day Sisyphus, rolled their intellectual boulders up hills of unfounded certainty and let them tumble hilariously down paths of reason. In observing them, he found a gentle charm; these debates were not matters of life and death but exercises in the frivolity of thought, emphasizing humanity's innate desire to question, no matter how absurdly. And so, in the heart of this lively discourse, he discovered an unexpected harmony—a quiet, personal solace amidst the roaring tide of nonsensical eloquence.
paragraph2: Now that he has stopped missing the peace and quiet of the “yes” years, the old man has actually begun to enjoy the quarrelsomeness of his fellow-citizens. The vanity of certainty, which gives each finger-wagging debater his or her reason for her or his insistence on that or this dispute, strikes the old man as the very fons et origo of comedy. The fervor with which many people in the piazza hold opinions that are demonstrably untrue—the sun, madam, does not rise in the west, no matter how vehemently you may argue that it does, and, sir, the moon is not made of Gorgonzola cheese, and to say this is not to agree with your opponent, who describes it as an elaborate papier-mâché fake, nailed to the sky to make us believe that we live in a three-dimensional universe of stars, planets, and satellites, rather than upon a dish with a great lid over it, a lid like an inverted colander, with many holes through which, at night, shines the bright thing we have been deceived into calling starlight. The piazza is full of passionate nonsense such as this, and the old man thinks, Oh, let them go on, there’s no harm in it, after all.

paragraph1: That evening I thought about my father’s phone call from the night before, and how I had wanted to tell Nick about it, and for a moment I really thoughtI will call Nick and he will come back. Things like this can be undone. But I knew that he would never come back again, not really. He wasn’t only mine any more, that part was over. Melissa knew things that I didn’t know. After everything that had happened between them they still desired one another. I thought about her email, and about how I was sick and probably infertile anyway, and how I could give Nick nothing that would mean anything to him. For the next few days I stared at my phone for hours on end and accomplished nothing. The time moved past visibly on the illuminated onscreen clock and yet I still felt as though I didn’t notice it passing. Nick didn’t call me that evening, or that night. He didn’t call me the next day, or the day after that. Nobody did. Gradually the waiting began to feel less like waiting and more like this was simply what life wasthe distracting tasks undertaken while the thing you are waiting for continues not to happen. I applied for jobs and turned up for seminars. Things went on.
paragraph2: Every day feels like an endless loop of uncertainty and heartache as I find myself tangled in my thoughts about Nick, a name that lingers in the back of my mind like an uninvited guest who refuses to leave. As I sit in my room, staring at the fading paint on the wall, the phone rings, startling me. It's my father, calling with his familiar voice offering both comfort and a stark reminder of the contrast between my past and present. Our conversation shifts to banal topics, yet ends with my unspoken wish to fill the void inside me by reconnecting with Nick, even though I know that door has closed. He's moved on, finding solace in the arms of another—Melissa, a name I can't utter without tasting bitterness. Deep down, I grapple with a growing sense of inadequacy, convinced that perhaps I was never enough. Days pass by weighed down by an oppressive silence, each one filled with a persistent longing that feels both frantic and futile. I watch my phone obsessively, hoping for its shrill ring to signal a change, yet knowing it never will. Desperate to escape this self-imposed stasis, I throw myself into job applications and attend seminars, each activity a feeble attempt at normalcy, a distraction from the inevitable realization: I'm waiting for something that may never happen.

paragraph1: There is an urge to be good. To be seen to be good. To be seen. Also to be. Badness, invisibility, things as they are in reality as opposed to things as they seem, death itself—these are out of fashion. This is basically what I told Mary. I said, Mary, all these things I just mentioned are not really done anymore, and also, while we’re on the subject, that name of yours is not going to fly, nobody’s called Mary these days, it’s painful for me even to say your name—actually, could you get the hell out of here? Mary left. Scout came by—a great improvement. Scout is so involved and active. She is on all platforms, and rarely becomes aware of anything much later than, say, the three-hundredth person. By way of comparison, the earliest I’ve ever been aware of anything was that time I was the ten-million-two-hundred-and-sixth person to see that thing. There’s evidently a considerable gulf between Scout and me. But that’s why I am always so appreciative of her coming by and giving me news.
paragraph2: "They want us to be all shiny and perfect these days, don't they?" I mused aloud, looking at Mary. "Goodness is in style, and no one dares to show their true, flawed selves anymore." Mary, with her old-fashioned name, seemed perplexed, a relic of simpler times. "Mary is such a yesteryear name," I remarked, inadvertently stinging her with my words. With a sigh and a shake of her head, she left, leaving me alone until Scout entered the room, full of energy like a gust of wind. "Hey, what's the latest buzz?" I asked. I knew she'd be on top of things, never missing a beat across any platform. Scout was the epitome of what society celebrated now—active, dynamic, always trending. I envied her swiftness in catching waves of news when it seemed like I was dog-paddling in their aftermath. Her visits were a lifeline, a bridge to the outside world that shifted and evolved faster than I could manage. I cherished Scout for that glimpse into what mattered beyond my static bubble.

paragraph1: Generally, women can’t do this, but men retain the ancient ability to leave a family and a past. They just unhook themselves, like removing a fake beard, and skulk discreetly back into society, changed men. Unrecognizable. In this manner, a new Archie is about to emerge. We have caught him on the hop. For he is in a past-tense, future-perfect kind of mood. He is in a maybe this, maybe that kind of mood. Approaching a forked road, he slows down, checks his undistinguished face in the wing-mirror, and quite indiscriminately chooses a route he’s never taken before, a residential street leading to a place called Queens Park. Go straight pastGo!, Archie-boy, he tells himself; collect two hundred and don’t for gawd’s sake look back.
paragraph2: Archie stood at the proverbial fork in the road, grappling with the emotional complexity of leaving his past behind—a past he discarded like an old, worn mask. As he wrestled internally, the act of transformation hovered over him, creating a mélange of anticipation and uncertainty. His indistinct features reflected back at him from a nearby shop window, prompting a moment of introspection. Yet, embracing his new self, Archie committed to an uncharted path. He turned down the unfamiliar streets leading towards Queens Park—a destination that, for him, encapsulated potential and renewal. With a renewed sense of purpose, he was determined to move forward. Much like a player urged to advance in the game of Monopoly, Archie resolved to keep progressing, pushing himself onwards without a second glance at the life he had known, accepting the consequences of his arbitrary decision.

paragraph1: Standing before the bathroom mirror, she examined her reflection, the years etched lightly across her thirty-five-year-old face, a stark reminder of the passage of time and the shifting sands of trends and mores. It was the precipice of a new decade, one that promised to sweep society into uncharted waters, leaving her grappling with the feeling of being adrift, a relic of the eighties thrust into the uncertain embrace of the nineties. Though relatively young, the pervasive sensation of being out of step with the world gnawed at her spirit, igniting an introspective journey through her life’s landscape, littered with the ghosts of missed opportunities and roads not taken. Each decision, each path turned away from now reemerged in her mind like spectral signposts pointing toward what might have been. In the throes of a peculiar illness, a fever clinging to her skin like a stubborn mist, she eschewed the rational step of seeking medical guidance. Instead, drawn inexplicably to the living room, she perched herself cross-legged before the mantelpiece where Hairball resided in its glass prison. The object drew her in, its presence both comforting and peculiarly unsettling. The room hummed with an enigmatic buzzing, a sound resonant of bees, enveloping her in a cocoon of eerie introspection as she delved deeper into the labyrinth of her thoughts, questioning what might be reclaimed or renewed from the chapters of her life she still held dominion over.
paragraph2: She stares into the bathroom mirror, assesses her face in the misted glass. A face of the eighties, a mask face, a bottom-line face; push the weak to the wall and grab what you can. But now it’s the nineties. Is she out of style, so soon? She’s only thirty-five, and she’s already losing track of what people ten years younger are thinking. That could be fatal. As time goes by, she’ll have to race faster and faster to keep up, and for what? Part of the life she should have had is just a gap, it isn’t there, it’s nothing. What can be salvaged from it, what can be redone, what can be done at all?When she climbs out of the tub after her sponge bath, she almost falls. She has a fever, no doubt about it. Inside her, something is leaking, or else festering; she can hear it, like a dripping tap. A running sore, a sore from running so hard. She should go to the emergency ward at some hospital, get herself shot up with antibiotics. Instead, she lurches into the living room, takes Hairball down from the mantelpiece in its bottle, places it on the coffee table.She’s cross-legged, listens. Filaments wave. She can hear a kind of buzz, like bees at work.

Each decision, each path turned away from now reemerged in her mind like spectral signposts pointing toward what might have been. paragraph1: He knows that a lot of the literary people in college see books primarily as a way of appearing cultured. When someone mentioned the austerity protests that night in the Stag’s Head, Sadie threw her hands up and saidNot politics, please! Connell's initial assessment of the reading was not disproven. It was culture as class performance, literature fetishised for its ability to take educated people on false emotional journeys, so that they might afterwards feel superior to the uneducated people whose emotional journeys they liked to read about. Even if the writer himself was a good person, and even if his book really was insightful, all books were ultimately marketed as status symbols, and all writers participated to some degree in this marketing. Presumably this was how the industry made money. Literature, in the way it appeared at these public readings, had no potential as a form of resistance to anything. Still, Connell went home that night and read over some notes he had been making for a new story, and he felt the old beat of pleasure inside his body, like watching a perfect goal, like the rustling movement of light through leaves, a phrase of music from the window of a passing car. Life offers up these moments of joy despite everything.
paragraph2: Connell often finds himself observing the literary dynamics within his college environment, noticing a rather performative engagement with books by many of his peers. As he surveys this world, he sees people like Sadie, who seem to interact with literature more as a badge of cultural sophistication than out of any genuine appreciation for the art. An encounter at a social gathering underscores this notion: Sadie’s aversion to discussing politics strikes Connell as emblematic of a trend where literature serves as a kind of class performance. It permits individuals to claim an intellectual high ground, subtly elevating themselves above the very struggles and stories depicted in the texts they consume. Connell's keen eye catches the commercialization of literature, observing how the industry wraps books in a veneer of status symbols and reaps benefits from this cultural posture. Yet, amid these sometimes disheartening realizations, Connell finds solace and genuine pleasure in writing. For him, crafting narratives is akin to savoring life's small, tangible joys. Through the exploration of language and ideas, Connell perceives a deeper connection to both art and existence, a contrast to the superficial engagement he often witnesses. Despite the widespread inclination toward literary elitism, Connell remains anchored by his authentic passion for storytelling, which fuels his resilience and devotion to writing.

paragraph1: I go back to the hardware store and ask for a glue that’s good for ceramics. They give me a product that has superpowers, they say, that can make anything stick to anything else. Back at home, seated at my desk, I open the tube, follow the directions, and attach the slice to the rest of the cake. It sets instantly so that I can barely see the crack. It looks like a single folded hair. But when I close the tube I press it by mistake and a sizable clump of glue spurts out, covering my fingers, drying immediately, leaving a stubborn film on my skin. I wash my hands but that just makes matters worse. The water doesn’t rinse away the glue, and by now my fingers are sticking to one another as firmly as the slice to the rest of the cake. I look up and see myself in the mirror, weary, stiff hands coated with glue whose ghostly traces resemble the dust I’ve been working hard to get rid of all day, and after a long time, or maybe for the first time, I burst out laughing.
paragraph2: I strode into the hardware store, determined to find a remedy for my shattered ceramic cake. The employees, animated and enthusiastic, directed me to a glue that they claimed had "superpowers." It seemed too good to be true, yet intriguing enough to purchase. Back home, I approached the fractured cake with a blend of skepticism and hope. Following the instructions meticulously, I applied the glue with precision. Miraculously, the crack vanished, leaving only the faintest trace—a triumph of adhesive engineering. Elated, I celebrated my success with a little too much zeal, squeezing the tube tighter than intended. To my dismay, glue erupted onto my fingers, setting almost instantly. I rushed to the sink, scrubbing frantically, but the situation spiraled as my fingers transformed into sticky stalactites, stubbornly stuck together. Desperation turned to humor when I caught sight of my hands in the mirror. They were speckled with glue, resembling dusty artifacts unearthed from some ancient ruin. I couldn't help but laugh, unsure if it was out of sheer exasperation or amused resignation. My fingers, although temporarily bound, reminded me of the unpredictability and hilarity that sometimes accompany even the simplest of tasks.

paragraph1: Spring is a challenging time for me, with its promise of renewal ironically sapping my energy. The influx of spring light and the explosion of nature’s blooms seem to conspire against my senses, overwhelming me rather than refreshing me. Pollen fills the air, and each day begins with the ritual of a morning allergy pill, which unfortunately leaves me drowsy and unfocused—a kind of fog that intensifies as afternoon approaches. Adding to my discomfort, the erratic temperatures play a cruel trick; while the day can be uncomfortably warm, the nights often plunge into a cold that leaves me shivering. This season also stirs within me a deep-seated unease, as it is tightly interwoven with personal memories of loss and heartache. Each budding tree, each vibrant fruit in the market, seems to whisper stories of betrayal and disappointment. Today, though, is a Saturday, providing rare refuge from these discomforts. With no obligations pressing upon me, the mere act of staying indoors offers a quiet solace, making it the best part of my day.
paragraph2: In spring I suffer. The season doesn’t invigorate me, I find it depleting. The new light disorients, the fulminating nature overwhelms, and the air, dense with pollen, bothers my eyes. To calm my allergies I take a pill in the morning that makes me sleepy. It knocks me out, I can’t focus, and by lunchtime I’m tired enough to go to bed. I sweat all day and at night I’m freezing. No shoe seems right for this temperamental time of year.Every blow in my life took place in spring. Each lasting sting. That’s why I’m afflicted by the green of the trees, the first peaches in the market, the light flowing skirts that the women in my neighborhood start to wear. These remind me only of loss, of betrayal, of disappointment. I dislike waking up and feeling pushed inevitably forward. But today, Saturday, I don’t have to leave the house. I can wake up and not have to get up. There’s nothing better.
