paragraph1: As I stood at the edge of the Tongue River, the realization that my mother's wedding ring was lost forever hit me like an unanticipated wave. I had hoped that releasing this treasured piece into the water might bring some semblance of catharsis, a poetic letting go that would ease the ache of her absence. Instead, it carved another hollow notch into my heart, a harsh and blunt reminder of her irreplaceable presence now diminished further. I stood there, feeling the weight of the truth pressing down on me, the mingled silt of my grief settling in layers around my ankles. I was not ready to cope with the starkness of this new reality, yet I knew that I had no choice but to keep moving forward. Healing, as it turns out, is not a grand sweeping gesture but rather an accumulation of smaller, often painfully mundane steps. I slowly stood up, my joints protesting against the resistant truth, trudged back to my truck, and drove away. Each mile put between me and the river symbolized another small step in leaving behind a part of my mother who was not just my only true connection to love but the most sacred piece of love itself.
paragraph2: But this isn’t fiction. Sometimes a story is not about anything except what it is about. Sometimes you wake up and find that you actually have lost your nose. Losing my mother’s wedding ring in the Tongue River was not OK. I did not feel better for it. It was not a passage or a release. What happened is that I lost my mother’s wedding ring and I understood that I was not going to get it back, that it would be yet another piece of my mother that I would not have for all the days of my life, and I understood that I could not bear this truth, but that I would have to.Healing is a small and ordinary and very burnt thing. And it’s one thing and one thing onlyit’s doing what you have to do. It’s what I did then and there. I stood up and got into my truck and drove away from a part of my mother. The part of her that had been my lover, my wife, my first love, my true love, the love of my life.

paragraph1: He stood at the window of his childhood and looked out at the Arabian Sea. The moon was almost full; moonlight, stretching from the rocks of Scandal Point out to the far horizon, created the illusion of a silver pathway, like a parting in the water's shining hair, like a road to miraculous lands. He shook his head; could no longer believe in fairy-tales. Childhood was over, and the view from this window was no more than an old and sentimental echo. To the devil with it! Let the bulldozers come. If the old refused to die, the new could not be born. "Come along," Zeenat Vakil's voice said at his shoulder. It seemed that in spite of all his wrong-doing, weakness, guilt -- in spite of his humanity -- he was getting another chance. There was no accounting for one's good fortune, that was plain. There it simply was, taking his elbow in its hand. "My place," Zeeny offered. "Let's get the hell out of here." "I'm coming," he answered her, and turned away from the view.
paragraph2: As he stood at the window of his childhood home, gazing out at the vast expanse of the Arabian Sea, the man found himself momentarily entranced by the breathtaking moonlit view. The shimmering light formed a magical silver pathway across the water, evoking a sense of wonder reminiscent of bedtime stories and fairy tales he once passionately believed in as a child. Yet now, as an adult, he was starkly aware that fairy tales had no place in his reality, resigning the enchanting scene to a mere nostalgic echo of his past. His reverie was gently interrupted by Zeenat Vakil, whose presence beside him served as a reminder of the present moment. Her voice, though soft, carried the weight of urgency, urging him to leave behind this vestige of yesterday. He contemplated her words and the liberating notion of letting the past slip away to make room for a future brimming with possibilities. With a newfound resolve spurred by Zeenat's encouragement, he decided to seize the fresh opportunity life had presented, finally turning away from the window and stepping forward.

paragraph1: Sitting alone by the gentle murmurs of the river, I found myself engulfed in a meditative state that seemed to stretch through time, an introspective journey of repentance that finally dawned on me after years of silent guilt. As if participating in a sacred ritual, I plucked blades of grass meticulously, each representing a misguided act, a piece of my shadowed history slipping into the water’s embrace. Blue eye shadow stolen in a moment of vanity, fancy soaps taken for their elusive promise of elegance, a small dog figurine pocketed on a whim, a pretty sweater that once whispered warmth—all these items, reflected in fragile blades, drifted downstream, carrying my whispered words of forgiveness. With each blade released, I felt an unseen burden lift, the current washing away years of wrongdoing, fostering a burgeoning sense of genuine absolution.
paragraph2: Years after I stopped stealing things I was sitting alone by a river. As I sat looking at the water I found myself thinking about all the things I’d taken that didn’t belong to me and before I even knew what I was doing I began picking a blade of grass for each one and then dropping it into the water. I am forgiven, I thought as I let go of the blade that stood in for the blue eye shadow. I am forgiven, I thought for each of those fancy soaps. I am forgiven, for the dog figurine and the pretty sweater, and so on until I’d let all the bad things I’d done float right on down the river and I’d said I am forgiven so many times it felt like I really was.

paragraph1: Henry Perowne, a renowned surgeon, often finds himself under close examination by prospective patients who scrutinize his hands with intense focus during their initial consultations. These patients search for signs of a skilled practitioner, such as steady, sensitive, and unblemished hands, reflecting their hope and need for reassurance about the choice they contemplate making. For some, even the slightest imperfection or perceived tremor leads them to reconsider, marked by hesitant glances, shaky questions, and excessively polite farewells, indicating their decision to seek another surgeon. Others, despite their apprehensions, ultimately decide to stay with Perowne, swayed by his formidable reputation or perhaps driven by a simple indifference that overshadows their initial doubts. There are those, too, who, due to cognitive impairments, fail to notice his hands altogether. Despite this potential loss of patients, Perowne remains unperturbed, confident in the steady influx of patients with neurological issues who will inevitably seek his expertise, thereby ensuring that his practice continues uninterrupted.
paragraph2: Most people at their first consultation take a furtive look at the surgeon’s hands in the hope of reassurance. Prospective patients look for delicacy, sensitivity, steadiness, perhaps unblemished pallor. On this basis, Henry Perowne loses a number of cases each year. Generally, he knows it’s about to happen before the patient doesthe downward glance repeated, the prepared questions beginning to falter, the overemphatic thanks during the retreat to the door. Other patients don’t like what they see but are ignorant of their right to go elsewhere; some note the hands but are placated by the reputation, or don’t give a damn; and there are still others who notice nothing, or feel nothing, or are unable to communicate owing to the cognitive impairment that has brought them in the first place.Perowne himself is not concerned. Let the defectors go along the corridor or across town. Others will take their place. The sea of neural misery is wide and deep.

Henry Perowne, a renowned surgeon, often finds himself under close examination by prospective patients who scrutinize his hands with intense focus during their initial consultations. These patients search for signs of a skilled practitioner, such as steady, sensitive, and unblemished hands, reflecting their hope and need for reassurance about the choice they contemplate making. For some, even the slightest imperfection or perceived tremor leads them to reconsider, marked by hesitant glances, shaky questions, and excessively polite farewells, indicating their decision to seek another surgeon. Others, despite their apprehensions, ultimately decide to stay with Perowne, swayed by his formidable reputation or perhaps driven by a simple indifference that overshadows their initial doubts. There are those, too, who, due to cognitive impairments, fail to notice his hands altogether. Despite this potential loss of patients, Perowne remains unperturbed, confident in the steady influx of patients with neurological issues who will inevitably seek his expertise, thereby ensuring that his practice continues uninterrupted.

Paragraph 2:
Most people at their first consultation take a furtive look at the surgeon’s hands in the hope of reassurance. Prospective patients look for delicacy, sensitivity, steadiness, perhaps unblemished pallor. On this basis, Henry Perowne loses a number of cases each year. Generally, he knows it’s about to happen before the patient doesthe downward glance repeated, the prepared questions beginning to falter, the overemphatic thanks during the retreat to the door. Other patients don’t like what they see but are ignorant of their right to go elsewhere; some note the hands but are placated by the reputation, or don’t give a damn; and there are still others who notice nothing, or feel nothing, or are unable to communicate owing to the cognitive impairment that has brought them in the first place.Perowne himself is not concerned. Let the defectors go along the corridor or across town. Others will take their place. The sea of neural misery is wide and deep.

paragraph1: Leaving behind a homeland under Russian occupation, I remember the jarring yet liberating first weeks of our emigration, coinciding with an era when Stalinism was widely discredited. This global condemnation of his policies cast a "respectable sadness" over us, creating an empathetic space among strangers who understood the burden we carried. In Paris, I often found solace in the company of an intellectual, a kind-hearted and supportive soul who seemed to exist solely to help dissect the weighty themes of persecution and newfound freedom. As we sat surrounded by heavy tomes on philosophy and politics, I often tried to alleviate the gravity of our discussions with a humorous memory from the days before my escape. It was a time marked by daring yet comedic attempts to outwit the pervasive state surveillance; I had switched apartments and identities with a friend. This small act of rebellion existed not just to elude the ever-watchful eyes of the state police, but also to indulge my friend's insatiable romantic curiosity. With my identity as his newfound cloak, he romanced women, leaving me to orchestrate a seamless escape. As I sent farewell cards to women I'd never met—a contrived performance of a life left behind—he basked in the serendipitous freedom our little ruse provided.
paragraph2: I recall the early weeks of my emigration. As Stalinism had already been unanimously condemned, people readily understood the tragedy the Russian occupation meant for my country, and they saw me as wrapped in an aura of respectable sadness. I remember sitting at a bar with a Parisian intellectual who had given me much support and help. It was our first meeting in Paris, and I could see grand words hovering in the air above uspersecution, gulag, freedom, banishment from the homeland, courage, resistance, totalitarianism, police terror. Eager to drive off the kitsch of those solemn spectres, I started describing how the fact of being followed, of having police microphones in our apartments, had taught us the delectable art of the hoax. A friend and I had switched apartments, and names as well; he, a big womanizer who was regally indifferent to the microphones, had pulled off some of his finest exploits in my studio. Given that the trickiest moment in any amorous adventure is the breakup, my emigration worked out perfectly for himone fine day the girls and the ladies arrived to find the apartment locked and my name gone from the door, while I was sending off little farewell cards from Paris, with my own signature, to seven women I had never seen

paragraph1: In 1967, in the papers and on All India Radio, they started hearing about a place called Naxalbari. It was one of a string of villages in the Darjeeling District, a narrow corridor at the northern tip of West Bengal. Tucked into the foothills of the Himalayas, nearly four hundred miles from Calcutta, closer to Tibet than to Tollygunge.Most of the villagers were tribal peasants who worked on tea plantations and large estates. For generations, they’d lived under a feudal system that hadn’t substantially changed. They were manipulated by wealthy landowners. They were pushed off fields they’d cultivated, denied revenue from crops they’d grown.That March, when a sharecropper in Naxalbari tried to plow land from which he’d been illegally evicted, his landlord sent thugs to beat him. The police had refused to intervene. After this, groups of sharecroppers began retaliating. They started burning deeds and records that had cheated them. Forcibly occupying land.It wasn’t the first instance of peasants in the Darjeeling District revolting. But this time their tactics were militant. Armed with primitive weapons, carrying red flags, shouting “Long Live Mao Tse-tung.”
paragraph2: In 1967, the air around the village of Naxalbari, nestled in the Darjeeling District of West Bengal, India, buzzed with rising tensions as the marginalized reality of its tribal peasant populace took center stage. Predominantly employed on tea plantations and estates, these peasants, shackled by an enduring feudal system, found themselves ensnared in cycles of manipulation and exploitation by wealthy landowners. This longstanding inequity reached a boiling point when a sharecropper, attempting to reclaim his rightful land, was brutally attacked by thugs dispatched by his landlord, an incident that served as a catalyst for collective outrage and resistance. In a fervent stand against their oppressors, the sharecroppers began to orchestrate militant uprisings, discarding passivity for bold defiance. They set fire to the oppressive deeds tethering them to servitude and occupied lands that were once mere dreams of ownership. Their struggles and aspirations resonated with Maoist ideologies, a connection that was emblazoned in their carrying of red flags and the fervent chants that filled the air, signifying a newfound unity and determination to reclaim not only their land but their dignity and rights.

paragraph1: Over a quarter of a century ago she and Vernon had made a household for almost a year, in a tiny rooftop flat on the rue de Seine. There were always damp towels on the floor then, and cataracts of her underwear tumbling from drawers she never closed, a big ironing board that was never folded away, and in the one overfilled wardrobe dresses , crushed and shouldering sideways like commuters on the metro. Magazines, makeup, bank statements, bead necklaces, flowers, knickers, ashtrays, invitations, tampons, LPs, airplane tickets, high heeled shoes- not a single surface was left uncovered by something of Molly's, so that when Vernon was meant to be working at home, he took to writing in a cafe along the street. And yet each morning she arose fresh from the shell of this girly squalor, like a Botticelli Venus, to present herself, not naked, of course, but sleekly groomed, at the offices of Paris Vogue.
paragraph2: During a time marked by both creativity and disarray, Molly, a dedicated professional in the fashion industry, and her partner Vernon, shared a humble existence in a diminutive rooftop flat on the picturesque rue de Seine. Their living space, though charmingly located, was perpetually overwhelmed by a sea of Molly's belongings, each corner and surface buried under a collection of fashion essentials, glossy magazines, and an assortment of personal paraphernalia. Despite the seemingly intractable clutter, Molly managed to present herself with unwavering poise and immaculate style each morning as she departed for her prestigious position at Paris Vogue—a testament to her commitment and passion for fashion. The incessant disorder, however, proved an insurmountable obstacle for Vernon, whose attempts to work from the confines of their cramped abode were persistently thwarted. Consequently, he found solace and productivity in the ambient bustle of a nearby café, where the environment was more conducive to creativity than their chaotic apartment ever could be.

paragraph1: My middle sister Muneeza, now eleven, was entering her delinquent phase a little early. She was the true inheritor of my father’s black rage, and when she lost control it was terrible to behold. That summer she seemed to pick fights with my father on purpose; seemed prepared, at her young age, to test her strength against his. (I intervened in her rows with Abba only once, in the kitchen. She grabbed the kitchen scissors and flung them at me. They cut me on the thigh. After that I kept my distance.) As I witnessed their wars I felt myself coming unstuck from the idea of family itself. I looked at my screaming sister and thought how brilliantly selfdestructive she was, how triumphantly she was ruining her relations with the people she needed most. And I looked at my choleric, face-pulling father and thought about British citizenship. My existing Indian passport permitted me to travel only to a very few countries, which were carefully listed on the second right-hand page. But I might soon have a British passport and then, by hook or by crook, I would get away from him. I would not have this face-pulling in my life. At sixteen, you still think you can escape from your father. You aren’t listening to his voice speaking through your mouth, you don’t see how your gestures already mirror his; you don’t see him in the way you hold your body, in the way you sign your name. You don’t hear his whisper in your blood.
paragraph2: As I sit on the worn-out couch, observing the latest encounter unfold between Muneeza and our father, I can't help but feel a growing sense of unease. At eleven, Muneeza has already begun to channel an aggressive defiance that I never quite managed. This time, it erupted in a shocking crescendo; I still remember my sharp intake of breath as she hurled the kitchen scissors across the room, a lethal arc ending with them piercing my thigh. The sting lingered, a physical reminder of why I spent most of my days avoiding their clashes. Watching the tempest that our home life has become, I am more determined than ever to find a way out, away from the volatile shadows our father casts over us. I often dream of obtaining British citizenship, envisioning a life where his influence doesn't loom large, where I can redefine family away from the storm. Yet, beneath my youthful optimism lies a fear I rarely acknowledge: that his traits might run deeper in me than I'd care to admit. In the quiet moments, when the house finally settles after one of these familial tempests, I find myself wondering. Should I still believe in an escape that seems both impossibly close and infinitely far? Perhaps, with time, I will learn how to gently unravel the intertwined threads of our father in myself—if such a thing is even possible. Until then, I live in these observations, hoping for change while quietly fearing the legacy he might unknowingly pass on to us all.

paragraph1: Avie sat in the quiet of her small study, the soft glow of the desk lamp lending a gentle warmth to the room as she pondered the contents of a letter she had received many years ago from Grace during her first pregnancy. Grace’s words, penned in a shaky hand, revealed the turmoil of her post-college life, marked by health issues and anxiety that seemed to grip her when she had dropped out of college. A vivid image of her once vibrant friend haunted by nervy uncertainty filled Avie’s mind, as she remembered a disturbing dream she had shared with Grace, now eerily etched in the letter. Avie, in that moment years back, had been swept up in the vibrant whirlwind of her life’s new chapter, her thoughts wrapped tightly around the small yet all-consuming universe that pregnancy wove around her, leaving little room for contemplation of past collegiate exchanges. The remembrance of a deep conversation with Marsha about colitis flitted through her mind, a ghostly echo of past talks. Yet Grace’s pleading tone made her pause, and she had postponed replying. Wondering about Grace’s current state, Avie had tentatively brought it up with Royce, whose curt dismissal reminded her of cherished memories and lingering regrets.
paragraph2: When that first pregnancy was well advanced, around Christmas time, Avie had received a brief letter from Grace."I hear you are married and expecting. You may not have heard I have dropped out of college, due to some troubles I have had with my health and my nerves. I often think of our talks and particularly the dream you told me about. It still scares the daylights out of me. Love, Grace."Avie remembered then the conversation with Marsha. The colitis. The tone of Grace’s letter seemed off kilter, with some pleading note in it that made her put off answering. She herself was feeling quite happy at the time, full of practical concerns, light-years away from whatever stuff they had talked about in college. She didn’t know if she could ever find her way back there or find a way to talk to Grace as she was now. And later, of course, she got too busy.She asks Royce if he heard anything from Grace, ever."No. No. Why should I?" "I just thought." "No.""I thought you might have looked her up later on."Not a good idea."She has disappointed him. Prying. Trying to get at some spot of live regret right under the ribs. A woman.

paragraph1: Unlike the slog of other winter holidays spent with family, always arduous, P’s birthday, at the beginning of the New Year, was an unpredictable gathering, languorous and light. I looked forward to the commotion of the crowded house, the pots of water on the verge of boiling, the smartly dressed wives always ready to lend a hand in the kitchen. I waited for the first few glasses of prosecco before lunch to go to my head, sampled the various appetizers. Then I liked to join the other adults out on the patio for a little fresh air, to smoke a cigarette and comment on the soccer game the kids played without interruption in the yard.
paragraph2: Attending P's birthday party at the start of the New Year is a refreshing departure from the usual winter holiday gatherings with family, which often feel more like a chore than a celebration. Unlike those tedious affairs, P's party is a joyful occasion. I eagerly anticipate the lively atmosphere within the bustling house, where the kitchen teems with helpful wives, each contributing to the festive spirit. The thrill of sipping prosecco before lunch while sampling an array of appetizers adds to the day’s excitement. Eventually, I find myself on the patio with other adults, unwinding as we share cigarettes and lively conversations. We chat about everything from life to the uninterrupted soccer game the children eagerly play in the yard.

paragraph1: Reflecting on human nature, I find myself pondering the intricacies of our priorities, particularly how often they seem to skew towards personal relationships, even when larger issues like resource distribution and sustainable economics loom pressing on a global scale. It's fascinating, and admittedly frustrating, to recognize that our collective energies are so frequently absorbed by those closest to us—the familiar bonds of love, sex, and friendship. It seems that we're inherently inclined to care deeply for those we know, perhaps at the detriment of tackling broader, more critical challenges facing humanity. Yet, despite this apparent foolishness, there's something undeniably endearing about it. I find it enchanting and hope-provoking, suggesting perhaps that our capacity to prioritize love in its many forms is a testament to our endurable human spirit.
paragraph2: Maybe we're just born to love and worry about the people we know, and to go on loving and worrying even when there are more important things we should be doing. And if that means the human species is going to die out, isn't it in a way a nice reason to die out, the nicest reason you can imagine? Because when we should have been reorganising the distribution of the world's resources and transitioning collectively to a sustainable economic model, we were worrying about sex and friendship instead. Because we loved each other too much and found each other too interesting. And I love that about humanity, and in fact it's the very reason I root for us to survive - because we are so stupid about each other.

paragraph1: In the heart of a bustling city, the weight of religion and tradition loomed largely over Samad’s life like an ancient tapestry woven with intricate care, yet imbued with a subtle power that often defied modern understanding. Tradition, to Samad, was not just a relic of bygone eras but a living essence that encircled him, quietly shaping his actions and aspirations. This intangible force, which he both revered and resented, stood as a testament to his cultural identity and the origins from which he drew strength, even as he grappled with the constraints it imposed on his modern existence. For Samad, this age-old framework was akin to roots anchoring him to an ancestral soil rich with stories of struggle and salvation. Despite the internal decay he perceived within himself, symbolically captured by the thought that even the most persistent weeds maintain roots, he clung to the hope that these ties might deliver stability. However, his resolve was challenged as he found himself being metaphorically pulled from his roots by someone named Poppy Burt-Jones. Witnessing this struggle sparked in him a renewed, fervent desire to cultivate robust roots for his sons, hoping to secure their futures against the inevitable winds of change that life would unfurl upon them.
paragraph2: If religion is the opium of the people, tradition is an even more sinister analgesic, simply because it rarely appears sinister. If religion is a tight band, a throbbing vein and a needle, tradition is a far homelier concoctionpoppy seeds ground into tea; a sweet cocoa drink laced with cocaine; the kind of thing your grandmother might have made. To Samad, as to the people of Thailand, tradition was culture, and culture led to roots, and these were good, these were untainted principles. That didn’t mean he could live by them, abide by them or grow in the manner they demanded, but roots were roots and roots were good. You would get nowhere telling him that weeds too have tubers, or that the first sign of loose teeth is something rotten, something degenerate, deep within the gums. Roots were what saved, the ropes one throws out to rescue drowning men, to Save Their Souls. And the further Samad himself floated out to sea, pulled down to the depths by a siren named Poppy Burt-Jones, the more determined he became to create for his boys roots on shore, deep roots that no storm or gale could displace.

paragraph1: In this tangled web of societal perceptions, I find myself caught between fear and fascination, like a spider both loathed and revered; a peculiar paradox, navigating the murky waters of public intrigue as much an enigma to myself as to those who scrutinize me. Once simply part of the myriad social accomplishments and titles paraded as badges of honor—singer, actress—now I'm inexplicably adorned with the morbid moniker of "celebrated murderess." How such a grim label managed to entwine with my identity remains a mystery, yet it clings to me, casting shadows as persuasive and pungent as the scent of decaying flowers. The term "murderess" is an echo of danger, heavy with implications, infinitely more evocative than the straightforward brutality associated with "murderer." Its feminine suffix—so often seen as delicate, perhaps even nurturing—now twisted to wield a macabre elegance, intrigues me. I embrace this identity not from vanity or acceptance but a curious preference for its darkly poetic resonance. Where "murderer" lays bare blunt atrocity, "murderess" paints with a palette of complex allure, suggesting layers of secrecy and untold stories. So, in this grayed twilight between infamy and admiration, I continue to ponder my place, questioning how much of this guise is a mask and how much has seeped into my veins, becoming a part of who I am.
paragraph2: So here she is, and she must make the most of her social position and accomplishments, and although an object of fear, like a spider, and of charity as well, I am also one of the accomplishments. I come into the room and curtsy and move about, mouth straight, head bent, and I pick up the cups or set them down, depending; and they stare without appearing to, out from under their bonnets.The reason they want to see me is that I am a celebrated murderess. Or that is what has been written down. When I first saw it I was surprised because they say Celebrated Singer and Celebrated Poetess and Celebrated Spiritualist and Celebrated Actress, but what is there to celebrate about murder? All the same, Murderess is a strong word to have attached to you. It has a smell to it, that word--musky and oppressive, like dead flowers in a vase. Sometimes at night I whisper it over to myself. Murderess, Murderess. It rustles, like a taffeta skirt across the floor.Murderer is merely brutal. It's like a hammer, or a lump of metal. I would rather be a murderess than a murderer, if those are the only choices.

paragraph1: In the somber city of Alifbay, overwhelmed by a profound and pervasive sadness so deep that it has forgotten its own name, life drifts languidly against a backdrop of melancholy. Perched beside a desolate sea where glumfish swim listlessly, the city exudes a sorrowful air that lingers persistently, even beneath the azure expanse of welcoming skies. To compound this gloom, factories located to the north of the city tirelessly manufacture sadness in vast quantities, exporting this despondency to corners of the world near and far. Yet amidst this depressive tapestry, there resides a beacon of cheer in the form of Haroun, a jovial boy whose father is the renowned storyteller Rashid Khalifa. Rashid, often adored as the "Ocean of Notions" by enthusiasts and dismissed as the "Shah of Blah" by skeptics, injects life into their humble household with captivating stories. Alongside him, Soraya, Rashid's wife, laces her ethereal singing through their days, providing a harmonious soundtrack to their lives. However, this vibrant cocoon is not impervious to the encroaching tides of sadness enveloping the city. The hauntingly ominous silence that falls upon their home when Soraya suddenly ceases her singing signals the advent of underlying troubles, the echoes of which resonate deeply within the family. In this narrative, the third-person narrator does not remain detached, frequently interjecting with personal observations, as if to remind us of the omnipresent nature of this deep-seated despair. Such interjections add layers of complexity to the depiction of a city and family teetering on the brink of losing their grip on happiness, painting a poignant picture of how the city's gloom threatens to extinguish even the most radiant of spirits, a tragic testament to the far-reaching fingers of melancholy that define Alifbay.
paragraph2: There was once, in the country of Alifbay, a sad city, the saddest of cities, a city so ruinously sad that it had forgotten its name. It stood by a mournful sea full of glumfish, which were so miserable to eat that they made people belch with melancholy even though the skies were blue. In the north of the sad city stood mighty factories in which (so I’m told) sadness was actually manufactured, packaged and sent all over the world, which never seemed to get enough of it. Black smoke poured out of the chimneys of the sadness factories and hung over the city like bad news. And in the depths of the city, beyond an old zone of ruined buildings that looked like broken hearts, there lived a happy young fellow by the name of Haroun, the only child of the storyteller Rashid Khalifa, whose cheerfulness was famous throughout that unhappy metropolis, and whose never-ending stream of tall, short and winding tales had earned him not one but two nicknames. To his admirers he was Rashid the Ocean of Notions, as stuffed with cheery stories as the sea was full of glumfish; but to his jealous rivals he was the Shah of Blah. To his wife, Soraya, Rashid was for manyyears as loving a husband as anyone could wish for, and during these years Haroun grew up in a home in which, instead of misery and frowns, he had his father’s ready laughter and his mother’s sweet voice raised in song. Then something went wrong. (Maybe the sadness of the city finally crept in through their windows.) The day Soraya stopped singing, in the middle of a line, as if someone had thrown a switch, Haroun guessed there was trouble brewing. But he never suspected how much.

paragraph1: In the intricate tapestry of life, the choices we make, though seemingly simple, can ignite profound transformations. Consider the man who, with quiet resolve, decides not to invite his abusive mother to his wedding, safeguarding a day meant for joy. Or the woman who, breaking routine, attends a drawing class instead of succumbing to the endless hum of household chores, honoring her passions over mundane obligations. There's the writer who, recognizing the corrosive nature of envy, deliberately chooses restraint, nurturing his creative spirit untainted by comparison. A parent grapples with anger, not through explosive rage, but by embracing patience, modeling strength to the watching eyes of a child. These acts—a tapestry of conscious, deliberate gestures—illuminate paths of self-improvement for you and me. In choices, both grand and discreet, lies the essence of true change.
paragraph2: Real change happens on the level of the gesture. It’s one person doing one thing differently than he or she did before. It’s the man who opts not to invite his abusive mother to his wedding; the woman who decides to spend her Saturday mornings in a drawing class instead of scrubbing the toilets at home; the writer who won’t allow himself to be devoured by his envy; the parent who takes a deep breath instead of throwing a plate. It’s you and me standing naked before our lovers, even if it makes us feel kind of squirmy in a bad way when we do. The work is there. It’s our task. Doing it will give us strength and clarity. It will bring us closer to who we hope to be.

paragraph1: Each afternoon followed the familiar cadence for Habara and the woman he mysteriously called "Scheherazade." After their intimate encounter, she would recline beside him, weaving mesmerizing tales that transported him far beyond the confines of his self-imposed seclusion. Her stories, rich in detail and intrigue, echoed the timeless enchantment of "A Thousand and One Nights." Yet, unlike the historic queen, this modern Scheherazade faced no threats to her existence, nor did she linger until daylight to ensure her safety. Instead, she shared her narratives willingly, driven by a profound urge to connect with Habara and infuse his solitary life with a touch of magic and solace. For Habara, who spent his days perpetually indoors, these story-filled afternoons became sacred interludes of connection and possibility. In the confines of his private diary, he documented the essence of each narrative with cryptic notations, preserving her identity as a mysterious muse, a Scheherazade of his own, known only to him in the labyrinth of his solitude.
paragraph2: Each time they had sex, she told Habara a strange and gripping story afterward. Like Queen Scheherazade in “A Thousand and One Nights.” Though, of course, Habara, unlike the king, had no plan to chop off her head the next morning. (She never stayed with him till morning, anyway.) She told Habara the stories because she wanted to, because, he guessed, she enjoyed curling up in bed and talking to a man during those languid, intimate moments after making love. And also, probably, because she wished to comfort Habara, who had to spend every day cooped up indoors.Because of this, Habara had dubbed the woman Scheherazade. He never used the name to her face, but it was how he referred to her in the small diary he kept. “Scheherazade came today,” he’d note in ballpoint pen. Then he’d record the gist of that day’s story in simple, cryptic terms that were sure to baffle anyone who might read the diary later.

paragraph1: As I reflect on the nature of humanity, I'm struck by our innate tendency to prioritize love and relationships above all else. Despite the pressing global issues we face—like the fair distribution of resources and the dire need for sustainable economics—our focus seems stubbornly fixed on personal connections. This inclination, one might argue, is a potential harbinger of our extinction, yet I find something deeply endearing in this narrative. It is both our potential downfall and our saving grace. This obsession with each other, this relentless pursuit of love, makes me cautiously optimistic about our future. It’s a curious contradiction; our collective foolishness and self-interested focus might be how we ultimately persevere, ensuring our survival—not through grand gestures or sweeping reforms, but through the seemingly simple, yet profound human heart.
paragraph2: Maybe we're just born to love and worry about the people we know, and to go on loving and worrying even when there are more important things we should be doing. And if that means the human species is going to die out, isn't it in a way a nice reason to die out, the nicest reason you can imagine? Because when we should have been reorganising the distribution of the world's resources and transitioning collectively to a sustainable economic model, we were worrying about sex and friendship instead. Because we loved each other too much and found each other too interesting. And I love that about humanity, and in fact it's the very reason I root for us to survive - because we are so stupid about each other.

paragraph1: But the plan had to change. She was not well. At first, they thought it was nerves. The upheaval. The foolish fuss.Then the pains came. Pain whenever she took a deep breath. Pain under the breastbone and in her left shoulder. She ignored it. She joked about God punishing her for her amorous adventure and said that he, God, was wasting his time when she didn’t even believe in him.She had something called pericarditis. It was serious and she had ignored it to her peril. It was something she would not be cured of but could manage, with difficulty. She could never teach again. Any infection would be dangerous, and where is infection more rampant than in a schoolroom? It was Ray now who had to support her, and he took a job as a policeman in this small town called Maverley, just over the Grey-Bruce border. He didn’t mind the work and she didn’t mind, after a while, her semi-seclusion
paragraph2: Amidst the hustle and bustle of daily life, she first dismissed the unsettling whispers of her body as mere stress or trivial concerns, nothing more than fleeting discomforts that plagued everyone at some point. But the pain persisted, as if trying to tell her a story she refused to hear, until, finally, it was diagnosed as pericarditis, a condition that lay hidden beneath her casual disregard. The gravity of her illness shattered the fragile illusion of normalcy she had clung to, forcing her to confront the reality that her teaching career, once a source of joy and purpose, must be abandoned due to her vulnerability to infections. Her partner, Ray, embraced this unexpected shift with quiet determination, finding work as a policeman in Maverley, a small town that would now be the backdrop of their transformed lives. Through the lens of her experiences, the narrative captures their efforts to navigate this abrupt change, framing their journey of adaptation and resilience within the tender bounds of love and commitment.

paragraph1: In each apartment, there was also a locked glass cabinet displaying Chinese porcelains, teacups, silver sets, sugar bowls, snuffboxes, crystal glasses, rosewater pitchers, plates, and censers, which no one ever touched, although among them I sometimes found hiding places for miniature cars. There were unused desks inlaid with mother-of-pearl, turban shelves on which there were no turbans, and Japanese and Art Nouveau screens behind which nothing was hidden. There, in the library, gathering dust behind the glass, were my uncle’s medical booksin the twenty years since he’d immigrated to America, no one had touched them. To my childish mind, these rooms were furnished not for the living but for the dead.
paragraph2: As I wandered through the apartments, a sense of eerie stillness enveloped me, my youthful eyes drawn to the ornate decorations and furniture that seemed untouched by time. Each room whispered stories of a past era; a locked glass cabinet showcased an eclectic collection of treasures—delicate Chinese porcelains, fine teacups, and exquisite silver sets that gleamed under the dim light. Unused desks stood stoically, empty turban shelves echoed with silence, and decorative screens crafted elaborate illusions of privacy. Even my uncle's old medical books lined the shelves, unloved and unopened for over twenty years since his immigration to America. These rooms felt like mausoleums, more suited for the dead than the living, embodying a static world of forgotten echoes.

Paragraph 1:
In each apartment, there was also a locked glass cabinet displaying Chinese porcelains, teacups, silver sets, sugar bowls, snuffboxes, crystal glasses, rosewater pitchers, plates, and censers, which no one ever touched, although among them I sometimes found hiding places for miniature cars. There were unused desks inlaid with mother-of-pearl, turban shelves on which there were no turbans, and Japanese and Art Nouveau screens behind which nothing was hidden. There, in the library, gathering dust behind the glass, were my uncle’s medical booksin the twenty years since he’d immigrated to America, no one had touched them. To my childish mind, these rooms were furnished not for the living but for the dead.

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: Corrie moved through her morning with an unsettling sense of emptiness, a hollow ache settling in her chest as she mechanically dressed and wandered through the quiet rooms of her house. The familiar ritual of making coffee offered no comfort; she left the mug untouched, her hands unable to bridge the gap between her usual routine and the profound change she faced. Continuously, she attempted to reorient herself to the stark new reality that had descended upon her life, yet found herself adrift, grappling with the upheaval wrought by Sadie's sudden absence. Sadie's death loomed unspoken, an invisible barrier she wasn't ready to breach with him. In her solitude, Corrie realized the weight of the decision she held—the knowledge of Sadie's death was her secret to unveil. In those silent moments, she understood the magnitude of her choice, accepting the responsibility to shape their shared narrative and to shoulder the consequences of years entwined. Navigating back into the kitchen, Corrie moved with deliberate care, as if by careful action, she might impose a semblance of order onto her fractured world.
paragraph2: She gets up and quickly dresses and walks through every room in the house, introducing the walls and the furniture to this new idea. A cavity everywhere, most notably in her chest. She makes coffee and doesn’t drink it. She ends up in her bedroom once more, and finds that the introduction to the current reality has to be done all over again.But then there is a surprise. She is capable, still, of shaping up another possibility.If he doesn’t know that Sadie is dead he will just expect things to go on as usual. And how would he know, unless he is told? And who would he be told by, unless by Corrie herself?She could say something that would destroy them, but she does not have to.What a time it has taken her, to figure this out.And after all, if what they had—what they have—demands payment, she is the one who can afford to pay.When she goes down to the kitchen again she goes gingerly, making everything fit into its proper place.

paragraph1: Reflecting on my internal struggles, I find myself caught in a dichotomy. On one hand, there's a deep yearning for peace and quiet acceptance of those matters beyond my control, a simple surrender to the flow of life. On the other, there's an almost fervent urge to engage in a holy war, a spiritual "Jihad," not against others but within myself, to reconcile these contradictory desires. I understand that each of us walks along a path shaped by unique pasts, truths, and solutions, and it's this divergence that often seeds conflict among us. I grapple with uncertainty about what others expect of me. Should I speak in truths even if they might be uncomfortable, or stand firm in silence and contemplation? Perhaps neither will fully satisfy the diverse expectations I encounter. My solace lies in the hope of the Day of Resurrection, as foretold by the Prophet Muhammad, when all voices will be silenced, giving us all perhaps a much-needed respite. And so, with these thoughts, I politely excuse myself.
paragraph2: We are split people. For myself, half of me wishes to sit quietly with my legs crossed, letting the things that are beyond my control wash over me. But the other half wants to fight the holy war. Jihad! And certainly we could argue this out in the street, but I think, in the end, your past is not my past and your truth is not my truth and your solution — it is not my solution. So I do not know what it is you would like me to say. Truth and firmness is one suggestion, though there are many other people you can ask if that answer does not satisfy. Personally, my hope lies in the last days. The prophet Muhammad — peace be upon Him! — tells us that on the Day of Resurrection everyone will be struck unconscious. Deaf and dumb. No chit-chat. Tongueless. And what a bloody relief that will be. Now, if you will excuse me.

paragraph1: Mother died on Monday 7 April in the old people’s home attached to the hospital at Pontoise, where I had installed her two years previously. The nurse said over the phone“Your mother passed away this morning, after breakfast.” It was around ten o’clock.For the first time the door of her room was closed. The body had already been washed and a strip of gauze had been wrapped around her head and under her chin, pushing all the skin up around her eyes and mouth. A sheet covered her body up to her shoulders, hiding her hands. She looked like a small mummy. The cot sides had been taken down and left on either side of the bed. I wanted to slip her into the white nightdress with a crochet border that she had once bought for her own funeral. The nurse told me one of the staff would see to this and would also take the crucifix my mother kept in her bedside drawer and place it on her chest. The two screws that pinned the copper arms on to the cross were missing. The nurse wasn’t sure they could be replaced. It didn’t matter, I wanted her to have her crucix all the same. On the trolley stood the bunch of forsythia I had brought the day before. The nurse suggested I go straight to the administration office while they drew up an inventory of my mother’s personal belongings. She had very few things of her own left – a suit, a pair of blue summer shoes, an electric shaver.
paragraph2: Early in the morning, as the first hints of dawn gently painted the sky, the phone rang, its persistent voice piercing the stillness of the room. I answered it to hear the nurse’s calm yet solemn words informing me that my mother had passed away shortly after breakfast, in the care facility where she had spent her last days. The trip to the hospital in Pontoise felt surreal, like moving through a dense fog, each moment tinged with a profound sense of loss. Upon arrival, I was guided to the quiet room where her body rested. The room was heavy with the echo of silence, and there she lay, with gauze softly wrapped around her head, a sheet drawn up to her shoulders as if she were merely asleep. It was a poignant image, both haunting and peaceful. I found myself wanting to give her the dignity she deserved by dressing her in the nightdress she had carefully chosen for this inevitable farewell. Her bedside drawer had a small crucifix that needed to be placed on her chest, a testament of her faith. The nurse, a gentle presence, suggested I visit the administration office. I realized this was a step towards bringing closure and understanding of her last belongings, those few personal items she had kept with her till the end. The inventory echoed a simplicity that marked her life, a reminder of what truly remained after a lifetime, underscoring the notion that, in the end, our attachments are ephemeral.

paragraph1: Afterward, at tea in Shiva’s flat, I talked to my elder sister Kamla. We talked about Shiva as a child; we remembered how, shortly after we had moved to our own house, he had once swallowed a plum and had begun seriously to choke. Fortunately, our house was next door to a doctor’s office, and he was in attendance that afternoon. He swiftly attended to the matter. It was a small crisis, but we could still, my sister and I, after all these years, celebrate the little boy’s escape from death, as though it were something final.I said to Kamla, expecting some solace from her, "And now we have nothing." She said, "And now we have nothing." My sorrow lasted for two years. For two years I mentally dated everything, even the purchase of a book, by its distance from Shiva's death.
paragraph2: As we sat sipping tea in Shiva’s flat, I found solace in the gentle clinking of cups, a stark contrast to the emotional weight of our conversation. Kamla, my elder sister, brought up a childhood memory that lingered heavily in the air—a time when Shiva, as a mischievous boy, nearly met his end choking on a plum. A doctor’s timely intervention turned a potential tragedy into a family anecdote, but now, more than anything, it served as a painful reminder of Shiva’s mortality. I couldn't help but feel a hollow emptiness since Shiva's death, a sentiment Kamla echoed with a shared grief. In those quiet moments, we silently acknowledged our connected loss. I realized that the two years following his death had been filled with a profound sorrow, each calendar day marked by its proximity to that heart-wrenching event, an indelible timestamp on our lives.

paragraph1: What do we want from our mothers when we are children? Complete submission. Oh, it's very nice and rational and respectable to say that a woman has every right to her life, to her ambitions, to her needs, and so on--it's what I've always demanded myself--but as a child, no, the truth is it's a war of attrition, rationality doesn't come into it, not one bit, all you want from your mother is that she once and for all admit that she is your mother and only your mother, and that her battle with the rest of life is over. She has to lay down arms and come to you. And if she doesn't do it, then it's really a war, and it was a war between my mother and me. Only as an adult did I come to truly admire her--especially in the last, painful years of her life--for all that she had done to claw some space in this world for herself.
paragraph2: As a child, I viewed my relationship with my mother as an incessant war of attrition, born from my selfish, childlike desire for her complete attention and unwavering submission to my whims, entirely oblivious to her own needs, desires, and ambitions. I wanted her world to revolve around me, not realizing that she was a person apart with dreams and struggles of her own. She was, in my youthful eyes, the general in our domestic skirmishes, somehow always holding the line against my tireless demands, and yet I failed to see the truth of her resilience. Her refusals and quiet resistance seemed threatening, but in truth, they were the boundaries she set to retain some semblance of self amidst the chaos of motherhood. Now, as an adult, I admire her not only for her strength but for her unfaltering commitment to carve out her own space. Her spirit, especially evident in her later, more challenging years, has become a source of inspiration, a testament to the delicate balance she achieved.

paragraph1: But what is the sense in forever speculating what might have happened had such and such a moment turned out differently? One could presumably drive oneself to distraction in this way. In any case, while it is all very well to talk of 'turning points', one can surely only recognize such moments in retrospect. Naturally, when one looks back to such instances today, they may indeed take the appearance of being crucial, precious moments in one's life; but of course, at the time, this was not the impression one had. Rather, it was as though one had available a never-ending number of days, months, years in which to sort out the vagaries of one's relationship with Miss Kenton; an infinite number of further opportunities in which to remedy the effect of this or that misunderstanding. There was surely nothing to indicate at the time that such evidently small incidents would render whole dreams forever irredeemable.
paragraph2: As I reflect on the intricacies of my past relationship with Miss Kenton, I find myself ensnared in the fruitless exercise of pondering what might have been had certain moments unfolded differently. In the realms of my past, there were instances that seemed trivial but upon reflection emerge as pivotal junctures—crossroads where the paths chosen have indelibly shaped the direction of my life. My mind often wanders back to those interactions laden with misunderstandings and missed opportunities, moments that seemed insignificant, yet now carry the weight of regret. The folly of presuming an endless abundance of time cloaked the decisions made then, lending a misguided confidence that loose ends could be tied at one's leisure, emotions reconciled and truths finally spoken. Yet, time has a cruel way of revealing its scarcity, snapping shut the window of possibilities before one is fully aware. I am left sifting through these memories, aware of the futility of rearranging a past already etched in stone.

paragraph1: There was a time when I could travel England for weeks on end and remain at my sharpest—when, if anything, the travelling gave me an edge. But now that I am older I become disoriented more easily. So it was that on arriving at the village just after dark I failed to find my bearings at all. I could hardly believe I was in the same village in which not so long ago I had lived and come to exercise such influence.There was nothing I recognized, and I found myself walking forever around twisting, badly lit streets hemmed in on both sides by the little stone cottages characteristic of the area. The streets often became so narrow I could make no progress without my bag or my elbow scraping one rough wall or another. I persevered nevertheless, stumbling around in the darkness in the hope of coming upon the village square—where I could at least orient myself—or else of encountering one of the villagers. When after a while I had done neither, a weariness came over me, and I decided my best course was just to choose a cottage at random, knock on the door, and hope it would be opened by someone who remembered me.
paragraph2: As I stand at the edge of the village, the damp air clinging to my skin, I reflect on how my ability to navigate these familiar places has changed with age. There was a time when traveling through England invigorated me, when each cobblestone and bending lane felt like a promise of discovery, but now I find myself disoriented and bewildered in the very village I once knew intimately and had even influenced significantly. I wander through the narrow, poorly lit streets, the stone cottages looming like silent, indifferent sentinels, and I struggle to recognize the nuanced details that once guided me so effortlessly to the heart of the village, the square where life used to unfold in vivid, comforting patterns. My mind races, questioning whether the village has changed or if it is I who have altered so much. Each turn feels fruitless, and with each moment, my energy wanes, leaving me exhausted and disheartened by my inability to find my bearings in a place that should have felt like home. Admitting my defeat and with a glimmer of hope, I decide to knock on the door of a random cottage, a gentle rap echoing in the chilly air, hoping against hope that someone familiar, who remembers the person I once was, might open the door.

paragraph1: Connell often finds himself observing the literary dynamics within his college environment, noticing a rather performative engagement with books by many of his peers. As he surveys this world, he sees people like Sadie, who seem to interact with literature more as a badge of cultural sophistication than out of any genuine appreciation for the art. An encounter at a social gathering underscores this notion: Sadie’s aversion to discussing politics strikes Connell as emblematic of a trend where literature serves as a kind of class performance. It permits individuals to claim an intellectual high ground, subtly elevating themselves above the very struggles and stories depicted in the texts they consume. Connell's keen eye catches the commercialization of literature, observing how the industry wraps books in a veneer of status symbols and reaps benefits from this cultural posture. Yet, amid these sometimes disheartening realizations, Connell finds solace and genuine pleasure in writing. For him, crafting narratives is akin to savoring life's small, tangible joys. Through the exploration of language and ideas, Connell perceives a deeper connection to both art and existence, a contrast to the superficial engagement he often witnesses. Despite the widespread inclination toward literary elitism, Connell remains anchored by his authentic passion for storytelling, which fuels his resilience and devotion to writing.
paragraph2: He knows that a lot of the literary people in college see books primarily as a way of appearing cultured. When someone mentioned the austerity protests that night in the Stag’s Head, Sadie threw her hands up and saidNot politics, please! Connell's initial assessment of the reading was not disproven. It was culture as class performance, literature fetishised for its ability to take educated people on false emotional journeys, so that they might afterwards feel superior to the uneducated people whose emotional journeys they liked to read about. Even if the writer himself was a good person, and even if his book really was insightful, all books were ultimately marketed as status symbols, and all writers participated to some degree in this marketing. Presumably this was how the industry made money. Literature, in the way it appeared at these public readings, had no potential as a form of resistance to anything. Still, Connell went home that night and read over some notes he had been making for a new story, and he felt the old beat of pleasure inside his body, like watching a perfect goal, like the rustling movement of light through leaves, a phrase of music from the window of a passing car. Life offers up these moments of joy despite everything.

paragraph1: "This way, Minister. This way.” So many people seemed to be touching the Minister, guiding him, advising him, that he felt as if he were not so much walking as being carried. He stopped trying to speak. What point was there in words? Actions, only actions. A few feet from the stairs to the plane, he became aware of a sudden change in the lightan impudent gray cloud between the Minister of the Interior and that fat beautiful moon. Large warm raindrops big as acorns fell on his nose, on his single shoe, on his lapel, on the world. Rain fell off the curve of the plane in torrential sheets, rain rioted on the cheap tin roof of the airport, soaking the Minister to the skin, making it even harder to hear instructions, and then, just as abruptly, stopped. The cloud moved on, the moon returned. The Minister held his elbow together. He pressed his suit bag to his chest. "This way, Minister, this way.” The Minister shut his mouth and followed.
paragraph2: The Minister felt as if he were being carried by an unseen force as he approached the waiting plane, guided by the hands and voices surrounding him. Each step felt more like a motion directed by others than an act of his own volition, casting a shadow of detachment over his thoughts. His faith in the power of words waned, replaced by the understanding that, in this precise moment, only his actions held significance. As the stairs to the plane came within reach, the night sky shifted; a lone gray cloud swept over the moon, plunging the world into a brief, somber twilight. Suddenly, large raindrops crashed down, blurring the Minister's vision and muffling the hurried instructions shouted at him. The rain, however, ceased as abruptly as it had begun, the cloud drifted away, and moonlight cut through the darkness once more. Regaining his composure, the Minister clutched his suit bag tighter, collecting himself against the unexpected chill, and pressed on, attentively following the directives of his entourage without further hesitation.

paragraph1: Junpei sat at his cluttered desk, staring intently at the blank page before him, his fingers poised over the keyboard. This time, he was weaving the intricate tale of Kirie, a woman whose life seemed inexorably intertwined with a peculiar, kidney-shaped stone. While initially intending to portray Kirie's struggles as primarily internal, Junpei found that the stone was inexplicably altering the course of his story each night. It appeared as though Kirie, or perhaps a deeper aspect of her psyche, was subtly steering the narrative into surreal and unforeseen territories he had not planned on exploring. His original vision had been to craft a straightforward psychological tale of Kirie ultimately breaking away from a married surgeon, a man whose presence in her life both complicated and constrained her. This detachment, he believed, would align her real-life actions with her unconscious desires. Yet, as Junpei wrote, he realized that the story's trajectory was continuously shifting, driven by the enigmatic power of Kirie's own inner self and the mystical movements of the elusive stone.
paragraph2: The dark kidney-shaped stone now controls the greater part of her life.Surely the stone is not an object that has come to her from withoutJunpei becomes aware of this as his story progresses. The main point is something inside herself. Something inside herself is activating the kidney-shaped stone and urging her to take some kind of action. It keeps sending her signals for that purpose—signals in the form of the stone’s nightly movements.While he writes, Junpei thinks about Kirie. He senses that she (or something inside her) is propelling the story; it was never his intention to write something so divorced from reality. What Junpei had imagined vaguely beforehand was a more tranquil, psychological story line. In that story line, rocks did not take it upon themselves to move around.Junpei imagined that the doctor would cut her ties to the married surgeon. She might even come to hate him. This was probably what she had been seeking all along, unconsciously.

paragraph1: In the city of Sikri, an ethereal atmosphere envelops the landscape as dawn breaks, unveiling its sandstone palaces that seem to materialize from the red smoke of the early morning. The astonishing architecture, shrouded in the swirls of mist, gives Sikri the illusory quality of a mirage gently aborning, a reflection of dreams instead of stones. As the sun ascends, its relentless heat distorts the boundaries of reality, bending the borders between sanity and madness. This surreal environment leaves its mark on all residents, influencing even the mighty Emperor Akbar, who starts to see his court filled with ethereal queens of spectral allure. Among these apparitions is Jodha, a wife created by the emperor’s vivid imagination, yet she holds more sway over him than his corporeal consorts. The existence of Jodha, as a vivid figment, is accepted without question by those surrounding Akbar, a testament to their reverence or perhaps their own blurring perceptions in the intoxicating haze of Sikri. This acceptance reflects the profound reach of the city’s dreamlike essence, where the boundaries between the real and the unreal are lovingly dissolved in the brilliant light of Akbar’s reign.
paragraph2: At dawn the haunting sandstone palaces of the new “victory city” of Akbar the Great looked as if they were made of red smoke. Most cities start giving the impression of being eternal almost as soon as they are born, but Sikri would always look like a mirage. As the sun rose to its zenith, the great bludgeon of the day’s heat pounded the flagstones, deafening human ears to all sounds, making the air quiver like a frightened blackbuck, and weakening the border between sanity and delirium, between what was fanciful and what was real.Even the Emperor succumbed to fantasy. Queens floated within his palaces like ghosts, Rajput and Turkish sultanas playing catch-me-if-you-can. One of these royal personages did not really exist. She was an imaginary wife, dreamed up by Akbar in the way that lonely children dream up imaginary friends, and in spite of the presence of many living, if floating, consorts, the Emperor was of the opinion that it was the real queens who were the phantoms and the nonexistent beloved who was real. He gave her a name, Jodha, and no man dared gainsay him.

paragraph1: What if I forgave myself? I thought. What if I forgave myself even though I'd done something I shouldn't have? What if I was a liar and a cheat and there was no excuse for what I'd done other than because it was what I wanted and needed to do? What if I was sorry, but if I could go back in time I wouldn't do anything differently than I had done? What if I'd actually wanted to fuck every one of those men? What if heroin taught me something? What if yes was the right answer instead of no? What if what made me do all those things everyone thought I shouldn't have done was what also had got me here? What if I was never redeemed? What if I already was?
paragraph2: Reflecting on my journey, I often find myself tangled in the web of my past actions, questioning where forgiveness, both from others and myself, truly lies. My history is not without blemishes—times marked by lies, deceit, and succumbing to temptations with various men, choices fueled by desires and needs that seem, in hindsight, all too transient. The haze of drug use only clouds the lines further, blurring the separation between who I am and who I was. Guilt claws at me relentlessly, yet a whisper of self-acceptance urges me to embrace every fragment of my history. I am constantly navigating this landscape of regret, pondering if redemption is an eventual destination or if perhaps, despite my missteps, it has been woven into the fabric of my journey all along.

What if I already was?

paragraph1: Doree and Maggie had established a weekly routine that revolved around the simple, yet meaningful, act of grocery shopping together after retrieving their children's school papers. Usually followed by their children, the task had become a bonding ritual that deepened their friendship. Occasionally, their outings extended to Riverside Park, where their kids would unleash their energy on the playground, allowing Doree and Maggie to take a moment for themselves. Weather permitting, they would watch from a park bench, but if it was too chilly, they retreated to the warmth of Maggie’s mini. As their children played, their conversations flowed as naturally as a winding river, anchored by discussions about their children and the latest culinary explorations. Yet, within these exchanges, layers of personal histories emerged. Maggie regaled Doree with tales from her youthful adventures in Europe before settling into her career as an optometrist, while Doree unveiled stories of her early marriage. Doree admitted her initial comfort with pregnancy before confiding her husband's, Lloyd's, troubling suspicions about her fertility struggles. Each story threaded between them stitched a fabric of understanding that strengthened their connection, evolving their grocery outings into a cherished tradition.
paragraph2: Doree and Maggie got into the habit of shopping for groceries together, after they’d picked up the papers at the school. Then sometimes they got take-out coffees at Tim Horton’s and took the children to Riverside Park. They sat on a bench while Sasha and Maggie’s boys raced around or hung from the climbing contraptions, and Barbara Ann pumped on the swing and Dimitri played in the sandbox. Or they sat in the mini, if it was cold. They talked mostly about the children, and things they cooked, but somehow Doree found out about how Maggie had trekked around Europe before training as an optometrist and Maggie found out how young Doree had been when she got married. Also about how easily she had become pregnant at first, and how she didn’t so easily anymore, and how that made Lloyd suspicious, so that he went through her dresser drawers looking for birth-control pills—thinking she must be taking them on the sly.

paragraph1: Life in these circumstances becomes, in a small way, a constant gamble and an anxiety. We all learn to live with it. And, in fact, after much coming and going we at last found someone suitable for my father’s house. Jo was a country girl, but very much up to the minute, single, with a couple of children, dually fathered, if that is grammatically possible, who brought her quite a tidy sum every week. She spoke of people being of “good stock,” and she seemed to suggest that after her early mistakes she was striving for higher things.This didn’t impress me. I took it as a mark of criminality. I have known criminals all my professional life, and in my experience this is how criminals like to present themselves. But I was wrong about this woman. She stayed, and was good and reliable. She was in her thirties, educated, able to write reasonably well, an elegant dresser (buying stylish things cheap from mail-order firms), and her manners were good. She stayed for six, seven, eight years. She became a fixture. I began—almost—to take her for granted.
paragraph2: When Jo first stepped into my father's life—a modern country girl with a straightforward manner and two children from different fathers—I couldn't help but feel skeptical. My life's work involved constant interactions with those society deems criminal, leaving me suspicious of anyone who talked of "good stock" or chasing betterment. Such ambitions often masked underlying inconsistencies or intentions, at least from my experience. To my surprise, though, Jo defied every preconceived notion I held. Far from the troublesome type, she turned out to be as dependable as clockwork, an educated individual with manners far surpassing my initial expectations. Over time, her presence wove into the fabric of our lives. She became more than just an employee; she became an essential part of the household, offering stability where it was sorely needed. The children, too, became fixtures in our family tapestry, blurring the lines between employer and friend. Jo's decency and diligence reminded me that sometimes, aspirations are simply expressions of resilience and hope rather than red flags for dubious behavior. Embracing Jo taught me the profound lesson that character often transcends our biases, waiting patiently to be recognized.

paragraph1: Being a man of reason, Ibn Rushd did not guess that the girl was a supernatural creature, a jinnia, of the tribe of female jinna grand princess of that tribe, on an earthly adventure, pursuing her fascination with human men in general and brilliant ones in particular. He took her into his cottage as his housekeeper and lover, and in the muffled night she whispered her “true”—that is to say, false—Jewish name into his ear, and that was their secret. Dunia the jinnia was as spectacularly fertile as her prophecy had implied. In the two years, eight months, and twenty-eight days and nights that followed, she was pregnant three times and brought forth a multiplicity of children, at least seven on each occasion, it would appear, and on one occasion eleven, or possibly nineteen; the records are vague. All the children inherited her most distinctive featurethey had no earlobes.If Ibn Rushd had been a scholar of the occult arcana, he would have realized then that his children were the offspring of a non-human mother, but he was too wrapped up in himself to work it out.
paragraph2: In a quiet town, where reason was held in high esteem yet untouched by the mystical, lived Ibn Rushd, a rational intellectual consumed by the pursuit of knowledge. Unbeknownst to him, his housekeeper and lover, Dunia, harbored a secret—a jinnia masquerading as an ordinary woman. Driven by her fascination with intelligent human men, Dunia adopted a false identity, presenting herself under a "Jewish" name. For two years and eight months, she shared her life with Ibn Rushd, immersing herself in the everyday normalcy he believed in. During this period, her supernatural nature subtly manifested through an extraordinary fertility, one that seemed to defy the natural order. She bore child after child, each inheriting her unique lack of earlobes, a trait peculiar yet unnoticed by Ibn Rushd. His unwavering attention to his studies blinded him to the anomaly nestled within his family. Thus, he remained oblivious to the fact that the bizarre absence of earlobes—a detail so small but significant—should have sparked curiosity beyond the mundane. In this house, the extraordinary thrived in plain sight, an irony lost on a man devoted to logic and reason, too absorbed to question the mysteries lurking beneath his own roof.

Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
Being a man of reason, Ibn Rushd did not guess that the girl was a supernatural creature, a jinnia, of the tribe of female jinna grand princess of that tribe, on an earthly adventure, pursuing her fascination with human men in general and brilliant ones in particular. He took her into his cottage as his housekeeper and lover, and in the muffled night she whispered her “true”—that is to say, false—Jewish name into his ear, and that was their secret. Dunia the jinnia was as spectacularly fertile as her prophecy had implied. In the two years, eight months, and twenty-eight days and nights that followed, she was pregnant three times and brought forth a multiplicity of children, at least seven on each occasion, it would appear, and on one occasion eleven, or possibly nineteen; the records are vague. All the children inherited her most distinctive featurethey had no earlobes.If Ibn Rushd had been a scholar of the occult arcana, he would have realized then that his children were the offspring of a non-human mother, but he was too wrapped up in himself to work it out.

Paragraph 2:
In a quiet town, where reason was held in high esteem yet untouched by the mystical, lived Ibn Rushd, a rational intellectual consumed by the pursuit of knowledge. Unbeknownst to him, his housekeeper and lover, Dunia, harbored a secret—a jinnia masquerading as an ordinary woman. Driven by her fascination with intelligent human men, Dunia adopted a false identity, presenting herself under a "Jewish" name. For two years and eight months, she shared her life with Ibn Rushd, immersing herself in the everyday normalcy he believed in. During this period, her supernatural nature subtly manifested through an extraordinary fertility, one that seemed to defy the natural order. She bore child after child, each inheriting her unique lack of earlobes, a trait peculiar yet unnoticed by Ibn Rushd. His unwavering attention to his studies blinded him to the anomaly nestled within his family. Thus, he remained oblivious to the fact that the bizarre absence of earlobes—a detail so small but significant—should have sparked curiosity beyond the mundane. In this house, the extraordinary thrived in plain sight, an irony lost on a man devoted to logic and reason, too absorbed to question the mysteries lurking beneath his own roof.

paragraph1: Remember the first time we kissed? he said. At the party. And I said I didn’t think the utility room was a good place to be kissing and we left. You know I went up to my room and waited for you, right? I mean for hours. And at first I really thought you would come. It was probably the most wretched I ever felt in my life, this kind of ecstatic wretchedness that in a way I was practically enjoying. Because even if you did come upstairs, what then? The house was full of people, it’s not like anything was going to happen. But every time I thought of going back down again I would imagine hearing you on the stairs, and I couldn’t leave, I mean I physically couldn’t. Anyway, how I felt then, knowing that you were close by and feeling completely paralysed by it, this phone call is very similar. If I told you where my car is right now, I don’t think I’d be able to leave, I think I would have to stay here just in case you
paragraph2: Reflecting on that evening, I remember the moments we shared, like a shrouded secret held within the dim confines of the utility room at the party. The air was heavy with anticipation, and yet, I couldn’t shake off the feeling that the space was not befitting such a delicate, significant moment as our first kiss. As I stepped out, hoping to retain a measure of decorum, I waited in my room, each passing hour drawing out a symphony of hope and despair in equal measure. My heart was a metronome, ticking anxiously, as I perched on the edge of expectancy, straining to hear the faintest of footsteps that might herald your arrival. Time stretched thin, like a rope pulled taut, binding my will to move. Even now, echoing that immobilized state, a mere phone call brings a similar tempest of emotion. It shadows me with a longing to locate my car, knowing that if I did, it would root me to the spot again. It’s as though my heart and will are entangled in a silent dance with my desire for you, a persistent echo of a night suspended in memory.
