paragraph1: The girl embarked on a solitary quest, a journey unlike any other, driven by an inexplicable yearning to find her own face. Laden with the weight of this unique pursuit, she borrowed a temporary visage to blend in among the people she encountered, wary of appearing too odd in a world that valued familiarity over the unknown. Her travels led her through a tapestry of diverse and breathtaking landscapes—over towering, craggy mountains, across the serene yet treacherous ripples of mighty rivers, through vast, scorching deserts, and into the chaotic, vibrant depths of unyielding jungles. Each step of her journey held its own peril, a trial of endurance and courage, leaving her teetering on the brink of disaster more times than she could recall. She narrowly escaped the thundering stampede of elephants by a hair’s breadth, felt the menace of a lurking spider poised to strike, and survived the violent kick of wild horses driven to frenzy. Driving this relentless odyssey was a silent cry for self-discovery, narrated through a kaleidoscope of third-person storytelling, interspersed with intimate, introspective glimpses into her yearning heart. Time became an unyielding force, transforming her from a hopeful girl into a weary woman, her despair deepening as her own reflection continued to elude her, each borrowed face just a hollow shell that offered no solace, no recognition in the mirror of her soul.
paragraph2: So the girl decided to set out alone on a face-seeking journey. For the time being, she found a face that would fit her, and pasted it on where her own face should be. Without a face of some kind, people she met along the way would find her strange.The girl walked all over the world. Climbed high mountains, crossed deep rivers, walked across vast deserts, managed to make her way through savage jungles. She was sure that if she came across her face she’d recognize it right away. Since this is a very important part of my existence, she told herself. As she travelled, she met many people, and had all kinds of odd experiences. She was nearly trampled by a herd of elephants, was attacked by a huge black spider, was almost kicked by wild horses.A long time passed as she walked everywhere, examining countless faces as she went, yet she never found her own face. What she saw were always the faces of others. She didn’t know what to do. And before she knew it she was no longer a girl but an adult woman. Would she never be able to find her own face again? She fell into despair.

paragraph1: As I sit beside the fountain, watching the dancers spin and twirl in a symphony of movement, I feel as if a translucent barrier separates me from them—a pane of glass that reflects back my own solitude. Once, the simplicity of my life allowed me to dive into the whirlpool of experiences, leading me to believe I had lived many lives simultaneously. Yet, an unsettling incident has seared into my consciousness—a day when "Soul Brother" was painted outside my door, a cryptic message amid whispered rumors of violence. This made me question my connections with the world. I used to feel part of the collective river that carried the joys and sorrows of others, but a single glimpse in the mirror snapped me into another reality. That moment of self-awareness triggered a longing for freedom. Ironically, this freedom now magnifies my awareness of the physical and mundane responsibilities I must carry until my days' final tick.
paragraph2: I am a simple man who decided to act and see for himself, and it is as though I have had several lives. I do not wish to add to these. Some afternoons I walk to the circle with the fountain. I see the dancers but they are separated from me as by glass. Once, when there were rumours of new burnings, someone scrawled in white paint on the pavement outside my houseSoul Brother. I understand the words; but I feel, brother to what or to whom? I was once part of the flow, never thinking of myself as a presence. Then I looked in the mirror and decided to be free. All that my freedom has brought me is the knowledge that I have a face and have a body, that I must feed this body and clothe this body for a certain number of years. Then it will be over.

That moment of self-awareness triggered a longing for freedom. Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: When I first took up English teaching after university, it seemed a good enough life—much like an extension of university. Language schools were mushrooming all over Europe, and if the teaching was tedious and the hours exploitative, at that age you don’t care too much. You spend a lot of time in bars, friends are easy to make, and there’s a feeling you’re part of a large network extending around the entire globe. You meet people fresh from their spells in Peru or Thailand, and this gets you thinking that if you wanted to, you could drift around the world indefinitely, using your contacts to get a job in any faraway corner you fancied. And always you’d be part of this cosy, extended family of itinerant teachers, swapping stories over drinks about former colleagues, psychotic school directors, eccentric British Council officers. In the late ’80s, there was talk of making a lot of money teaching in Japan, and I made serious plans to go, but it never worked out. I thought about Brazil too, even read a few books about the culture and sent off for application forms. But somehow I never got away that far. Southern Italy, Portugal for a short spell, back here to Spain. Then before you know it, you’re forty-seven years old, and the people you started out with have long ago been replaced by a generation who gossip about different things, take different drugs and listen to different music.
paragraph2: After graduating from university, I dove headfirst into a career as an English teacher, feeling like I was still basking in the university lifestyle, even though it was cloaked in more tedious work and extended hours. The social aspect of teaching was invigorating, with friendships blossoming effortlessly. I was part of a global network of wandering teachers; each meeting was alive with tales of travels and dreams of teaching in exotic places like Japan and Brazil. Despite the grandiose visions, life took me on unexpected adventures through Southern Italy, Portugal, and Spain. Each location enriched my understanding and respect for the vastness of cultures we inhabit. Initially, it all seemed like a grand celebratory extension of my younger, carefree days, but the reality of it all gradually settled in. The years accumulated stealthily, and suddenly I found myself realizing I had aged amidst classrooms and student essays, witnessing a subtle yet palpable shift. The new wave of teachers I encountered appeared to bring with them modern, vibrant interests that didn’t quite align with mine, marking a divergence in both my social and professional circles. Those carefree, camaraderie-driven discussions evolved into more solitary reflections on my journey. It became clear that, while the external environment advanced rapidly, my internal compass was subtly guiding me on a quieter path, one where the allure of youthful wanderlust blended with the introspective wisdom of experience.

When I first took up English teaching after university, it seemed a good enough life—much like an extension of university. Language schools were mushrooming all over Europe, and if the teaching was tedious and the hours exploitative, at that age you don’t care too much. You spend a lot of time in bars, friends are easy to make, and there’s a feeling you’re part of a large network extending around the entire globe. You meet people fresh from their spells in Peru or Thailand, and this gets you thinking that if you wanted to, you could drift around the world indefinitely, using your contacts to get a job in any faraway corner you fancied. And always you’d be part of this cosy, extended family of itinerant teachers, swapping stories over drinks about former colleagues, psychotic school directors, eccentric British Council officers. In the late ’80s, there was talk of making a lot of money teaching in Japan, and I made serious plans to go, but it never worked out. I thought about Brazil too, even read a few books about the culture and sent off for application forms. But somehow I never got away that far. Southern Italy, Portugal for a short spell, back here to Spain. Then before you know it, you’re forty-seven years old, and the people you started out with have long ago been replaced by a generation who gossip about different things, take different drugs and listen to different music.

Paragraph 2:
After graduating from university, I dove headfirst into a career as an English teacher, feeling like I was still basking in the university lifestyle, even though it was cloaked in more tedious work and extended hours. The social aspect of teaching was invigorating, with friendships blossoming effortlessly. I was part of a global network of wandering teachers; each meeting was alive with tales of travels and dreams of teaching in exotic places like Japan and Brazil. Despite the grandiose visions, life took me on unexpected adventures through Southern Italy, Portugal, and Spain. Each location enriched my understanding and respect for the vastness of cultures we inhabit. Initially, it all seemed like a grand celebratory extension of my younger, carefree days, but the reality of it all gradually settled in. The years accumulated stealthily, and suddenly I found myself realizing I had aged amidst classrooms and student essays, witnessing a subtle yet palpable shift. The new wave of teachers I encountered appeared to bring with them modern, vibrant interests that didn’t quite align with mine, marking a divergence in both my social and professional circles. Those carefree, camaraderie-driven discussions evolved into more solitary reflections on my journey. It became clear that, while the external environment advanced rapidly, my internal compass was subtly guiding me on a quieter path, one where the allure of youthful wanderlust blended with the introspective wisdom of experience.

where `preference` should be "1" if you think Paragraph 1 is better, "2" if you think Paragraph 2 is better.

paragraph1: Maybe we're just born to love and worry about the people we know, and to go on loving and worrying even when there are more important things we should be doing. And if that means the human species is going to die out, isn't it in a way a nice reason to die out, the nicest reason you can imagine? Because when we should have been reorganising the distribution of the world's resources and transitioning collectively to a sustainable economic model, we were worrying about sex and friendship instead. Because we loved each other too much and found each other too interesting. And I love that about humanity, and in fact it's the very reason I root for us to survive - because we are so stupid about each other.
paragraph2: As I reflect on the nature of humanity, I'm struck by our innate tendency to prioritize love and relationships above all else. Despite the pressing global issues we face—like the fair distribution of resources and the dire need for sustainable economics—our focus seems stubbornly fixed on personal connections. This inclination, one might argue, is a potential harbinger of our extinction, yet I find something deeply endearing in this narrative. It is both our potential downfall and our saving grace. This obsession with each other, this relentless pursuit of love, makes me cautiously optimistic about our future. It’s a curious contradiction; our collective foolishness and self-interested focus might be how we ultimately persevere, ensuring our survival—not through grand gestures or sweeping reforms, but through the seemingly simple, yet profound human heart.

paragraph1: When I’m driving and the Beatles song “Yesterday” comes on the radio, I can’t help but hear those crazy lyrics Kitaru crooned in the bath. And I regret not writing them down. The lyrics were so weird that I remembered them for a while, but gradually my memory started to fade until finally I had nearly forgotten them. All I recall now are fragments, and I’m not even sure if these are actually what Kitaru sang. As time passes, memory, inevitably, reconstitutes itself.When I was twenty or so, I tried several times to keep a diary, but I just couldn’t do it. So many things were happening around me back then that I could barely keep up with them, let alone stand still and write them all down in a notebook. And most of these things weren’t the kind that made me think, Oh, I’ve got to write this down. It was all I could do to open my eyes in the strong headwind, catch my breath, and forge ahead.
paragraph2: When "Yesterday" by the Beatles fills the airwaves, it transports me back to a chapter of my life intertwined with both laughter and nostalgia. I can almost hear Kitaru's quirky yet heartfelt rendition of the song echoing through the walls, his voice mingling with the splashes of bathwater. This whimsical medley, long gone and carried only in fragments of my mind, evokes a sense of longing for the past. Regret tugs at me, a gentle reminder of the ephemerality of memory; how I wish I had captured those tender moments in writing before they faded like morning mist. It reminds me of my earlier attempts to maintain a diary during my twenties, a time of incessant hustle and elusive events. I struggled then, as I do now, to document everything. Life moved faster than my pen could capture, and hindsight magnifies what I let slip through. Memories, it seems, are as fleeting as they are selective, reconstructed by the narrative we tell ourselves over time.

paragraph1: My mother died thirty years ago today. When I woke this morning I lay in bed thinking about that morning three decades ago, when I ran into her hospital room and found her dead. Too late to say goodbye, I clutched her body to mine and said it anyway. Goodbye, Mom. Goodbye, Mom. Goodbye.I am always with you, is what’s written on the tombstone my family and I laid on the spot of ground in the woods in northern Minnesota where we scattered her ashes. Before she died, she told me that’s what she wanted it to say because she wanted us—my brother, sister and me—to know it was true. Nothing distressed my mother more in her dying than the fact that she was leaving her children motherless. The only thing that gave her comfort was believing that she’d loved us hard enough that we’d feel her with us forever.“But I want you actually with me!” I remember protesting, weeping, begging. As if we could negotiate. As if lung cancer and I could make a deal.Thirty years gone and my mother is always with me. Thirty years gone and I still ache for her every day. Thirty years gone and my sorrow has sweetened into gratitude. How lucky I am to have been her daughter. To still be. To feel her shimmering in my bones with every step.
paragraph2: Thirty years have passed since that life-altering morning when I awoke to the numb realization that my mother—my rock, my comfort—had slipped away into the beyond, leaving a gaping chasm in our lives. Every detail of that day remains etched in my mind with vivid clarity, like a painting drawn in hues of grief and bewilderment. I raced into the sterile hospital room, my heart pounding, only to find her already gone—a gentle, unyielding stillness enveloping her. I clutched her body, whispering farewells through tears, grappling with the finality that shut its door on any last words or touches. My siblings and I were torn to shreds, each fragment struggling to find peace in the aftermath of a loss so profound it shook the very foundations of our lives. Yet somehow, amid our despair, we found solace in the inscription she had chosen for her tombstone—a gentle promise of her unwavering presence, her spirit forever interwoven with ours. In those early days, I recall the desperation in my heart, an unyielding, childlike wish for her to remain, fending off illness and fate. Time, however, has a way of reshaping sorrow, and while my heart still aches, I've learned to embrace this enduring bond—forever grateful for the privilege of being her child, cherishing our connection that transcends the boundaries of life and death.

paragraph1: So the girl decided to set out alone on a face-seeking journey. For the time being, she found a face that would fit her, and pasted it on where her own face should be. Without a face of some kind, people she met along the way would find her strange.The girl walked all over the world. Climbed high mountains, crossed deep rivers, walked across vast deserts, managed to make her way through savage jungles. She was sure that if she came across her face she’d recognize it right away. Since this is a very important part of my existence, she told herself. As she travelled, she met many people, and had all kinds of odd experiences. She was nearly trampled by a herd of elephants, was attacked by a huge black spider, was almost kicked by wild horses.A long time passed as she walked everywhere, examining countless faces as she went, yet she never found her own face. What she saw were always the faces of others. She didn’t know what to do. And before she knew it she was no longer a girl but an adult woman. Would she never be able to find her own face again? She fell into despair.
paragraph2: The girl embarked on a solitary quest, a journey unlike any other, driven by an inexplicable yearning to find her own face. Laden with the weight of this unique pursuit, she borrowed a temporary visage to blend in among the people she encountered, wary of appearing too odd in a world that valued familiarity over the unknown. Her travels led her through a tapestry of diverse and breathtaking landscapes—over towering, craggy mountains, across the serene yet treacherous ripples of mighty rivers, through vast, scorching deserts, and into the chaotic, vibrant depths of unyielding jungles. Each step of her journey held its own peril, a trial of endurance and courage, leaving her teetering on the brink of disaster more times than she could recall. She narrowly escaped the thundering stampede of elephants by a hair’s breadth, felt the menace of a lurking spider poised to strike, and survived the violent kick of wild horses driven to frenzy. Driving this relentless odyssey was a silent cry for self-discovery, narrated through a kaleidoscope of third-person storytelling, interspersed with intimate, introspective glimpses into her yearning heart. Time became an unyielding force, transforming her from a hopeful girl into a weary woman, her despair deepening as her own reflection continued to elude her, each borrowed face just a hollow shell that offered no solace, no recognition in the mirror of her soul.

paragraph1: Your friend Eric called me flat-chested today in front of everyone.Connell paused. She felt his breathing. I didn’t hear that, he said. You were in the bathroom or somewhere. He said I looked like an ironing board.Fuck's sake, he's such a prick. Is that why you're in a bad mood? She shrugged. Connell put his arms around her belly. He's only trying to get on your nerves, he said. If he thought he had the slightest chance with you, he would be talking very differently. He just thinks you look down on him. She shrugged again, chewing on her lower lip.You have nothing to worry about with your appearance, Connell said.Hm.I don’t just like you for your brains, trust me.She laughed, feeling silly.He rubbed her ear with his nose and addedI would miss you if you didn’t want to see me anymore. Would you miss sleeping with me? she said. He touched his hand against her hipbone, rocking her back against his body, and said quietlyYeah, a lot. Can we go back to your house now? He nodded. For a few seconds they just stood there in stillness, his arms around her, his breath on her ear. Most people go through their whole lives, Marianne thought, without ever really feeling that close with anyone.
paragraph2: Connell listened intently as Marianne recounted the discomforting incident involving Eric, one of Connell's friends, who had thoughtlessly insulted her by calling her flat-chested in front of their peers. Although Connell hadn't been present to witness the incident, he felt a flicker of frustration at Eric's insensitivity, mingled with concern for Marianne's feelings. In an effort to console her, Connell tenderly assured Marianne that Eric's flippant remarks held no truth about her worth or beauty, emphasizing qualities far beyond mere physical appearance. Embracing her gently, Connell whispered assurances and praises, refuting the careless words that had momentarily wounded her. As they held each other, the comfortable silence between them began to speak volumes about their relationship—a depth and understanding that few could claim. Their conversation soon turned inward, exploring their own emotions and the uncertain paths that lay before them. Through whispered words and lingering touches, they reaffirmed a bond that transcended superficial judgments and societal measures, revealing an intimacy that, Marianne mused quietly to herself, was rare and precious. In that shared moment, with questions about their futures and a mutual acknowledgment of their feelings, Marianne realized the profound rarity of their connection, acknowledging that such closeness was not only exceptional but a cherished anomaly in their lives.

paragraph1: "What are you saying, princess? How can our love wither? Isn't it stronger now than when we were foolish young lovers?""But Axl, we can't even remember those days. Or any of the years between. We don't remember our fierce quarrels or the small moments we enjoyed and treasured. We don't remember our son or why he's away from us.""We can make all those memories come back, princess. Besides, the feeling in my heart for you will be there just the same, no matter what I remember or forget. Don't you feel the same, princess?""I do, Axl. But then again I wonder if what we feel in our hearts today isn't like these raindrops still falling on us from these soaked leaves above, even though the sky itself long stopped raining. I'm wondering if without our memories, there's nothing for it but our love to fade and die.""God wouldn't allow such a thing, princess." Axl said this quietly, almost under his breath, for he had himself felt an unnamed fear welling up within him.
paragraph2:
AXL: My dearest, don't let the shadows of forgotten times cloud your heart. Our love, it'll always remain steady, like the ever-beckoning lighthouse amidst a storm, don't you think? Even without the pictures of our yesterdays, I feel it—stronger, unwavering.

PRINCESS: Axl, I understand your confidence, but can a love truly thrive without its roots? Memories are the soil from which love blossoms. Without them, isn't it like raindrops sliding off leaves, dissolving back to nothingness? How do we hold onto something so fleeting?

AXL: But that's just it, my love. Perhaps our hearts know a truth our minds can't recall. Love, in its purest form, transcends our shared stories. It's there—ever-present, beneath the surface, like stars hidden by daily sunlight.

[AXL, privately musing] But what if she's right? These fears gnaw at me, echoing in the quiet of my mind. Uncertainty trails me like a fading shadow; I have to stay hopeful, for both our sakes.

PRINCESS: I want to believe this, Axl. I truly do.

You are given two pararaphs of creative writing for a given writing instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
Thirty years have passed since that life-altering morning when I awoke to the numb realization that my mother—my rock, my comfort—had slipped away into the beyond, leaving a gaping chasm in our lives. Every detail of that day remains etched in my mind with vivid clarity, like a painting drawn in hues of grief and bewilderment. I raced into the sterile hospital room, my heart pounding, only to find her already gone—a gentle, unyielding stillness enveloping her. I clutched her body, whispering farewells through tears, grappling with the finality that shut its door on any last words or touches. My siblings and I were torn to shreds, each fragment struggling to find peace in the aftermath of a loss so profound it shook the very foundations of our lives. Yet somehow, amid our despair, we found solace in the inscription she had chosen for her tombstone—a gentle promise of her unwavering presence, her spirit forever interwoven with ours. In those early days, I recall the desperation in my heart, an unyielding, childlike wish for her to remain, fending off illness and fate. Time, however, has a way of reshaping sorrow, and while my heart still aches, I've learned to embrace this enduring bond—forever grateful for the privilege of being her child, cherishing our connection that transcends the boundaries of life and death.

Paragraph 2:
My mother died thirty years ago today. When I woke this morning I lay in bed thinking about that morning three decades ago, when I ran into her hospital room and found her dead. Too late to say goodbye, I clutched her body to mine and said it anyway. Goodbye, Mom. Goodbye, Mom. Goodbye.I am always with you, is what’s written on the tombstone my family and I laid on the spot of ground in the woods in northern Minnesota where we scattered her ashes. Before she died, she told me that’s what she wanted it to say because she wanted us—my brother, sister and me—to know it was true. Nothing distressed my mother more in her dying than the fact that she was leaving her children motherless. The only thing that gave her comfort was believing that she’d loved us hard enough that we’d feel her with us forever.“But I want you actually with me!” I remember protesting, weeping, begging. As if we could negotiate. As if lung cancer and I could make a deal.Thirty years gone and my mother is always with me. Thirty years gone and I still ache for her every day. Thirty years gone and my sorrow has sweetened into gratitude. How lucky I am to have been her daughter. To still be. To feel her shimmering in my bones with every step.

paragraph1: A person is nothing but his image. Philosophers can tell us that it doesn't matter what the world thinks of us, that nothing matters but what we really are. But philosophers don't understand anything. As long as we live with other people, we are only what other people consider us to be. Thinking about how others see us and trying to make our image as attractive as possible is considered a kind of dissembling or cheating. But does there exist another kind of direct contact between my self and their selves except through the mediation of the eyes? Can we possibly imagine love without anxiously following our image in the mind of the beloved? When we are no longer interested in how we are seen by the person we love, it means we no longer love.
paragraph2: I've often found myself contemplating the complex tapestry of identity and how intertwined it is with the perceptions others hold of us. Philosophers might argue that our true essence should remain unshaken by public opinion, but I can't help but question this idea. As social beings, we naturally navigate a world rich with interpretations, where our very existence feels linked to how others see us. It makes me ponder whether we can ever truly know each other without the filters of appearance and preconceived notions. This interplay becomes especially poignant in matters of love. Isn't it crucial to consider how our loved ones perceive us? To me, love demands an investment in the image we project. Indifference towards how we're viewed by someone dear might even suggest an absence of affection. Hence, I wrestle with balancing self-perception against the myriad external lenses through which I am viewed.

paragraph1: Aidan carefully closed the car door behind him and placed his bag on the ground, his mind preoccupied with thoughts of a woman whose presence seemed to weave in and out of his life like an enigmatic breeze. He couldn't quite pinpoint her connection to Declan, his brother, whom he initially believed she was dating. Yet their recent encounter at the hotel introduced a new, perplexing dynamic; she had appeared strikingly glamorous and self-assured, offering him a discreet invitation for a drink. He pondered whether he should confront Declan and unravel the mystery, recognizing the risk of provoking his brother's ire with such a direct inquiry. Meanwhile, Pauline, who had been observing him with curiosity, interrupted his contemplation with a pragmatic question. She asked how he planned to get home without a lift, to which he casually replied that he would walk, prompting her to curiously ask how long the journey might take.
paragraph2: Aidan closes the door and puts his bag down at his feet. O.K., he says. The car smells of alcohol. Aidan still feels that he doesn’t really know who this woman is, this woman lying on the back seat. She’s coming up fairly often in his life at this point, but who is she? At first he thought she was Declan’s girlfriend, or at least a candidate for that role, but then in the hotel the other night she seemed different—glamorous in a way, with all those men looking at her—and of course Declan wasn’t there, and she even invited Aidan for a drink afterward. He could ask his brother, How do you know this girl? I mean, are you riding her, or what? But Declan’s sensibilities would be offended by that kind of thing.How would you get home if you didn’t have a lift? Pauline says.Walk, Aidan says.How long would it take?

paragraph1: Before heading out, the mother shows me the stuff in the fridge that they don’t want to take back to the city. She tells me that she’s grown quite fond of this house, that she already misses it. Maybe, when she’s feeling stressed, or overwhelmed by work, she’ll think of this placethe clean air, the hills, the clouds blazing at sunset.I wish the family safe travels and say goodbye. I stand there waiting until the car’s out of sight. Then I start to prepare the house for the new family that’s supposed to get here tomorrow. I make the beds. I tidy the room the girls turned upside down. I sweep the flies they swatted.They’ve forgotten, or left on purpose, a few things they don’t need, things I hold on to. Pictures the girls drew, shells they picked up at the beach, the last drops of a perfumed shower gel. Shopping lists in the faint, small script that the mother used, on other sheets of paper, to write all about us.
paragraph2: As I stood in the rustic kitchen, the mother, with a gentle resolve, showed me the contents of the fridge, pointing out the food they'd leave behind as they returned to their city life. Her voice carried a bittersweet nostalgia as she spoke of the cozy, secluded house, confessing how its memory might offer solace during stressful times back in the urban sprawl. It was a moment of intimate honesty, and I could see a flicker of emotion cross her face, a soft glow of fondness mixed with the reluctance of departure. After bidding the family a heartfelt farewell and watching them disappear down the gravel road, I turned back to the empty abode, ready to prepare it for new occupants. As I cleaned and organized, I discovered personal items they left behind—pictures that caught snippets of joy and shells that whispered stories of their beachside adventures. Tucked away in a corner, I found shopping lists scribbled in her neat handwriting, each one an echo of the family's ordinary yet cherished routine in this countryside retreat.

paragraph1: As I reached the summit, a wave of fulfillment washed over me, a feeling so profound yet elusive that words barely grasp its essence. This hike was more than a mere physical journey; it was an introspective pilgrimage that made me confront the ineffable truths embedded in my experiences. Echoes from "The Dream of a Common Language" reverberated in my mind, fostering a sense of connectedness with the unspoken shared understanding that life's unvarnished truths are universal. Just as fish swim gracefully beneath the water's surface, so too do I glide through the currents of life, trusting in its mysterious, irrevocable, and sacred nature. In that moment of realization, I found contentment—a deep-seated acceptance of life's inherent wildness, a knowledge that to witness and experience is, in itself, enough. This understanding fills me with a serene joy, embracing all that life offers.
paragraph2: It was all unknown to me then, as I sat on that white bench on the day I finished my hike. Everything except the fact that I didn't have to know. That is was enough to trust that what I'd done was true. To understand its meaning without yet being able to say precisely what it was, like all those lines from The Dream of a Common Language that had run through my nights and days. To believe that I didn't need to reach with my bare hands anymore. To know that seeing the fish beneath the surface of the water was enough. That it was everything. It was my life - like all lives, mysterious and irrevocable and sacred. So very close, so very present, so very belonging to me.How wild it was, to let it be.

paragraph1: Then I made a mistake. This was yesterday. If you’re anything like Scout, you probably heard about it already. (Scout e-mailed me fifteen minutes after it happened to commiserate and also to alert me to the fact that she would not be e-mailing me anymore.) How it happened wasone of our poets said something beyond the pale. He is one of the newer poets—the musical kind—and so his words tend to go everywhere, floating between our towers, rising above the city. People were appalled, furious. All arrows pointed to him. And I said, Look, politically you’re absolutely within your rights to be angry, but existentially you’re wrong—existentially this particular poet just wants us all to be free. As a matter of fact, he’s not even a poet at all, he’s a philosopher. Yes, I said itHe’s one of us. But then the poet himself said that philosophy makes nothing happen and also that he happened to quite like the Devil—whom we sometimes call "the adversary” and sometimes nothing at all—and then he said that he was glad that he-who-shall-not-be-named had come to power, because he admired his energy, his inability to distinguish between past, present, and future, and soon after that the poet got cancelled and, soon after that, me, too.
paragraph2: Recently, I found myself in a whirlwind of controversy after trying to defend a new, musically-inclined poet whose audacious voice had captivated and divided audiences. It all started with an email from Scout, alerting me to a firestorm surrounding an incendiary statement the poet had made. True to my nature, I sprang to his defense, framing him as a philosopher and a beacon of creative freedom in a world increasingly hostile to original thought. I stressed his right to express and explore controversial ideas, emphasizing his yearning for unencumbered artistic expression. However, the situation took an unexpected and unfortunate turn when the poet openly expressed admiration for a controversial political figure, who shall remain unnamed, sending shockwaves through our community and sparking a fierce backlash. In a matter of days, both the poet and I found ourselves socially "cancelled," our reputations marred by association and our voices drowned out by a cacophony of disapproval. Friends and acquaintances distanced themselves, and doors that had previously been open now seemed firmly shut. The experience left me reflecting on the fine line between advocacy and complicity, pondering how to navigate support for free expression without inadvertently endorsing harmful ideologies. It was a stark reminder of how quickly the tides of public opinion can turn, sweeping away certainty and replacing it with lingering doubts.

paragraph1: In the small, somewhat insular town of Maverley, the Capital movie theatre stood as a modest hub of entertainment and diversion, its operations carefully maintained by Morgan Holly, the somewhat reclusive owner and projectionist. Morgan found solace in the dim confines of his upstairs cubbyhole, where he diligently worked the projector, avoiding interaction with the public as much as possible. His preference for seclusion and routine was disrupted when the young ticket girl confided that she was quitting due to her pregnancy. This announcement, given her recent marriage and the traditional expectations of the era, was not entirely unexpected in the social norms of Maverley. Nevertheless, her decision struck a nerve with Morgan, who had a deep aversion to change and the intricacies of personal matters. It was a reminder that life, outside his carefully curated environment, continued to shift unpredictably.
paragraph2: In the old days when there was a movie theatre in every town there was one in this town, too, in Maverley, and it was called the Capital, as such theatres often were. Morgan Holly was the owner and the projectionist. He didn’t like dealing with the public—he preferred to sit in his upstairs cubbyhole managing the story on the screen—so naturally he was annoyed when the girl who took the tickets told him that she was going to have to quit, because she was having a baby. He might have expected this—she had been married for half a year, and in those days you were supposed to get out of the public eye before you began to show—but he so disliked change and the idea of people having private lives that he was taken by surprise.

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: Growing up during the pioneering era of artificial human development was nothing short of exhilarating for someone like me, an ardent enthusiast of technology and human potential. Witnessing humanity’s age-old aspiration to replicate and enhance itself take tangible form was awe-inspiring, in spite of the inevitable complexities and ethical debates that accompanied such progress. There was something undeniably thrilling about being part of this momentous leap in human evolution, seeing us edge ever closer to bridging the gap between man and machine. Yet, I couldn’t ignore the murmurs of disappointment that permeated discussions about these creations; after all, we had been primed for this moment by decades of science fiction, which painted vivid pictures of charismatic, often flawed, artificial companions in our collective imaginations. Our journey, while groundbreaking, felt like a quieter echo of what books, films, and TV shows had led us to expect. Society had already mentally rehearsed living alongside these entities whose human-like quirks and imperfections made them so compelling on screen compared to their unassuming reality.
paragraph2: More practically, we intended to devise an improved, more modern version of ourselves and exult in the joy of invention, the thrill of mastery. In the autumn of the twentieth century, it came about at last, the first step towards the fulfilment of an ancient dream, the beginning of the long lesson we would teach ourselves that however complicated we were, however faulty and difficult to describe in even our simplest actions and modes of being, we could be imitated and bettered. And I was there as a young man, an early and eager adopter in that chilly dawn.But artificial humans were a cliché long before they arrived, so when they did, they seemed to some a disappointment. The imagination, fleeter than history, than technological advance, had already rehearsed this future in books, then films and TV dramas, as if human actors, walking with a certain glazed look, phony head movements, some stiffness in the lower back, could prepare us for life with our cousins from the future.

paragraph1: It wasn’t because I was in love with him. We’d only spoken a few times in the six months since he’d visited me in Minneapolis and gotten me pregnant. It had been Paul I’d grieved in the previous months, despite the fact that it was me who’d shattered our marriage to bits. Paul who occupied the center of my broken heart. Paul who’d been my lover and companion, my best friend and anchor in the years after my mother died, when my life had become unmoored. But I was compelled by Joe, powerfully drawn to his bad boy ways, sparked if not to life, then to flame. What I felt for him was weightless and by virtue of its weightlessness it seemed when I was with him that everything else in my life weighed less too. As if the sincere, earnest, sentimental life I’d made with Paul was nothing but a funny dream. I knew, as I drove to see Joe that day, that it wasn’t so much him that I longed to visit, but rather the version of myself that he brought out in me—the one who was outlandish and bold, the wild, self-destructive woman who would do anything.
paragraph2: As I sit in the car, the engine humming beneath me, the road blurring past in a dizzying array of colors, my mind is a tumultuous mix of emotions and memories. On one end, there's Joe; captivating and unpredictable, a whirlwind of rebellion and spontaneity that threatens to consume me whole. The electricity of his presence is unmistakable, a stark contrast to the safety and predictability I once cherished in my now broken marriage to Paul. Paul was my rock, my anchor after my mother's death, carrying me through some of the darkest times of my life. His unwavering support was a balm then, comforting but ultimately unable to quench the restlessness growing within me. In Joe's company, I'm not just fascinated by the magnetic pull of his free-spirited life but also enticed by the unrestrained version of myself he coaxes into being—a woman unafraid of roads less traveled, one eager for adventure's intoxicating embrace even as it teeters on self-destruction. Driving to meet Joe, I wonder if it is really him I am drawn to or the reflection of myself I see in his eyes—a self that craves the wildness, a tempest raging against the confines of a life once neatly assembled and now irrevocably changed.

You are given two pararaphs of creative writing for a given writing instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
It wasn’t because I was in love with him. We’d only spoken a few times in the six months since he’d visited me in Minneapolis and gotten me pregnant. It had been Paul I’d grieved in the previous months, despite the fact that it was me who’d shattered our marriage to bits. Paul who occupied the center of my broken heart. Paul who’d been my lover and companion, my best friend and anchor in the years after my mother died, when my life had become unmoored. But I was compelled by Joe, powerfully drawn to his bad boy ways, sparked if not to life, then to flame. What I felt for him was weightless and by virtue of its weightlessness it seemed when I was with him that everything else in my life weighed less too. As if the sincere, earnest, sentimental life I’d made with Paul was nothing but a funny dream. I knew, as I drove to see Joe that day, that it wasn’t so much him that I longed to visit, but rather the version of myself that he brought out in me—the one who was outlandish and bold, the wild, self-destructive woman who would do anything.

Paragraph 2:
As I sit in the car, the engine humming beneath me, the road blurring past in a dizzying array of colors, my mind is a tumultuous mix of emotions and memories. On one end, there's Joe; captivating and unpredictable, a whirlwind of rebellion and spontaneity that threatens to consume me whole. The electricity of his presence is unmistakable, a stark contrast to the safety and predictability I once cherished in my now broken marriage to Paul. Paul was my rock, my anchor after my mother's death, carrying me through some of the darkest times of my life. His unwavering support was a balm then, comforting but ultimately unable to quench the restlessness growing within me. In Joe's company, I'm not just fascinated by the magnetic pull of his free-spirited life but also enticed by the unrestrained version of myself he coaxes into being—a woman unafraid of roads less traveled, one eager for adventure's intoxicating embrace even as it teeters on self-destruction. Driving to meet Joe, I wonder if it is really him I am drawn to or the reflection of myself I see in his eyes—a self that craves the wildness, a tempest raging against the confines of a life once neatly assembled and now irrevocably changed.

paragraph1: As I sat in front of my television, tuning into Canal Plus, there was a particular aura of excitement tempered with a tinge of frustration, given my lack of a proper decoder which left the images blurred and the audio distorted, transforming my first encounter with an X-rated film into an indistinct yet intriguing experience. Through the haze, I could just about make out the contours of a woman in a corset and stockings, her presence barely distinguishable alongside a man whose actions were equally obscured by the lack of clarity. This obscured narrative played out like a shadow play on the screen, leaving me to piece together the storyline where comprehension struggled against the fog of uncertainty, leaving me unable to predict the characters' intentions or actions. Yet it was unmistakably clear when the scene shifted to a more explicit focus—switching angles multiple times to hone in on their genitals and the fervent act of intercourse, which somehow pierced through the grainy fog and hit with unexpected intensity. The culmination arrived in the form of the man’s ejaculation on the woman’s belly, a moment as shocking as it was mesmerizing given the novelty and visual bluntness of such an act. Reflecting on this visual specter, I pondered the cinematic power encompassed therein, how it forces a viewer into confronting visceral reactions—an amalgam of anxiety and awe untainted by moral judgments—and mused how meaningful writing should emulate this raw, unfiltered emotional pull.
paragraph2: This summer, for the first time, I watched an X-rated film on Canal Plus. My television set doesn't have a decoder; the images on the screen were blurred, the words replaced by strange sound effects, hissing and babbling, a different sort of language, soft and continuous. One could make out the figure of a woman in a corset and stockings, and a man. The story was incomprehensible; it was impossible to predict any of their actions or movements. The man walked up to the woman. There was a close-up of the woman's genitals, clearly visible among the shimmerings of the screen, then of the man's penis, fully erect, sliding into the woman's vagina. For a long time this coming and going of the two sex organs was shown from several angles. The cock reappeared, in the man's hand, and the sperm spilled on to the woman's belly. No doubt one gets used to such a sight; the first time is shattering. Centuries and centuries, hundreds of generations have gone by, and it is only now that one can see this—a man's penis and a woman's vagina coming together, the sperm—something one could barely take in without dying has become as easy to watch as a handshake.It occurred to me that writing should also aim for that—the impression conveyed by sexual intercourse, a feeling of anxiety and stupefaction, a suspension of moral judgment.

paragraph1: In October 1963, in the city of Rouen, I waited for my period for over a week. It was a warm, sunny month. I felt heavy and stuffy in my winter coat, especially in the department stores where I had taken to browsing and buying stockings, waiting for college to resume. When I got back to my room in the girls’ dorm in the Rue d’Herbouville, I would still hope to see a stain appear on my panties. I began writing in my diary every evening—the word NOTHING in big, underlined capital letters. I would wake up in the middle of the night and instinctively know that "nothing" had happened. The year before, around the same time, I had started work on a novel; now this seemed faraway, something that was not to be pursued. One afternoon I went to see Il Posto, an Italian film in black and white. It was the slow, sad story of a young man working as an office clerk—his very first job. The cinema was almost empty. As I watched the frail figure of the boy in his cheap raincoat, the humiliations he suffered during his pathetic existence, somehow I knew the bleeding would not come back. One evening I was talked into going to the theater by some of the girls who had gotten a spare ticket. They were putting on Huis Clos by Jean-Paul Sartre and I had never been to see a contemporary production. The theater was packed. I stared at the brightly lit stage at the back, obsessed with the fact that I no longer had my period. All I can remember about the play is the character called Estelle, a blonde girl in a blue dress, and the Boy dressed as a manservant, with red, lidless eyes. In my diary I wrote"Fantastic. If only I didn’t have this REALITY inside me.
paragraph2: In October 1963, I found myself in Rouen, suffocated by a waiting game that was wearing me thin. Every day, I anticipated the reassurance of my menstrual period, but as each night descended, I was left with the bitter disappointment of another "NOTHING" penned into my diary. The city carried on its routines under an unexpectedly warm sky while I, wrapped in a winter coat that felt too heavy for both the weather and my unsettled state of mind, wandered through department stores. They were a temporary refuge as I lingered in the disquiet of wanting college to start again, hoping academic distractions might alleviate the personal turmoil within. The novel I had eagerly begun the previous year now lay forgotten, much like the childhood moments of carefree imagination that had once filled the voids of anticipation. Amidst the uncertainty, I allowed myself a flicker of escape through cinema, attending a screening of *Il Posto*. This Italian film unexpectedly served a harsh reminder that the reality of my situation might not resolve as simply as I wished; the absence of my period lingered like a question never asked. Despite the knot in my stomach that wouldn't untangle, I found myself in a theater with other girls from my dorm, hesitantly agreeing to see Sartre's *Huis Clos*. My thoughts persistently drifted towards what wasn't there, my absentee period shadowing even the characters on stage. Estelle, a woman from the play, captured my attention with her complexities, while another's red eyes seemed to echo the intensity of my inner restlessness. Back in my dorm room, I reflected on a reality painted stark by these unfamiliar colors, filling my diary with notes on these characters, their echoes somehow offering a semblance of companionship as I grappled with the distressing uncertainty that had draped itself over my life like an unwelcome cloak.

paragraph1: As I stare out through the window, my weary bones settle into the comfortable embrace of my favorite chair, and the peculiar solemnity of being both creator and enemy of my own literary world weighs heavily on my mind. The gray light filters through the half-opened curtains, casting a gentle glow over a landscape etched with countless memories—a park, bridges, and the winding driveway that winds its way through the chapters of my imagination, where Robbie and Cecilia linger forever in their youthful prime. They are characters once condemned by my pen, yet afforded a redemption that I, their godlike creator, seldom extend to myself. In the serendipitous moments of my narrative, they discover joy and connection, an ethereal love allowed to blossom as a direct answer to the real despair I once penned. But here, in the reality of my advancing years, I find myself grappling with a profound moral conundrum: how does one who dictates destinies in ink find atonement for the fates not bravely changed? The notion of forgiveness, sought not just from those I write but perhaps more piercingly from myself, is distant and elusive. As I sit by the shadowed window, I allow myself an indulgent daydream: Robbie and Cecilia, for whom I've crafted a gentler fate, gathered amidst friends at a celebration of my life's work—a birthday perhaps. Yet deep down, I know my desire for their absolution is merely a step toward my own rest, one that remains an unresolved narrative.
paragraph2: The problem these fifty-nine years has been this: how can a novelist achieve atonement when, with her absolute power of deciding outcomes, she is also God? There is no one, no entity or higher form that she can appeal to, or be reconciled with, or that can forgive her. There is nothing outside her. In her imagination she has set the limits and the terms. No atonement for God, or novelists, even if they are atheists. It was always an impossible task, and that was precisely the point. The attempt was all. I’ve been standing at the window, feeling waves of tiredness beat the remaining strength from my body. The floor seems to be undulating beneath my feet. I’ve been watching the first gray light bring into view the park and the bridges over the vanished lake. And the long narrow driveway down which they drove Robbie away, into the whiteness. I like to think that it isn’t weakness or evasion, but a final act of kindness, a stand against oblivion and despair, to let my lovers live and to unite them at the end. I gave them happiness, but I was not so self-serving as to let them forgive me. Not quite, not yet. If I had the power to conjure them at my birthday celebration … Robbie and Cecilia, still alive, still in love, sitting side by side in the library, smiling at The Trials of Arabella? It’s not impossible. But now I must sleep.

paragraph1: What I find strange about growing old isn’t that I’ve got older. Not that the youthful me from the past has, without my realizing it, aged. What catches me off guard is, rather, how people from the same generation as me have become elderly, how all the pretty, vivacious girls I used to know are now old enough to have a couple of grandkids. It’s a little disconcerting—sad, even. Though I never feel sad at the fact that I have similarly aged.I think what makes me feel sad about the girls I knew growing old is that it forces me to admit, all over again, that my youthful dreams are gone forever. The death of a dream can be, in a way, sadder than that of a living being.There’s one girl—a woman who used to be a girl, I mean—whom I remember well. I don’t know her name, though. And, naturally, I don’t know where she is now or what she’s doing. What I do know about her is that she went to the same high school as I did, and was in the same year (since the badge on her shirt was the same color as mine), and that she really liked the Beatles.
paragraph2: Reflecting on the passage of time, I find myself struck by an unexpected mix of surprise and sadness, not so much at my own aging, but at witnessing the transformation of my peers and former acquaintances from our vibrant youth. There's a peculiar, deep-seated melancholy that envelops me when I see photographs or hear stories of people I once knew, especially the women who are now grandmothers, living a chapter of life I’ve never fully imagined they'd reach. Their lives have unfolded into roles and responsibilities that, as teenagers, we barely comprehended. This encounter with their mature realities forces me to confront the poignant loss of our youthful dreams, a loss that echoes in my heart as a different kind of sadness. Among these reflections, a specific memory flickers like an old photograph in my mind—of a girl from high school, who shared the same classroom and had a fondness for the Beatles. Despite the vividness of this memory, her name eludes me, as does any knowledge of her current life. Has she too embraced this life stage with grace? The questions linger, unanswered, as I grasp the fleeting nature of time and the distant sands of youth that slip away, leaving only fragments behind.

paragraph1: I find myself constantly reflecting on the world around me, particularly the stark contrast between my mundane existence and the lives of the affluent and accomplished. It's almost as if we inhabit different universes, where the boundaries of opportunity are drawn sharply by our birth circumstances. My primary goal, however, is not to wallow in self-pity but to invest in the future of my younger brother, aspiring to see him rise above the limitations we've known. Unlike our father, who seems content with his illiteracy—often turning it into a joke—my brother and I are driven by a relentless ambition to change our narrative. Our father relies heavily on his younger brother, a law clerk in the city, to navigate legalities and paperwork. This dependency illustrates the divide between those who triumph and those who lag behind, a divide I am determined to bridge for my brother. I remain steadfast, ensuring he steps into a world brimming with opportunities waiting to be seized.
paragraph2: Ordinary for me, but for my brother it wasn’t going to be like that. He was going to break away; he was going to be a professional man; I was going to see to that. For the rich and the professional the world is not ordinary. I know, I see them. Where you build a hut, they build a mansion; where you have mud and a pará-grass field, they have a garden; when you kill time on a Sunday, they have parties. We all come out of the same pot, but some people move ahead and some people get left behind. Some people get left behind so far they don’t know and they stop caring .Like my father. He couldn’t read and write and he didn’t care. He even joke about his illiteracy, slapping his fat arms and laughing. He say he is happy to leave that side of life to his younger brother, who is a law clerk in the city.

paragraph1: After graduating from university, I dove headfirst into a career as an English teacher, feeling like I was still basking in the university lifestyle, even though it was cloaked in more tedious work and extended hours. The social aspect of teaching was invigorating, with friendships blossoming effortlessly. I was part of a global network of wandering teachers; each meeting was alive with tales of travels and dreams of teaching in exotic places like Japan and Brazil. Despite the grandiose visions, life took me on unexpected adventures through Southern Italy, Portugal, and Spain. Each location enriched my understanding and respect for the vastness of cultures we inhabit. Initially, it all seemed like a grand celebratory extension of my younger, carefree days, but the reality of it all gradually settled in. The years accumulated stealthily, and suddenly I found myself realizing I had aged amidst classrooms and student essays, witnessing a subtle yet palpable shift. The new wave of teachers I encountered appeared to bring with them modern, vibrant interests that didn’t quite align with mine, marking a divergence in both my social and professional circles. Those carefree, camaraderie-driven discussions evolved into more solitary reflections on my journey. It became clear that, while the external environment advanced rapidly, my internal compass was subtly guiding me on a quieter path, one where the allure of youthful wanderlust blended with the introspective wisdom of experience.
paragraph2: When I first took up English teaching after university, it seemed a good enough life—much like an extension of university. Language schools were mushrooming all over Europe, and if the teaching was tedious and the hours exploitative, at that age you don’t care too much. You spend a lot of time in bars, friends are easy to make, and there’s a feeling you’re part of a large network extending around the entire globe. You meet people fresh from their spells in Peru or Thailand, and this gets you thinking that if you wanted to, you could drift around the world indefinitely, using your contacts to get a job in any faraway corner you fancied. And always you’d be part of this cosy, extended family of itinerant teachers, swapping stories over drinks about former colleagues, psychotic school directors, eccentric British Council officers. In the late ’80s, there was talk of making a lot of money teaching in Japan, and I made serious plans to go, but it never worked out. I thought about Brazil too, even read a few books about the culture and sent off for application forms. But somehow I never got away that far. Southern Italy, Portugal for a short spell, back here to Spain. Then before you know it, you’re forty-seven years old, and the people you started out with have long ago been replaced by a generation who gossip about different things, take different drugs and listen to different music.
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of creative writing for a given writing instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
After graduating from university, I dove headfirst into a career as an English teacher, feeling like I was still basking in the university lifestyle, even though it was cloaked in more tedious work and extended hours. The social aspect of teaching was invigorating, with friendships blossoming effortlessly. I was part of a global network of wandering teachers; each meeting was alive with tales of travels and dreams of teaching in exotic places like Japan and Brazil. Despite the grandiose visions, life took me on unexpected adventures through Southern Italy, Portugal, and Spain. Each location enriched my understanding and respect for the vastness of cultures we inhabit. Initially, it all seemed like a grand celebratory extension of my younger, carefree days, but the reality of it all gradually settled in. The years accumulated stealthily, and suddenly I found myself realizing I had aged amidst classrooms and student essays, witnessing a subtle yet palpable shift. The new wave of teachers I encountered appeared to bring with them modern, vibrant interests that didn’t quite align with mine, marking a divergence in both my social and professional circles. Those carefree, camaraderie-driven discussions evolved into more solitary reflections on my journey. It became clear that, while the external environment advanced rapidly, my internal compass was subtly guiding me on a quieter path, one where the allure of youthful wanderlust blended with the introspective wisdom of experience.

Paragraph 2:
When I first took up English teaching after university, it seemed a good enough life—much like an extension of university. Language schools were mushrooming all over Europe, and if the teaching was tedious and the hours exploitative, at that age you don’t care too much. You spend a lot of time in bars, friends are easy to make, and there’s a feeling you’re part of a large network extending around the entire globe. You meet people fresh from their spells in Peru or Thailand, and this gets you thinking that if you wanted to, you could drift around the world indefinitely, using your contacts to get a job in any faraway corner you fancied. And always you’d be part of this cosy, extended family of itinerant teachers, swapping stories over drinks about former colleagues, psychotic school directors, eccentric British Council officers. In the late ’80s, there was talk of making a lot of money teaching in Japan, and I made serious plans to go, but it never worked out. I thought about Brazil too, even read a few books about the culture and sent off for application forms. But somehow I never got away that far. Southern Italy, Portugal for a short spell, back here to Spain. Then before you know it, you’re forty-seven years old, and the people you started out with have long ago been replaced by a generation who gossip about different things, take different drugs and listen to different music.

where `preference` should be "1" if you think Paragraph 1 is better, "2" if you think Paragraph 2 is better.

paragraph1: The Lazy River is a metaphor and at the same time a real body of artificial water, in an all-inclusive hotel, in Almería, somewhere in southern Spain. We do not leave the hotel (except to buy flotation devices). The plan is to beat our hotel at its own game. What you do is you do thisyou drink so much alcohol that your accommodation is effectively free. (Only the most vulgar among us speak this plan aloud but we are all on board.) For in this hotel we are all British, we are en masse, we are unashamed. We enjoy one another’s company. There is nobody French or German here to see us at the buffet, rejecting paella and swordfish in favor of sausages and chips, nor anyone to judge us as we lie on our loungers, turning from the concept of literature toward the reality of sudoku. One of our tribe, an older gentleman, has a portrait of Amy Winehouse on each shin, and we do not judge him, not at all, how could we? We do not have so many saints of Amy’s calibre left to us; we cherish her. She was one of the few who expressed our pain without ridiculing or diminishing it. It is therefore fitting that in the evenings, during the brief spell in which we emerge from the Lazy River, we will, at karaoke hour, belt out her famous torch songs—full-throated, already drunk—content in the knowledge that later, much later, when all of this is over, these same beloved verses will be sung at our funerals.
paragraph2: As British vacationers immersing ourselves in the lush and spirited embrace of an all-inclusive hotel in Almería, southern Spain, we find ourselves floating at the heart of what we've come to affectionately call the Lazy River—a winding path of watery leisure that has become not just a physical feature of our sun-drenched oasis but a metaphorical symbol for the languorous rhythm of our vacation experience. We drift through our days with an unspoken pact to indulge in just enough alcohol to make our stay feel generously unrushed—though this plan is never formally acknowledged, it’s a shared understanding that unites us. Our time unfolds in a tapestry of socializing, laughter, and the cozy comfort of British cultural touchstones, such as hearty sausages, golden chips, and the quiet mental gymnastics of sudoku, all of which trump any curiosity we might have had toward the local Spanish offerings. Among us, an older gentleman proudly carries his connection to Amy Winehouse with every step; tattoos of the late singer emblazoned on his shins silently speak volumes. She is our collective muse, an embodiment of the raw, shared cultural pain that resonates deeply within us. When evening descends, we gather under the star-speckled Spanish sky for karaoke—the highlight of our communal festivities—where we raise our voices in celebration of Winehouse’s songs. Her melodies forge a bond among us, every note a reminder of her enduring significance and the unspoken threads of understanding that tie our eclectic band of travelers together in this sunlit escape.

paragraph1: Now and then on the streets of my neighborhood I bump into a man I might have been involved with, maybe shared a life with. He always looks happy to see me. He lives with a friend of mine, and they have two children. Our relationship never goes beyond a longish chat on the sidewalk, a quick coffee together, perhaps a brief stroll in the same direction. He talks excitedly about his projects, he gesticulates, and at times as we’re walking our synchronized bodies, already quite close, discreetly overlap.
paragraph2: As I stroll through the neighborhood, I occasionally bump into him, sparking a familiar yet poignant reflection. In a different life, we might have been more than acquaintances—a tantalizing thought, though reality tells a different story. Now he shares his life with one of my friends, raising two lively children. Our interactions remain cordial and amicable, confined to extended sidewalk chats or the occasional short coffee outing. His animated gestures breathe life into his stories, and sometimes, the closeness between us is tinged with a subtly intimate warmth, a reminder of roads not taken.

paragraph1: Navigating the river under the cloak of night was an unsettling experience that left me feeling acutely aware of my vulnerability. The darkness enveloped me, even on a night illuminated by the moon, and it was as if my usual senses were rendered nearly useless. The river seemed to possess a formidable presence, its currents whispering secrets only it could understand, while the towering silhouettes of trees formed an impenetrable wall, making me feel like an unwelcome guest in this ancient realm. Despite my discomfort and the eerie sense of being out of control, I couldn't shake a deeper connection that seemed to pulse from the very earth beneath me. It was as if the land itself was calling to me, binding me in an unspoken bond with something both familiar and unfathomably old, a reminder of an intrinsic, primordial link to the natural world.
paragraph2: Going home at night! It wasn't often that I was on the river at night. I never liked it. I never felt in control. In the darkness of river and forest you could be sure only of what you could see — and even on a moonlight night you couldn't see much. When you made a noise — dipped a paddle in the water — you heard yourself as though you were another person. The river and the forest were like presences, and much more powerful than you. You felt unprotected, an intruder ... You felt the land taking you back to something that was familiar, something you had known at some time but had forgotten or ignored, but which was always there. You felt the land taking you back to what was there a hundred years ago, to what had been there always.

paragraph1: This is why men are so sad, why they feel so cut off, why they think of themselves as orphans cast adrift, footloose and stringless in the deep void.“What void?” she asks.“What are you talking about? The void of the Universe,” he says.And she says “Oh,” and looks out the window and tries to get a handle on it, but it’s no use, there’s too much going on, too many rustlings in the leaves, too many voices, so she says, "Would you like a cheese sandwich, a piece of cake, a cup of tea?"And he grinds his teeth because she doesn’t understand, and wanders off, not just alone but Alone, lost in the dark, lost in the skull, searching for the other half, the twin who could complete him.Then it comes to himhe’s lost the Female Body! Look, it shines in the gloom, far ahead, a vision of wholeness, ripeness, like a giant melon, like an apple, like a metaphor for breast in a bad sex novel; it shines like a balloon, like a foggy noon, a watery moon, shimmering in its egg of light.Catch it. Put it in a pumpkin, in a high tower, in a compound, in a chamber, in a house, in a room. Quick, stick a leash on it, a lock, a chain, some pain, settle it down, so it can never get away from you again.
paragraph2: In the dim quiet of the cafe, surrounded by the gentle clinking of cups and low murmur of distant conversations, he sat across from her, feeling as though he were floating aimlessly in the vast, empty expanse of the universe. The words tumbled out of him, heavy and forlorn, as he tried to convey the depth of his sadness and the aching isolation that clung to him like a second skin. She listened, her brow slightly furrowed in puzzlement as she attempted to make sense of his abstract expressions. His feelings, complex and nebulous, seemed to elude her grasp, prompting her to offer a practical solution – "Would you like some coffee or tea?" Her well-meaning offer irked him, her pragmatic response colliding with the chaotic swirl of emotions inside him. Frustration simmered beneath his skin as he withdrew further into his thoughts, where a gnawing sense of incompleteness festered. He yearned for connection, a profound linkage that seemed perpetually out of reach. Within the confines of his mind, he envisioned the "Female Body" as a symbol of fertility and completeness, an embodiment of all he longed to capture and possess. It became an object of his fascination, its allure akin to a vessel that promised containment and control, yet always eluding his grasp, leaving him adrift, searching for solace in the void.

paragraph1: Your wound, your silly little wound! That's your real love, Leo, that wound, the one true love of your life! I know how it will be, even if we tried, even if we managed to build something all over again. The music too, that would be no different. Even if they'd accepted you tonight, even if you became celebrated in this town, you'd destroy it all, you'd destroy everything, pull it all down around you just as you did before. And all because of that wound. Me, the music, we're neither of us anything more to you than mistresses you seek consolation from. You'll always go back to your one real love. To that wound! And you know what makes me so angry? Leo, are you listening to me? Your wound, it's nothing special, nothing special at all. In this town alone, I know there are many people with far worse. And yet they carry on, every one of them, with far greater courage than you ever did. They go on with their lives. They become something worthwhile. But you, Leo, look at you. Always tending your wound.
paragraph2: Leo, you stand there, tangled in the web of your self-inflicted despair, fixated on that wound as if it were a badge of honor. It seems to be the axis around which your entire existence spins, the only thing you truly cherish. You wear it with a kind of twisted pride, not realizing it has become a prison of your own making. No matter how many times life offers you the tools to rebuild, to achieve something greater, you end up sabotaging those efforts. It's almost as if you're afraid of what lies beyond that familiar pain. The people you meet, the passions you briefly entertain, are mere distractions to you; temporary solace, never blossoming into true commitments. I watch, disheartened, as you retreat into this cycle of attachment to your anguish, while others, people facing challenges greater than you've ever known, stride forward courageously. They continue to mold meaningful lives despite their battles, courageously embracing each new sunrise. But you, Leo, with all your potential, remain shackled to that wound, unwilling to confront the truth and rise above it. And in that unwillingness, you remain a shadow of what you could be.

paragraph1: Drapes. That would be her word for the blue curtains—drapes. And why not? He thought of the ginger cookies so perfectly round that she had to announce they were homemade, the ceramic coffee mugs on their ceramic tree, a plastic runner, he was sure, protecting the hall carpet. A high-gloss exactness and practicality that his mother had never achieved but would have admired—was that why he could feel this twinge of bizarre and unreliable affection? Or was it because he’d had two more drinks after the first?The walnut-stain tan—he believed now that it was a tan—of her face and neck would most likely continue into her cleavage, which would be deep, crêpey-skinned, odorous and hot. He had that to think of as he dialled the number that he had already written down. That and the practical sensuality of her cat’s tongue. Her gemstone eyes.
paragraph2: He stood in the living room, absorbing the elegant ambiance of her home, each detail a testament to her meticulous nature. Blue curtains elegantly flanked the windows; he called them "drapes," noting their soft movement in the evening breeze. His eyes flickered to the perfectly round ginger cookies she assured him were homemade, resting alongside ceramic mugs tastefully arranged on a display stand. Each element conjured a high-gloss, practical atmosphere, a sophisticated simplicity his own mother never achieved but would surely admire. As he pondered these particulars, he questioned whether his growing affection for her was real or merely swayed by the alcohol. Her tan skin captivated him, igniting his imagination as it swept smoothly into her alluring cleavage. Her "practical sensuality" was undeniable, accentuated by the elegant lines of her face, which he held in mind while dialing a number he'd carefully written down.

paragraph1: I consider these things idly. Each one of them seems the same size as all the others. Not one seems preferable. Fatigue is here, in my body, in my legs and eyes. That is what gets you in the end. Faith is only a word, embroidered. I look out at the dusk and think about its being winter. The snow falling, gently, effortlessly, covering everything in soft crystal, the mist of moonlight before a rain, blurring the outlines, obliterating color. Freezing to death is painless, they say, after the first chill. You lie back in the snow like an angel made by children and go to sleep. Behind me I feel her presence, my ancestress, my double, turning in midair under the chandelier, in her costume of stars and feathers, a bird stopped in flight, a woman made into an angel, waiting to be found. By me this time. How could I have believed I was alone in here? There were always two of us. Get it over, she says. I'm tired of this melodrama, I'm tired of keeping silent. There's no one you can protect, your life has value to no one. I want it finished.
paragraph2: As I look out at the winter landscape, my mind drifts into a contemplative state, deeply soaked in a reverie colored by the blankets of snow that cover the ground, rendering everything beneath it mute and lifeless. The cold wraps around me like a thick fog, and with it comes a fatigue that has settled into my very bones, making each moment feel elongated and heavy. In this introspective stillness, I feel the presence of my ancestress behind me—a spectral figure hovering like an ethereal watchguard. She turns in midair, almost celestial, her movements graceful and haunting, like some angelic apparition that haunts the edges of my consciousness. Though she is a whisper in the hallowed silence of my thoughts, her presence reverberates within me. I have always sensed this bond, this lingering connection that assures me I have never been truly alone, no matter the solitude my life seems to suggest. Her voice, weary and burdened with an unsaid truth, breaks the silence, urging me to awaken from this stupor, questioning the very fiber of my world. She suggests, with a sad acceptance, that my existence carries little weight in the world, pressing me towards a decisive change.
