There's no one you can protect, your life has value to no one. I want it finished.

Paragraph 2:
As I look out at the winter landscape, my mind drifts into a contemplative state, deeply soaked in a reverie colored by the blankets of snow that cover the ground, rendering everything beneath it mute and lifeless. The cold wraps around me like a thick fog, and with it comes a fatigue that has settled into my very bones, making each moment feel elongated and heavy. In this introspective stillness, I feel the presence of my ancestress behind me—a spectral figure hovering like an ethereal watchguard. She turns in midair, almost celestial, her movements graceful and haunting, like some angelic apparition that haunts the edges of my consciousness. Though she is a whisper in the hallowed silence of my thoughts, her presence reverberates within me. I have always sensed this bond, this lingering connection that assures me I have never been truly alone, no matter the solitude my life seems to suggest. Her voice, weary and burdened with an unsaid truth, breaks the silence, urging me to awaken from this stupor, questioning the very fiber of my world. She suggests, with a sad acceptance, that my existence carries little weight in the world, pressing me towards a decisive change.

paragraph1: It was a poorly built house in a way, since wind blew in through cracks and gaps all over the place. Pleasant enough in the summer, but, come winter, it was hell. With no money to buy a space heater, my wife and I and the cat would crawl under the futons once the sun set, literally clinging to each other to keep warm. Many a time we’d wake up to find the water in the kitchen faucet frozen solid.Once winter passed, the spring would come. And spring was a lovely season. She and I and the cat would breathe a sigh of relief. In April, the railroads went on strike for a few days, and we were ecstatic. Not a single train came rumbling by all day. We carried the cat down to the railroad tracks and sat there sunning ourselves. It was so quiet it was as if we were sitting at the bottom of a lake. We were young, just married, and the sunshine was free!Even now, when I hear the word “poor,” I remember that thin, triangular sliver of land. And I wonder, Who could be living there now?
paragraph2: I vividly remember our first home, a tiny, poorly built house where my wife, our cat, and I tried to make the best of our frugal beginnings. Winters were a particular challenge, as the inadequate insulation forced us to huddle closely under futons, our cat nestled between us for warmth. The kitchen faucet often froze, a testament to how unforgiving the cold could be without a proper space heater, something we couldn’t afford. Despite these hardships, spring emerged as our sanctuary, bringing with it a sense of renewal that remains my favorite time of year. One particular spring, an April railroad strike inadvertently gifted us a stretch of silence, transforming usually clamorous train tracks into peaceful sanctuaries where we basked in the gentle sunlight with our cat, undisturbed. We were young and newly married then, and despite the struggles, our lives felt full of promise. Even now, years later, whenever I encounter the word "poor," my thoughts drift back to that tiny house. I find myself wondering who lives there now, hoping they experience the same joy we did when it wasn’t winter. It’s a place bound to my heart, fondly recalled with every passing of the seasons.

paragraph1: When I first ventured to the Passage Cardinet, it marked the beginning of a period enveloped in fear, a sentiment which only intensified after I began taking penicillin. Every moment was thereafter tinged with unease, primarily stemming from my vivid recollections of Madame P-R’s apartment. There, the kitchen and bedroom are etched into my memory so strongly that, even now, they trigger a familiar anxiety. In fleeting moments of candor, I confided in my colleagues at the canteen—those whom I casually refer to as "the girls"—revealing that my nervousness was tied to the removal of a rather prominent beauty spot. Their startled reactions to my apprehension regarding what they considered a minor procedure were oddly comforting, offering me brief respite from my internal turmoil. It is peculiar how deeply rooted my terror became, as it often felt akin to envisioning an imposing older woman in a mundane setting, irrationally fantasizing that she harbored intentions to harm me. Such a mix of imagination and fear colored my experience with a shade of persistent dread.
paragraph2: After my first trip to the Passage Cardinet, I began taking penicillin and my life was suddenly ruled by fear. I kept imagining the kitchen and the bedroom in Madame P-R’s apartment, I couldn’t face what would come next. I told the girls at the canteen that I was afraid because I was having a large beauty spot removed from my back. They seemed surprised that such a harmless operation should make me so nervous. Admitting I was scared gave me a huge sense of relieffor a split-second, I could see myself in a pristine operating room, attended to by a surgeon in rubber gloves, instead of an ageing nurse in some dingy back kitchen.(To experience anew the emotions I felt back then is quite impossible. The closest I can get to the state of terror thrust upon me that week is to pick out any hostile, harsh-looking woman in her sixties waiting in line at the supermarket or the post office and to imagine that she is going to rummage around in my loins with some foreign object.)

paragraph1: As I settle into my familiar, well-worn chair at the small wooden table that has witnessed countless breakfasts and afternoon teas, I find my gaze drawn to the half-full pitcher of water resting in a silent vigil before me. There's something mesmerizing about the simple act of pouring water, a routine I've performed countless times yet still find strangely captivating. Today, I decide against drinking immediately, choosing instead to lose myself in the reflection of the years gone by and the quiet beauty found in life's smallest, often overlooked moments. The table seems to echo my thoughts, a silent companion in my reverie. My eyes drift to my hairbrush, bristles tangled with wisps of my once-vibrant hair, now thin and gray. It seems each strand that falls is like a chapter being shed, marking time in its quiet and unceremonious way. Gently setting the brush down, I ponder the permanence of those things that stay untouched, the forgotten objects and fleeting thoughts left to languish on tables and in corners. They, like the motionless pitcher before me, remain unchanged and unchanging—frozen snapshots of time, holding their charge without regard for the rushing world outside my window, where seasons blur and years fold into one another like pages of a cherished book.
paragraph2: I sit down on the chair slowly, looking at the tabletop. Things in silence. A half-full pitcher, the water in it standing motionless. When I want to drink I remove the glass cover, fill it, listening to and watching the water flow; the glass tinkles; the water runs; cool air rises; it's unique; it fascinates me. I'm fascinated, but I don't drink. Not yet. You have to be careful using up the things that make the time pass. I look at my hairbrush and see my hairs caught in it. I pick it up and begin to clean it out. The weak thin hairs of my ninety years. They're falling out one by one. Time, I whispered, what they call our years; we shed them that way, too. I stop and set the brush down. It lies there like an insect on its back, revolting me. If I leave everything this way and nobody touches it for a thousand years, that's how it will stay for a thousand years. Things on top of a table, a key or a water pitcher. How strange; everything in its place, without moving! Then my thoughts would freeze too, colorless and odorless and just sitting there, like a piece of ice.

paragraph1: Reflecting on the passage of time, I find myself struck by an unexpected mix of surprise and sadness, not so much at my own aging, but at witnessing the transformation of my peers and former acquaintances from our vibrant youth. There's a peculiar, deep-seated melancholy that envelops me when I see photographs or hear stories of people I once knew, especially the women who are now grandmothers, living a chapter of life I’ve never fully imagined they'd reach. Their lives have unfolded into roles and responsibilities that, as teenagers, we barely comprehended. This encounter with their mature realities forces me to confront the poignant loss of our youthful dreams, a loss that echoes in my heart as a different kind of sadness. Among these reflections, a specific memory flickers like an old photograph in my mind—of a girl from high school, who shared the same classroom and had a fondness for the Beatles. Despite the vividness of this memory, her name eludes me, as does any knowledge of her current life. Has she too embraced this life stage with grace? The questions linger, unanswered, as I grasp the fleeting nature of time and the distant sands of youth that slip away, leaving only fragments behind.
paragraph2: What I find strange about growing old isn’t that I’ve got older. Not that the youthful me from the past has, without my realizing it, aged. What catches me off guard is, rather, how people from the same generation as me have become elderly, how all the pretty, vivacious girls I used to know are now old enough to have a couple of grandkids. It’s a little disconcerting—sad, even. Though I never feel sad at the fact that I have similarly aged.I think what makes me feel sad about the girls I knew growing old is that it forces me to admit, all over again, that my youthful dreams are gone forever. The death of a dream can be, in a way, sadder than that of a living being.There’s one girl—a woman who used to be a girl, I mean—whom I remember well. I don’t know her name, though. And, naturally, I don’t know where she is now or what she’s doing. What I do know about her is that she went to the same high school as I did, and was in the same year (since the badge on her shirt was the same color as mine), and that she really liked the Beatles.

paragraph1: Paint had peeled off it in spots, and it was starting to rust. I couldn’t think of anything else to do, so I pressed the intercom button one more time, holding it down longer, but the result was the same as before—deep silence.With no idea what to do, I leaned back against the gate and stood there for some ten minutes. I had a faint hope that someone else might show up before long. But no one came. There was no sign of any movement, either inside the gate or outside. There was no wind. No birds chirping, no dogs barking. As before, an unbroken blanket of gray cloud lay above.I finally gave up—what else could I do?—and with heavy steps started back down the street toward the bus stop, totally in the dark about what was going on. The only clear thing about the whole situation was that there wasn’t going to be a piano recital or any other event held here today. All I could do was head home, bouquet of red flowers in hand. My mother would doubtless ask, “What’re the flowers for?,” and I would have to give some plausible answer. I wanted to toss them in the trash bin at the station, but they were—for me, at least—kind of expensive to just throw away.
paragraph2: Standing in front of the neglected façade, I felt a sinking sense of defeat wash over me. The paint on the building was peeling in long curls, revealing patches of rusted metal underneath—a testament to years of neglect. I pressed the intercom button again and again, each subsequent attempt more futile than the last. Silence stretched out like an unwelcome guest, wrapping around me as I stood alone, the gray sky casting a somber shadow over the empty street. I glanced around, hoping against hope for someone else to arrive, but there was only the stillness, an eerie quiet that made the hairs on the back of my neck prickle. After what felt like an eternity of waiting, I reluctantly accepted the inevitable—the event was not happening. With a weary sigh, I turned away, bouquet of red flowers clutched tightly in my hand, their vibrant color in stark contrast to the dreary surroundings. As I walked toward the bus stop, I couldn't help but imagine my mother's curious inquiries regarding the flowers. The thought of tossing them away at the station crossed my mind briefly; the notion, however, felt like an additional waste, given how much I had spent on them. Despite the failed evening, I remained resolute, determined to keep the flowers, their brilliance offering a glimmer of consolation amidst my disappointment.

paragraph1: Nell stood in the attic, a place where memories seemed to cling to the walls and whisper secrets long forgotten. Her fingers traced the edges of a yellowed note, its corners curled with time, penned by Tig, whose presence she felt more acutely in these moments of quiet solitude. The note was straightforward, detailing the careful packing of mosquito netting into a green bag once the bug season drew to a close, part of a forgotten community service project they had once embarked on together. Yet, Nell couldn't help but smile wryly at the thought of Tig’s meticulously outlined plans never coming to fruition, musing that the green bag was likely discarded, and the netting left haphazardly bundled and tucked away. To her, the note resonated beyond its mundane instructions; it was a relic, a piece of Tig that persisted beyond the constraints of life and death. Nell folded the fragile paper with a tenderness reserved for precious artifacts and slipped it into her own bag, a silent pact formed with the past. As she turned to leave, her mind wandered to the city, a world bustling and indifferent to such personal relics. She mused on the nature of messages left by those who had departed from life, wondering if they crafted these notes as markers for others to stumble upon and find solace in their cryptic echoes.
paragraph2: The day before Nell and Lizzie are due to leave for the city, Nell comes across a note written by Tig, long ago, when the two of them installed mosquito nets over the beds as a communal service. The mosquitoes can be thick as fur on the outsides of the screens, especially in June; they can squeeze through the tiniest cracks. Once inside, they whine. Even if you’ve got repellent on, they can ruin your night."Large mosquito nettingAt the end of the bug season the large netting should be packed in this bag. The wooden frame, once collapsed, is inserted in the inner compartment of the green bag—Thanks."What green bag? she wonders. Probably it got mildew and someone discarded it. In any case, no one had ever followed these instructions of Tig’s; the mosquito netting is merely left in place and tied into a bundle when not in use.She smooths out the piece of paper carefully and stores it away in her bag. It’s a message, left by Tig for her to find. Magical thinking, she knows that perfectly well, but she indulges in it, anyway, because it’s comforting. She’ll take this piece of paper back to the city, but what will she do with it there? What does one ever do with these cryptic messages from the dead?

paragraph1: I squeezed her hand and said nothing. I knew little about Keats or his poetry, but I thought it possible that in his hopeless situation he would not have wanted to write precisely because he loved her so much. Lately I'd had the idea that Clarissa's interest in these hypothetical letters had something to do with our own situation, and with her conviction that love that did not find its expression in a letter was not perfect. In the months after we'd met, and before we'd bought the apartment, she had written me some beauties, passionately abstract in the ways our love was different from and superior to any that had ever existed. Perhaps that's the essence of a love letter, to celebrate the unique. I had tried to match her, but all that sincerity would permit me were the facts, and they seemed miraculous enough to mea beautiful woman loved and wanted to be loved by a large, clumsy, balding fellow who could hardly believe his luck.
paragraph2: As I sit contemplating John Keats and his poetry, I often wonder whether he ever put pen to paper not for verse, but for love. Perhaps the overwhelming depth of his feelings rendered him wordless in the realm of personal correspondence. My partner, Clarissa, finds this notion fascinating, pondering hypothetical letters Keats might have penned to his beloved. This inevitably brings me to reflect on the early days of our own relationship when Clarissa filled pages with passionate love letters that seemed almost otherworldly in their celebration of us, of our love, and of our potential future. In response, I struggled to match her eloquence; my earnest attempts only highlighted my limitations. My letters, sincere yet simple, expressed an unwavering amazement at the fortune of being loved by someone as extraordinary as Clarissa—a woman whose beauty and grace seemed to belong to the pages of Keats' poetry itself. Despite my awkwardness with words, I think she understood my profound gratitude and disbelief at having her in my life.

Paragraph 1:

I knew little about Keats or his poetry, but I thought it possible that in his hopeless situation he would not have wanted to write precisely because he loved her so much. Lately I'd had the idea that Clarissa's interest in these hypothetical letters had something to do with our own situation, and with her conviction that love that did not find its expression in a letter was not perfect. In the months after we'd met, and before we'd bought the apartment, she had written me some beauties, passionately abstract in the ways our love was different from and superior to any that had ever existed. Perhaps that's the essence of a love letter, to celebrate the unique. I had tried to match her, but all that sincerity would permit me were the facts, and they seemed miraculous enough to mea beautiful woman loved and wanted to be loved by a large, clumsy, balding fellow who could hardly believe his luck.

Paragraph 2:
As I sit contemplating John Keats and his poetry, I often wonder whether he ever put pen to paper not for verse, but for love. Perhaps the overwhelming depth of his feelings rendered him wordless in the realm of personal correspondence. My partner, Clarissa, finds this notion fascinating, pondering hypothetical letters Keats might have penned to his beloved. This inevitably brings me to reflect on the early days of our own relationship when Clarissa filled pages with passionate love letters that seemed almost otherworldly in their celebration of us, of our love, and of our potential future. In response, I struggled to match her eloquence; my earnest attempts only highlighted my limitations. My letters, sincere yet simple, expressed an unwavering amazement at the fortune of being loved by someone as extraordinary as Clarissa—a woman whose beauty and grace seemed to belong to the pages of Keats' poetry itself. Despite my awkwardness with words, I think she understood my profound gratitude and disbelief at having her in my life.

paragraph1: Recently, I found myself in a whirlwind of controversy after trying to defend a new, musically-inclined poet whose audacious voice had captivated and divided audiences. It all started with an email from Scout, alerting me to a firestorm surrounding an incendiary statement the poet had made. True to my nature, I sprang to his defense, framing him as a philosopher and a beacon of creative freedom in a world increasingly hostile to original thought. I stressed his right to express and explore controversial ideas, emphasizing his yearning for unencumbered artistic expression. However, the situation took an unexpected and unfortunate turn when the poet openly expressed admiration for a controversial political figure, who shall remain unnamed, sending shockwaves through our community and sparking a fierce backlash. In a matter of days, both the poet and I found ourselves socially "cancelled," our reputations marred by association and our voices drowned out by a cacophony of disapproval. Friends and acquaintances distanced themselves, and doors that had previously been open now seemed firmly shut. The experience left me reflecting on the fine line between advocacy and complicity, pondering how to navigate support for free expression without inadvertently endorsing harmful ideologies. It was a stark reminder of how quickly the tides of public opinion can turn, sweeping away certainty and replacing it with lingering doubts.
paragraph2: Then I made a mistake. This was yesterday. If you’re anything like Scout, you probably heard about it already. (Scout e-mailed me fifteen minutes after it happened to commiserate and also to alert me to the fact that she would not be e-mailing me anymore.) How it happened wasone of our poets said something beyond the pale. He is one of the newer poets—the musical kind—and so his words tend to go everywhere, floating between our towers, rising above the city. People were appalled, furious. All arrows pointed to him. And I said, Look, politically you’re absolutely within your rights to be angry, but existentially you’re wrong—existentially this particular poet just wants us all to be free. As a matter of fact, he’s not even a poet at all, he’s a philosopher. Yes, I said itHe’s one of us. But then the poet himself said that philosophy makes nothing happen and also that he happened to quite like the Devil—whom we sometimes call "the adversary” and sometimes nothing at all—and then he said that he was glad that he-who-shall-not-be-named had come to power, because he admired his energy, his inability to distinguish between past, present, and future, and soon after that the poet got cancelled and, soon after that, me, too.

paragraph1: As I look back on the years I've traversed, it's intriguing to reflect on how much the world has transformed around me. In those bygone days, I remember streets being thoughtfully watered every summer to keep the dust at bay, while women gracefully adorned themselves with waist cinchers and crinolines, embodying a distinct sartorial elegance. Those times, however, were not without their shadows—ailments like polio and leukemia loomed large, casting a pall over many lives. My thoughts often drift to my first job at the tender age of thirteen, a milestone as much as a necessity born out of tragedy. This opportunity came about because of Young Mr. Crozier's misfortune—a former fighter pilot who survived the throes of war only to face leukemia after working towards becoming a historian. He moved with his wife to live with his stepmother, Old Mrs. Crozier, as his health waned. Even now, his courage amidst adversity remains etched in my memory, shaping not just my first job, but also my understanding of resilience.
paragraph2: I am amazed sometimes to think how old I am. I can remember when the streets of the town I lived in were sprinkled with water to lay the dust in summer, and when girls wore waist cinchers and crinolines that could stand up by themselves, and when there was nothing much to be done about things like polio and leukemia. Some people who got polio got better, crippled or not, but people with leukemia went to bed, and, after some weeks’ or months’ decline in a tragic atmosphere, they died.It was because of such a case that I got my first job, in the summer holidays, when I was thirteen.Old Mrs. Crozier lived on the other side of town. Her stepson, Bruce, who was usually called Young Mr. Crozier, had come safely home from the war, where he had been a fighter pilot, had gone to college and studied history, and got married, and now he had leukemia. He and his wife were staying with Old Mrs. Crozier.

paragraph1: Reflecting on my journey, I often find myself tangled in the web of my past actions, questioning where forgiveness, both from others and myself, truly lies. My history is not without blemishes—times marked by lies, deceit, and succumbing to temptations with various men, choices fueled by desires and needs that seem, in hindsight, all too transient. The haze of drug use only clouds the lines further, blurring the separation between who I am and who I was. Guilt claws at me relentlessly, yet a whisper of self-acceptance urges me to embrace every fragment of my history. I am constantly navigating this landscape of regret, pondering if redemption is an eventual destination or if perhaps, despite my missteps, it has been woven into the fabric of my journey all along.
paragraph2: What if I forgave myself? I thought. What if I forgave myself even though I'd done something I shouldn't have? What if I was a liar and a cheat and there was no excuse for what I'd done other than because it was what I wanted and needed to do? What if I was sorry, but if I could go back in time I wouldn't do anything differently than I had done? What if I'd actually wanted to fuck every one of those men? What if heroin taught me something? What if yes was the right answer instead of no? What if what made me do all those things everyone thought I shouldn't have done was what also had got me here? What if I was never redeemed? What if I already was?

paragraph1: Initially, I believed I was crafting a story primarily focused on the intertwining destinies of two families, underpinned by themes like sexual rivalry, power, and revenge—a narrative dominated by masculine energy. However, as the story unfolded, the women demanded their rightful place in the tapestry, refusing to remain mere background figures. Their voices surged forward, insisting their own experiences and complexities be woven into the narrative's fabric. It became evident that their stories not only coexisted with those of their male counterparts but also explained and, at times, overshadowed them. This shift cast a revealing light on a society steeped in repression, where strict codes of honor and propriety suffocate women's existence, concealing their true influence. As I reflected, I realized this societal repression impacted every aspect of life, binding men and women alike. The supposed separation between the 'male' and 'female' narratives began to dissolve, revealing an interwoven story where destinies are not singularly masculine or feminine, but profoundly interconnected. In acknowledging this intertwined reality, the story gained depth, offering a richer, more comprehensive exploration of both families' intertwined destinies.
paragraph2: Once upon a time there were two families, their destinies inseparable even by death. I had thought, before I began, that what I had on my hands was an almost excessively masculine tale, a saga of sexual rivalry, ambition, power, patronage, betrayal, death, revenge. But the women seem to have taken over; they marched in from the peripheries of the story to demand the inclusion of their own tragedies, histories and comedies, obliging me to couch my narrative in all manner of sinuous complexities, to see my 'male' plot refracted, so to speak, through the prisms of its reverse and 'female' side. It occurs to me that the women knew precisely what they were up to that their stories explain, and even subsume, the men's. Repression is a seamless garment; a society which is authoritarian in its social and sexual codes, which crushes its women beneath the intolerable burdens of honour and propriety, breeds repressions of other kinds as well. Contrariwisedictators are always or at least in public, on other people's behalf puritanical. So it turns out that my 'male' and 'female' plots are the same story, after all.

paragraph1: And so we said goodbye. I went to get my watch, which had been repaired, and my former girlfriend’s older brother slowly set off down the hill to Shibuya station. His tweed-jacketed figure was swallowed up in the afternoon crowd.I never saw him again. Chance had brought us together a second time. With nearly twenty years between encounters, in cities three hundred miles apart, we’d sat, a table between us, sipping coffee and talking over a few things. But these weren’t subjects you just chatted about over coffee. There was something more significant in our talk, something that seemed meaningful to us, in the act of living out our lives. Still, it was merely a hint, delivered by chance. There was nothing to link us together in a more systematic or organic way. (QuestionWhat elements in the lives of these two men were symbolically suggested by their two meetings and conversations?)I never saw that lovely young girl again, either, the one who was holding the LP “With the Beatles.” Sometimes I wonder—is she still hurrying down that dimly lit high-school hallway in 1964, the hem of her skirt fluttering as she goes? Sixteen even now, holding that wonderful album cover with the half-lit photo of John, Paul, George, and Ringo, clutching it tightly as though her life depended on it.
paragraph2: As I sipped my coffee, I couldn't help but feel an overwhelming sense of nostalgia wash over me. It was a rare chance encounter with my former girlfriend's older brother—someone I hadn't seen in nearly twenty years. Our conversation dipped into realms both profound and mundane, hinting at deeper meanings in our lives, yet paradoxically, there was no enduring connection left to cling to. The years had created canyons that could not be bridged in a single sitting at a café. This meeting stirred another memory, of a "lovely young girl," vivid yet untouchable, who used to glide down the old high school hallways with an LP of "With the Beatles" cradled lovingly in her arms. She is a static image, forever encased in the sepia tones of 1964, preserved as youthful and hopeful, untouched by the inexorable march of time. I find myself wondering about the symbols our lives become—whether the girl, enshrined in that timeless corridor, was an embodiment of innocence and possibility that life gradually chisels away. As I said my goodbyes to both the brother and the phantom of that young girl, I pondered over what these chance encounters meant for me. Are they mere reminders that the sands in our life's hourglass drift irreversibly, or are they small openings to reflect and rediscover what was once significant?

paragraph1: As he stands in the dimly lit bedroom, mid-motion in the act of undressing, his gaze fixates on her seated form on the bed. The room is imbued with a muted warmth that enhances the intimate ambiance, casting gentle shadows that dance across the walls. She sits comfortably amidst a cascade of pillows, her knees tucked against her chest, her demeanor effortlessly relaxed. Clad in only her green cotton knickers and an oversized green T-shirt, its size hinting at origins beyond her own wardrobe, he momentarily contemplates the implications—was this a trace of another man, a potential rival who once occupied this very space? Yet, the T-shirt, with its soft, worn fabric, intrigues him more than it troubles him, drawing his attention back to her. Her vibrant green eyes, once interpreted as harsh, now reveal a spirited daring that beckons him closer, a testament to her boldness and changing depths. Her round face radiates a softer openness, accentuated beautifully by the play of natural light that subtly highlights her cheekbones, giving her an almost ethereal glow. She meets his eyes with a patient, wry expression that speaks volumes, a silent communication that only deepens the allure of the moment. As she nonchalantly peels off the T-shirt, the air between them becomes charged with unspoken promises, cementing the shared sense of vulnerability and anticipation.
paragraph2: The memory would never leave him. The bed was a double by the standards of the time, less than five feet across. Two sets of two pillows. She sat against one set with her knees drawn up. While he was undressing, she had taken off her cardigan and jeans. Her knickers, like her T-shirt, were green. Cotton, not silk. The T-shirt was a large man’s size, and perhaps he should have worried about a rival. The folds of the material, brushed cotton, seemed to him voluptuous in his heightened state. Her eyes were also green. He had once thought there was something cruel about them. Now their color suggested daring. She could do anything she wanted. Her bare legs had traces of a summer tan. Her round face, which once had the quality of a mask, now had a soft and open look. The light through the small bedroom window picked out the strength of her cheekbones. No lipstick this Saturday morning. The hair she had worn in a bun for lessons was very fine and strands of it floated up when she moved her head. She was looking at him in that patient, wry way she had. Something about him amused her. She pulled her T-shirt off and let it fall to the floor.

paragraph1: As I wandered through the apartments, a sense of eerie stillness enveloped me, my youthful eyes drawn to the ornate decorations and furniture that seemed untouched by time. Each room whispered stories of a past era; a locked glass cabinet showcased an eclectic collection of treasures—delicate Chinese porcelains, fine teacups, and exquisite silver sets that gleamed under the dim light. Unused desks stood stoically, empty turban shelves echoed with silence, and decorative screens crafted elaborate illusions of privacy. Even my uncle's old medical books lined the shelves, unloved and unopened for over twenty years since his immigration to America. These rooms felt like mausoleums, more suited for the dead than the living, embodying a static world of forgotten echoes.
paragraph2: In each apartment, there was also a locked glass cabinet displaying Chinese porcelains, teacups, silver sets, sugar bowls, snuffboxes, crystal glasses, rosewater pitchers, plates, and censers, which no one ever touched, although among them I sometimes found hiding places for miniature cars. There were unused desks inlaid with mother-of-pearl, turban shelves on which there were no turbans, and Japanese and Art Nouveau screens behind which nothing was hidden. There, in the library, gathering dust behind the glass, were my uncle’s medical booksin the twenty years since he’d immigrated to America, no one had touched them. To my childish mind, these rooms were furnished not for the living but for the dead.

There, in the library, gathering dust behind the glass, were my uncle’s medical booksin the twenty years since he’d immigrated to America, no one had touched them. To my childish mind, these rooms were furnished not for the living but for the dead.

paragraph1: Robbie Turner, a determined young man, had emerged from his modest beginnings as the son of a local cleaning lady, thanks largely to the generous support of Briony's father, who had recognized his academic potential and facilitated his education. Initially harboring dreams of becoming a landscape gardener, Robbie's ambitions evolved, fueled by an unyielding resolve to elevate himself, as he aspired to study medicine. Though his roots were humble, Robbie envisioned a future in which he could transcend social barriers, culminating in his daring pursuit of Cecilia, the object of his deep affection. In a scene both unsettling and captivating, Robbie exerts an unexpected influence over Cecilia, who, defying all anticipated propriety, complies with his enigmatic request to disrobe and wade into a nearby pond with a sense of urgency that borders on defiance. The scenario unfolds with an air of the surreal, leaving Briony, who has clandestinely observed the scene, grappling with uncertainty and a profound sense of intrigue. Her youthful mind, steeped in romantic ideals and narrative conventions, struggles to reconcile the radical departures from societal norms and expected behaviors exhibited by Robbie and Cecilia. Briony’s perceptions are further clouded by the peculiar dynamics at play, posing an implicit challenge to her understanding of love and agency. This unsettling tableau unveils complexities that fuel her imagination, beckoning her to question not just the motivations behind Robbie's actions, but also her own assumptions about the nature of desire, power, and the subtle nuances of human relationships that transcend simple categorization in her youthful attempts to interpret the world.
paragraph2: Robbie Turner, only son of a humble cleaning lady and of no known father, Robbie who had been subsidized by Briony’s father through school and university, had wanted to be a landscape gardener, and now wanted to take up medicine, had the boldness of ambition to ask for Cecilia’s hand. It made perfect sense. Such leaps across boundaries were the stuff of daily romance. What was less comprehensible, however, was how Robbie imperiously raised his hand now, as though issuing a command which Cecilia dared not disobey. It was extraordinary that she was unable to resist him. At his insistence she was removing her clothes, and at such speed. She was out of her blouse, now she had let her skirt drop to the ground and was stepping out of it, while he looked on impatiently, hands on hips. What strange power did he have over her? Blackmail? Threats? Briony raised two hands to her face and stepped back a little way from the window. She should shut her eyes, she thought, and spare herself the sight of her sister’s shame. But that was impossible, because there were further surprises. Cecilia, mercifully still in her underwear, was climbing into the pond, was standing waist deep in the water, was pinching her nose—and then she was gone. There was only Robbie, and the clothes on the gravel, and beyond, the silent park and the distant, blue hills. The sequence was illogical—the drowning scene, followed by a rescue, should have preceded the marriage proposal. Such was Briony’s last thought before she accepted that she did not understand, and that she must simply watch.

paragraph1: I vividly remember our first home, a tiny, poorly built house where my wife, our cat, and I tried to make the best of our frugal beginnings. Winters were a particular challenge, as the inadequate insulation forced us to huddle closely under futons, our cat nestled between us for warmth. The kitchen faucet often froze, a testament to how unforgiving the cold could be without a proper space heater, something we couldn’t afford. Despite these hardships, spring emerged as our sanctuary, bringing with it a sense of renewal that remains my favorite time of year. One particular spring, an April railroad strike inadvertently gifted us a stretch of silence, transforming usually clamorous train tracks into peaceful sanctuaries where we basked in the gentle sunlight with our cat, undisturbed. We were young and newly married then, and despite the struggles, our lives felt full of promise. Even now, years later, whenever I encounter the word "poor," my thoughts drift back to that tiny house. I find myself wondering who lives there now, hoping they experience the same joy we did when it wasn’t winter. It’s a place bound to my heart, fondly recalled with every passing of the seasons.
paragraph2: It was a poorly built house in a way, since wind blew in through cracks and gaps all over the place. Pleasant enough in the summer, but, come winter, it was hell. With no money to buy a space heater, my wife and I and the cat would crawl under the futons once the sun set, literally clinging to each other to keep warm. Many a time we’d wake up to find the water in the kitchen faucet frozen solid.Once winter passed, the spring would come. And spring was a lovely season. She and I and the cat would breathe a sigh of relief. In April, the railroads went on strike for a few days, and we were ecstatic. Not a single train came rumbling by all day. We carried the cat down to the railroad tracks and sat there sunning ourselves. It was so quiet it was as if we were sitting at the bottom of a lake. We were young, just married, and the sunshine was free!Even now, when I hear the word “poor,” I remember that thin, triangular sliver of land. And I wonder, Who could be living there now?

paragraph1: An aging Indian man, experiencing the unsettling decline of his mental faculties, embarks on a journey across the United States fueled by an obsessive infatuation with a television personality named Miss Salma R., a captivating and renowned talk-show host. As his mind grapples with the confusions brought by aging, he becomes mistakenly convinced that his fascination with Salma is true love. His imagination, somewhat unhinged, draws inspiration from the romantic opera "Don Quichotte," leading him to adopt the moniker 'Quichotte.' With this new identity, he envisions himself as Salma's devoted knight-errant. Driven by an eccentric mix of devotion and fantasy, he resolves to cross the threshold of the television screen, determined to penetrate her glamorous world and win her heart through acts of chivalry and charm.
paragraph2: There once lived, at a series of temporary addresses across the United States of America, a travelling man of Indian origin, advancing years, and retreating mental powers, who had developed an unwholesome, because entirely one-sided, passion for a certain television personality, the beautiful, witty, and adored talk-show host Miss Salma R., whom he had never metan infatuation that he characterized, quite inaccurately, as love. In the name of this so-called love, he christened himself Quichotte, for the opera “Don Quichotte,” and resolved to be his “beloved” ’s knight-errant, to pursue her zealously right through the television screen into whatever exalted high-definition reality she and her kind inhabited, and, by deeds as well as by grace, to win her heart.

paragraph1: As I sit by the clear, lovely stream that runs just behind the remnants of a once-glorious kingdom, I dip my feet into the icy-cold water. The shock of the cold is invigorating, and I watch as fish glide gracefully through the stream, utterly indifferent to the political upheaval that has unfolded around them. These simple creatures seem entirely detached from the woes of failed governance, focusing only on their existence, nibbling on the weeds untroubled by any notion of human folly. As I gaze upstream, the fallen kingdom's remnants cast shadows on the water—a looming, crumbling wall and a solitary tower, where a two-colored flag still flutters against the sky, a stubborn remnant of a bygone power. Occasionally, passersby pause to comment on it, echoing tales of the kingdom's failure as they gaze up at that forlorn emblem, still defiantly marking the landscape.
paragraph2: Just behind the kingdom that failed ran a nice little river. It was a clear, lovely stream, and many fish lived in it. Weeds grew there, too, and the fish ate the weeds. The fish didn’t care whether or not the kingdom had failed, of course. Whether it was a kingdom or a republic made no difference to them. They didn’t vote or pay taxes. Makes no difference to us, they figured.I washed my feet in the stream. A short soak in the icy-cold water turned them red. From the stream, you could see the walls and the tower of the castle in the kingdom that failed. The two-colored flag still flew from the tower, fluttering in the breeze. Everyone passing along the riverbanks would see the flag and say, “Hey, look at that. It’s the flag of the kingdom that failed.”

paragraph1: As I opened the door, April's chill lingered in the air, and I braced myself for the comforting sight of my boyfriend. Instead, standing on my doorstep was a woman whose face I recognized but couldn't quite place until she spoke his name. Her voice faltered momentarily as she introduced herself, revealing an astonishing truth neither of us anticipated. For nearly five years, we had unknowingly shared the affections of the same man. Her discovery came courtesy of a negligently circulated book he had borrowed from me — inside it, a receipt betrayed my name and address. The book became the unexpected bridge between us. Piecing together the clues she'd overlooked before, everything suddenly made sense: the inconsistent stories, the perpetual but faint shadow of another presence. This realization confirmed the existence of an orchestrated romantic triangle where we’d both been unwilling players.
paragraph2: Then one day in April someone rang my buzzer. I thought it was him. Instead it was another woman who knew my boyfriend just as well as I did, who saw him on the days I didn’t. I’d shared the same man with this woman for nearly five years. She lived in another neighborhood, and she’d come to know about me thanks to a book I’d lent him, the same book that he in turn, idiotically, had lent to her. Unbelievable. Inside that book there was a piece of paper, the receipt from a doctor’s visit, with my name and address. At which point all the little things that puzzled her about their relationship made sense. She realized that she was only one of his lovers, and that we were an unwitting threesome.

paragraph1: As I sat in the car with Paul, the road stretching endlessly from Portland to Montana, I couldn't shake the heavy sensation settling in the pit of my stomach—a throbbing headache and a gnawing sense of nausea that made me wonder if it was the residue of our reckless dalliances with drugs. The journey felt surreal, as though we were slipping into a realm detached from reality, an experience akin to the dissociative haze of heroin. Despite being physically there, the chaos of our relationship seemed to pull at the edges of my consciousness, drawing me into a vortex of tumultuous emotions. There was the moment everything boiled over in a vicious argument, our words cutting through the confined space of the car like shards of glass. In the aftermath, silence settled, punctuated only by the raw, reflective dialogue about the grim prospect of divorce. It was a simultaneous evocation of hatred and love, Paul representing both a cherished anchor and a suffocating prison. Our history, woven with threads of my mother's connection to him, added a labyrinthine complexity that I couldn't easily untangle.
paragraph2: I packed a few things and called Paul. When he pulled up to the corner where I was waiting, I got into his car. By sunset Portland was long gone. In Montana we checked into a motel to sleep. I held myself in bed, rocking with a headache, a sickness in my gut. Paul brought me water and chocolate and watched television. I sat in the car as we drove across the country, and I felt my real life present but unattainable, as if heroin had taken me entirely from myself. Paul and I fought and cried and shook the car with our fighting. We were monstrous in our cruelty. We talked kindly afterward, shocked at ourselves and each other. We decided that we would get divorced. I hated him and I loved him. He had known my mother. I felt trapped, branded, held, and beloved. Like a daughter. “I didn’t ask you to come to Portland,” I screamed. “You came for your own reasons,” I said.

Paragraph 2:
I packed a few things and called Paul. When he pulled up to the corner where I was waiting, I got into his car. By sunset Portland was long gone. In Montana we checked into a motel to sleep. paragraph1: None of you will go to America, none of you will be film stars. And none of you will be working in supermarkets as I heard some of you planning the other day. Your lives are set out for you. You’ll become adults, then before you ‘re old, before you ‘re even middle-aged, you’ll start to donate your vital organs. That’s what each of you was created to do. You’re not like the actors you watch on your videos, you’re not even like me. You were brought into this world for a purpose, and your futures, all of them, have been decided. So you’re not to talk that way any more. You’ll be leaving Hailsham before long, and it’s not so far off, the day you’ll be preparing for your first donations. You need to remember that. If you ‘re to have decent lives, you have to know who you are and what lies ahead of you, every one of you.”Then she went silent, but my impression was that she was continuing to say things inside her head, because for sometime her gaze kept roving over us, going from face to face just as if she were still speaking to us. We were all pretty relieved when she turned to look out over the playing field again.“It’s not so bad now,” she said, even though the rain was as steady as ever. “Let’s just go out there. Then maybe the sun will come out too.”
paragraph2: As she stood before the group of eager, young faces, her voice carried the weight of a thousand unsaid words, each one heavier with the reality she was about to impart. My impression was one of reluctant determination, as though she, too, had wrestled with the gravity of what she was about to say. She began, her tone firm but not unkind, addressing them as one might address innocent souls about to embark on a journey they never chose. "It is important for you to understand," she said, her eyes scanning the room, "that your lives will not unfold like those out there," referring to a world of boundless possibilities, unlike the rigid paths theirs must follow. Her words painted a stark contrast between these students and the freedom of choice enjoyed by countless others, the actors and singers they adored, or even herself, who had a semblance of choice in her life. They would not visit America, shine on the silver screen, or even find solace in the mundane aisles of a supermarket. Instead, their existence had been predetermined, orchestrated towards a singular, somber purpose—to be the givers of life, one vital organ at a time. Yet, as if to offer a glimmer amidst the rain-soaked heaviness, she raised her eyes to the drizzly field outside, hinting at the possibility of sunshine. "Let’s hope for brighter skies; let's go outside," she suggested, infusing a sense of optimism into the bleakness, a whisper of hope that resonated more profoundly than the storm just passed.

paragraph1: Prue offered George a mischievous smile, the kind that spoke volumes of a shared past and boundless familiarity, as they sat together in the cozy confines of Wacousta Lodge. She lowered her sunglasses just enough to peer over the top, her eyes meeting his with a playful glint, and teasingly called him "shameless." This small act stirred a rush of memories for George, whisking him back to the late fifties, a time when he was freshly arrived in Toronto, a Hungarian refugee amidst the vibrant swirl of Canadian culture. It was at a bustling party in the heart of the city that he first noticed Prue's captivating smile, a smile that seemed to promise secrets and endless stories. Even now, decades on, it held the same allure, unchanged by time. Yet, as George reflected on this moment, he resolved to suppress any lingering impulses. Wacousta Lodge was a place of retreat for him, a sanctuary where the complexities of his past and present life did not intermingle. Despite the undeniable charm of Prue’s expression, he chose to honor the tranquillity he found there, opting to cherish their memories silently rather than stir the waters of a relationship that had settled into a comfortable, enduring friendship.
paragraph2: Prue lowers the sunglasses to the end of her nose and looks at him over the plastic rims. “George, you are totally shameless,” she says. “You always were.” She gives him an innocent smile, a mischievous smile, a smile with a twist of real evil in it. paragraph1: The last time I saw my mother at her home, it was July, a Sunday. I travelled there by train. At Motteville, we sat in the station for a long time. It was hot. It was quiet, both in the compartment and outside. I looked out the open window; the platform was empty. On the other side of the S.N.C.F. railroad barriers, the tall grass almost touched the lowest branches of the apple trees. It was then that I could really feel that I was approaching C. and that I was going to see my mother. The train continued on to C. at a reduced speed.Leaving the station, I thought I recognized various faces, without being able to put a name to any of them. Perhaps I had never known the names. It was less hot, thanks to the wind. It’s always windy in C. Everyone, including my mother, believes that it’s colder in C. than in other places, even those just five kilometres away.I didn’t take the taxi that was parked in front of the railway hotel, as I would have anywhere else. As soon as I’m in C., I go back to my old waysa taxi is for communions, weddings, and burials. There’s no reason to spend money like that. I headed up Rue Carnot, to the town center. At the first pâtisserie, I bought cakes, éclairs, and apple tarts—the kind she used to tell me to bring home after midday Mass. I bought some flowers, too, gladioli, which last a long time. Until I got to the housing complex where she lives, I didn’t think anything besides, I’m going to see her again and She’s waiting for me.
paragraph2: As I settled into the train's rhythm, the familiar landscape unfurled like a comforting story, one that I had read many times, yet never grew tired of. It was a warm July Sunday, a day that seemed to beckon travelers with its promise of memories revived and bonds renewed. At each station, I felt the subtle shift, the anticipation building gradually, but it was at Motteville where the pause was longest, allowing the hot, still air to drape itself over the station. Here, in this silent oasis of warmth, I felt a deep sense of nearing, an intrinsic pull towards C., a place that seemed to reside more in feeling than geography. Upon arriving, the bustling crowd was both familiar and nebulous, with faces I must have known yet failed to identify. The curious coolness and brisk winds of C. brushed past me, an oddity that everyone, including my mother, claimed was a hallmark of this place. It was refreshing, a sharp contrast to the earlier heat that clung to the train. Foregoing the taxi, I chose the pedestrian path, a choice that deeply rooted me in tradition. Walking to the town center, where pastries and flowers awaited, I found myself enveloped in nostalgia. Each step was a memory, every shop front a piece of my myriad visits, tethering me firmly to the past as I anticipated the future. The pastries, with their sweet fragrance, and the delicate arrangement of blooms were tokens, small gestures of love, akin to the many times I had returned under similar circumstances. As my mother’s welcoming presence grew nearer, my heart echoed with the anticipation of reunion, finding solace in the ritual and familiarity of this journey.

paragraph1: It was another cloudless day. The low afternoon sun, well past the equinox, blazed through the glazed upper half of the kitchen door into the little sitting room and spilled across the table. As Roland ate his omelette, he felt again the insidious desire to be off, hurtling along the route he had in mind. Out of the question. He had already been told that while she ironed his clothes he would be washing the dishes. She had earned the right to tell him what to do. But she’d had it from the beginning.“What a relief,” she kept saying. “Aren’t you happy? You don’t look it.” “I am, honestly. It’s amazing. What a relief.”Thirty years later, he would understand the damage, how derailed his life was by her, how distorted his expectation of love. When he was twelve, she had touched and unwound a little coil in his being and, without having to do more, she had possessed him. Two years later, pursued by fear and childish vanity and incoherent desire, he had run to her. It would take him half a lifetime to frame it in such simple terms. But now, here at the sunlit lunch table, many layers below his outward decorum, and barely available to the ignorant boy, was a mere suspicion that he had been cheated of something. The world would go on, he would remain unvaporized. He needn’t have done a thing.
paragraph2: On a sunlit afternoon, Roland sat at his modest kitchen table, absently trailing the fork through his omelette, a dish that was more ritualistic necessity than culinary delight. The bright rays streaming through the window seemed at odds with the tangled emotions stirring within him. On the surface, everything appeared serene; the rhythmic clatter of dishes in the background, Roland's obligatory task. Yet, beneath this veneer of normalcy lay a profound yearning for liberation, an escape from the invisible chains that bound him. This dichotomy of freedom and constraint was magnified by the presence of "her," the pivotal figure who stood across the room, methodically ironing clothes. Her influence over Roland was indelible, shaping not only his day-to-day existence but also his deepest notions of love and loyalty. Raised under her watchful eye, Roland's perception of affection had been a skewed reflection of her ideals, unwittingly distorting his understanding of life's grander narrative. Now, as he chewed a tasteless bite of the omelette, a creeping suspicion nudged at the corners of his consciousness—that something vital had been denied to him, an awareness whose clarity would only emerge after many long years. This moment was a microcosm of Roland's life journey, an intricate dance of control, compliance, and the slow, unhurried awakening to his own suppressed truths. The afternoon's warm light, seemingly benign, only highlighted the shadows of realization that cloaked Roland’s heart.

paragraph1: Once she has parked outside the building, she saysYou can give me your number. But I don’t know if I’ll get in touch or not. O.K.? And, if you don’t hear from me, it won’t be because I haven’t thought about you. I will think about you. I just have to figure out what’s best. He says he understands, and he keys the number into her phone. The time on the dashboard is 8:56 a.m. He gets out of the car, and she watches him walk up to the main entrance of the building, carrying his black suitcase. One of the wheels on the case is hanging askew, broken—she can see that now. That’s probably why he carries it, instead of using the wheels.At the entrance, he turns back and looks at her over his shoulder. Then he’s gone, the door swinging shut behind him. The door of her own workplace, with its flat rectangular handle, with one glass panel broken at the bottom and patched with brown tape. She has been contained before, contained and directed, by the trappings of ordinary life. Now she no longer feels contained or directed by these forces; no longer directed by anything at all. Life has slipped free of its netting. She can do very strange things now; she can find herself a very strange person. Young men can invite her into holiday cottages for sexual reasons. It means nothing. That isn’t trueit means something, but the meaning is unfamiliar.
paragraph2: The woman sat in her car, hands lightly draped over the steering wheel, gazing momentarily at the man beside her who had just entered his number into her phone with a hesitant assurance that seemed to understand her uncertainty about future contact. As she watched him move back toward the building with his broken-wheeled suitcase in tow, the digital clock on the dashboard read 8:56 a.m., a mundane detail amid a morning unexpectedly tinged with contemplation. He carried the suitcase rather than rolling it, an image she found oddly fitting for their ambiguous encounter. His brief, backward glance lingered with a quiet question, an agreement between them that they might never need to speak again or perhaps just might. Once he vanished into the building, the woman sat alone, listening to her quiet reflections. She acknowledged her release from the pressures that once dictated her daily routines—noticed in this strange, undefined freedom a thrill she had not anticipated. Encounters, like this one, presented themselves as invitations to step outside what she once considered obligatory confines. The young man's number in her phone represented more than a mere possibility of connection; it symbolized the weight of choices she was learning to navigate, marking the dawn of a personal liberation. For her, these invitations, particularly those from young men seeking casual connections, became contemplative pauses that queried her introspection, unraveling a potent, though unfamiliar, significance in their mere propositions, subtly shaping her evolving narrative.

paragraph1: Seated at one of the small tables inside Café Brazza, its dim lighting casting a cozy glow around me, I nursed a warm mug of hot chocolate, hoping its comforting aroma would somehow inspire me to focus on the stack of essays demanding my attention. But distraction crept in subtly, my gaze inevitably drawn to a young couple entwined in a tender embrace across the room, their presence a silent testament to unspoken love. Perhaps emboldened by this romantic ambiance, I felt the tug of curiosity about the restroom's location, an urge that lingered persistently. After politely inquiring directions from the barman, who pointed with a knowing nod, I made my way there, only to encounter a "Turkish-style" toilet. Standing there, I was momentarily transported back in time, pondering how this once-common fixture in public spaces had gradually become a rarity. My musings continued until they found me standing back on the platform of Malesherbes Métro station, the clatter of trains echoing my own restless thoughts. Somehow, I found myself returning to Passage Cardinet, quietly yearning for a moment that, for reasons unclear, felt significant.
paragraph2: I went into the Café Brazza. I ordered a hot chocolate and got out some essays to mark but I couldn’t read a single line. I kept telling myself that I had to check out the restroom. A young couple were kissing, leaning over the café table. Finally I stood up and asked the barman where the restroom was. He pointed to a door at the back of the café. It gave onto a tiny closet with a washbasin, a mirror just above and a second door leading to the bathroom. It was a "Turkish-style" toilet. I couldn’t remember whether the café I went into thirty-five years ago had one like this. It wasn’t the sort of detail I would have noticed back then, practically all public toilets were built that waya hole in the cement with room on either side to place your feet and squat.Standing on the platform at Malesherbes Métro station, I realized that I had gone back to the Passage Cardinet in the hope that something might happen to me.

paragraph1: When I look back at my younger self, the one who held a passport marked "Member of the Council of Europe," I see a person filled with hope and dreams yet to be realized. That marked document was meant to be my gateway to endless European adventures. However, it ended up embodying a failed first attempt at leaving the borders of Turkey. Disillusioned, I decided to place my travel aspirations on hold, anchoring myself firmly in Istanbul for the next twenty-four years. During this time, I marveled at tales from globetrotters and those who brandished passports like trophies, envying their worldly experiences. Yet, even as opportunities to travel presented themselves, I found something compelling in my decision to stay. My heart told me that my destiny lay not in foreign lands but in the sprawling world of literature hidden in this very city. I believed that, ultimately, my dedication to writing would offer the recognition and fulfillment I longed for. When success finally came, it manifested in a door creaking open, urging me to apply for a new passport to tour Germany, a country where the vibrant Turkish diaspora awaited my stories.
paragraph2: I never used that passport again. Although it bore the words “Member of the Council of Europe,” it was a reminder of my first failed European adventure, and such was the vehemence of my decision to turn inward that it would be another twenty-four years before I left Turkey again. When I was young, I always gazed with admiration and envy at those who acquired passports and travelled to Europe and beyond, but, despite the opportunities that were presented to me, I remained fearfully certain that it was my lot to sit in a corner in Istanbul and give myself over to the books that I hoped would one day make my name and complete me as a person. In those days, I believed that one could understand Europe best through its greatest books.In the end, it was my books that prompted me to apply for a second passport. After years spent alone in a room, I had managed to turn myself into an author. Now I was invited to go on tour in Germany, where many Turks had found political asylum;

paragraph1: As I sit contemplating John Keats and his poetry, I often wonder whether he ever put pen to paper not for verse, but for love. Perhaps the overwhelming depth of his feelings rendered him wordless in the realm of personal correspondence. My partner, Clarissa, finds this notion fascinating, pondering hypothetical letters Keats might have penned to his beloved. This inevitably brings me to reflect on the early days of our own relationship when Clarissa filled pages with passionate love letters that seemed almost otherworldly in their celebration of us, of our love, and of our potential future. In response, I struggled to match her eloquence; my earnest attempts only highlighted my limitations. My letters, sincere yet simple, expressed an unwavering amazement at the fortune of being loved by someone as extraordinary as Clarissa—a woman whose beauty and grace seemed to belong to the pages of Keats' poetry itself. Despite my awkwardness with words, I think she understood my profound gratitude and disbelief at having her in my life.
paragraph2: I squeezed her hand and said nothing. I knew little about Keats or his poetry, but I thought it possible that in his hopeless situation he would not have wanted to write precisely because he loved her so much. Lately I'd had the idea that Clarissa's interest in these hypothetical letters had something to do with our own situation, and with her conviction that love that did not find its expression in a letter was not perfect. In the months after we'd met, and before we'd bought the apartment, she had written me some beauties, passionately abstract in the ways our love was different from and superior to any that had ever existed. Perhaps that's the essence of a love letter, to celebrate the unique. I had tried to match her, but all that sincerity would permit me were the facts, and they seemed miraculous enough to mea beautiful woman loved and wanted to be loved by a large, clumsy, balding fellow who could hardly believe his luck.

Paragraph 1:
As I sit contemplating John Keats and his poetry, I often wonder whether he ever put pen to paper not for verse, but for love. Perhaps the overwhelming depth of his feelings rendered him wordless in the realm of personal correspondence. My partner, Clarissa, finds this notion fascinating, pondering hypothetical letters Keats might have penned to his beloved. This inevitably brings me to reflect on the early days of our own relationship when Clarissa filled pages with passionate love letters that seemed almost otherworldly in their celebration of us, of our love, and of our potential future. In response, I struggled to match her eloquence; my earnest attempts only highlighted my limitations. My letters, sincere yet simple, expressed an unwavering amazement at the fortune of being loved by someone as extraordinary as Clarissa—a woman whose beauty and grace seemed to belong to the pages of Keats' poetry itself. Despite my awkwardness with words, I think she understood my profound gratitude and disbelief at having her in my life.

Paragraph 2:
I squeezed her hand and said nothing. I knew little about Keats or his poetry, but I thought it possible that in his hopeless situation he would not have wanted to write precisely because he loved her so much. Perhaps that's the essence of a love letter, to celebrate the unique. I had tried to match her, but all that sincerity would permit me were the facts, and they seemed miraculous enough to mea beautiful woman loved and wanted to be loved by a large, clumsy, balding fellow who could hardly believe his luck.

paragraph1: Verna, a young girl adrift in a rigid institution alongside other delinquents, spends her days entangled in the monotony of menial chores: peeling endless heaps of potatoes, scrubbing floors tirelessly until they gleam, and scouring toilets until her hands ache. In this world, Verna and her counterparts are clothed identically in drab gray maternity dresses, paired with itchy wool stockings and cumbersome brown shoes, all provided through donations. The narrative unfolds in third person, capturing the dreary rhythm of daily life infused with relentless prayer sessions and moral lectures. These sessions serve as relentless reminders that the girls' current plight results from their past missteps, and they are exhorted to achieve redemption through relentless hard work and severe self-discipline. Prohibited from indulging in alcohol, tobacco, and even the simple pleasure of chewing gum, they hear that future marital prospects would be nothing short of miraculous. After enduring an excruciating labor, Verna is immediately separated from her newborn to prevent any maternal bond. Despite falling ill with complications, she overhears a dismissive exchange among nurses condemning her as an unfit mother. Ultimately, she receives scant financial support and a ticket to return to her mother's care, remaining a minor in the eyes of the world.
paragraph2: There Verna spent the days peeling potatoes and scrubbing floors and scouring toilets along with her fellow-delinquents. They wore gray maternity dresses and gray wool stockings and clunky brown shoes, all paid for by generous donations, they were informed. In addition to their scouring and peeling chores, they were treated to bouts of prayer and self-righteous hectoring. What had happened to them was justly deserved, the speeches went, because of their depraved behavior, but it was never too late to redeem themselves through hard work and self-restraint. They were cautioned against alcohol, tobacco, and gum chewing, and were told that they should consider it a miracle of God if any decent man ever wanted to marry them.Verna’s labor was long and difficult. The baby was taken away from her immediately so that she would not get attached to it. There was an infection, with complications and scarring, but it was all for the best, she overheard one brisk nurse telling another, because those sorts of girls made unfit mothers anyway. Once she could walk, Verna was given five dollars and a bus ticket and instructed to return to the guardianship of her mother, because she was still a minor.

paragraph1: So here she is, and she must make the most of her social position and accomplishments, and although an object of fear, like a spider, and of charity as well, I am also one of the accomplishments. I come into the room and curtsy and move about, mouth straight, head bent, and I pick up the cups or set them down, depending; and they stare without appearing to, out from under their bonnets.The reason they want to see me is that I am a celebrated murderess. Or that is what has been written down. When I first saw it I was surprised because they say Celebrated Singer and Celebrated Poetess and Celebrated Spiritualist and Celebrated Actress, but what is there to celebrate about murder? All the same, Murderess is a strong word to have attached to you. It has a smell to it, that word--musky and oppressive, like dead flowers in a vase. Sometimes at night I whisper it over to myself. Murderess, Murderess. It rustles, like a taffeta skirt across the floor.Murderer is merely brutal. It's like a hammer, or a lump of metal. I would rather be a murderess than a murderer, if those are the only choices.
paragraph2: In this tangled web of societal perceptions, I find myself caught between fear and fascination, like a spider both loathed and revered; a peculiar paradox, navigating the murky waters of public intrigue as much an enigma to myself as to those who scrutinize me. Once simply part of the myriad social accomplishments and titles paraded as badges of honor—singer, actress—now I'm inexplicably adorned with the morbid moniker of "celebrated murderess." How such a grim label managed to entwine with my identity remains a mystery, yet it clings to me, casting shadows as persuasive and pungent as the scent of decaying flowers. The term "murderess" is an echo of danger, heavy with implications, infinitely more evocative than the straightforward brutality associated with "murderer." Its feminine suffix—so often seen as delicate, perhaps even nurturing—now twisted to wield a macabre elegance, intrigues me. I embrace this identity not from vanity or acceptance but a curious preference for its darkly poetic resonance. Where "murderer" lays bare blunt atrocity, "murderess" paints with a palette of complex allure, suggesting layers of secrecy and untold stories. So, in this grayed twilight between infamy and admiration, I continue to ponder my place, questioning how much of this guise is a mask and how much has seeped into my veins, becoming a part of who I am.

paragraph1: In optimistic moments, she tried to convince herself that she suffered from no more than a heightened form of squeamishness that was bound to pass. Certainly, the thought of Edward’s testicles, pendulous below his “engorged penis”—another horrifying term—had the potency to make her upper lip curl, and the idea of herself being touched “down there” by someone else, even someone she loved, was as repulsive as, say, a surgical procedure on her eye. But her squeamishness did not extend to babies. She liked them; she had looked after her cousin’s little boys on occasion and enjoyed herself. She thought that she would love being pregnant by Edward, and in the abstract, at least, she had no fears about childbirth. If only she could, like the mother of Jesus, arrive at that swollen state by magic.Florence suspected that there was something profoundly wrong with her, that she had always been different, and that at last she was about to be exposed. Her problem, she thought, was greater, deeper, than straightforward physical disgusther whole being was in revolt against the prospect of entanglement and flesh; her composure and essential happiness were about to be violated. She simply did not want to be “entered” or “penetrated.” Sex with Edward could not be the summation of her joy but the price she must pay for it.
paragraph2: Florence found herself in a complex emotional maze, struggling with a profound discomfort surrounding sexual intimacy, particularly when it involved Edward, the man she deeply loved. Despite her affection for him, the thought of physical intimacy invoked a visceral reaction of squeamishness and revulsion within her. However, this aversion was paradoxically accompanied by a genuine fondness for children. Florence often daydreamed about the possibility of one day embracing motherhood, envisioning herself nurturing a child with warmth and affection. Yet, she harbored a secret wish that this dream could be realized magically, circumventing the act she so detested. Her reflections led her to ponder whether her unease stemmed from more than just physical disgust—perhaps it was rooted in a deeper, more pervasive issue that fundamentally disrupted her inner peace and happiness. She felt as though every fiber of her being recoiled at the thought of sexual engagement, as if it were an impending threat to her serenity and composure. To her, intimacy with Edward was not an anticipated joy but a burdensome necessity she felt compelled to endure, merely to preserve other facets of happiness in their relationship. This inner conflict left Florence trapped in a paradox where love and revulsion coexisted uncomfortably, threatening her chance at true contentment.
